parties.appellant: Robert P. Conlon and Betsy A. Conlon, as personal representatives of the Estate of Michael Conlon (plaintiffs in the district court)
parties.appellee: City of Newton; Officer Francis Scaltreto; Officer Richard Benes; Sergeant Glenn Chisholm; Captain Dennis Dowling; Captain Christopher Marzilli, all of the Newton Police Department (defendants in the district court)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
The case arises from a January 5, 2021 police confrontation that culminated in the fatal shooting of Michael Conlon inside his Newton, Massachusetts apartment building. Around 1:45 p.m., Newton Police Department (NPD) Officer Zachary Raymond responded to a report of an ongoing armed robbery at Indulge!, a candy store at 16 Lincoln Street in Newton. Upon arrival, Raymond saw Michael Conlon standing outside the store holding a small kitchen knife. Raymond drew his sidearm and ordered Conlon to drop the knife. Conlon, a twenty-eight-year-old man suffering from mental illness that caused him to fear the police, fled into his adjacent three‑story apartment building instead of complying.

Conlon ran up to the third (top) floor with Officer Raymond pursuing. On reaching the third floor, Conlon turned toward Raymond, held the kitchen knife to his own neck, and threatened to cut his own throat if Raymond advanced. Raymond then retreated to the second‑floor landing to await backup. Conlon used the butt of the knife to knock on the door of Apartment 3 at the top of the stairs, repeatedly asking to speak with a neighbor who was not home.

Several NPD officers and Massachusetts State Police (MSP) troopers arrived, including Captains Dennis Dowling and Christopher Marzilli. They observed Conlon standing in front of the entryway to Apartment 3 on the third‑floor landing. Conlon was spitting and drooling, saying he believed he was in a simulation and questioning whether the officers were "real." Dowling and Marzilli recognized that Conlon was in a mental‑health crisis, and an NPD social worker was called to the scene. An NPD officer arrived with NPD social worker Sarah Eknanian, who stayed in a police car outside, and an NPD lieutenant contacted the Northeastern Massachusetts Law Enforcement Council (the "Council") to request a negotiator and a tactical team trained in de‑escalation and negotiation with mentally ill or suicidal persons. The Council typically requires about thirty minutes to respond in Newton.

Additional officers continued to arrive. Officer Francis Scaltreto assumed the primary role of negotiating with Conlon, positioning himself about twelve feet away from Conlon in the narrow third‑floor hallway. Either Dowling or Marzilli instructed Sergeant Glenn Chisholm to retrieve his "beanbag shotgun," described as a usually less‑than‑lethal weapon, and stand in the doorway of Apartment 4 alongside Officer Richard Benes. Apartment 4’s entryway was approximately twenty feet down the hall from where Conlon stood outside Apartment 3. Two MSP troopers flanked Chisholm and Benes near the doorway to Apartment 4, and four additional NPD officers waited inside Apartment 4. An NPD lieutenant with a shield waited at the bottom of the stairwell below Conlon. Officers also gained access to the building’s back entrance, used Apartment 4 as a staging area, and barricaded the rear door to Apartment 3 so that Conlon could not exit through that unit.

Captain Marzilli informed arriving officers that Conlon was a "psych patient" and that the situation was a "mental health issue." Captains Dowling and Marzilli agreed they should attempt to wait for the Council’s team before apprehending Conlon, while also agreeing that if the situation deteriorated, Sergeant Chisholm would incapacitate Conlon using the beanbag shotgun. If that occurred, two MSP troopers were to back up Chisholm with tasers, and, if those non‑lethal measures failed, Officer Benes was to be prepared to use his sidearm as lethal force. This plan was communicated to officers on scene. Marzilli, Chisholm, and Benes supported the plan. The MSP troopers expressed doubts that their tasers would be effective because Conlon was wearing thick winter clothing.

During negotiations, Conlon, still agitated, held the kitchen knife in one hand and a fire extinguisher in the other. He insisted he was in a simulation and repeatedly asked to speak with his father. Several officers adopted his delusional framework, telling him they would call his father if he dropped the knife. After approximately twenty minutes of negotiation, Officer Scaltreto persuaded Conlon to drop both the knife and the fire extinguisher by telling him that the rules of the "simulation" required him to release the knife before the police could contact his father. Officers also promised Conlon that he would not be harmed. Conlon complied and dropped the items to the floor.

Once Conlon dropped the knife, Officer Scaltreto communicated to the officers behind him that there was an "opening." Captain Marzilli relayed this to Captain Dowling, who then radioed Sergeant Chisholm to use the beanbag shotgun on Conlon; Marzilli confirmed the order to Chisholm. Chisholm, standing about twelve feet from Conlon, pointed the beanbag shotgun at Conlon’s collarbone and pulled the trigger. The weapon misfired, making a loud clicking noise but not discharging. Chisholm then attempted to clear the malfunction by discharging a round but was unable to do so.

According to some, but not all, officers’ accounts, Conlon reacted to the misfire by picking up the knife and moving toward Sergeant Chisholm. An MSP trooper then deployed his taser at Conlon. Nearly simultaneously, Officers Benes and Scaltreto fired their sidearms, fatally shooting Conlon. Plaintiffs allege that the officers gave "inconsistent statements" after the incident about officers’ positions, what Conlon was doing in the hallway, and whether he picked up the knife after the beanbag shotgun was fired. Plaintiffs further allege that officers have not corroborated the claim that Conlon rearmed himself with photographic evidence and that there was conflicting testimony regarding whether the knife was near Conlon when he was killed. The Council’s tactical and negotiation team arrived about six minutes after the shooting. An autopsy revealed that Conlon suffered fatal gunshot wounds to the head, neck, and torso.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs, as personal representatives of Michael Conlon’s estate, filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the City of Newton and several NPD officers involved in the incident: Officers Francis Scaltreto and Richard Benes, Sergeant Glenn Chisholm, and Captains Dennis Dowling and Christopher Marzilli. As relevant to the appeal, Plaintiffs asserted: (1) claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the individual officers for use of excessive force in violation of the Fourth Amendment (Count 1); (2) claims under the Massachusetts Civil Rights Act (MCRA) against the officers, based on alleged excessive force (Count 8); (3) a wrongful death claim under the Massachusetts Wrongful Death Act (Count 9); (4) a common law assault claim against Sergeant Chisholm (Count 10); (5) a § 1983 Monell claim against the City alleging failure to train and supervise officers regarding mental‑health emergencies and the use of beanbag shotguns (Count 2); and (6) claims against the City under Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act alleging failure to accommodate Conlon’s disability and failure to adequately train officers (Counts 4–6).
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The City of Newton and the officer defendants moved to dismiss all claims under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6), arguing failure to state a claim and asserting qualified immunity on behalf of the officers. The district court granted the motion in full, dismissing all federal and state claims against the officers and the City. In dismissing the § 1983 excessive force claim based on the fatal shooting, the court noted that the complaint left open "myriad factual questions" about the critical moments before the shooting but read the complaint as accepting that Conlon was armed with a knife and advancing on Sergeant Chisholm when he was shot, and concluded that the officers were entitled to qualified immunity on that basis. The district court also dismissed the beanbag shotgun–related excessive force theory, the MCRA claim, the Monell claim against the City, and the ADA and Rehabilitation Act claims.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: On appeal, Plaintiffs challenge the district court’s dismissal of: (1) their § 1983 Fourth Amendment excessive force claim against Officers Scaltreto, Benes, Chisholm, Dowling, and Marzilli, both as to the attempted deployment of the beanbag shotgun and the subsequent fatal shooting; (2) their § 1983 Monell failure‑to‑train and supervise claim against the City of Newton; (3) their ADA claims (including failure-to-train and failure-to-accommodate theories); (4) their Rehabilitation Act claims; and (5) their MCRA claim against the officer defendants. Plaintiffs do not develop any meaningful appellate argument challenging the dismissal of their Massachusetts wrongful death (Count 9) and common law assault (Count 10) claims, and they do not respond in their reply brief to the officers’ arguments regarding those claims; the appellate court treats any challenge to the dismissal of Counts 9 and 10 as waived and limits its review to the remaining claims.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing Plaintiffs’ § 1983 Fourth Amendment excessive force claim against the individual officers insofar as it is based on Sergeant Chisholm’s attempted deployment of the beanbag shotgun and on Officers Benes and Scaltreto’s use of lethal force in shooting Michael Conlon.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To state a Fourth Amendment excessive force claim under § 1983, a plaintiff must allege a seizure and that the force used was objectively unreasonable under the circumstances. Reasonableness is assessed from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, accounting for tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolving circumstances, and balancing the nature and quality of the intrusion against the governmental interests at stake (Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 386). When qualified immunity is asserted, the plaintiff must plausibly allege (1) a violation of a federal statutory or constitutional right and (2) that the unlawfulness of the officer’s conduct was clearly established at the time, meaning existing controlling authority or a robust consensus of persuasive authority would have put a reasonable officer on notice that the conduct was unconstitutional, and that an objectively reasonable officer would have understood that his conduct violated clearly established law.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly dismissed Plaintiffs’ Massachusetts Civil Rights Act claim against the officer defendants, which is premised on the alleged use of excessive force.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The MCRA provides a civil cause of action against any person who interferes, or attempts to interfere, with the exercise or enjoyment of rights secured by federal or state law "by threats, intimidation or coercion" (Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 12, §§ 11H–11I). Courts interpret this to require proof of threats, intimidation, or coercion in addition to the underlying rights violation; a direct violation of rights, without more, does not itself satisfy the statute’s threats/intimidation/coercion requirement (Longval v. Comm’r of Corrs., 404 Mass. 325; Sarvis v. Boston Safe Deposit & Trust Co., 711 N.E.2d 911). Allegations of excessive force alone, without facts showing that the force was used to coerce the plaintiff into forgoing some additional right, are generally insufficient.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing Plaintiffs’ § 1983 Monell claim against the City of Newton alleging failure to train and supervise officers with respect to mental‑health emergencies and the use of beanbag shotguns.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Monell v. Department of Social Services, 436 U.S. 658, a municipality is liable under § 1983 only when an official policy or custom causes a constitutional violation; it is not vicariously liable for employees’ acts. To establish failure-to-train municipal liability, a plaintiff must show: (1) a municipal policy or custom of inadequate training; (2) that this deficiency actually caused the constitutional injury; and (3) that municipal policymakers were deliberately indifferent to the rights of persons with whom officers come into contact (City of Canton v. Harris, 489 U.S. 378). Deliberate indifference is a stringent standard, typically requiring a showing of a pattern of similar constitutional violations by untrained employees, or, in a narrow range of cases, that the need for specific training was so obvious that the constitutional violation was a highly predictable consequence of the failure to equip officers to handle recurring situations (Connick v. Thompson, 563 U.S. 51; Young v. City of Providence, 404 F.3d 4).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly dismissed Plaintiffs’ ADA Title II and Rehabilitation Act claims against the City of Newton based on alleged failures to adequately train officers regarding mental illness and to reasonably accommodate Michael Conlon’s mental disability during the encounter.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Title II of the ADA provides that no qualified individual with a disability shall, by reason of such disability, be excluded from participation in, or denied the benefits of, the services, programs, or activities of a public entity, or be subjected to discrimination by any such entity (42 U.S.C. § 12132). To state a Title II claim, a plaintiff generally must allege: (1) that the decedent was a qualified individual with a disability; (2) that he was excluded from participation in or denied the benefits of a public entity’s services, programs, or activities, or otherwise discriminated against; and (3) that such exclusion, denial, or discrimination was by reason of his disability. A failure‑to‑accommodate claim requires that the public entity knew or reasonably should have known of the disability and failed to make reasonable modifications in policies, practices, or procedures when necessary to avoid discrimination, unless such modifications would fundamentally alter the nature of the service or activity. In this circuit, it remains an open question whether Title II imposes a duty to adopt specific policies and training for police in dealing with mentally ill individuals, but where a department has policies and training, mere allegations that they were inadequate do not suffice to state a claim (Buchanan v. Maine, 469 F.3d 158). The Rehabilitation Act applies substantially the same standards as Title II to entities receiving federal financial assistance; the same legal framework generally governs both statutes.

appellant_arguments: Plaintiffs argue that the First Amended Complaint plausibly alleges that the officer defendants used excessive force in violation of the Fourth Amendment both when Sergeant Chisholm attempted to fire the beanbag shotgun and when Officers Benes and Scaltreto used lethal force. They emphasize that Conlon was in a mental‑health crisis, had not threatened to harm anyone but himself, and had complied with officers’ requests to drop the knife and fire extinguisher based on assurances that he would not be harmed and that his father would be contacted. According to Plaintiffs, firing a beanbag shotgun at close range at an unarmed, compliant, mentally ill individual unreasonably escalated the encounter, and the subsequent lethal shooting was likewise unreasonable, especially given alleged inconsistencies in officers’ accounts of whether Conlon had rearmed himself with the knife and how he moved in the moments before being shot.

Regarding qualified immunity, Plaintiffs contend that clearly established law prohibits officers from increasing the level of force once a suspect has ceased resisting or posing an immediate threat, and they invoke First Circuit precedents such as Jennings v. Jones and Raiche v. Pietroski, as well as decisions from other circuits addressing beanbag and less‑lethal weapons, to argue that an objectively reasonable officer would have known that deploying the beanbag shotgun in these circumstances was unlawful. They also argue that whether Conlon was armed and advancing with a knife at the time of the fatal shooting is a disputed factual issue that cannot be resolved at the motion‑to‑dismiss stage.

On the MCRA claim, Plaintiffs argue that the use or attempted use of the beanbag shotgun, in the context of the threats inherent in pointing and firing such a weapon at Conlon, constituted threats or coercion sufficient to satisfy the statute’s requirement of interference with rights by threats, intimidation, or coercion. They assert that the shooting and the surrounding conduct interfered with Conlon’s constitutional rights in a coercive manner.

With respect to the § 1983 Monell claim, Plaintiffs assert that the City of Newton failed to adequately train and supervise its officers on the use of deadly force, including beanbag shotguns, and on how to respond to individuals with mental illness. They contend that the need for such training was so obvious that the City’s failure to provide it amounted to deliberate indifference, even in the absence of a documented pattern of similar prior incidents. They argue that the complaint’s allegations, including that the officers had never before fired a beanbag shotgun in an active situation and that NPD training on responding to mental illness was minimal, plausibly support a single‑incident theory of municipal liability.

On their ADA and Rehabilitation Act claims, Plaintiffs argue that the City’s failure to train officers in dealing with mentally ill individuals and its failure during this incident to adjust tactics in light of Conlon’s mental illness constitute failures to reasonably accommodate his disability, thereby denying him the benefits of nondiscriminatory police services. They maintain that the officers and the City knew or should have known of Conlon’s mental disability, yet failed to use available mental‑health resources (such as the social worker on scene and the Council’s specialized team) and instead escalated force. Plaintiffs argue that, under Title II and the Rehabilitation Act, the City had an obligation to make reasonable modifications to its practices in dealing with Conlon and that the complaint plausibly alleges discrimination "by reason of" his disability.
appellee_arguments: The City of Newton and the officer defendants argue that the complaint fails to state a viable § 1983 excessive force claim under the Fourth Amendment because, on the facts alleged and reasonably inferred, the officers’ use of both the beanbag shotgun and, subsequently, lethal force was objectively reasonable given Conlon’s behavior, his possession and proximity to a knife, and the tense, rapidly evolving circumstances inside a narrow third‑floor hallway. They assert that Conlon remained a threat even after initially dropping the knife because it lay at his feet and could be readily picked up, as some officers reported he did after the beanbag misfire, and that the officers were seeking to de‑escalate the situation by attempting non‑lethal incapacitation before resorting to deadly force.

On qualified immunity, the officer defendants argue that, even if a constitutional violation could be inferred, they are entitled to immunity because there was no clearly established law at the time of the incident indicating that attempting to deploy a beanbag shotgun, a usually less‑than‑lethal weapon, at Conlon under these circumstances violated the Fourth Amendment. They contend that existing case law did not provide fair notice that their conduct was unlawful and that a reasonable officer, aware of NPD’s General Order 301 regarding beanbag use and the risks posed by a knife‑armed individual in close quarters, could have believed the force used (or attempted) was lawful. They also maintain that, under clearly established law, officers are permitted to use deadly force when confronting a suspect advancing with a knife who poses an immediate threat to officers or others.

Regarding the MCRA claim, defendants argue that Plaintiffs allege only the direct use of force in effecting a seizure, without any separate threats, intimidation, or coercion aimed at compelling Conlon to forgo some additional right. They contend that Massachusetts law requires more than the underlying use of force itself to state an MCRA claim and that the complaint does not allege that the force was used to coerce Conlon into giving up a particular statutory or constitutional right such as speech, association, or the right to resist arrest (which, they note, is not protected).

On the Monell claim, the City argues that Plaintiffs fail to allege deliberate indifference because the complaint identifies only a single incident—the Conlon shooting—and does not plead any pattern of similar constitutional violations or any specific facts about existing training that would show an obvious and patently inadequate program. The City notes that NPD had policies regarding beanbag shotguns and that officers called in specialized mental‑health resources (the Council and the department social worker), which, in the City’s view, contradicts the assertion that it failed to train or was deliberately indifferent. The City maintains that allegations of minimal or imperfect training are insufficient under the stringent deliberate indifference standard.

With respect to the ADA and Rehabilitation Act claims, the City argues that Title II does not impose vicarious liability on municipalities for officers’ on‑the‑scene use of force and that, in any event, Plaintiffs merely allege that existing policies and training were ineffective or inadequate, which is not actionable under Buchanan v. Maine. The City also contends that Plaintiffs do not plausibly allege that Conlon was denied access to any specific service, program, or activity of the City, or that any actions taken by officers were "by reason of" his disability as opposed to his conduct (e.g., possessing a knife, noncompliance). The City asserts that Plaintiffs fail to identify a specific, feasible reasonable accommodation that officers should have implemented in the rapidly evolving circumstances, and that the same analysis forecloses the Rehabilitation Act claim, which follows the same standards as Title II.

issue_1.reasoning: At the Rule 12(b)(6) stage, the court must accept plaintiffs’ factual allegations and reasonable inferences in their favor. The complaint does not clearly concede that Conlon was armed and advancing with a knife at the instant he was shot; indeed, it highlights inconsistencies and the absence of corroboration on that point. The district court effectively resolved those factual disputes against plaintiffs when it treated Conlon as armed and advancing. Taking the complaint as pled, there is a plausible Fourth Amendment claim that (1) attempting to shoot an unarmed, compliant, mentally ill person with a beanbag shotgun at close range—after he dropped the knife in reliance on promises that he would not be harmed—was an unreasonable escalation of force, and (2) the subsequent use of lethal force was likewise unreasonable if a jury could find that he had not rearmed himself or posed an immediate threat. On qualified immunity, First Circuit precedent (e.g., Jennings, Raiche) and broader case law clearly establish that officers may not increase the level of force once a suspect has ceased resisting and no longer poses an immediate threat. The absence of a beanbag‑specific case does not defeat clearly established law where the core principle—escalating force against an unarmed, surrendered individual—is well settled. Because the complaint plausibly alleges a violation of clearly established law and the district court relied on inferences contrary to the pleadings, dismissal of the § 1983 excessive‑force claim on qualified‑immunity grounds was improper.

issue_2.reasoning: The MCRA requires threats, intimidation, or coercion distinct from the underlying rights violation. Plaintiffs’ theory rests entirely on the force used in effecting the seizure—pointing and attempting to fire the beanbag shotgun and then using lethal force. Under Massachusetts precedent (Longval and progeny), a direct use of force to effect an arrest or seizure, without something more aimed at coercing the victim to forgo an additional right, does not satisfy the statute. Plaintiffs do not plausibly allege that force was used to make Conlon relinquish some separate right (e.g., speech, association); rather, the alleged coercion is the excessive force itself. That is insufficient as a matter of law, so dismissal of the MCRA claim is properly affirmed.

issue_3.reasoning: To state a Monell failure‑to‑train claim, plaintiffs must plausibly allege a municipal policy or custom of inadequate training and deliberate indifference—usually demonstrated by a pattern of similar violations, or in the narrow single‑incident context, by an obvious need so acute that the violation was a highly predictable consequence. The complaint identifies only this single episode and offers generalized assertions that NPD training on beanbag shotguns and mental‑health encounters was minimal, while also acknowledging that NPD had a beanbag policy and that officers summoned a social worker and a specialized outside negotiation/tactical team. Those facts cut against an inference of total failure to train or deliberate indifference. The allegations lack specifics showing that the City’s program was patently deficient or that policymakers consciously disregarded a known risk of similar constitutional violations. Under the stringent Canton/Connick standard, this is not enough to state a plausible Monell claim, so dismissal is affirmed.

issue_4.reasoning: The ADA and Rehabilitation Act require discrimination or denial of benefits “by reason of” disability, and Buchanan limits failure‑to‑train theories in this circuit. Plaintiffs essentially repackage their failure‑to‑train Monell theory as an ADA/Rehab Act claim and allege that Conlon was denied the benefit of nondiscriminatory police services because officers did not more fully utilize mental‑health resources or delay until the regional team arrived. But the pleadings also show that the police recognized his mental illness, called a social worker, and requested a specialized team. The complaint does not plausibly allege that Conlon was excluded from any particular service or treated worse than non‑disabled persons would have been in materially similar, armed, barricaded‑suspect circumstances; the asserted discrimination flows from how officers responded to his conduct (flight, possession of a knife, erratic behavior), not from his disability per se. Nor do plaintiffs identify a specific, reasonably feasible accommodation officers were required to implement in the midst of the evolving confrontation, beyond a general preference for more or better training. Under Buchanan and analogous cases, those allegations are insufficient as a matter of law under Title II and the Rehabilitation Act, so dismissal is affirmed.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The combination of a motion‑to‑dismiss posture, pleaded factual ambiguities about whether Conlon was armed or advancing, and well‑settled Fourth Amendment principles against escalating force on an unarmed, compliant individual make it likely that the appellate court revives the § 1983 excessive‑force claim and rejects qualified immunity at this early stage. By contrast, the Massachusetts Civil Rights Act claim is squarely foreclosed by state precedent requiring threats or coercion beyond the force itself. The Monell failure‑to‑train allegations are thin and identify only this incident, while acknowledging existing policies and mental‑health resources, which undermines deliberate‑indifference and obvious‑need theories. For the ADA and Rehabilitation Act, First Circuit law (especially Buchanan) is skeptical of using those statutes as generalized failure‑to‑train vehicles in policing contexts; the complaint does not plead discrimination “by reason of” disability or a specific, reasonable accommodation, especially given that officers actually sought mental‑health resources. Taken together, the likely result is a mixed disposition: reversal as to the individual officers on the § 1983 excessive‑force claim, and affirmance as to the MCRA, Monell, ADA, and Rehabilitation Act claims.

parties.appellant: Ramón González-Beiró, Secretary of the Puerto Rico Department of Agriculture, and Alex Muñiz-Lasalle, Deputy Secretary of the Puerto Rico Department of Agriculture (defendants in the district court)
parties.appellee: Northwestern Selecta, Inc. (plaintiff in the district court), a Puerto Rico importer of poultry products

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Northwestern Selecta, Inc. (NWS) is a San Juan-based company that imports fresh and frozen poultry products into Puerto Rico from the continental United States and from abroad. The domestically transported products at issue are shipped by sea in large cargo containers and enter Puerto Rico through the Port of San Juan. All poultry products that NWS brings from the mainland United States are inspected by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) prior to transport and receive an official USDA inspection mark.

When the containers arrive in Puerto Rico, they are offloaded onto the Port of San Juan's docks to await clearance by the appropriate authorities, including the Puerto Rico Department of Agriculture (PRDA). NWS provides the PRDA with copies of the shipments' bills of lading to inform the agency of the contents of the containers that have arrived. These bills of lading do not indicate the condition of the contents upon arrival. After the containers are cleared, a contractor hired by NWS transports them from the Port directly to NWS's nearby facility, where the containers are opened and unloaded.

In June 2016, the PRDA promulgated Market Regulation No. 8, titled 'To Govern the Quality and the Marketing of Poultry Meat in the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico,' registered as Regulation No. 8764 with the Puerto Rico Department of State. The stated purpose of Regulation No. 8 is to prevent illegal practices and to protect the integrity of the quality and health of local and imported poultry products marketed in Puerto Rico. Regulation No. 8 sets requirements for transportation, storage, inspection, packaging, and labeling of poultry products brought into Puerto Rico. It authorizes the PRDA to detain lots of poultry meat that do not meet its requirements, impose fines on importers for violations, and, for repeated violations, revoke an importer’s license.

Article XII(B) of Regulation No. 8 provides that an official of the PRDA must be present at the time of opening and unloading the container used to bring poultry products into Puerto Rico. For about five years after Regulation No. 8 was promulgated, the PRDA did not enforce or seek to enforce Article XII(B) against NWS.

In June 2021, the PRDA issued several detention orders against NWS, impounding over 200,000 pounds of fresh poultry products that NWS had transported from the continental United States. Violation notices explained that the orders were issued because a PRDA inspector was not physically present when the shipping containers were opened and unloaded at NWS's facilities, in alleged violation of Article XII(B). Over the following months, PRDA issued violation notices to NWS regarding thirty-five shipping containers that had been opened and unloaded outside the presence of a PRDA inspector, and asserted the right to impose approximately $263,000 in fines for these alleged violations.

procedural_history.claims_brought: After unsuccessfully attempting to challenge the PRDA's violation notices through the administrative procedures outlined in Regulation No. 8, NWS filed a verified complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. NWS alleged, among other things, that Article XII(B) (the inspector-at-unloading requirement) and Article XIV(A)(6) (a labeling provision) of Market Regulation No. 8 are expressly preempted by the federal Poultry Products Inspection Act (PPIA), 21 U.S.C. §§ 451–473, and its implementing regulations. NWS sought declaratory and injunctive relief barring enforcement of those provisions against it.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: After PRDA filed its answer, NWS moved for injunctive relief and later filed an emergency motion for a preliminary injunction to prevent enforcement of Article XIV(A)(6) (the labeling provision) against it; the district court granted that emergency motion. NWS then filed another emergency motion seeking to extend injunctive relief to Article XII(B), asserting that continued enforcement of the inspector-at-unloading requirement disrupted NWS's orderly and timely operations. The district court granted this motion, concluding that Article XII(B)'s inspector requirement fell within the PPIA's express preemption clause and was not preserved by the PPIA's savings clause. The court granted declaratory relief and permanently enjoined enforcement of Article XII(B) against NWS. It also granted declaratory and permanent injunctive relief on NWS's challenge to Article XIV(A)(6).
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The PRDA, through its Secretary and Deputy Secretary, appealed the district court's ruling as to Article XII(B). The appeal challenges the district court's determination that Article XII(B)'s requirement of a PRDA inspector's presence when containers are opened and unloaded at NWS's facility is expressly preempted by the PPIA and not saved by the PPIA's savings clause. The PRDA did not appeal the district court's ruling regarding Article XIV(A)(6).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the Poultry Products Inspection Act's express preemption clause, 21 U.S.C. § 467e, precludes Puerto Rico's Article XII(B) requirement that a PRDA official be present when containers are opened and unloaded at NWS's facility, on the ground that this requirement is 'with respect to premises, facilities and operations' of an 'official establishment' and is 'in addition to, or different than' federal requirements.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Interpretation of an express preemption clause under the Supremacy Clause by focusing on the plain text of the federal statute, including the meaning of terms such as 'with respect to premises, facilities and operations,' 'official establishment,' and 'in addition to, or different than' the federal requirements, and considering statutory context and purpose. When a federal statute contains an express preemption clause, courts focus on the clause's wording without applying a presumption against preemption, using traditional tools of statutory construction to determine Congress's preemptive intent.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, assuming Article XII(B) falls within the scope of the PPIA's preemption clause, the provision is nonetheless preserved by the PPIA's savings clause, which allows states and territories to exercise concurrent jurisdiction over articles required to be inspected under the PPIA to prevent distribution for human food purposes of adulterated or misbranded articles that are outside an official establishment.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Construction of the PPIA's savings clause in 21 U.S.C. § 467e by examining its plain language, including the scope of states' and territories' concurrent jurisdiction over inspected articles that are 'outside' an official establishment, and determining when state or territorial requirements are equivalent to, and consistent with, federal requirements. Under preemption provisions barring state requirements 'in addition to, or different from' federal requirements, state rules equivalent to and fully consistent with federal requirements may be permissible, while non-equivalent additional requirements are not.

appellant_arguments: The PRDA contends that Article XII(B) is not preempted because the PPIA's term 'operations' in the phrase 'premises, facilities and operations of any official establishment' should be read in light of the statute's context as limited to slaughtering and processing activities, not to all aspects of a business such as distribution and unloading of containers. The PRDA points to the PPIA's definition of 'official establishment' as one at which inspection of the slaughter of poultry or the processing of poultry products is maintained, and to statutory and regulatory provisions referencing slaughtering and processing, to argue that matters not implicating slaughter or processing fall outside the PPIA's regulatory scope and thus outside the preemption clause.

The PRDA further argues that even if 'operations' is given its ordinary, broader meaning, Article XII(B) has no direct effect on NWS's operations within the meaning of the PPIA's preemption clause. It asserts that the provision does not regulate how NWS processes, receives, handles, packages, or markets meat inside its facility, and that any impact from requiring an inspector to be present when containers are opened is merely incidental, unlike the direct regulation of slaughterhouse activities that was at issue in National Meat Association v. Harris under a parallel meat inspection statute.

The PRDA also contends that the phrase 'premises, facilities and operations' should be read together to limit preemption to requirements concerning onsite operations of official establishments, i.e., those occurring on the establishments' premises or facilities. Relying on the Seventh Circuit's decision in Chicago-Midwest Meat Association v. City of Evanston, it argues that preemption does not extend to regulations affecting activities it characterizes as occurring outside the official establishment. By analogy to the municipal ordinance in that case permitting inspection of delivery vehicles away from regulated establishments, the PRDA suggests that Article XII(B) should be viewed as regulating an external aspect of delivery rather than onsite operations.

Regarding the savings clause, the PRDA argues that the district court erred in concluding that Article XII(B) cannot be justified as an exercise of concurrent jurisdiction over poultry products that are 'outside' the official establishment. It maintains that the containers and their contents, when subject to inspection and the inspector-presence requirement, should be regarded as outside NWS's official establishment for purposes of the PPIA savings clause, drawing again on Chicago-Midwest Meat Association as support for its position that similar vehicle- or container-based inspection provisions may survive federal preemption.

The PRDA disputes the district court's understanding of the interaction between the preemption clause and the savings clause, maintaining that the savings clause permits the Commonwealth to regulate in the manner Article XII(B) requires in order to prevent the distribution of adulterated or misbranded poultry products, and that this authority is not constrained solely to locations physically removed from an official establishment.
appellee_arguments: NWS argues that Article XII(B) is squarely within the PPIA's express preemption clause because it imposes a requirement concerning the 'operations' of an 'official establishment' that is 'in addition to, or different than' the requirements established by the PPIA and its regulations. NWS emphasizes that its facility has been designated as an 'official establishment' under the PPIA, and that the PPIA and its implementing regulations do not require the presence of a PRDA (or any state) inspector when shipping containers are opened and unloaded.

NWS contends that 'operations' should be given its ordinary, broad meaning, encompassing the full range of activities involved in running its business, including receiving, unloading, handling, and distributing poultry products. It asserts that Article XII(B) directly regulates its operations by dictating when and how it may open and unload containers, affecting its distribution processes, causing delays, and decreasing the shelf life of imports, particularly in light of PRDA’s acknowledged lack of sufficient inspectors and practice of conducting aleatory inspections.

NWS argues that the PPIA's text and structure demonstrate that the statute regulates more than slaughter and processing, encompassing distribution, labeling, sanitation, recordkeeping, and other aspects of poultry products in commerce. It cites provisions concerning labeling, sanitation, and prohibitions on distribution of adulterated or misbranded products to show the breadth of the PPIA's regulatory scheme and to refute PRDA’s claim that 'operations' is limited to slaughtering and processing.

Regarding the geographic scope of 'premises, facilities and operations,' NWS relies on the parties' joint stipulation and PRDA's own violation notices establishing that the relevant shipping containers are 'opened and unloaded at the NWS facilities.' On this basis, NWS maintains that Article XII(B) regulates onsite operations within the official establishment and thus falls within the PPIA preemption clause, distinguishing this case from the delivery-vehicle inspections in Chicago-Midwest Meat Association, which involved inspections away from the premises.

On the savings clause, NWS contends that it permits states and territories only to exercise concurrent jurisdiction over articles that have left an official establishment, to prevent distribution of adulterated or misbranded products outside that establishment. It argues that Article XII(B), as applied to NWS, does not regulate articles 'outside' the establishment because the containers are at NWS's own facility when opened and unloaded. NWS also maintains that the savings clause does not authorize states or territories to impose requirements that are additional to or different from federal requirements inside official establishments, but only to impose equivalent and fully consistent requirements or to enforce conduct that independently violates federal standards.

issue_1.reasoning: The scope of the PPIA’s express preemption clause is a pure question of statutory interpretation reviewed de novo. The text of § 467e preempts state requirements “with respect to premises, facilities and operations of any official establishment” that are “in addition to, or different than” federal requirements. NWS’s facility is undisputedly an “official establishment.” The jointly stipulated facts and PRDA’s own notices establish that the containers are “opened and unloaded at the NWS facilities,” so Article XII(B) regulates onsite activity, not off-premises conduct. The ordinary meaning of “operations” comfortably includes the receiving and unloading of containers as part of the establishment’s business; the PPIA and its regulations address not only slaughter and processing but also handling and distribution of inspected products, which undercuts PRDA’s narrow reading. There is no federal requirement that a Commonwealth inspector be physically present during unloading; thus Article XII(B) imposes an additional, different condition on the establishment’s operations. Chicago‑Midwest is distinguishable because that ordinance authorized inspections away from the establishment premises, whereas here the requirement attaches to operations at the official establishment itself. Under the plain text, Article XII(B), as applied to NWS, falls within the preempted field. The district court’s holding of express preemption is therefore likely affirmed.

issue_2.reasoning: Construction of the PPIA’s savings clause is also a legal question reviewed de novo. The savings clause allows states and territories to exercise concurrent jurisdiction over inspected articles “for the purpose of preventing the distribution for human food purposes of any such articles which are adulterated or misbranded” when those articles are “outside” an official establishment. By its terms, it preserves only post‑establishment regulation of products that have left an official establishment; it does not authorize additional or different requirements governing the operations of an official establishment itself. Here, the regulated activity is the opening and unloading of containers at NWS’s facility—conduct occurring within the official establishment’s premises and operations. PRDA’s attempt to characterize the containers as “outside” the establishment for savings‑clause purposes conflicts with the stipulated facts and stretches the clause beyond its text. Moreover, even where the savings clause permits concurrent jurisdiction, it does not license state rules that are “in addition to, or different than” federal requirements within the preempted subject matter; it allows equivalent, consistent enforcement against adulterated or misbranded products after they leave the establishment. Article XII(B) is a process requirement imposed at the establishment, not a parallel rule about adulteration or misbranding of goods outside it. Accordingly, the savings clause does not rescue Article XII(B), and the district court’s conclusion that it is not preserved is properly affirmed.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Both issues turn on the interpretation of the same preemption framework in § 467e, which the district court approached by giving the relevant terms their ordinary meanings and by tracking Supreme Court guidance in analogous meat‑inspection cases. The undisputed facts place the containers and the unloading activity squarely at NWS’s official establishment, making the comparison to off‑premises vehicle inspections in Chicago‑Midwest inapposite. The statutory phrase “premises, facilities and operations of any official establishment” is broad enough to encompass receiving and unloading, and there is no parallel federal requirement mandating state inspector presence; Article XII(B) therefore adds a distinct operational condition and is preempted. The savings clause, by its own text, is limited to concurrent jurisdiction over inspected articles after they have left an official establishment and does not reopen the field Congress expressly occupied within official establishments. PRDA’s broader reading of the savings clause would largely undercut the preemption clause and is unlikely to be adopted. Given this textual and structural analysis, the appellate court is likely to affirm the district court’s declaratory and injunctive relief as to Article XII(B).

parties.appellant: Dahua Technology USA, Inc., plaintiff in the district court seeking reformation/declaratory relief and asserting breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing
parties.appellee: Feng "Frank" Zhang, defendant in the district court and counterclaim-plaintiff for breach of contract

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Dahua Technology USA, Inc. (Dahua) is the U.S. subsidiary of Zhejiang Dahua Technology Co., Ltd. (Zhejiang), a publicly traded Chinese surveillance technology company based in Hangzhou, China. Dahua maintains corporate offices in Waltham, Massachusetts. In January 2016, Feng "Frank" Zhang assumed an executive role at Dahua as Chief Strategy Officer, Vice President, and President of North American and Enterprise Sales.

Zhang’s original employment terms were set out in a one-page agreement dated November 5, 2015 (the "2015 Employment Agreement"). Under that agreement, Zhang was to receive a one-time grant of Dahua common stock and a base salary of $510,000 annually for a three-year term. The agreement stated that his annual base salary was "conditionally guaranteed," meaning it remained payable in full even if the company terminated Zhang for cause, subject to a carveout for termination for "illegal conduct or company misconduct," in which event he would be compensated only for the duration of his employment without additional compensation.

By mid-2017, Zhejiang’s Board of Directors decided to remove Zhang from day-to-day management of its North American business. Zhejiang’s leadership, headed by founder and chairman Liquan Fu, consulted outside and in-house counsel on how to minimize risk from Zhang’s early removal. Counsel identified two principal concerns: (1) potential exposure from terminating the 2015 Employment Agreement before the end of the three-year term, including remaining base salary, lost benefits, and the value of the guaranteed term; and (2) the lack of restrictive covenants in the 2015 Employment Agreement to prevent a disgruntled Zhang from publicizing security vulnerabilities the company had concealed, particularly given his role in negotiations for an important strategic acquisition.

Zhejiang’s lawyers advised that mitigation required providing Zhang with a baseline severance package that would compensate him for salary, bonus, and other benefits due through the end of his three-year term, plus additional compensation to entice him to release all claims against Dahua and agree to restrictive covenants.

In late August 2017, Fu traveled to Massachusetts to negotiate Zhang’s removal terms. On the drive from the airport, Fu told Zhang he was considering having "young guys" run the business. The next day at Fu’s hotel, Fu told Zhang he wanted Zhang to move to a different role and offered Zhang a "senior management" position at Zhejiang’s headquarters in China. Zhang declined, citing his children’s education. Fu then offered Zhang a senior company advisor role in the United States. Zhang expressed interest but asked how the company would handle the remaining terms of the 2015 Employment Agreement. Fu said the company would "follow whatever the [2015 Employment Agreement] says." Zhang replied, "If [you] can take care of the agreement, I'm ok." Zhang asked what he would be asked to sign, and Fu said the company would make sure Zhang was "comfortable" and would "treat [him] well."

Fu left to make a phone call. On returning, he told Zhang they were "all set." Zhejiang in-house counsel Haiyan Yue then emailed Dahua’s outside counsel stating: "It’s been decided: [Zhang] will serve as a consultant. Dahua will pay him the remaining 16[-] month salary plus a monthly consulting fee. The consulting period is 2 years."

Later that day at Dahua’s Waltham office, Attorney Yue presented Fu and Zhang with drafts of a separation agreement and a consulting agreement. Under these proposed agreements, Zhang’s employment with Zhejiang would terminate, and he would be re-engaged by Dahua as an outside consultant, paid hourly for ad hoc projects on an at-will basis. These drafts did not provide compensation for Zhang’s remaining entitlements under the 2015 Employment Agreement. Zhang refused to sign, saying the terms were not what had been discussed with Fu and reminding Attorney Yue that Fu had said the company would "treat [him] well."

After further internal discussions, Zhejiang’s attorneys prepared two new letter agreements: (1) a release agreement (the "Release Agreement"), and (2) a new employment agreement for Zhang’s role as Senior Corporate Advisor (the "2017 Employment Agreement"). Collectively, these are referred to as the "2017 Agreement."

The Release Agreement purported to "memorialize[] the terms . . . agreed to with respect to the termination of [the 2015 Employment Agreement]" and contained a general release of claims, a non-competition clause, a confidentiality provision, and mutual non-disparagement. In exchange for execution, non-revocation, and compliance, the Release Agreement provided:

"Payments. In consideration for your execution, non-revocation and compliance with this Agreement, the Company agrees to make monthly severance payments to you in the amount of $680,000 for sixteen (16) months following the offer termination [d]ate (the 'Severance Period'), payable subject to standard payroll deductions and withholdings on the Company's ordinary payroll dates over the Severance Period. . . ."

The 2017 Employment Agreement described Zhang’s "new position" as a Dahua "Senior Corporate Advisor" who would participate in forward-looking projects but would not be involved in day-to-day business operations. It set a salary of $10,000 biweekly, equating to $240,000 annually.

Attorney Yue presented both the Release Agreement and the 2017 Employment Agreement together for Zhang and Fu to consider. After about ten to fifteen minutes, Zhang and Fu signed both documents without further discussion. Zhang’s employment as Senior Corporate Advisor began on August 29, 2017.

In the months that followed, Dahua continued to pay Zhang in monthly amounts consistent with his annual base salary under the 2015 Employment Agreement (effectively $510,000 per year) and the new advisor salary of $240,000 per year under the 2017 Employment Agreement.

On January 10, 2018, Dahua’s human resources department emailed Zhang informing him of his immediate termination, attaching a new separation and release agreement for him to review and sign. The proposed new agreement would have superseded the 2017 Agreement and provided Zhang with severance payments totaling $910,000.

Zhang refused to sign the new agreement and requested acceleration of what he viewed as the agreed severance amount under the Release Agreement. Zhang’s counsel sent a demand letter asserting that under the 2017 Agreement Dahua was "already contractually obligated to pay Mr. Zhang over $11,000,000." Zhejiang’s counsel replied that she had "just learned" of a "scrivener's error" in the Release Agreement, claiming the language mistakenly provided for a monthly severance payment of $680,000 for 16 months instead of a total severance of $680,000 paid as $42,000 (or $42,500) per month for 16 months. Counsel asked Zhang to sign an amendment to correct the alleged error. Zhang declined. Dahua then initiated this litigation.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Dahua filed a diversity action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts seeking a declaration that the Release Agreement was unenforceable on the ground that the severance provision contained a scrivener’s error resulting from a mutual mistake of the parties. Dahua sought reformation of the severance provision to reflect what it claimed was the parties’ intent: monthly severance payments of $42,500 for 16 months, totaling $680,000. Dahua also asserted that Zhang breached the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing by insisting that the Release Agreement as written reflected the parties’ intent. Zhang counterclaimed for breach of contract, alleging that Dahua refused to pay him in accordance with the terms of the Release Agreement.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
On cross-motions for summary judgment, the district court initially granted judgment for Dahua on all counts. It found no genuine dispute of material fact that a unilateral, if not mutual, mistake permeated the Release Agreement and ordered reformation of the severance provision as Dahua requested. The court also entered judgment for Dahua on its implied covenant claim. Zhang appealed. The First Circuit vacated the summary judgment in Dahua’s favor, holding that there were several disputed issues of material fact concerning the viability of any mistake defense, and remanded the case.

On remand, the case was reassigned to a different district judge, and an eleven-day bench trial was held focused on core factual disputes identified by the First Circuit. The parties agreed that the trial should resolve three principal factual questions: (1) whether, at the time of signing, Fu believed he was offering $680,000 per month for 16 months or a total of $680,000 over 16 months; (2) whether Zhang believed Fu was offering $680,000 per month for 16 months or $680,000 total over 16 months; and (3) if Dahua made a drafting mistake, whether Zhang knew or had reason to know of that mistake when he executed the Release Agreement.

After trial, the district court answered these factual questions in Dahua’s favor, finding that Dahua made a mistake in setting forth the severance payment as $680,000 per month instead of $680,000 payable over 16 months, and that the mistake was either mutual or that Zhang knew or had reason to know of it. However, the court concluded that, under Massachusetts law, it could not reform or rescind the Release Agreement based on unilateral or mutual mistake in these circumstances. The court held that reformation was unavailable because Dahua had not clearly demonstrated a prior, express agreement that the writing could be reformed to reflect, finding the parties’ pre-signing agreement to be limited to Zhang’s change in role and additional advisor salary while he continued to receive salary and benefits from the 2015 Employment Agreement, without any prior agreement on a release or detailed severance structure.

As to rescission, the district court concluded that Dahua’s mistake arguments were supported by evidence, including lawyers’ contemporaneous internal communications and the stark discrepancy between an initial offer that provided no severance and the later written provision implying approximately $10.88 million in severance. The court reasoned that this discrepancy should have alerted Zhang to a mistake. Nonetheless, the court found that Dahua bore the risk of the mistake because Dahua and its lawyers drafted the Release Agreement, controlled the information given to drafting counsel, and Fu approved and signed an English-language agreement he could not read. The court also found that equitable considerations weighed against rescission because Zhang had already performed under new restrictive covenants — including maintaining silence during the company’s strategic acquisition negotiations — and voiding the severance provision would effectively deprive him of compensation for those covenants.

The district court therefore entered judgment against Dahua on its claims for reformation and for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. It did not immediately enter judgment for Zhang on his breach of contract counterclaim. Instead, it requested additional briefing on whether, having found no prior oral agreement and having found mutual or known unilateral mistake but also that Dahua bore the risk of mistake, it had authority to fashion an equitable remedy or was required to enforce the Release Agreement as written.

In response, Dahua proposed several equitable approaches intended to avoid what it characterized as an unintended multimillion-dollar windfall to Zhang, including implying a quasi-contract that would provide for total severance of $680,000. Dahua later also argued the court could treat the problem as one of contract interpretation, contending that the severance provision could be viewed as ambiguous in light of the agreement as a whole. The district court rejected Dahua’s interpretive/ambiguity argument on waiver grounds and, alternatively, on the merits, concluding that the provision unambiguously promised Zhang $680,000 per month for 16 months. The court also found Dahua’s proposed equitable alternatives unpersuasive and held there was no basis to override the severance provision as written. Having determined that the Release Agreement’s terms, including the severance provision, controlled, it entered judgment for Zhang on his breach of contract counterclaim and awarded him $10,200,000 in severance plus prejudgment interest, for a total award of $16,953,787.88.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: In this second appeal, Dahua challenges the district court’s rulings following the bench trial and post-trial briefing. Specifically, Dahua appeals the determination that the severance provision of the Release Agreement unambiguously obligated Dahua to pay Zhang $680,000 per month for sixteen months and must be enforced as written; the rejection of Dahua’s late-raised ambiguity/interpretation theory; the denial of reformation or other equitable relief from the severance provision in light of the court’s factual findings about mistake; and the resulting judgment for Zhang on his breach of contract counterclaim. Dahua’s separate claim that Zhang breached the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing was also litigated and addressed by the district court and is part of the overall appellate posture.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the severance provision in the Release Agreement — stating that the company agrees to make "monthly severance payments to you in the amount of $680,000 for sixteen (16) months" — is ambiguous or unambiguous as a matter of law, and whether the district court should have interpreted that provision using extrinsic evidence of the parties’ intent rather than enforcing it as a clear promise of sixteen monthly payments of $680,000.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Massachusetts law, interpretation of a contract is a question of law. A contractual provision is ambiguous if its phraseology can support a reasonable difference of opinion as to the meaning of the words and the obligations undertaken. Courts interpret language in the context of the entire contract, the circumstances of negotiation and execution, and the objectives sought, seeking to construe the contract as a rational business instrument and to give effect to every word if possible.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Dahua waived its argument that the severance provision is ambiguous by not timely raising an ambiguity/interpretation theory before or during trial and by initially focusing its theory on mistake and reformation, and whether the district court correctly treated the ambiguity argument as waived.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Theories not timely raised in the trial court are generally deemed waived and cannot be raised on appeal. Waiver rules are informed by considerations of fairness and judicial economy, but appellate courts may, in rare instances, overlook a waiver, particularly where the issue is purely legal, the district court has addressed it on the merits, or it is inextricably intertwined with issues preserved for appeal.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, given the district court’s factual findings that the written severance amount did not reflect the parties’ shared or known intent and that Dahua bore the risk of any mistake, the court had authority in equity (e.g., reformation, rescission, quasi-contract, or other equitable adjustment) to avoid enforcing the severance provision as written, or was compelled by law to enforce it according to its plain terms.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Massachusetts law, reformation is available when a written agreement fails to express the parties’ prior express agreement and intention, and the proponent clearly proves that prior agreement. Rescission based on mutual or unilateral mistake is available where a mistake regarding a basic assumption has a material effect on the agreed exchange, unless the adversely affected party bears the risk of mistake. Courts applying these doctrines also consider the allocation of risk and equitable factors.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Zhang breached the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing by refusing to sign an amendment to correct the alleged scrivener’s error in the Release Agreement and by insisting that the Release Agreement as written governed the parties’ rights and obligations.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Massachusetts implies a covenant of good faith and fair dealing in every contract. The covenant is shaped by, and its scope is limited to, the existing contractual relationship; it concerns performance and enforcement of the contract, not pre-contract conduct or negotiation. The covenant does not create obligations beyond those in the contract, and courts generally do not impose duties on a party to renegotiate or modify an agreement absent contractual provisions requiring such conduct.

appellant_arguments: The severance provision is ambiguous as to whether $680,000 is the monthly amount or the total amount of severance to be paid over sixteen months. Grammatically, "monthly" can modify the verb "make" rather than the object "severance payments," such that the clause can reasonably be read as calling for severance payments, made monthly, in a total amount of $680,000 over sixteen months rather than $680,000 each month.

When the Release Agreement and the 2017 Employment Agreement are read together as an integrated transaction, the structure and economics of the deal support the interpretation that $680,000 is the total severance. Zhang’s advisor salary is expressed as an annual total ($240,000) and a periodic payment ($10,000 biweekly), whereas the severance provision lists only one dollar figure ($680,000), creating uncertainty about whether it is a total or periodic amount.

Background circumstances and business context make it implausible that Zhejiang intended to pay Zhang more than $10 million in severance — an amount far in excess of his remaining conditionally guaranteed base salary — and then also pay him an additional $480,000 as advisor compensation. Such a bargain is not a rational commercial arrangement when contrasted with the initial draft that offered no severance at all. This context demonstrates at least that the provision is susceptible to more than one reasonable interpretation.

Because the provision is ambiguous, the district court should have considered extrinsic evidence of intent, including internal communications and negotiation history, to determine whether the parties meant total severance of $680,000 or monthly installments of that amount. This interpretive inquiry is distinct from and, in some respects, precedes analysis of equitable remedies like reformation or rescission.

The ambiguity/interpretation argument was not waived. Although Dahua earlier emphasized a mistake/reformation theory and at times disclaimed relying on ambiguity, it raised the interpretive argument in response to the district court’s explicit post-trial request for briefing on whether the agreement had to be enforced as written. The issue was fully briefed and decided on the merits by the district court, so considering it on appeal would not unfairly prejudice Zhang or undermine judicial economy.

Even under traditional waiver doctrine, the appellate court should consider the ambiguity issue because it is purely legal, arises from the same contractual language that must be construed to review the existing judgment, and is inextricably intertwined with the questions of reformation, rescission, and breach of contract.

Regarding the implied covenant claim, Zhang’s refusal to sign an amendment correcting a perceived scrivener’s error cannot constitute a breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Nothing in the 2017 Agreement obliges him to renegotiate or modify its terms, and the covenant cannot be used to impose duties that contradict or go beyond the contract’s express provisions or to police pre-formation understandings.

Zhang’s alleged knowledge of the drafting mistake relates to contract formation, not performance. The implied covenant regulates the performance and enforcement of an existing contract, so using it to sanction Zhang for not disclosing an apparent mistake at the time of signing or for declining to amend the agreement is outside the covenant’s proper scope.
appellee_arguments: The severance provision unambiguously provides that the company will make sixteen monthly payments of $680,000. The phrase "make monthly severance payments to you in the amount of $680,000 for sixteen (16) months" is naturally read to mean that each monthly severance payment is $680,000, and the district court correctly applied the rule that every word should be given effect by treating "monthly" as modifying "severance payments."

Dahua’s alternative reading requires ignoring or diminishing the word "monthly" and is not grammatically or commercially the more natural construction. The inclusion of a single dollar amount in the provision is consistent with setting the amount of each monthly payment; the parties knew how to express total and periodic amounts separately, as they did in the advisor salary clause, and did not do so for the severance.

Any claimed ambiguity argument was waived. Throughout most of the litigation, Dahua expressly disclaimed an ambiguity theory and focused instead on reformation and mistake. Only after trial, when the district court solicited briefing on equitable remedies versus enforcing the agreement as written, did Dahua raise ambiguity. That sequence makes the ambiguity claim an untimely, "delinquent" argument that should not be considered on appeal.

Because Dahua chose to litigate on a mistake/reformation theory and not on contract interpretation, it should be held to that strategic choice and not allowed to shift theories after adverse factual findings. Allowing this late pivot undermines waiver doctrine and is unfair to Zhang, who framed his trial strategy around the issues Dahua actually presented.

On mistake and equitable relief, Zhang maintains that the district court’s factual findings already grant all the relief equitable doctrines could support. The court found that Dahua bore the risk of any drafting mistake, having controlled the drafting process through its lawyers and having chosen the language, and that equitable considerations counseled against rescission or quasi-contract remedies because Zhang had already performed under the restrictive covenants, providing Dahua with substantial benefits.

Regarding the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, Zhang argues that his conduct did not breach any implied duty. The 2017 Agreement does not impose an obligation to renegotiate or correct drafting errors after execution, and an implied covenant claim cannot be used to compel a party to forgo or modify rights clearly provided in the written contract. Moreover, any alleged bad faith related to recognizing and not disclosing Dahua’s drafting error at the formation stage is not actionable under the implied covenant, which governs performance and enforcement, not pre-contract negotiations.

issue_1.reasoning: Contract interpretation is reviewed de novo. The phrase "make monthly severance payments to you in the amount of $680,000 for sixteen (16) months" is, in ordinary English, most naturally read to set the amount of each monthly payment at $680,000, made over sixteen months. Reading $680,000 as the total, paid monthly, would either render "monthly" surplusage or force an unnatural parsing ("make [monthly] severance payments ... in the amount of $680,000 total"), which the text does not say. The district court also read the two agreements together and still found no textual foothold for treating $680,000 as a total rather than the payment amount. While the commercial implausibility of a >$10 million severance is strong evidence of mistake, it does not by itself create a second reasonable textual meaning; it supports a mistake theory, not ambiguity. Given Massachusetts’ emphasis on giving effect to all words and enforcing clear language even if the bargain later appears improvident, an appellate court is likely to agree that the provision is unambiguous and means sixteen monthly payments of $680,000.

issue_2.reasoning: Application of waiver/forfeiture rules to litigation theories is reviewed for abuse of discretion, subject to de novo review on underlying legal principles. Dahua litigated the case through summary judgment, a prior appeal, and an eleven-day bench trial on a pure mistake/reformation theory, at times explicitly disavowing an interpretation/ambiguity argument. Only after losing on reformation and rescission did it pivot in post-trial briefing to argue that the severance clause was ambiguous and should be interpreted using extrinsic evidence. The district court treated this as waived as a new, late-raised theory. That application of waiver doctrine falls well within the normal, "hold-the-party-to-its-strategy" range. Even though the court also addressed ambiguity on the merits in the alternative, that does not cure the lateness. Nor is this an exceptional case compelling the appellate court to overlook waiver; the new theory could have materially affected how evidence and cross-examination were framed at trial. The First Circuit is therefore likely to uphold the district court’s waiver ruling and, alternatively, its determination that the provision is not ambiguous.

issue_3.standard_of_review: mixed (underlying facts for clear error; ultimate equitable decision for abuse of discretion / de novo on legal limits)
issue_3.reasoning: The factual findings—(a) that the written severance amount did not reflect either party’s actual intended economic deal, (b) that Zhang at least knew or had reason to know of the error, and (c) that Dahua bore the risk of the drafting mistake—are reviewed for clear error and are strongly supported by the record as summarized: internal emails predating the final draft, the huge gap between the earlier no‑severance proposal and the $10+ million written severance, and Dahua’s exclusive control of drafting. On those findings, Massachusetts law sharply limits equitable relief. Reformation requires proof of a definite prior express agreement that the writing fails to capture; the district court found no such express agreement on a release or specific severance structure, only a general understanding that Zhang’s role and advisor salary would change while his existing salary/benefits continued. That is insufficient under settled Massachusetts precedent, so refusing reformation is legally correct. Rescission for mistake is likewise unavailable where the mistaken party bears the risk of the mistake, as the district court explicitly found, and where equities (here, Zhang’s full performance under restrictive covenants, including silence during a strategic acquisition) would make unwinding one-sided and punitive. The court reasonably concluded Dahua had assumed the drafting risk and that rescission or quasi‑contract would improperly rewrite a clear, integrated bargain after the other party had fully performed. Those are classic discretionary equitable determinations, and on this record an appellate court is unlikely to find an abuse of discretion or legal error in concluding it was compelled to enforce the severance clause as written and to reject reformation, rescission, or quasi‑contract relief.

issue_4.standard_of_review: de novo (application of implied covenant to essentially undisputed conduct)
issue_4.reasoning: The implied covenant claim turns on the scope of the covenant under Massachusetts law, not on disputed facts. The district court ultimately entered judgment against Dahua on its implied covenant claim, and that ruling accords with Massachusetts doctrine: the covenant governs performance and enforcement of an existing contract and does not impose a duty to renegotiate, correct perceived drafting errors, or surrender contract rights once the agreement is in place. Zhang’s refusal to sign an amendment and his insistence that Dahua comply with the written Release Agreement are exactly the type of conduct that courts routinely hold cannot constitute bad faith; a party may stand on the contract it negotiated absent a specific duty to amend. Any alleged opportunism in recognizing a mistake at the moment of signing goes to formation and is outside the covenant’s reach. An appellate court is therefore likely to affirm the rejection of Dahua’s implied covenant claim.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The key turning point is that, after remand from the first appeal, Dahua had its opportunity to prove mistake and secure equitable relief and largely succeeded on facts but failed on law and equity: the district court found a drafting error but also that Dahua assumed the risk and that Massachusetts law did not permit reformation or rescission on these facts. Those legal conclusions are well-grounded in Massachusetts cases requiring a prior express agreement for reformation and denying rescission where the mistaken party bears the risk. The court then enforced the contract as written, entering a very large award for Zhang. On this second appeal, Dahua’s main attempt to avoid that result is to recharacterize the problem as one of ambiguity/interpretation instead of pure mistake. That theory was raised only after trial, was reasonably deemed waived, and in any event is weak on the contract’s actual wording. The implied covenant issue cuts strongly against Dahua: Massachusetts law does not obligate Zhang to correct or renegotiate a written contract to his detriment. Given the deferential standards (clear error for factual findings; abuse of discretion on waiver and equitable relief) and the unfavorable substantive contract and equity doctrines, the appellate court is most likely to affirm across all issues, leaving intact the district court’s enforcement of the severance clause and the judgment on Zhang’s counterclaim, while also affirming the rejection of Dahua’s implied covenant claim.

parties.appellant: Govanni R. Nunez, plaintiff in the district court and claimant for Social Security Disability Insurance and Supplemental Security Income benefits
parties.appellee: Commissioner of Social Security, defendant in the district court and head of the agency that denied Nunez’s disability claims

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Before the onset of his mental health symptoms, Govanni R. Nunez worked full time as a security guard for the New York Public Library, stationed at the library’s Fifth Avenue entrance where he checked patrons for weapons and contraband. His formal education was limited; he had been in special education classes through the fifth grade and then dropped out due to instability at home.

In 2013, at age 35, Nunez experienced his first panic attack while riding the subway to work. Since that time, he has suffered panic symptoms in enclosed spaces, especially on the subway. His panic attacks generally last 5 to 20 minutes and cause tachycardia, palpitations, cold sweats, nausea, shortness of breath, and tingling in his extremities.

Nunez has been treated for anxiety and panic attacks since at least November 2016. He was initially prescribed Lexapro (escitalopram), to which he responded well and was symptom free for about a year. After tapering off Lexapro, his symptoms reemerged in June 2018. Although he resumed Lexapro by August 2018, he continued to have panic attacks, including at work as a security guard, sometimes requiring him to leave his security post during work hours. His medications also made him drowsy, and he began falling asleep during his shifts. On August 22, 2018, the library terminated his employment, telling him he was having too many panic attacks on the job.

To address his panic attacks, Nunez was also prescribed Atarax (hydroxyzine) as an "emergency" medication to take when he felt a panic attack coming on.
