They argue that the sequence of adverse licensing actions following their public opposition supports a retaliation theory.

On substantive due process, plaintiffs argue that they had protected property interests in their liquor and entertainment licenses and that the Town’s conduct in repeatedly delaying renewals, imposing restrictions and suspensions, and subjecting them to "untimely, costly, protracted, non-statutory and unconstitutional public hearings"—during which their counsel was sometimes muted and unable to cross-examine witnesses—amounts to an abuse of governmental power that is not keyed to any legitimate state interest. They contend the district court erred by focusing only on whether the conduct "shocks the conscience" and by not fully considering whether the actions were legally irrational or arbitrary.

On procedural due process, plaintiffs maintain that the Board failed to follow procedures required by state law and the Governor's Executive Orders (including Executive Orders Nos. 37 and 50) and Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 138 governing licensing, thereby depriving them of lawful, unbiased procedures. They argue that the Board held unlawful hearings and imposed sanctions without adhering to mandated procedures, and that the district court improperly relied on the existence of postdeprivation remedies without adequately considering the alleged unlawfulness of the procedures actually used.

Regarding the MCRA, plaintiffs argue that the defendants conspired to deny them rights secured by federal and state constitutions through threats, intimidation, or coercion. They point to alleged veiled threats from former Board Chair MacAskill (such as telling them to "kiss the ring" and wishing them "good luck") and to an incident in which MacAskill had to be restrained from physically attacking Jared Brackett. Plaintiffs contend that, when considered along with the economic pressure of licensing actions, these episodes amount to coercion within the meaning of the statute.

On the common law civil conspiracy claim, plaintiffs contend that the Harwich defendants, as the enforcers of the Town’s liquor and entertainment regulations, wielded a "peculiar power of coercion" over them. They argue that by acting in unison—through coordinated license suspensions, restrictions, and delays—these defendants used their collective regulatory power to exert pressure on plaintiffs beyond what any one official could exercise alone.

On the defamation claims, plaintiffs assert that Sluis and O'Neill made false reports to the Harwich Police, the Massachusetts Department of Labor Standards, and the Harwich Health Agent accusing Ember and The Port of violating COVID-19 guidance and their licenses, and that Ballantine defamed them in a newspaper interview by stating that their conduct was "very flagrant" and that they "ignored the whole of COVID-19 regulations." They argue these statements were factual assertions, false, and damaging to their business reputations, and that any conditional privilege for Ballantine should not apply or should be deemed abused. They further contend they should have been allowed discovery to probe Ballantine’s role and capacity when he spoke to the press.

Plaintiffs argue that the district court should not have dismissed their supplemental state-law claims with prejudice after disposing of the federal claims. They contend the court should have declined supplemental jurisdiction and allowed the state claims to proceed in state court.

Finally, plaintiffs contend that the district court abused its discretion in denying their two motions for leave to amend. They argue they were entitled to at least one further opportunity to amend before dismissal with prejudice, and that limited discovery was necessary to flesh out allegations and attribute conduct to specific defendants. They maintain that they could have augmented their complaint with additional specific factual allegations had leave to amend and limited discovery been granted.
appellee_arguments: The Town of Harwich and its officials argue that the amended complaint fails to state any claim under § 1983. They emphasize that the Board’s licensing and enforcement actions—suspending and restricting entertainment licenses after noise complaints, imposing sanctions for alleged COVID-19 violations, revoking an outdoor dining permit, and delaying license renewals—fall squarely within their lawful regulatory authority and are rationally related to legitimate governmental interests in enforcing noise and public health regulations. They characterize the dispute as a routine, albeit contentious, local licensing matter that does not rise to the level of a constitutional violation.

The municipal appellees contend that the complaint does not plausibly allege any substantive due process or equal protection violations because there is no conscience-shocking or legally irrational conduct, and the allegations at most show disagreement with discretionary licensing decisions. They argue that general claims of selective enforcement or interpersonal animus are insufficient. On procedural due process, they assert that Massachusetts law provides ample predeprivation and postdeprivation processes for licensees, including statutory judicial review under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 249, § 4, and appeals to the ABCC under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 138, § 67, which plaintiffs in fact utilized. Under the Parratt-Hudson doctrine, they maintain that any alleged unauthorized deviations from prescribed procedures do not constitute a federal due process violation so long as adequate state remedies exist.

As to Sluis and O'Neill, appellees argue that these private individuals are not state actors for § 1983 purposes under any test. They maintain that reporting complaints to authorities or engaging in communications with town officials does not constitute exercising powers traditionally and exclusively reserved to the state, nor does it amount to joint action or state compulsion. They note that the complaint alleges, at most, that Sluis and O'Neill made complaints and received non-public information, which they argue is insufficient to transform them into state actors.

Appellees further assert that several federal theories were waived or inadequately developed. They point out that plaintiffs abandoned their facial and as-applied First Amendment challenges to the Noise Ordinance in their appellate briefing and at oral argument. They also note that plaintiffs did not plead or argue a First Amendment retaliation claim in the district court in a developed way and therefore cannot raise it for the first time on appeal. Similarly, they argue that the § 1985 conspiracy and Fifth Amendment 'facial taking' theories were only mentioned perfunctorily and are waived.

Regarding the MCRA, appellees argue that the alleged conduct—veiled statements like "kiss the ring" or "good luck" and an incident where MacAskill was restrained from a physical confrontation—does not objectively amount to threats, intimidation, or coercion interfering with protected rights. They note that plaintiffs do not allege that these incidents actually deterred them from exercising any right or were tied to specific demands to forgo legal or constitutional rights.

On the civil conspiracy claim, the Harwich defendants argue that plaintiffs have not alleged either an underlying tort for a vicarious-liability conspiracy, or the kind of peculiar power of coercion that arises from concerted action beyond the officials’ ordinary regulatory authority. They contend that the mere fact that multiple officials participated in licensing decisions does not amount to the special, heightened coercive power required under Massachusetts conspiracy law.

For the defamation claims, appellees argue that the complaint fails to identify any specific false statement made by Sluis or O'Neill, and therefore does not satisfy Massachusetts pleading requirements for defamation. As to Ballantine, they argue that his statement to the Cape Cod Times was conditionally privileged because he was speaking in his capacity as a public official about enforcement of public health regulations, a matter of public concern. They also contend that plaintiffs conceded the existence of a qualified privilege in the district court and did not properly argue that the privilege did not apply, thereby waiving any contrary position.

On supplemental jurisdiction, the appellees maintain that the district court acted within its discretion to adjudicate and dismiss the state-law claims with prejudice after resolving the federal claims, given the investment of judicial resources and considerations of judicial economy, convenience, and fairness.

Finally, the appellees argue that the district court properly denied leave to amend because plaintiffs had already amended once, failed to specify concrete additional facts they would allege in another amendment, and sought essentially a "second bite at the apple." They contend that any further amendment would be futile because the core factual narrative would remain the same and could not give rise to the asserted federal and state claims under the applicable legal standards.

issue_1.reasoning: The court reviews the Rule 12(b)(6) and 12(c) dismissals de novo. The complaint describes a contentious licensing dispute—suspensions, restrictions, and delays in liquor/entertainment licenses and enforcement of COVID and noise rules—but those actions are facially within the Town’s regulatory mandate and rationally related to legitimate interests (noise control and public health). First Circuit precedent is extremely reluctant to constitutionalize local land‑use/licensing fights; selective enforcement against one or a few businesses, even if motivated by animus, generally does not amount to conscience‑shocking or legally irrational conduct, nor to an equal protection violation absent a well‑pleaded class‑of‑one theory with specific comparators, which is not clearly and concretely alleged here. For procedural due process, Massachusetts affords pre‑ and post‑deprivation remedies, including statutory review and ABCC appeals, which plaintiffs in fact pursued; under Parratt‑Hudson, alleged deviations from state procedures during hearings do not make out a federal due process claim where adequate state remedies exist. As to the private parties, the allegations amount to citizens complaining to and communicating with officials and receiving inside information; under First Circuit law this does not satisfy the public function, joint action, or state compulsion tests. Plaintiffs’ general assertions that Sluis and O’Neill ‘directed’ or ‘instigated’ enforcement are conclusory and insufficient to convert them into state actors. The district court’s conclusion that the § 1983 claims (including against the private defendants) were not plausibly pleaded is therefore likely affirmed.

issue_2.reasoning: The First Circuit strictly applies waiver and forfeiture rules. The summary indicates plaintiffs did not develop on appeal their facial and as‑applied First Amendment challenges to the Noise Ordinance and effectively abandoned them, and that retaliation, § 1985 conspiracy, and Fifth Amendment taking theories were either not developed below or raised only perfunctorily in the district court and/or on appeal. Under well‑settled circuit law, issues raised in a cursory fashion or for the first time on appeal are treated as waived. The district court’s treatment of these theories as inadequately pleaded or waived will be sustained, and the appellate court will decline to resurrect them.

issue_3.reasoning: On a motion to dismiss, whether the alleged facts amount to ‘threats, intimidation, or coercion’ under the MCRA is a legal sufficiency question. Massachusetts courts set a relatively high bar, usually requiring clear, objectively threatening conduct or substantial coercive pressure. Here, the alleged remarks (‘kiss the ring,’ ‘good luck’) and one heated confrontation that was defused, combined with regulatory actions taken through formal processes, are unlikely to be viewed as the sort of threats or coercion MCRA requires, especially where plaintiffs continued operating and actively litigated rather than being intimidated into foregoing rights. Economic pressure inherent in the exercise of ordinary licensing powers, without more, generally does not suffice. The district court’s conclusion that these allegations do not state an MCRA claim is likely affirmed.

issue_4.reasoning: The court evaluates whether the complaint states a claim under either Massachusetts conspiracy theory. For the vicarious‑liability form, plaintiffs must plead an underlying tort plus an agreement; the district court already found no adequately pleaded underlying torts (e.g., no viable MCRA, defamation, or constitutional tort), and the complaint’s references to a ‘conspiracy’ are largely conclusory. For the ‘peculiar power of coercion’ form, Massachusetts decisions require that defendants’ concerted action give them a special coercive leverage they would not possess individually. Here, the Town officials were simply exercising their collective authority as a multi‑member licensing board; that is the exact structure by which their statutory power is supposed to be exercised and does not constitute a peculiar power beyond their usual roles. The pleadings do not satisfy either theory; dismissal will be affirmed.

issue_5.standard_of_review: de novo (sufficiency of pleadings) with de novo / deferential mixed review on privilege and waiver
issue_5.reasoning: Massachusetts requires defamation plaintiffs to identify the specific defamatory statements. The complaint, as described, does not quote or precisely describe particular false statements by Sluis or O’Neill, but instead alleges broadly that they made ‘false complaints’ to various authorities. That is insufficiently specific even at the pleading stage. As to Ballantine, he was speaking to a newspaper about ongoing enforcement of COVID regulations—a classic matter of public concern—and the statement that plaintiffs’ violations were ‘very flagrant’ and that they ‘ignored’ COVID rules fits comfortably within the conditional privilege for public officials. Plaintiffs did not meaningfully contest the applicability of the privilege or plead facts showing abuse of it, and any argument that he was acting in a purely private capacity appears waived. The district court’s dismissal of the defamation claims is therefore likely affirmed.

issue_6.reasoning: Even after federal claims are dismissed, a district court retains discretion either to decline or to exercise supplemental jurisdiction. Here, the court had already expended substantial resources analyzing the state‑law theories on the merits, and the parties fully briefed them. Under First Circuit precedent, adjudicating and dismissing such claims with prejudice can be proper, especially when the defects are legal and not curable by re‑pleading. The baseline presumption favoring dismissal without prejudice is not absolute. Nothing in the summary suggests that the district court misapplied § 1367 factors or acted outside the range of reasonable choices, so no abuse of discretion is likely to be found.

issue_7.reasoning: Plaintiffs had already amended once and twice moved for further leave to amend but did not proffer a proposed amended complaint or specify concrete, nonconclusory new facts that would cure the deficiencies. They also effectively sought discovery before stating a viable claim, which the First Circuit routinely rejects. The district court was entitled to conclude that further amendment would be futile, as the core narrative (a contentious but ordinary licensing enforcement dispute) cannot be converted into a constitutional or tort claim by more detail. Denying further amendment and limited discovery falls squarely within the court’s case‑management discretion and is unlikely to be deemed an abuse.

stage2_decision.reasoning: All challenged rulings arise from a familiar pattern the First Circuit has repeatedly treated as a non‑constitutional dispute over local licensing and regulatory enforcement. The complaint, while detailed, essentially alleges selective and perhaps heavy‑handed enforcement of noise and COVID rules, interpersonal friction with town officials, and citizen complaints by neighbors or competitors. Under settled circuit doctrine, such allegations seldom clear the high bars for substantive or procedural due process, equal protection, MCRA, or Massachusetts conspiracy, particularly where robust state‑law review mechanisms are available and used. The private defendants’ conduct—complaining to authorities and communicating with officials—does not make them state actors. The defamation counts are under‑pleaded as to the private parties and clearly subject to conditional privilege for Ballantine. The district court also acted within its discretion in retaining supplemental jurisdiction and denying further amendment as futile when plaintiffs could not articulate specific new facts. There is no strong doctrinal foothold for reversal on any discrete issue, making a full affirmance the most probable appellate disposition.

parties.appellant: Jana Romanova, plaintiff in the district court; a professional photographer alleging willful copyright infringement
parties.appellee: Amilus Inc., defendant in the district court; operator and owner of the website www.ai-ap.com

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Jana Romanova is a professional photographer and Russian citizen who earns her primary income from licensing her photographs for online and print publication. She created and owns the copyright in a photograph depicting a Russian woman with two snakes in a domestic environment, one snake wrapped around the woman's left hand and another crawling up her torso (the "Photograph" or the "Work"). Romanova licensed National Geographic Magazine to publish this Photograph on a single-use basis in an article titled "Intimate Photos of People and Their Beloved Pet Snakes," which was published on September 29, 2017. On October 3, 2017, Romanova registered the Photograph with the United States Copyright Office.

Amilus Inc. is the registered owner of the website www.ai-ap.com (the "Website"). On December 31, 2017, Amilus copied Romanova's Photograph from the National Geographic article and republished it on the Website in an article titled "Trending: Dogs, Cats . . . and Other Pets, to Start Off 2018." The Website is accessible only to subscribers who pay a monthly membership fee of about $5, and the Website also sells merchandise to the public. The Amilus article featured ten photographs of people with pets, each apparently copied from other publications, as part of what the site described as a "semi-regular series focusing on the ever-increasing amount of pet photography we find online." The article added that it included "some pet snakes thrown in for good measure." The Website's caption for Romanova's Photograph was "Intimate Photos of People and Their Beloved Pet Snakes," the same title as the original National Geographic article. Romanova's Photograph was the only image in the Amilus article featuring snakes.

Romanova discovered the Photograph on Amilus's Website on December 26, 2019, approximately two years after it had first been posted there. She twice sent notifications to Amilus demanding that it take down the Photograph and cease and desist from further unauthorized use. Amilus did not respond to these communications and did not remove the Photograph.

procedural_history.claims_brought: On October 20, 2022, Romanova filed a civil action in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York alleging willful copyright infringement under Section 501 of the Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 501, based on Amilus's unauthorized copying and display of her Photograph on its Website. She sought relief premised on Amilus's use of her photograph without a license and in the face of her takedown and cease-and-desist demands.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: Romanova served Amilus with the summons and complaint. Amilus did not appear and did not file an answer. The Clerk entered a Certificate of Default. Romanova then moved for a default judgment. The district court issued an order directing Amilus to show cause why a default judgment should not be entered. According to a letter from Romanova's counsel, a corporate officer of Amilus confirmed receipt of the Clerk's Certificate of Default and the Order to Show Cause and stated that Amilus would not participate in the proceedings. The district court held a hearing on the motion for default judgment. Instead of granting the motion, the court sua sponte ordered Romanova to show cause why the complaint should not be dismissed on the ground that Amilus's use of the Photograph constituted fair use. Romanova filed a memorandum and declaration in response. Thereafter, the district court dismissed the complaint with prejudice, concluding that Romanova had failed to state a claim because, in the court's view, the fair use defense was clearly established on the face of the complaint.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Romanova appeals the district court's judgment dismissing her copyright infringement complaint with prejudice. She challenges the district court's conclusion that Amilus's republication of the Photograph constituted fair use based solely on the allegations in her complaint, and she also challenges the court's decision to raise and apply the affirmative defense of fair use sua sponte on behalf of a non-appearing, defaulting defendant.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in determining, based on the face of Romanova's complaint and incorporated materials, that Amilus's unauthorized copying and publication of her Photograph on its commercial subscription Website constituted fair use under 17 U.S.C. § 107, thereby concluding that she failed to state a claim for copyright infringement.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: On a motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6), the court must construe the complaint liberally, accept all factual allegations as true, and draw all reasonable inferences in the plaintiff's favor. To state a claim, the complaint must allege sufficient facts to state a plausible claim for relief. The court need not accept as true legal conclusions couched as factual allegations. Fair use under 17 U.S.C. § 107 is an affirmative defense on which the proponent bears the burden of proof. The statute sets forth four nonexclusive factors: (1) the purpose and character of the use, including whether it is commercial or for nonprofit educational purposes; (2) the nature of the copyrighted work; (3) the amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to the work as a whole; and (4) the effect of the use on the potential market for or value of the work. Supreme Court precedent explains that fair use requires, among other things, consideration of whether the secondary use is transformative and whether there is a justification for the copying; fair use is ordinarily raised and proven by the defendant as an affirmative defense.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court procedurally erred by sua sponte raising and applying the affirmative defense of fair use on behalf of a non-appearing, defaulting defendant, and by effectively placing on Romanova the burden to negate that defense in order to avoid dismissal for failure to state a claim.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Fair use is an affirmative defense to copyright infringement, and the party asserting it bears the burden of proof. Generally, affirmative defenses must be raised by the defendant, and trial courts are cautioned against sua sponte raising affirmative defenses in ways that undermine the principle of party presentation. In assessing a complaint on a Rule 12(b)(6) basis, a court evaluates whether the plaintiff has pled a prima facie claim; it does not ordinarily require a plaintiff to anticipate and disprove affirmative defenses not asserted by the defendant. In default situations, courts may examine whether the well-pleaded allegations state a claim but must still accept the factual allegations as true and draw reasonable inferences in the plaintiff's favor.

appellant_arguments: Romanova contends that her complaint adequately alleged a prima facie claim of copyright infringement: she owns a valid copyright in the Photograph, which was registered with the Copyright Office, and Amilus copied and publicly displayed the Photograph on its Website without authorization, including after she sent takedown and cease-and-desist notices.

She argues that the district court erred substantively in concluding that Amilus's use of the Photograph was fair use based solely on her pleadings. She maintains that the use was commercial, that Amilus reproduced the Photograph in full, that the Photograph is an artistic work used for the same expressive purpose, and that Amilus's unauthorized publication harmed the licensing market by offering substitute access to her work on a paywalled, subscription-based Website.

Romanova further asserts that the district court misapplied the concept of 'transformative use' by treating Amilus's surrounding text about trends in pet photography as sufficient to render the copying transformative, even though Amilus did not alter the Photograph or use it to comment on or critique the original work or its author.

Procedurally, she argues that the district court erred by sua sponte raising the affirmative defense of fair use on behalf of Amilus, a defendant that had defaulted and explicitly indicated it would not participate in the case. She maintains that this improperly shifted the burden to her to disprove a defense that Amilus never asserted and that, under governing precedent, affirmative defenses like fair use must be pleaded and proven by the defendant.

She seeks reversal of the dismissal and entry of default judgment, arguing that once liability is established by well-pleaded allegations and default, and absent a properly raised affirmative defense, she is entitled to judgment with further proceedings limited to determining damages and any other appropriate relief.
appellee_arguments: Amilus did not appear in the district court proceedings and has not appeared on appeal, and therefore has not presented arguments in support of the judgment or in support of any fair use defense.

The district court, acting on its own initiative, effectively advanced a fair use rationale on Amilus's behalf, reasoning that Amilus's article framed the Photograph within commentary on the trend of online pet photography and thereby imparted a different message than the original National Geographic use. The district court treated this framing as rendering the use transformative, and, on that basis and other inferences it drew from the pleadings, concluded that fair use was clearly established on the face of the complaint and that Romanova had failed to state a claim for infringement.

issue_1.reasoning:
Review of a Rule 12(b)(6) dismissal and of the application of the fair-use factors on the pleadings is de novo. The complaint adequately pleads a prima facie infringement claim: ownership of a registered copyright and unauthorized copying/display of the Photograph. Fair use is an affirmative defense on which the defendant bears the burden. On the face of the complaint and incorporated materials, fair use is not so clearly established that it can defeat the claim at the pleading stage, particularly where the defendant has defaulted and offered no evidence.

Applying the § 107 factors under the proper standard and in the posture of a motion to dismiss:
(1) Purpose and character: The use is commercial (behind a paid subscription wall on a site that also sells merchandise). The Photograph is republished in full as an illustrative image in another pet‑photography article, serving essentially the same illustrative purpose as the National Geographic use. The added surrounding text about a trend in pet photography does not comment on, criticize, or meaningfully transform the Photograph itself; it simply aggregates and showcases images. Under recent Supreme Court and Second Circuit guidance, a change in context or audience alone is not enough to be transformative when the secondary use shares the same purpose and provides a substitute illustration. This factor at a minimum does not clearly favor fair use at the pleading stage and plausibly favors Romanova.
(2) Nature of the work: The Photograph is a creative, artistic work, traditionally at the core of copyright protection. This weighs against fair use, or at least does not support dismissal on the pleadings.
(3) Amount and substantiality: Amilus copied the entire Photograph. Full reproduction of a creative work weighs against fair use absent a strong justification, which is not apparent on the face of the complaint and cannot be assumed in favor of a defaulting defendant.
(4) Market effect: Romanova alleges she earns primary income from licensing her images for online and print use, and that Amilus provided a substitute, unlicensed publication of the same Photograph on a paywalled site. At the pleading stage, the court must assume and reasonably infer a potential harm to the licensing market. The district court instead drew inferences against her and in favor of a fair-use defense, contrary to the Rule 12(b)(6) standard.

Because at least several factors plausibly favor the copyright holder and because the defendant bears (and has not carried) the burden of establishing fair use, the defense is not apparent as a matter of law on the face of the complaint. The district court therefore erred in using fair use to dismiss for failure to state a claim. That dismissal must be reversed.

issue_2.reasoning:
Whether a district court may sua sponte raise and apply an affirmative defense at the Rule 12(b)(6) stage, especially in the context of a default, is a question of law reviewed de novo. Fair use is an affirmative defense that must be raised and proven by the defendant. Under the party‑presentation principle and civil‑procedure norms, courts generally do not sua sponte interpose unpleaded affirmative defenses, particularly where doing so alters the allocation of burdens and deprives the plaintiff of the benefit of the adversarial process.

Here, Amilus not only failed to plead fair use, it defaulted and expressly declined to participate. The district court nonetheless:
(1) raised fair use on its own initiative after the Clerk’s entry of default,
(2) effectively converted the matter into a Rule 12(b)(6) analysis without a motion by the defendant,
(3) put the burden on Romanova to ‘show cause’ why fair use did not apply, and
(4) dismissed with prejudice based on its own view that the affirmative defense was clearly established.

This procedure both misallocated the burden of proof and contravened the principle that the plaintiff need not anticipate and negate affirmative defenses in the complaint. In the default context, the court may (and must) assess whether the well‑pleaded allegations establish a prima facie claim; here they do. But it may not manufacture and adjudicate an unasserted affirmative defense against the plaintiff, especially while drawing inferences against her. That constitutes legal error. The appropriate course is to accept liability as established by default (subject to the sufficiency of the complaint) and proceed to damages and any equitable relief, absent a properly raised defense. Thus, the judgment must be reversed on this procedural ground as well.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The district court dismissed a well‑pleaded infringement complaint with prejudice by sua sponte invoking and sustaining a fair‑use defense for a defaulting defendant. De novo application of both Rule 12(b)(6) standards and the fair‑use doctrine strongly suggests reversal. Substantively, the alleged use is commercial, reproduces the entire creative Photograph, serves a similar illustrative purpose, and plausibly harms the licensing market; fair use is not clearly established as a matter of law on the complaint alone, and the burden rests on the absent defendant. Procedurally, raising and deciding an unasserted affirmative defense against a non‑appearing party, and then requiring the plaintiff to negate that defense, conflicts with basic civil‑procedure principles and the allocation of burdens for fair use. Appellate courts in analogous cases have reversed such dismissals and remanded for further proceedings, typically directing the district court to enter default judgment as to liability and then address damages and any other relief. Accordingly, the prediction is that the appellate court reverses the dismissal on both issues and remands for entry of default judgment on liability and a determination of damages and remedies.

parties.appellant: Anna Gristina, plaintiff in the federal § 1983 action and criminal defendant in the earlier New York state prosecution
parties.appellee: Justice Juan Merchan, New York State Supreme Court Justice, presiding judge in Gristina’s criminal case, sued in his official capacity; Alvin Bragg, New York County District Attorney (substituted for former DA Cyrus Vance), sued in his official capacity

stage1_summary.factual_background:
In 2012, Anna Gristina, who ran what was described as a high-end prostitution operation, was prosecuted in New York State court. On September 25, 2012, she pleaded guilty to one count of promoting prostitution in the third degree, in violation of New York Penal Law § 230.25(1). Justice Juan Merchan presided over the criminal case and sentenced her to six months’ imprisonment and five years’ probation. Gristina did not appeal her conviction.

Almost a decade later, Gristina sought to obtain transcripts from proceedings in that criminal case in order, according to her later filings, to assist efforts to challenge or vacate her conviction on the ground that her guilty plea was coerced. On January 14, 2021, she filed a motion before Justice Merchan requesting unsealing of four transcripts and any related documents from her criminal case. In a short brief, she asserted that, under the Sixth Amendment and the New York due process clause, she had a right to view or copy any court document or record in order to put on a defense, take legal action concerning her case, or consult counsel about prospective legal matters. The New York County District Attorney’s Office opposed the motion.

On March 12, 2021, she supplemented her motion to request unsealing of an additional transcript as well as unredacted copies of a search warrant, search warrant affidavit, and related minutes. In total she was then seeking five transcripts plus related materials.

On March 22, 2021, Justice Merchan issued an order addressing the unsealing requests. The court noted that one requested transcript was not sealed, and another appeared to have been sealed in error and would be reviewed in camera. Three transcripts remained at issue: (1) a September 25, 2012 transcript, (2) an August 13, 2012 transcript, and (3) an August 16, 2012 transcript. As to the September 25 transcript, the court explained that it had been transcribed by a court reporter no longer employed by the Office of Court Administration, that it had been ordered from storage, and that the supervising court reporter would determine whether it was in fact sealed once retrieved.

The August 13 and August 16 transcripts related to proceedings in which Gristina was not directly participating in open court. The August 13 transcript involved only her co‑defendant, and Gristina was not present. The sealed August 16 transcript concerned an ex parte matter. Another August 16 transcript from a calendar call at which Gristina appeared and certain pretrial matters were discussed had already been unsealed.

Due to a clerical error, the court reporter had already provided Gristina with copies of the sealed August 13 and August 16 transcripts. Justice Merchan’s order stated that the court has inherent power in rare instances to seal its records and, in still rarer cases, to unseal them. The court concluded that Gristina had not met her burden to show why the sealed minutes of August 13 and 16 should be unsealed and that she had not justified retaining the copies she had received by mistake. The court ordered that the August 13 and 16 transcripts remain sealed and directed Gristina to return the erroneously released copies.

Gristina’s later filings asserted that she wanted the transcripts, among other reasons, to support a motion to vacate her conviction by showing that her guilty plea had been coerced.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
After Justice Merchan’s March 22, 2021 order, Gristina first sought relief in state court. On June 7, 2021, she filed an Article 78 petition in the New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, seeking a writ of prohibition or mandamus compelling unsealing of the August 13, August 16, and September 25 transcripts in her criminal case. The petition named Justice Merchan and then‑District Attorney Cyrus Vance, among others, as defendants, and asserted federal due process and equal protection violations arising from the opposition to and denial of her unsealing motion.

Separately, on October 20, 2021, Gristina filed a federal civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the Southern District of New York. The federal complaint again named Justice Merchan and DA Vance (later automatically substituted with DA Alvin Bragg under Fed. R. Civ. P. 25(d)) in their official capacities. She alleged that the District Attorney’s opposition to her unsealing motion and Justice Merchan’s denial of that motion violated her federal constitutional rights, including due process and equal protection. She sought injunctive relief directing defendants to allow her to pay for and obtain unsealed copies of the specified court minutes, and declaratory relief stating that she is entitled to those unsealed minutes.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
In the Article 78 proceeding, the Appellate Division, First Department, denied and dismissed the petition without opinion on October 14, 2021. It later denied Gristina’s motion for leave to appeal on January 11, 2022. The New York Court of Appeals denied leave to appeal on June 16, 2022.

In the federal action, Justice Merchan and the District Attorney moved to dismiss on multiple grounds: (1) lack of subject‑matter jurisdiction under the Younger abstention doctrine; (2) lack of jurisdiction under the Rooker‑Feldman doctrine; and (3) failure to state a claim based on judicial and prosecutorial immunity. On May 19, 2022, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York (Judge Paul A. Crotty) dismissed Gristina’s § 1983 complaint without prejudice. The court held that it was required to abstain under Younger because, when the federal suit was filed, the Article 78 proceeding was still pending on appeal in state court and involved the quintessentially judicial function of deciding whether to seal or unseal court records. In the alternative, the court concluded that the Rooker‑Feldman doctrine barred review because the state trial court’s order denying unsealing constituted a final state court judgment that the federal suit effectively invited the district court to review and reject.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: On appeal to the Second Circuit, Gristina challenges the district court’s dismissal of her § 1983 complaint. She contests the application of Younger abstention and the conclusion that her federal suit impermissibly interfered with an ongoing state proceeding concerning the sealing and unsealing of the transcripts. She also challenges the district court’s alternative reliance on the Rooker‑Feldman doctrine and its characterization of the state court’s denial of unsealing as a final judgment that deprived the federal court of jurisdiction.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly applied the Younger abstention doctrine to dismiss Gristina’s § 1983 action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to obtain unsealed state‑court transcripts, in light of the then‑pending state Article 78 proceeding over the same unsealing issues.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971), as clarified by Sprint Communications, Inc. v. Jacobs, 571 U.S. 69 (2013), permits abstention in three exceptional categories of state proceedings: (1) ongoing state criminal prosecutions, (2) certain civil enforcement proceedings akin to criminal prosecutions, and (3) civil proceedings involving orders uniquely in furtherance of the state courts’ ability to perform their judicial functions. For Younger to apply, there must be a pending qualifying state proceeding at the relevant time, an important state interest, and an adequate opportunity in the state forum to raise federal claims, subject to limited exceptions for bad faith, harassment, or extraordinary irreparable harm.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether a state appellate proceeding on Gristina’s Article 78 petition, which sought mandamus or prohibition to compel unsealing of criminal case transcripts, constitutes a “pending civil proceeding uniquely in furtherance of the state courts’ ability to perform their judicial functions” under the third Younger category.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under New Orleans Public Service, Inc. v. Council of New Orleans (NOPSI), 491 U.S. 350 (1989), and Pennzoil Co. v. Texaco Inc., 481 U.S. 1 (1987), proceedings fall within the third Younger category when they are closely tied to the state courts’ administration of their own processes and to the enforcement or implementation of their orders and judgments. Second Circuit precedents such as Falco v. Justices of the Matrimonial Parts of Supreme Court of Suffolk County, 805 F.3d 425 (2d Cir. 2015), and Cavanaugh v. Geballe, 28 F.4th 428 (2d Cir. 2022), further describe this category as encompassing proceedings that implicate core state court civil administrative processes, powers, and functions that allow state courts to adjudicate matters before them and enforce their judgments.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Younger abstention is assessed strictly as of the time the federal complaint is filed, or whether the subsequent completion of the state proceedings before the district court’s decision eliminates the basis for abstention.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Younger is a prudential, comity‑based abstention doctrine rather than a jurisdictional rule. Some precedent, including Hansel v. Town Court for Town of Springfield, N.Y., 56 F.3d 391 (2d Cir. 1995), evaluates the existence of a pending state proceeding at the time of filing of the federal action. Other cases, such as Silva v. Farrish, 47 F.4th 78 (2d Cir. 2022), and Pathways, Inc. v. Dunne, 329 F.3d 108 (2d Cir. 2003), recognize that Younger concerns can become moot once the state proceedings have concluded, and that federal courts then have authority and, ordinarily, an obligation to adjudicate properly filed cases.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the Rooker–Feldman doctrine deprived the federal district court of jurisdiction over Gristina’s § 1983 claims challenging the denial of her unsealing motion and related actions.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Exxon Mobil Corp. v. Saudi Basic Industries Corp., 544 U.S. 280 (2005), and Hoblock v. Albany County Board of Elections, 422 F.3d 77 (2d Cir. 2005), Rooker–Feldman applies only when: (1) the federal plaintiff lost in state court; (2) the plaintiff complains of injuries caused by a state‑court judgment; (3) the plaintiff invites the district court to review and reject that judgment; and (4) the state‑court judgment was rendered before the federal suit was filed. Hunter v. McMahon, 75 F.4th 62 (2d Cir. 2023), clarifies that when an appeal remains pending in state court, state proceedings have not “ended” and Rooker–Feldman does not apply, and that jurisdiction is assessed as of the time the federal complaint is filed.

appellant_arguments: Younger abstention was inapplicable because the state proceedings concerning the unsealing of the transcripts did not fall within any of the three narrow Sprint categories, particularly not the third category of proceedings uniquely in furtherance of state courts’ judicial functions. Gristina contends that an order refusing to unseal old transcripts from a long‑concluded criminal case is not akin to contempt orders or post‑judgment bond requirements and does not involve a process by which the state compels compliance with its judgments.

Even if the Article 78 proceeding was considered pending when she filed her federal suit, any Younger‑based concern dissipated once the state appellate process concluded. Because Younger is an equitable, prudential doctrine aimed at preventing interference with ongoing state processes, it no longer justified abstention by the time the district court ruled and certainly not by the time of appeal.

The state courts could not provide complete relief for her federal constitutional claims, or at least did not in fact do so. She asserts that she has a federal due process and equal protection right to access the transcripts to prepare a challenge to her conviction, and she sought federal declaratory and injunctive relief to vindicate those rights.

The Rooker–Feldman doctrine does not bar her suit because, at the time she filed in federal court, her state appeal from the Article 78 dismissal was still pending, so the state proceedings had not "ended" for Rooker–Feldman purposes. Moreover, her alleged injury—the inability to obtain the transcripts—was not caused by the state Article 78 judgment itself but by the continued sealing of records, a situation predating and existing independently of that judgment.

Her federal action does not function as an appeal of the state court decisions, but instead seeks a determination that the Constitution entitles her to access certain court records, a question that can be adjudicated without sitting in direct appellate review of the state courts. Any preclusive effect of the state decisions, if any, should be analyzed under ordinary claim or issue preclusion, not under Rooker–Feldman.
appellee_arguments: At the time Gristina filed her federal complaint, her Article 78 petition seeking to compel unsealing remained under review in the state appellate courts; thus, there was an ongoing state civil proceeding addressing the same subject matter. Under Second Circuit precedent, the existence of such a pending proceeding at the time of federal filing is sufficient to trigger Younger analysis.

The sealing and unsealing of court records is an inherent and fundamental aspect of a state court’s authority to manage its own proceedings and records, including protecting the integrity of criminal proceedings, safeguarding victims and witnesses, and balancing rights of public access against fair trial and confidentiality concerns. The Article 78 proceeding therefore fit within Younger’s third category as a civil proceeding uniquely in furtherance of the state court’s ability to perform its judicial functions.

Federal intervention ordering the unsealing of transcripts while the state courts were still considering Gristina’s unsealing request would create impermissible friction and duplication between the federal and state systems, effectively turning the federal court into an appellate tribunal second‑guessing state court management of its own records and procedures.

Gristina had an adequate opportunity in the Article 78 proceeding to raise the same federal constitutional claims she advances in federal court—indeed, she actually raised federal due process and equal protection arguments there—and she sought essentially the same relief (an order requiring unsealing). This undermines any claim that recourse to federal court is necessary to vindicate her federal rights.

Separately, the defendants argued that the federal district court lacked jurisdiction under the Rooker–Feldman doctrine because the federal suit effectively sought review and rejection of state court decisions refusing to unseal the transcripts, and that, in any event, the claims failed on the merits due to judicial and prosecutorial immunity. (The district court relied on Rooker–Feldman as an alternative ground, and the appellees maintain that rationale as an additional basis to support dismissal.)

issue_1.reasoning: Whether Younger abstention applies is reviewed de novo. At the time the federal complaint was filed, Gristina’s Article 78 proceeding—seeking mandamus/prohibition to compel the same unsealing she sought in federal court—was pending on appeal. The relief and federal theories were essentially identical. Under Sprint’s third Younger category, and Second Circuit cases like Falco and Cavanaugh, state proceedings that concern the management and sealing of court records fall within ‘civil proceedings involving orders uniquely in furtherance of the state courts’ ability to perform their judicial functions.’ The state courts also afforded an adequate opportunity to raise federal constitutional claims, which she in fact presented. No bad faith or extraordinary irreparable harm is plausibly alleged. Accordingly, as of filing, there was an ongoing state proceeding squarely within Younger’s third category, and abstention was proper. The district court’s application of Younger is therefore affirmed.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether the Article 78 appeal fits within Sprint’s third Younger category is a legal question reviewed de novo. The Article 78 proceeding directly challenged a state judge’s decision on whether to maintain or lift the sealing of judicial records in a concluded criminal case, and sought a writ compelling the judge to unseal those records. As in Falco (orders regarding attorney’s fees in matrimonial proceedings) and Cavanaugh (family‑court child-support mechanisms), this proceeding implicates core judicial functions: control of court files and confidentiality of proceedings. Pennzoil and NOPSI describe this category as covering state processes used to administer and enforce court orders and judgments. A petition that asks an appellate court to command a trial judge to unseal specified transcripts is precisely about how the state judiciary manages and enforces its own orders concerning its records. Thus, the Article 78 proceeding is a ‘civil proceeding uniquely in furtherance of the state courts’ ability to perform their judicial functions,’ and Younger’s third category is satisfied. The district court is affirmed on this point.

issue_3.reasoning: The temporal focus of Younger—whether to look at pendency as of filing—is a legal issue reviewed de novo. Second Circuit precedent, including Hansel and more recently Hunter and Silva (while recognizing Younger is prudential), consistently evaluates ‘ongoing state proceedings’ for both Younger and Rooker–Feldman as of the date the federal complaint is filed. The fact that the Article 78 appeal later concluded does not retroactively eliminate the basis for Younger abstention that existed when the district court addressed the case; Younger is concerned with avoiding interference at the time federal jurisdiction is invoked. Nor did the subsequent completion of the state appellate process mean that the district court was obligated to resurrect a case that was already properly dismissed on abstention grounds. At most, termination of the state case might support lifting a Younger stay in a stayed action, but here dismissal without prejudice on Younger grounds was not error. The district court’s treatment of the timing issue is therefore affirmed.

issue_4.reasoning: Application of Rooker–Feldman is a jurisdictional question reviewed de novo. One of its requirements is that the state-court judgment precede the federal filing and that the state proceedings have ‘ended’ before the federal suit begins. At the time Gristina filed her federal complaint (October 20, 2021), her Article 78 case was still pending in the Appellate Division; leave applications were later pursued. Under Exxon Mobil and the Second Circuit’s clarification in Hunter v. McMahon, state proceedings are not ‘ended’ while an appeal remains pending. Thus, the fourth Hoblock requirement was not met, and Rooker–Feldman did not apply. To the extent the district court deemed the sealing order a ‘final judgment’ for Rooker–Feldman purposes notwithstanding the live Article 78 appeal, that was legal error. Moreover, Gristina’s alleged injury—the ongoing sealing and the refusal to give her transcripts—flows from the continuing effect of state orders and policies, not exclusively from the Article 78 dismissal itself. Her claims might be precluded or barred for other reasons (including Younger, immunity, or preclusion), but Rooker–Feldman does not strip jurisdiction. The district court’s alternative reliance on Rooker–Feldman is therefore reversed.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The district court dismissed on two independent bases: Younger abstention and, in the alternative, Rooker–Feldman. The record squarely fits within the third Younger category as described in Sprint, Pennzoil, Falco, and Cavanaugh. When Gristina filed her federal § 1983 action, an Article 78 proceeding seeking the same unsealing relief against the same state actors was actively pending on appeal. That proceeding revolved around the state court’s control of its own records—an archetypal judicial function—and provided an adequate forum for her federal claims. Under Second Circuit practice, pendency is assessed at filing, and the later conclusion of the Article 78 case does not retroactively vitiate Younger’s applicability. Therefore, affirmance of the Younger-based dismissal is strongly supported.

By contrast, the alternative Rooker–Feldman ruling is inconsistent with the Supreme Court’s narrowing of that doctrine in Exxon Mobil and the Second Circuit’s focus on whether state proceedings have ‘ended’ (Hunter, Hoblock). Gristina’s state proceedings were ongoing when she filed in federal court, so the core Rooker–Feldman requirement of a prior final state judgment was not met. The federal suit may resemble a collateral attack on the state orders and may indeed be barred on Younger or preclusion grounds, but it is not jurisdictionally barred by Rooker–Feldman. Accordingly, the likely appellate disposition is to affirm dismissal under Younger while rejecting Rooker–Feldman as an alternative jurisdictional ground, producing a mixed outcome that leaves the case dismissed but clarifies the inapplicability of Rooker–Feldman.

parties.appellant: Angel Tudor, plaintiff in the district court and a high school math teacher employed by Whitehall Central School District
parties.appellee: Whitehall Central School District, defendant in the district court and Tudor’s employer

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Angel Tudor has worked for Whitehall Central School District for approximately twenty years, initially as a substitute teacher and later as a high school math teacher. Tudor has long suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) arising from sexual harassment and sexual assault by a supervisor at a prior workplace. Her PTSD symptoms have affected her neurological functioning, interfered with daily tasks, induced a stutter that impedes communication, and caused severe nightmares that at times led her to wake up vomiting. Tudor takes multiple medications to manage these symptoms and has been admitted for psychiatric care related to PTSD on three occasions.

Around 2008, Tudor’s PTSD symptoms escalated beyond what she could manage with therapy and medication alone. In consultation with her therapist, she requested and received an accommodation from Whitehall that allowed her to leave campus for one fifteen‑minute break during each of her morning and afternoon prep periods, times when she did not have responsibility for supervising students. She used these breaks to compose herself away from the school environment, which tended to trigger her PTSD symptoms.

In 2016, following a change in school administration, Whitehall adopted a policy prohibiting teachers from leaving school grounds during prep periods. When Tudor attempted to continue taking off‑campus breaks during those times, she was reprimanded for insubordination. She informed the new administration of her longstanding accommodation, but administrators told her that the documentation on file was insufficient to establish a right to a reasonable accommodation. Rather than immediately provide further documentation, Tudor took paid sick leave and then requested leave for the fall semester under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). Her physician described her condition as "PTSD with severe anxiety and agitation." During the FMLA leave, Tudor was unable to teach and attended an intensive outpatient treatment program five days a week to get her PTSD symptoms and anxiety under control.

When Tudor returned from FMLA leave in January 2017, Whitehall agreed to provide her one of the requested off‑campus breaks in the morning and an afternoon break on days when the school librarian could supervise her students. On days when a librarian was unavailable, Tudor could not take an afternoon break. This arrangement continued through the 2017–18 and 2018–19 school years. Whether this arrangement complied with the ADA was litigated in a separate lawsuit.

The present suit focuses on Tudor’s schedule for the 2019–20 school year. That schedule assigned her a morning prep period and an afternoon study hall. During that year, neither the school librarian nor any other Whitehall employee was available to cover Tudor’s class for a fifteen‑minute period during afternoon study hall. Despite this, Tudor left school grounds for a break during the study hall period on 91 of the first 100 school days before classes went remote because of the COVID‑19 pandemic. No Whitehall administrator expressly authorized these afternoon breaks, and it is unclear whether administrators were aware that she was taking them. Tudor testified that because she believed she was violating school policy by leaving, taking the breaks actually increased her anxiety.

Tudor claims that the school district’s refusal to guarantee her a daily fifteen‑minute afternoon off‑campus break during the 2019–20 school year exacerbated her PTSD‑related pain and anxiety, even though she continued to perform her teaching duties. In discovery in this case, she acknowledged that she could perform the essential functions of her job without the additional accommodation, but she stated that she did so only "under great duress and harm."

procedural_history.claims_brought: Tudor filed suit against Whitehall Central School District asserting a failure-to-accommodate claim under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) based on the District’s refusal to provide her a guaranteed fifteen‑minute afternoon break off campus during the 2019–20 school year. She also asserted related claims under New York State law, which she later stipulated to dismiss, leaving only the ADA claim at issue in this appeal.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: In the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York (Judge Sharpe), Whitehall moved for summary judgment on Tudor’s ADA failure‑to‑accommodate claim. For purposes of the motion, the district court assumed without deciding that Tudor had a qualifying disability under the ADA and that Whitehall’s scheduling decision for the 2019–20 school year—assigning her to an afternoon study hall without guaranteed coverage—constituted a denial of her requested accommodation (a daily fifteen‑minute afternoon off‑campus break). The court noted Tudor’s admission in discovery that she could perform the essential functions of her job without the requested accommodation, albeit under "great duress and harm." Relying on a formulation of the prima facie test for failure-to-accommodate claims, the district court concluded that Tudor could not establish the third element of her claim because she was able to perform the essential functions of her job without an accommodation, and it granted summary judgment in favor of Whitehall.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Tudor appeals from the district court’s March 21, 2023 judgment granting summary judgment to Whitehall on her ADA failure‑to‑accommodate claim. She challenges the district court’s conclusion that her acknowledged ability to perform the essential functions of her job without the requested accommodation necessarily prevented her from satisfying the third element of a prima facie failure‑to‑accommodate claim under the ADA.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether an employee’s ability to perform the essential functions of her job without a requested accommodation is, by itself, fatal to an ADA failure‑to‑accommodate claim, such that the employee cannot establish the third element of the prima facie case.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under the ADA, a plaintiff asserting a failure‑to‑accommodate claim must show by a preponderance of the evidence that: (1) her employer is subject to the ADA; (2) she is disabled within the meaning of the ADA; (3) she is otherwise qualified to perform the essential functions of the job, with or without reasonable accommodation; and (4) the employer refused to make a reasonable accommodation. 42 U.S.C. §§ 12111(8), 12112(a), 12112(b)(5)(A); Woolf v. Strada, 949 F.3d 89, 93 (2d Cir. 2020); Natofsky v. City of New York, 921 F.3d 337, 352 (2d Cir. 2019). A "qualified individual" under the statute is one who "with or without reasonable accommodation, can perform the essential functions" of the position. Reasonable accommodations can include job restructuring and part‑time or modified work schedules. The appeal centers on how this standard applies when the plaintiff concedes that she can perform essential job functions without the requested accommodation.

appellant_arguments: The district court applied an incorrect legal standard by treating her ability to perform the essential functions of her job without an accommodation as automatically disqualifying her from ADA protection and thereby precluding her failure‑to‑accommodate claim.

The statutory definition of "qualified individual"—someone who can perform essential job functions "with or without" reasonable accommodation—means that an employee may still be entitled to a reasonable accommodation even if she can technically do the job without it, especially where the accommodation would mitigate disability‑related pain and enable her to work without severe distress.

Her long history of receiving off‑campus breaks as an accommodation, followed by the school’s policy change and refusal to guarantee an afternoon break in 2019–20, shows that the requested accommodation was reasonable and necessary to manage her PTSD symptoms and the "terms, conditions, and privileges" of her employment, not just her bare ability to perform core teaching tasks.

Her admission that she could perform essential functions without the accommodation should not bar her claim because she performed those functions under "great duress and harm," and the ADA is intended to address discriminatory failures to reasonably accommodate known limitations, not only cases where an employee would otherwise be completely unable to work.
appellee_arguments: Because Tudor admitted during discovery that she was able to perform the essential functions of her job without the requested accommodation, she cannot satisfy the third element of a prima facie failure‑to‑accommodate claim, which they read as requiring proof that the employee could perform essential functions only with a reasonable accommodation.

The claimed accommodation—a guaranteed daily fifteen‑minute off‑campus afternoon break during study hall—was not required by the ADA because Tudor’s own testimony established that it was not necessary to enable her to perform her essential teaching duties.

To the extent Tudor alleges harm, the district court properly focused on whether she was qualified to perform essential functions and found that she was; thus, there is no failure‑to‑accommodate liability where the employee can work without the accommodation.

issue_1.reasoning:
The question is purely legal: whether a plaintiff’s conceded ability to perform essential job functions without the requested accommodation automatically defeats the third element of an ADA failure‑to‑accommodate claim at summary judgment. That is reviewed de novo.

The ADA defines a qualified individual as one who can perform the essential functions of the position "with or without reasonable accommodation." That text does not require that an employee be unable to perform essential functions absent accommodation; it requires only that the employee be capable of performing them, whether with or without such accommodation. The formulation used in Woolf and Natofsky focuses the third element on whether the plaintiff is qualified—i.e., can perform essential functions with or without accommodation—not on whether the employee can perform those functions only with an accommodation.

A contrary rule would read the phrase "with or without" out of the statute and would effectively deny accommodation to the exact group of working disabled individuals the statute is designed to protect—those who can perform their jobs but require reasonable accommodations to mitigate disability‑related limitations or pain, or to enjoy the terms and conditions of employment on an equal basis. Other circuits have recognized that an employee’s ability to work through significant pain or distress does not categorically bar an accommodation claim, particularly where the requested accommodation is a form of modified schedule or brief break, which the statute expressly contemplates.

Here, the district court assumed, for purposes of summary judgment, that Tudor was disabled and that the District denied the requested accommodation, but held that because she admitted she could perform the essential functions without the accommodation (albeit under "great duress and harm"), she necessarily failed the third element. That reasoning transforms the third element into a requirement that the plaintiff prove she is incapable of performing the job without an accommodation, which conflicts with the statutory language and the Second Circuit’s own articulation of the prima facie elements.

On this record, Tudor’s admission establishes that she is a "qualified individual" under the ADA; it does not defeat her status as such. The dispute over whether the fifteen‑minute afternoon off‑campus break was a reasonable accommodation and whether its denial violated the ADA goes to the fourth element and to issues of necessity and reasonableness, which the district court did not fully analyze under the proper legal framework. Because the court granted summary judgment based on an erroneous legal premise about the third element, that judgment must be reversed and the case remanded for application of the correct standard (including any further consideration of reasonableness, necessity, or undue hardship).

stage2_decision.reasoning: The dispositive issue on appeal is a narrow legal one: whether an employee’s ability to perform essential functions without an accommodation categorically bars a failure‑to‑accommodate claim by defeating the prima facie showing that she is "qualified." The ADA’s text—"with or without reasonable accommodation"—and the structure of the prima facie test in Second Circuit precedent point in the opposite direction. The plaintiff’s concession that she can do the work without the accommodation confirms that she is qualified; it does not extinguish her entitlement to seek a reasonable accommodation to address disability‑related limitations and to work without severe distress. The district court therefore applied an incorrect legal standard at summary judgment. Under de novo review, that legal error warrants reversal and remand for further proceedings under the correct framework, rather than affirmance based on Tudor’s admission alone.

parties.appellant: Natural Grocers; Citizens for GMO Labeling; Label GMOs; Rural Vermont; Good Earth Natural Foods; Puget Consumers Co-op; Center for Food Safety; National Organic Coalition – plaintiffs in the district court challenging the USDA/AMS regulations under the APA.
parties.appellee: Brooke L. Rollins, Secretary of the United States Department of Agriculture; Erin Morris, Administrator of the Agricultural Marketing Service; United States Department of Agriculture – defendants in the district court defending the regulations; American Farm Bureau Federation; United States Beet Sugar Association; American Sugarbeet Growers Association – intervenor-defendants in the district court supporting the agency.

stage1_summary.factual_background:
In 2016, Congress enacted Public Law No. 114-216, amending the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to add a national bioengineered food disclosure program. The new subtitle E of the Act, codified at 7 U.S.C. §§ 1639–1639j, requires the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a "national mandatory bioengineered food disclosure standard" within two years. The Act generally preempts state and local requirements regarding labeling of genetically engineered or genetically modified foods, while preserving state and federal remedies and certain other statutory schemes (such as the Organic Foods Production Act). The statute defines "bioengineering" with respect to a food as referring to a food that (1) "contains genetic material that has been modified through in vitro recombinant deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) techniques" and (2) the modification "could not otherwise be obtained through conventional breeding or found in nature." The term "bioengineering" is also defined to encompass "any similar term, as determined by the Secretary." The statute directs that the disclosure standard apply to "any bioengineered food and any food that may be bioengineered" and to foods subject to certain existing federal food labeling requirements, including under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. It also directs the Secretary to: (a) determine the amounts of a bioengineered substance that may be present in a food, as appropriate, in order for the food to be considered bioengineered for purposes of the standard; (b) establish a process for determining other factors and conditions under which a food is considered bioengineered; (c) ensure that "food derived from an animal" is not considered bioengineered solely because the animal consumed bioengineered feed; (d) provide alternative disclosure methods for small manufacturers and small or very small packages; and (e) exempt food served in restaurants or similar retail food establishments and food from very small manufacturers. Subtitle F contains preemption provisions stating that no state or political subdivision may establish or continue in effect any requirement relating to labeling of whether a food is genetically engineered or produced with genetic engineering, and separately barring non-identical state or local standards relating to whether a food is bioengineered or developed or produced with bioengineering.

The Act sets out specific rules for the permitted forms of disclosure. The Secretary must require that the form of a food disclosure be either text, symbol, or electronic or digital link, with the particular option chosen by the manufacturer. For the electronic or digital link option, the Act requires: an on-package statement such as "Scan here for more food information" or equivalent language reflecting technological changes; and a telephone number that provides access to the bioengineering disclosure. Congress also required the Secretary to conduct a study to identify technological challenges affecting consumer access to disclosures via electronic or digital means (such as QR codes). If, based on that study, the Secretary determines that consumers would not have sufficient access to the bioengineering disclosure through electronic or digital methods while shopping, the Secretary, after consulting with food retailers and manufacturers, must "provide additional and comparable options to access the bioengineering disclosure."

For enforcement, the statute makes it a prohibited act to knowingly fail to make a required disclosure, authorizes recordkeeping requirements and agency examinations or audits, and expressly states that the Secretary has no authority to recall food based solely on whether it bears a bioengineered disclosure.

The Secretary delegated responsibility for establishing and administering the national disclosure standard to the Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS). AMS first solicited public input via a series of questions posted online, then issued a notice of proposed rulemaking in May 2018. It received approximately 14,000 comments and issued a final rule in December 2018 titled "National Bioengineered Food Disclosure Standard," codified at 7 C.F.R. part 66. The disclosure requirements became fully mandatory as of January 1, 2022.

Three aspects of the final regulations are central to the dispute:

1. Treatment of highly refined foods made from bioengineered ingredients. AMS sought to define how the Act’s disclosure requirements applied to refined foods derived from bioengineered crops or ingredients. In the proposed rule, AMS presented two interpretive positions: Position 1 stated that refined products do not "contain genetic material" modified through in vitro recombinant DNA techniques because refining renders genetic material undetectable by common testing methods; Position 2 stated that all foods produced from bioengineering, including refined products, fall within the scope of "bioengineered" foods. In the final rule, AMS adopted Position 1 with modifications. In 7 C.F.R. § 66.1, AMS defined "bioengineered food" in language closely tracking the statute but added a proviso that such a food "does not contain modified genetic material if the genetic material is not detectable pursuant to § 66.9." Section 66.9 then specifies how regulated entities may demonstrate non-detectability: (a) the food is sourced from a non-bioengineered crop or source; (b) the food has been subjected to a refinement process validated to make modified genetic material undetectable; or (c) appropriate testing or analysis confirms absence of modified genetic material. Regulated entities relying on non-detectability must maintain records to support their claims. Under this framework, many highly refined foods made from bioengineered ingredients are treated as outside the definition of "bioengineered food"—and thus outside the disclosure requirement—if the genetic material is non-detectable under the regulatory standards.

2. Choice of disclosure terminology. The regulations require that all mandatory disclosures, regardless of format (text, symbol, electronic/digital link, or text message), use the statutory term "bioengineered." See 7 C.F.R. §§ 66.102–66.108. AMS declined to require or allow other terms—such as "genetically engineered," "genetically modified organism," or "GMO"—to satisfy the disclosure obligation, although manufacturers remain free to include such additional terms on labels so long as they comply with other applicable laws. AMS explained that it was selecting "bioengineered" because that is the term used by Congress; AMS viewed it as clearly and accurately describing the technology being disclosed, capable of providing consumers the information they desire, and conducive to disclosure consistency and minimized marketplace confusion. AMS also expressed concern that using other terms could create inconsistencies with the statutory preemption provisions or muddy the scope of the disclosure standard.

3. Electronic/digital link and text-message disclosure options. In response to the statutory requirement to study potential technological challenges to consumer access via electronic or digital links, the Secretary commissioned a Deloitte Consulting LLP study. After reviewing that study and public comments, AMS concluded that consumers, under ordinary shopping conditions at that time, would not have sufficient access to bioengineering disclosures through electronic or digital link methods alone. Under 7 U.S.C. § 1639b(c)(4), this determination triggered an obligation to "provide additional and comparable options" to access the disclosure. AMS decided to retain the electronic or digital link (e.g., QR code) option, which it viewed as mandated by the statute, and in addition to the statutory text and symbol options, it adopted a new, fourth option: a stand-alone text-message disclosure method. Section 66.106 governs use of the electronic/digital link option, requiring a QR code or similar link with the on-package statement "Scan here for more food information" and a telephone number with the statement "Call [1-000-000-000] for more food information" that provides the bioengineered food disclosure at all times. Section 66.108 establishes the text-message option, under which the label must instruct consumers to "Text [command word] to [number] for bioengineered food information." AMS took the position that it lacked authority to eliminate the electronic/digital link option, despite the study’s findings, and that the addition of the text-message option satisfied the statutory requirement to provide additional, comparable means of access.

The plaintiffs are a group of natural foods retailers and public interest or advocacy organizations focused on food labeling, organic standards, and GMO transparency. Natural Grocers operates 162 grocery stores in 20 states and has a business policy, based on founding principles and customer demand, of avoiding the sale of genetically engineered products, which it understands to include highly refined foods derived from bioengineered ingredients. The Center for Food Safety (CFS) is a nonprofit organization whose mission includes promoting clear and accessible labeling of genetically engineered foods. CFS members and supporters, as described in declarations, report that they seek to avoid genetically engineered foods, are familiar with and rely on terms such as "GMO" and "genetically engineered," and view the newer statutory term "bioengineered" as confusing, unfamiliar, or less informative. Several CFS members described practical obstacles to using QR codes or text-message systems in grocery aisles, such as limited smartphone access, data costs, time constraints, or usability barriers, and expressed a preference for clear on-package text or symbols. The plaintiffs allege that the challenged regulatory provisions frustrate their organizational purposes, impose additional costs on retailers attempting to avoid GMOs without the benefit of full federal disclosure coverage (e.g., for refined foods), and reduce their and their members’ ability to obtain clear and immediate information about whether foods are bioengineered or derived from bioengineered ingredients.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
