In July 2020, Natural Grocers, Citizens for GMO Labeling, Label GMOs, Rural Vermont, Good Earth Natural Foods, Puget Consumers Co-op, National Organic Coalition, and Center for Food Safety filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States Department of Agriculture, the Secretary of Agriculture, and the Administrator of the Agricultural Marketing Service (collectively referred to in the opinion as "the AMS"). The operative complaint included three causes of action under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A), relevant to the appeal:

1. A claim that the AMS’s regulations unlawfully and arbitrarily excluded highly refined foods from the definition and scope of "bioengineered food" by tying that definition to detectability of modified genetic material under 7 C.F.R. §§ 66.1 and 66.9, thereby exempting many refined foods made from bioengineered ingredients from the disclosure requirement.

2. A claim that the AMS acted contrary to the statute and arbitrarily and capriciously by requiring the use of the term "bioengineered" in all mandatory disclosures, and by not requiring or allowing more familiar terms like "genetically engineered," "genetically modified organism," or "GMO" to fulfill the disclosure obligation.

3. A claim that two specific disclosure-format regulations—7 C.F.R. § 66.106 (electronic or digital link/QR code option) and 7 C.F.R. § 66.108 (text-message option)—were unlawful and arbitrary and capricious. Plaintiffs argued that, in view of the statutory study’s finding that electronic/digital methods did not provide sufficient access, AMS was required to correct the deficiencies in the electronic/digital link method rather than retain it unchanged, and that the agency lacked statutory authority to add a fourth disclosure option (text messaging) beyond the three specified by Congress (text, symbol, or electronic/digital link).

The complaint also included three constitutional claims (not described in detail in the excerpt) that the district court later rejected, and plaintiffs did not pursue those claims on appeal.

In June 2021, the district court granted permissive intervention under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(b) to three trade associations: the United States Beet Sugar Association, the American Sugarbeet Growers Association, and the American Farm Bureau Federation (collectively, "Intervenors"). These intervenors joined as additional defendants supporting the AMS regulations.

Pursuant to a joint case-management proposal, plaintiffs moved for summary judgment in November 2021 on all of their claims. The AMS and Intervenors did not file formal cross-motions for summary judgment; instead, they stated in the joint proposal that they would ask the court to enter summary judgment in their favor under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56(f), which allows a court, after notice and an opportunity to respond, to grant summary judgment for a nonmovant. Plaintiffs acknowledged in that plan that they were on notice that summary judgment might be entered for defendants or intervenors on any or all claims, and that they would have an opportunity to address defendants’ arguments in their reply brief. In their oppositions to plaintiffs’ motion, the AMS and Intervenors expressly requested that the district court deny plaintiffs’ motion and enter judgment in favor of defendants (and intervenors) on all claims under Rule 56(f).

On September 13, 2022, the district court issued an order and judgment. The court:
- Granted summary judgment to plaintiffs on their APA claim challenging the two disclosure-format provisions, 7 C.F.R. §§ 66.106 and 66.108, holding those provisions unlawful, and remanded them to the AMS "without vacatur" for further proceedings.
- Denied plaintiffs’ summary judgment motion "in all other respects," which encompassed their APA claims challenging the highly refined foods (detectability) definition and the exclusive use of the term "bioengineered" in disclosures, as well as their constitutional claims. The order and judgment did not explicitly state that summary judgment was being entered for defendants and intervenors on the claims for which plaintiffs’ motion was denied.

The district court entered a judgment the same day reflecting those rulings. Plaintiffs timely filed a notice of appeal.

After appealing, plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion in the district court for an indicative ruling under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 62.1. They sought a statement from the district court that, if the court of appeals remanded for that purpose, the district court would amend its judgment to clarify that it had entered judgment in favor of defendants and intervenors, under Rule 56(f), on all claims as to which plaintiffs’ summary judgment motion was denied—thus confirming the judgment’s finality. Plaintiffs proposed replacement language specifying that, because their motion was denied in all other respects, judgment was entered for defendants and intervenors on all other claims. In March 2023, the district court denied the motion for an indicative ruling, stating that the existing judgment "provides total clarity on the disposition of the case."

On appeal, the Ninth Circuit examined its jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1291, given that the district court’s judgment expressly granted summary judgment to plaintiffs only on one APA claim, denied their motion as to all others, and did not explicitly state that judgment was being entered in favor of defendants and intervenors on the remaining claims. After reviewing the whole record, including the summary judgment proceedings, the parties’ motions, and the district court’s entry of judgment, the appellate court construed the judgment as implicitly granting summary judgment to the AMS and Intervenors on all remaining claims under Rule 56(f), thereby treating the judgment as a final, appealable decision disposing of all claims in the case.

The appellate court also addressed Article III standing. The agency did not contest standing on appeal, but the court examined declarations submitted at summary judgment. It relied on an uncontested declaration from a Natural Grocers officer describing the company’s avoidance of genetically engineered products, including refined foods derived from bioengineered ingredients, and the added costs it incurred to identify such products in the absence of federal disclosure coverage. It also relied on declarations from Center for Food Safety officials and CFS members demonstrating associational standing: members described confusion about the term "bioengineered" compared to more familiar terms like "GMO" or "genetically engineered" and explained the practical difficulties and burdens associated with accessing disclosures through QR codes or text messaging, especially while shopping. The court held that Natural Grocers had standing to challenge the exclusion of highly refined foods from the definition of bioengineered food, and that CFS had associational standing to challenge (1) the exclusive use of the term "bioengineered" and (2) the QR-code and text-message disclosure options. Because at least one plaintiff had standing to assert each APA claim at issue, the court proceeded to the merits.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
The district court’s core rulings relevant to the appeal include:

1. Highly refined foods/detectability definition: The district court rejected plaintiffs’ APA challenge to the regulatory definition of "bioengineered food" in 7 C.F.R. § 66.1 that excludes foods in which genetically modified material is not "detectable" pursuant to § 66.9. The court held that the AMS’s detectability-based approach was lawful and consistent with the statute, and it denied plaintiffs’ summary judgment motion on this claim, implicitly granting summary judgment to defendants and intervenors under Rule 56(f).

2. Required use of the term "bioengineered": The district court rejected plaintiffs’ APA challenge to the rule requiring use of the term "bioengineered" in all disclosures and disallowing terms like "genetically engineered" or "GMO" as substitutes for satisfying the mandatory disclosure. The court concluded that AMS’s decision to require a single uniform term and to select "bioengineered" was within its statutory authority and not arbitrary and capricious. It denied plaintiffs’ summary judgment motion on this claim, implicitly entering summary judgment for defendants and intervenors.

3. Electronic/digital link (QR code) and text-message options: The district court granted summary judgment to plaintiffs on their APA claim challenging the electronic/digital link disclosure provision (7 C.F.R. § 66.106) and the text-message disclosure provision (7 C.F.R. § 66.108). The court held that, in light of the statutory study’s conclusion that consumers lacked sufficient access to disclosures via electronic or digital means under ordinary shopping conditions, the statute required AMS to correct the deficiencies in that disclosure method. The court concluded that AMS acted contrary to law by: (a) retaining the existing electronic/digital link option, which the study had found inadequate, without fixing its accessibility problems; and (b) adding a new, independent text-message disclosure option as a fourth method, despite statutory language specifying only three forms of disclosure (text, symbol, or electronic/digital link). As a remedy, the district court remanded §§ 66.106 and 66.108 to AMS "without vacatur," meaning that both provisions remained in effect while the agency reconsidered them.

4. Constitutional claims: The district court rejected three constitutional claims asserted by plaintiffs, which are not pursued on appeal.

5. Remedy and vacatur: Applying Ninth Circuit precedent that vacatur is the usual APA remedy but may be withheld in limited circumstances, the district court concluded that although the text-message disclosure decision was a "significant error," vacatur of §§ 66.106 and 66.108 would unduly disrupt consumer access to bioengineering disclosures and disrupt the food industry, which had been required to comply with the regulations as of January 1, 2022. On that basis, the court remanded those rules without vacating them.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed:
On appeal, plaintiffs challenge only aspects of the district court’s judgment relating to their APA claims and the remedy. Specifically, they appeal:

1. The district court’s rejection of their APA claim challenging AMS’s detectability-based exclusion of highly refined foods from the definition of "bioengineered food" in 7 C.F.R. § 66.1 and § 66.9.

2. The district court’s rejection of their APA claim challenging AMS’s decision to require the term "bioengineered" as the exclusive mandatory disclosure terminology, rather than allowing or requiring terms such as "genetically engineered," "genetically modified organism," or "GMO" to satisfy the disclosure requirement.

3. The district court’s remedial decision to remand, but not vacate, the disclosure-format provisions at 7 C.F.R. §§ 66.106 (electronic/digital link/QR code) and 66.108 (text-message option), even after holding them unlawful. Plaintiffs argue that the district court should have vacated those regulatory provisions, at least prospectively, while the agency conducted further proceedings.

Plaintiffs do not appeal the district court’s rejection of their constitutional claims. The AMS and intervenors do not file a cross-appeal challenging the district court’s ruling that §§ 66.106 and 66.108 are unlawful, so that determination is treated as established for purposes of the appeal.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the AMS’s regulatory definition of "bioengineered food," which excludes foods in which genetically modified material is not detectable under the standards in 7 C.F.R. § 66.9 (including many highly refined foods made from bioengineered ingredients), is contrary to the statutory definition of "bioengineering" in 7 U.S.C. § 1639(1) and therefore unlawful or arbitrary and capricious under the APA.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: APA review under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A): the court must set aside agency action that is "arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law." Questions of statutory interpretation are reviewed de novo to determine whether the agency acted consistently with the statute. The court also considers whether the agency relied on factors which Congress has not intended it to consider, failed to consider an important aspect of the problem, or offered an explanation counter to the evidence. The court may not uphold discretionary agency action on grounds not invoked by the agency (SEC v. Chenery Corp.), and it evaluates whether any reliance on 7 U.S.C. § 1639b(b)(2)(B) (authority to determine the "amounts of a bioengineered substance" that may be present for food to be considered bioengineered) or other statutory provisions can sustain the detectability rule.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, even if the AMS erred in interpreting "contains" to mean "detectable" under the statute, the detectability-based exclusions can be justified as a permissible exercise of AMS’s discretionary authority to determine threshold amounts of bioengineered substances under 7 U.S.C. § 1639b(b)(2)(B) or related provisions, and whether the statute permits the agency to exclude certain foods (including some highly refined foods) based on detectability thresholds rather than requiring disclosure for all foods made from bioengineered ingredients.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: APA review under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). The court interprets 7 U.S.C. § 1639b(b)(2)(B), which directs the Secretary to "determine the amounts of a bioengineered substance that may be present in a food, as appropriate, in order for the food to be a bioengineered food," and considers whether that provision authorizes setting detection-based thresholds. The court also considers arguments grounded in other statutory provisions, including § 1639b(b)(2)(A) (animal-derived food), § 1639b(b)(2)(C) (other factors and conditions under which food is considered bioengineered), and preemption provisions, applying principles of statutory construction (e.g., surplusage, plain meaning) and APA limits on post hoc rationalizations (Chenery).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the AMS’s decision to require the term "bioengineered" as the exclusive mandatory disclosure term (and not to allow terms such as "genetically engineered," "GMO," or similar terms to satisfy the disclosure requirement) was arbitrary and capricious or inconsistent with the statute, given the Act’s reference to "similar term[s], as determined by the Secretary" and other statutory references to "genetically engineered" and "non-GMO" labeling.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: APA arbitrary-and-capricious review under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). The court evaluates whether AMS reasonably interpreted and exercised its authority under 7 U.S.C. § 1639(1) (defining "bioengineering" and allowing the Secretary to determine "any similar term"), as well as related provisions (e.g., § 1639c(c) and § 1639i(b) referring to "non-GMO" and "genetically engineered"). Under FCC v. Prometheus Radio Project, an agency action is arbitrary and capricious if it is not the product of reasoned decisionmaking or if the explanation is not reasonable and reasonably explained. The court examines whether AMS considered relevant factors, including consumer understanding, marketplace familiarity with alternative terms, and interplay with preemption provisions, and whether the agency adequately justified requiring a single uniform term.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion in remanding 7 C.F.R. §§ 66.106 (electronic/digital link) and 66.108 (text-message disclosure) to AMS without vacatur, after holding them unlawful under the APA, instead of vacating those rules (at least prospectively) while AMS reconsidered them.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Ninth Circuit precedent, when a court holds agency action unlawful under the APA, the default remedy is to vacate the rule and remand. A court may, in limited circumstances, remand without vacatur based on equitable discretion. The two principal factors are: (1) the seriousness of the agency’s errors, including whether the agency could adopt the same rule on remand or whether the flaws are fundamental; and (2) the disruptive consequences of vacatur and an interim change that may itself later change. This framework derives from cases such as California Communities Against Toxics v. U.S. EPA and Pollinator Stewardship Council v. U.S. EPA. The appellate court reviews the district court’s application of these factors for abuse of discretion.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the Ninth Circuit had appellate jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1291, given the district court’s order that granted summary judgment to plaintiffs on one claim, denied plaintiffs’ motion in all other respects, and remanded two regulatory provisions without vacatur, but did not explicitly state that summary judgment was entered for defendants on the remaining claims; and how to interpret the district court’s judgment in light of the record.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Jurisdictional and judgment-interpretation standards: The court of appeals has jurisdiction over "final decisions" of district courts under 28 U.S.C. § 1291. A denial of summary judgment is ordinarily not appealable, but when it is coupled with an entry of summary judgment on all remaining claims for the nonmoving party, the decision may be final. When a judgment is ambiguous, the appellate court must construe it to give effect to the issuing court’s intent, considering the entire record, including prior orders and the procedural history (United States v. DAS Corp.). The court also considers the availability of indicative rulings under Fed. R. Civ. P. 62.1 and remands under Fed. R. App. P. 12.1.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether at least one plaintiff had Article III standing for each of the three APA claims at issue (highly refined foods/detectability, mandatory use of "bioengineered" as the disclosure term, and the QR code/text-message disclosure-format rules), such that the federal courts had jurisdiction to adjudicate the merits.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Article III standing requires: (1) an injury in fact that is concrete, particularized, and actual or imminent; (2) a causal connection between the injury and the challenged conduct (traceability); and (3) redressability, meaning it is likely that the injury will be remedied by a favorable decision (Friends of the Earth v. Laidlaw). Plaintiffs must demonstrate standing for each claim and each form of relief they seek (TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez). However, where multiple plaintiffs seek the same non-monetary relief under the APA and the requested relief is the same for all, only one plaintiff needs to have standing for each claim for the court to proceed (Secretary of the Interior v. California; Melendres v. Arpaio). An organization has associational standing under Hunt v. Washington State Apple Advertising Commission if: (a) its members would have standing in their own right; (b) the interests it seeks to protect are germane to the organization’s purpose; and (c) neither the claim asserted nor the relief requested requires the participation of individual members.

appellant_arguments: On the detectability-based exclusion of highly refined foods, plaintiffs argue that AMS’s regulations unlawfully narrow the statutory definition of "bioengineering" in 7 U.S.C. § 1639(1). They contend that the statutory requirement that a food "contains genetic material" modified by in vitro recombinant DNA techniques is about actual presence, not detectability under particular testing methods. According to plaintiffs, AMS’s addition of a non-detectability proviso in 7 C.F.R. § 66.1 improperly rewrites Congress’s definition and effectively exempts many highly refined foods made from bioengineered inputs—foods that, in plaintiffs’ view, still "contain" modified genetic material at some point in the production process. They assert that the Act requires disclosure for all foods that contain or may contain bioengineered material, including refined foods, regardless of whether the genetic material is currently measurable by existing tests.

Plaintiffs further argue that AMS cannot justify the detectability provisions by invoking its authority under 7 U.S.C. § 1639b(b)(2)(B) to determine "amounts" of bioengineered substances that may be present in a food for it to be considered bioengineered. They argue that § 1639b(b)(2)(B) is intended to expand disclosure coverage or set thresholds that define when minimal, inadvertent traces of bioengineered material still trigger disclosure, not to authorize broad categorical exclusions of certain categories of foods. They also contend that AMS itself relied solely on its reading of the statutory definition of "bioengineering" and did not purport to exercise discretion under § 1639b(b)(2)(B) or any other threshold-setting authority when it adopted the detectability rule, making any such post hoc justification impermissible under Chenery.

Plaintiffs maintain that the statutory scheme does not permit AMS to exclude highly refined foods based on detectability thresholds, particularly when those foods are intentionally produced from bioengineered inputs, not merely contaminated inadvertently. They argue that any reliance on "amounts" of bioengineered substances under § 1639b(b)(2)(B) must be limited to incidental or unavoidable contamination, consistent with the separate regulatory provision at 7 C.F.R. § 66.5(c), which addresses inadvertent or technically unavoidable presence of bioengineered material. In their view, AMS’s detectability-based exclusions undermine the Act by leaving many foods made from bioengineered ingredients entirely outside the disclosure system.

On the required use of the term "bioengineered," plaintiffs argue that AMS acted arbitrarily and capriciously by refusing to allow or require more familiar terms such as "genetically engineered," "genetically modified organism," or "GMO" to satisfy the mandatory disclosure obligation. They point to widespread consumer familiarity with those terms and to the Act’s own references to "genetically engineered" foods and "non-GMO" claims in other sections, arguing that Congress intended these terms to be treated as equivalent or interchangeable with "bioengineered." Plaintiffs assert that AMS failed to adequately explain why it rejected these familiar terms and that requiring only the less familiar term "bioengineered" undermines consumer understanding and the Act’s informational goals.

Plaintiffs also contend that the AMS’s rationale about possible inconsistencies with the Act’s preemption provisions does not justify excluding terms like "GMO" and "genetically engineered". They argue that the statutory language in the preemption provisions, which includes references to "genetically engineered" and "other similar terms," confirms that Congress understood these terms to overlap with "bioengineered" and did not intend the narrower statutory definition of "bioengineering" to preclude broad use of those more common terms in federal disclosures.

Regarding the electronic/digital link and text-message options, plaintiffs argue that AMS violated the statute and the APA by retaining the electronic/digital link option in its existing form even after the mandated study determined that consumers would not have sufficient access to disclosures through that method while shopping. They assert that 7 U.S.C. § 1639b(c)(4) obligates the agency to "fix" the access problem revealed by the study—to ensure that any electronic/digital disclosure is effective and accessible—not merely to add an additional option. They further contend that AMS exceeded its statutory authority by adding a stand-alone text-message option as a fourth disclosure method, beyond the three forms (text, symbol, electronic/digital link) expressly specified in 7 U.S.C. § 1639b(b)(2)(D).

On remedy, plaintiffs argue that the district court erred by remanding §§ 66.106 and 66.108 without vacatur, despite finding them unlawful. They rely on Ninth Circuit precedent that vacatur is the default remedy under the APA once a rule is held unlawful and that remand without vacatur is reserved for limited circumstances where errors are minor or easily cured and where vacatur would cause serious disruption. Plaintiffs maintain that the errors in §§ 66.106 and 66.108 are substantive and fundamental, precluding re-adoption of those rules in their existing form on remand. They argue that leaving the unlawful disclosure options in place during the administrative process perpetuates inadequate, statutorily noncompliant disclosures and undermines consumer access to information.

Plaintiffs also challenge the district court’s findings on disruptive consequences. They argue that any disruption to the food industry (due to label changes or transition logistics) can be mitigated through a prospective vacatur that allows for a compliance timeline or sell-through period for existing inventory, rather than a blanket retention of unlawful rules for the entire remand period. They contend there is little or no evidence that vacatur would significantly disrupt consumer access to disclosures; in their view, continuing to allow inadequate electronic/digital and text-message options is itself a disruption to the statutory goal of providing sufficient access. Plaintiffs urge that the court should at least order a delayed or prospective vacatur, so that regulated entities can phase out the use of the invalidated options while AMS revises the regulations.

On jurisdiction and standing, plaintiffs maintain that the district court’s order and judgment, when viewed in light of the Rule 56(f) procedures and the parties’ explicit requests, should be interpreted as granting summary judgment to defendants on all claims for which plaintiffs’ motion was denied, thus creating a final, appealable decision under 28 U.S.C. § 1291. On standing, they rely on uncontroverted declarations: Natural Grocers asserts economic and operational injuries stemming from the exclusion of refined foods from the federal disclosure system, which forces it to expend additional resources to meet customer demands for non-GMO products; Center for Food Safety and its members allege informational and practical injuries due to confusing terminology and inaccessible disclosure methods. Plaintiffs assert that these injuries are traceable to the challenged regulations and would likely be remedied by invalidation and revision of those regulations.
appellee_arguments: On the detectability-based exclusion of highly refined foods, the AMS argues that its regulations lawfully implement the statutory definition of "bioengineering." It maintains that a food only "contains" modified genetic material within the meaning of 7 U.S.C. § 1639(1) if that material is present at levels detectable by scientifically accepted methods. AMS contends that because the statute does not define "contain," the agency reasonably interpreted the term in light of detection capabilities and the need to administer a workable disclosure regime. It asserts that tying coverage to detectability allows the agency to focus on foods where bioengineered genetic material can be reliably identified and avoids imposing disclosure obligations where no modified genetic material can be confirmed to be present in the finished product.

AMS further contends that its detectability framework is consistent with the statute’s structure, which directs the agency to determine "the amounts of a bioengineered substance that may be present in a food, as appropriate, in order for the food to be a bioengineered food" (7 U.S.C. § 1639b(b)(2)(B)). According to AMS, this authority encompasses setting thresholds below which the possible presence of bioengineered material does not trigger disclosure. It maintains that the detectability rule is a practical manifestation of Congress’s instruction, because it effectively defines the amount or level of modified genetic material required before a food is considered bioengineered for purposes of labeling. AMS argues that the statute does not mandate disclosure for all products that have ever been produced from bioengineered inputs, irrespective of whether any modified genetic material remains in the final product.

The AMS also points to its separate regulatory provision, 7 C.F.R. § 66.5(c), which sets a 5% allowance for inadvertent or technically unavoidable presence of bioengineered substances in ingredients, as evidence of its effort to calibrate disclosure obligations to meaningful levels of bioengineered content. It characterizes the detectability rule as part of a broader, coherent regulatory approach that balances statutory objectives with scientific and practical constraints, rather than as an unlawful narrowing of the statute.

On the required terminology, AMS argues that the statute grants it discretion to identify "similar terms" but does not compel it to authorize any particular term besides "bioengineered". It emphasizes that Congress repeatedly used the term "bioengineered" in the disclosure provisions and specially defined "bioengineering" by reference to a particular technology—modification through in vitro recombinant DNA techniques. AMS contends that other terms in the marketplace, such as "genetically engineered" or "GMO," can be broader or less precise, potentially covering products that fall outside the statutory definition (such as those created through different gene-editing techniques). To avoid confusion about the scope of the national standard and its interaction with the preemption provisions, AMS states it reasonably chose to require a single term—"bioengineered"—that aligns with the statutory definition. It notes that manufacturers remain free to include additional terms on labels (such as "GMO" or "genetically engineered") as long as such statements comply with other applicable laws and do not mislead consumers.

AMS defends its choice of "bioengineered" by pointing to the need for consistency and clarity in the marketplace. It argues that allowing different regulated entities to satisfy the disclosure requirement with different terms would confuse consumers and complicate enforcement. It maintains that selecting the statutory term promotes uniformity, communication of the specific technology Congress targeted, and harmonization with the Act’s preemption framework (which, AMS argues, deliberately uses broader language—"genetically engineered"—for state-law preemption while specifying a narrower, defined category—"bioengineered"—for federal disclosure).

Concerning the electronic/digital link and text-message options, AMS argues that the statute both mandates inclusion of an electronic or digital link as one of the available disclosure forms and separately requires the agency, upon finding insufficient consumer access, to provide "additional and comparable options". AMS interprets the statute as requiring retention of the electronic/digital link option, not elimination of that option altogether if the access study reveals problems. It contends that adding a text-message option as an additional method of access satisfies the requirement to provide "additional and comparable options" while preserving the statutorily mandated electronic/digital method. AMS maintains that the Act’s enumeration of text, symbol, and electronic/digital link in § 1639b(b)(2)(D) does not bar the agency from offering an additional, comparable disclosure mechanism (such as text messaging) under the separate authority in § 1639b(c)(4).

On remedy, AMS argues that remand without vacatur was appropriate and consistent with Ninth Circuit law. It emphasizes that the food industry had already made significant investments to comply with the labeling rules, including implementing QR codes and establishing text-message systems, by the time of the district court’s decision; that tens of thousands of products had already adopted the electronic/digital link option; and that vacatur would require substantial, costly label revisions and other changes on relatively short notice. AMS contends that such disruption, including potential confusion about when or whether previously compliant products could remain on the market, justifies allowing the challenged provisions to remain in effect while AMS conducts additional rulemaking to correct any identified legal deficiencies.

AMS also argues that immediate vacatur could temporarily decrease consumer access to bioengineering disclosures. It notes that, if the electronic/digital link and text-message options were vacated before replacement regulations were promulgated, some manufacturers might rely solely on text or symbol disclosures in ways that are not yet standardized or optimized for consumer understanding, or might need time before transitioning away from QR codes and text messaging. AMS maintains that, in light of these potential disruptions, the district court reasonably exercised its equitable discretion to remand without vacatur, thereby allowing the existing rules to operate during the interim period while AMS revises the regulatory scheme.

With respect to appellate jurisdiction, AMS ultimately does not challenge the Ninth Circuit’s jurisdiction but emphasizes that the district court intended to dispose of all claims in its September 2022 order and judgment. It notes that plaintiffs were on notice that the court might grant summary judgment to defendants and intervenors on non-prevailing claims under Rule 56(f), that the court denied plaintiffs’ motion "in all other respects," and that the court entered a judgment indicating final resolution of the case. AMS submits that any ambiguity in the judgment language was adequately resolved by interpreting the judgment in light of the full record and procedural history.

On standing, AMS does not contest plaintiffs’ standing on appeal. It does not submit contrary evidence to the declarations offered by Natural Grocers and Center for Food Safety. It relies on the district court’s acceptance of those declarations and on the appellate court’s independent duty to assure standing as satisfied by at least one plaintiff for each claim, while arguing the case on the merits.

issue_1.reasoning: The statutory definition in 7 U.S.C. § 1639(1) covers food that “contains genetic material that has been modified,” with no reference to detectability. AMS rewrote that definition in 7 C.F.R. § 66.1 by adding a non‑detectability carveout and then operationalizing it in § 66.9. Nothing in the text ties “contains” to what current tests can detect, and Congress elsewhere explicitly granted threshold‑setting authority in § 1639b(b)(2)(B), which would be largely redundant if “contains” already meant “detectably contains.” Given the express, detailed statutory definition and the separate threshold provision, the better reading is that AMS lacked authority to narrow the defined term by building detectability into the definition itself. Because AMS squarely relied on its interpretation of the definition and not on threshold authority, the detectability‑based exclusion is contrary to law and arbitrary under the APA. The district court’s approval of that interpretation should therefore be reversed.

issue_2.reasoning: AMS defends the same detectability carveout as an exercise of its separate authority under § 1639b(b)(2)(B) to determine the “amounts” of a bioengineered substance that may be present. But in the rulemaking, AMS did not invoke § 1639b(b)(2)(B) or explain the detectability rule as a quantitative threshold; it instead treated detectability as inherent in the statutory definition of “bioengineered food.” Under Chenery, the court cannot uphold the rule based on a rationale the agency itself did not adopt. Even on the merits, § 1639b(b)(2)(B) speaks to setting amounts of “a bioengineered substance” that may be present, which fits minimal or inadvertent content, not wholesale exclusion of entire categories of intentionally bioengineered‑derived refined foods. Treating “undetectable” as “zero” is a policy choice not grounded in the statutory text. The district court erred in accepting post‑hoc threshold theories to sustain the detectability regime, so it should be reversed and the detectability provisions set aside on this ground as well.

issue_3.reasoning: The statute repeatedly uses and specially defines “bioengineering” and then authorizes the Secretary to determine “any similar term,” not to require that similar terms be used. AMS chose to mandate the statutory term “bioengineered” for the federal disclosure while allowing, but not crediting, additional voluntary terms such as “GMO” or “genetically engineered.” That choice is consistent with the text, which does not obligate AMS to treat other terms as interchangeable labels for purposes of satisfying the federal standard. AMS explained that a single, statutorily defined term promotes uniformity, avoids confusion given the broader marketplace use of “GMO”/“GE,” and aligns the disclosure’s scope with the federal preemption scheme. Because manufacturers remain free to add familiar terms, AMS reasonably balanced consumer familiarity with statutory precision. The record reflects reasoned decisionmaking, so the district court correctly rejected the APA challenge to the exclusive use of “bioengineered,” and that ruling should be affirmed.

issue_4.reasoning: Vacatur is the default APA remedy, but courts may remand without vacatur when errors can be cured and vacatur would be highly disruptive. Here, the district court found the QR‑code and text‑message rules unlawful but concluded that: (1) AMS could potentially adopt similar mechanisms on remand in a lawful way (e.g., by fixing access deficiencies and grounding any additional option in clearer statutory authority); and (2) immediate vacatur would significantly disrupt an industry that had already overhauled labeling for tens of thousands of products and potentially reduce disclosure availability in the short term. Those findings fall squarely within the Ninth Circuit’s two‑factor framework (seriousness of error versus disruptive consequences). The court weighed both factors, recognized vacatur as the norm, and articulated a plausible, record‑based explanation for remanding without vacatur. That exercise of equitable discretion is within the permissible range and thus should be affirmed.

issue_5.reasoning: Although the written judgment explicitly granted summary judgment for plaintiffs only on the QR‑code/text‑message claim and merely “denied” plaintiffs’ motion on the others, the record makes clear that all parties proceeded under Rule 56(f) with notice that judgment could be entered for the nonmovants on any claim. Defendants expressly requested summary judgment in their favor on all non‑prevailing claims. The district court denied plaintiffs’ motion “in all other respects,” entered a judgment that ended the case, and later declined to issue an indicative ruling, stating the judgment was clear. Interpreting ambiguous judgments in light of the record, the Ninth Circuit reasonably construes this as an implicit grant of summary judgment to AMS and the intervenors on the remaining claims, producing a final decision under § 1291. Jurisdiction is therefore proper.

issue_6.reasoning: Unrebutted declarations from Natural Grocers show concrete economic and operational injuries traceable to the exclusion of refined foods from mandatory disclosure, redressable by vacating or revising the detectability rules. Declarations from Center for Food Safety members describe informational and practical injuries from the exclusive “bioengineered” terminology and from QR‑code/text‑message formats that are difficult to access while shopping. Those injuries are likewise traceable to the challenged rules and redressable through APA relief. CFS satisfies associational standing requirements, and only one plaintiff per claim is needed where the relief is non‑monetary and common. The record supports the conclusion that Article III is met for each APA claim. The district court (and the appellate court’s own review) properly recognized standing, so this aspect is affirmed.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The appellate court treats jurisdiction and Article III standing as satisfied, based on the full record and uncontested declarations. On the merits, the court is more likely than not to reject AMS’s detectability‑based narrowing of the statutory definition of “bioengineered food.” The statutory text already defines “bioengineering” and separately grants threshold authority; AMS’s insertion of a detectability condition into the definition conflicts with that structure and rests on a rationale the agency cannot recast as threshold‑setting after the fact. Thus the district court’s approval of the detectability rule is reversed. By contrast, the statute grants AMS broad discretion over the term used for federal disclosure, and AMS offered a reasoned explanation for choosing the uniform statutory term “bioengineered” while allowing other terms voluntarily. That decision comfortably survives arbitrary‑and‑capricious review, so the district court’s rejection of that APA claim is affirmed. On remedy, the district court explicitly weighed the seriousness of the legal defects in the QR‑code and text‑message rules against the disruptive consequences of vacatur in a mature, nationwide labeling regime. Its choice to remand without vacatur falls within the Ninth Circuit’s equitable framework and is not outside the range of permissible options, so it is affirmed. Taken together, this yields a mixed result: plaintiffs prevail on the highly refined foods/detectability issues but not on the terminology or remedial/vacatur questions.

parties.appellant: Madelaine Chocolate Novelties, Inc., d.b.a. The Madelaine Chocolate Company (plaintiff in the district court, insured under the policy)
parties.appellee: Great Northern Insurance Company (defendant in the district court, insurer under the policy)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Madelaine Chocolate Novelties, Inc. manufactures candy in a factory located on a narrow strip of land in Queens, New York, approximately three blocks from the Atlantic Ocean and one block from Jamaica Bay. In October 2012, Superstorm Sandy struck the area and inundated Madelaine Chocolate’s factory with more than three feet of saltwater. Madelaine Chocolate claimed that the storm caused over $53 million in physical damage to its production facility and related economic losses. It submitted a claim for these losses under a commercial insurance policy issued by Great Northern Insurance Company. Great Northern did not pay the full amount sought and instead paid approximately $4 million. In explaining its denial of most of the claimed amount, Great Northern relied on the policy’s flood-exclusion provision, which excludes, in relevant part, loss or damage caused by the rising, overflowing, or breaking of any boundary of any body of water, whether driven by wind or not (referred to as the Flood Exclusion). The Flood Exclusion includes an anti-concurrent causation (ACC) clause stating that the exclusion applies regardless of any other cause or event that directly or indirectly contributes to the loss or damage. Great Northern’s position was that Madelaine Chocolate’s losses were caused, at least in part, by wind-driven flooding or storm surge and therefore were excluded under the Flood Exclusion and its ACC clause. Madelaine Chocolate, in contrast, maintained that its losses were caused by a "windstorm," which is listed as a "specified peril" under the policy. Although the main policy did not define "windstorm," the policy contained a form entitled "Windstorm Or Hail Deductible Or Waiting Period" (the Windstorm Endorsement). That endorsement defined "windstorm" to include "wind-driven rain" and provided that this definition applied regardless of any other cause or event that directly or indirectly contributes to the loss or damage—language characterized as an arguably inverse ACC clause because it operates in favor of coverage for the defined peril. Madelaine Chocolate argued that this Windstorm Endorsement either independently provided coverage for its storm-surge losses or at least created an ambiguity when read together with the Flood Exclusion that had to be resolved in its favor. The parties also presented evidence about Madelaine Chocolate’s insurance purchasing history and communications. Evidence at trial included testimony from Madelaine Chocolate executives that the company had discontinued a $2.5 million excess-flood insurance policy in 2001; correspondence in which Madelaine Chocolate, when asked by a third party to disclose its flood insurance, listed only $3 million in coverage under the National Flood Insurance Program and did not list any flood coverage from Great Northern; and a loss-control report from a Great Northern professional to the head of Madelaine Chocolate’s insurance program that addressed natural hazards in separate sections, including distinct sections for windstorms and for flood hazards. Great Northern relied on this information to argue that both parties understood that the Great Northern policy did not provide coverage for storm-surge or flood-type losses, while Madelaine Chocolate argued that the policy, particularly through the Windstorm Endorsement, did provide or at least appeared to provide such coverage.

procedural_history.claims_brought: After Great Northern limited its payment on the Superstorm Sandy claim to about $4 million and denied the bulk of the claim by invoking the Flood Exclusion and its ACC clause, Madelaine Chocolate filed suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, alleging breach of contract and seeking coverage for its alleged more than $53 million in storm-related physical damage and economic losses. Madelaine Chocolate’s core position was that the losses were caused by a covered windstorm peril under the policy, as modified or clarified by the Windstorm Endorsement, and that any ambiguity between that endorsement and the Flood Exclusion should be construed in its favor.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: In an initial ruling, the district court concluded that the policy language was unambiguous and granted summary judgment in favor of Great Northern. The court determined that Madelaine Chocolate’s losses were caused by storm surge and, under then-existing precedent interpreting similar language, the Flood Exclusion applied to exclude coverage. The court further found that the Windstorm Endorsement merely addressed that the policy provided coverage for wind-related damage and adjusted the applicable deductible or waiting period; it did not provide a separate basis for coverage nor supersede the Flood Exclusion. On appeal, the Second Circuit vacated that judgment and remanded, directing the district court to consider the effect of the Windstorm Endorsement’s own ACC clause and whether it conflicted with or created ambiguity in relation to the Flood Exclusion. On remand, the district court found that the Windstorm Endorsement’s definition of "windstorm" and its ACC clause did create an ambiguity vis-à-vis the Flood Exclusion when the policy was read as a whole. The court then considered extrinsic evidence of the parties’ intent. Because there was extrinsic evidence that could support an interpretation of the policy that foreclosed coverage, the court concluded it could not resolve the ambiguity as a matter of law in favor of the insured and that the doctrine of contra proferentem need not be applied at the summary judgment stage. The district court denied both parties’ cross-motions for summary judgment and set the case for a jury trial. Following a week-long trial, the jury returned a verdict in favor of Great Northern. Madelaine Chocolate then filed post-trial motions for judgment as a matter of law under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 50 and, alternatively, for a new trial under Rule 59. The district court denied both motions.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Madelaine Chocolate appeals the district court’s August 24, 2022 judgment, which followed the jury verdict in Great Northern’s favor, as well as the district court’s denial of its Rule 50 motion for judgment as a matter of law and its Rule 59 motion for a new trial. On appeal, Madelaine Chocolate challenges the sufficiency of the evidence supporting the jury’s verdict in light of the burden imposed on the insurer under New York law, argues that the district court improperly allowed the jury to consider evidence of Great Northern’s uncommunicated subjective intent regarding the policy’s meaning, and contends that, under the law-of-the-case doctrine, Great Northern should not have been permitted at trial to advance its particular interpretation of the Windstorm Endorsement’s function in relation to the Flood Exclusion.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in denying Madelaine Chocolate’s motion for judgment as a matter of law under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 50 on the ground that there was insufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to find that the parties intended the Great Northern policy not to cover losses caused by storm surge arising from Superstorm Sandy.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Rule 50(a)(1), judgment as a matter of law is appropriate when, after a party has been fully heard on an issue during a jury trial, a reasonable jury would not have a legally sufficient evidentiary basis to find for that party on the issue. On review of a Rule 50 denial, the court must draw all reasonable inferences in favor of the nonmoving party and may not make credibility determinations or weigh the evidence. In the insurance-coverage context under New York law, when policy language is found to be ambiguous and extrinsic evidence is considered, the insurer bears the burden at trial to prove that its interpretation of an exclusion is correct in order to avoid the application of contra proferentem, which would otherwise require that ambiguities be resolved in favor of the insured.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court improperly allowed the jury to consider evidence of Great Northern’s uncommunicated subjective intent regarding the meaning and scope of coverage under the policy when determining the parties’ understanding of the policy’s application to storm-surge losses.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under New York contract law, a court determining whether a contract is ambiguous looks only to the contract’s language and relevant objective indicia; uncommunicated subjective intent plays no role in that threshold determination. Once a contract is deemed ambiguous and the matter proceeds to trial, the meaning of the ambiguous terms becomes a question of fact, and extrinsic evidence of the parties’ intent, including evidence that may reflect subjective understanding so long as it bears on negotiations or objective conduct, can be admissible for the jury’s consideration.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion in denying Madelaine Chocolate’s motion for a new trial under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 59, including whether the alleged evidentiary errors concerning Great Northern’s subjective intent and the interpretation of the Windstorm Endorsement resulted in a seriously erroneous verdict or a miscarriage of justice.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A motion for a new trial under Rule 59 may be granted when the district court is convinced that the jury has reached a seriously erroneous result or that the verdict is a miscarriage of justice. The decision to grant or deny a new trial is reviewed for abuse of discretion. The standard focuses on whether alleged errors, including evidentiary rulings or improper arguments, so affected the trial that the result is fundamentally unfair.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, under the law-of-the-case doctrine, Great Northern was precluded from arguing at trial that the Windstorm Endorsement only modified deductibles and waiting periods applicable to windstorm damage and did not supersede or alter the Flood Exclusion’s limitation on coverage for storm-surge losses.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The law-of-the-case doctrine provides that a legal determination made at one stage of a case generally becomes binding in later stages of the same litigation. However, the doctrine does not extend to issues that an appellate court did not address or decide. On remand, the district court and parties are bound only by the appellate court’s actual holdings and directions, not by issues left open or expressly reserved.

appellant_arguments: Madelaine Chocolate contends that under New York law, once the policy was deemed ambiguous and extrinsic evidence did not conclusively resolve that ambiguity at the summary judgment stage, Great Northern bore a particularly heavy burden at trial to show that its interpretation of the policy—namely, that storm-surge losses were excluded—was the only reasonable construction. Madelaine Chocolate argues that the trial evidence was insufficient to meet this burden, and therefore no reasonable jury could have found that the parties intended to exclude coverage for storm-surge losses, entitling Madelaine Chocolate to judgment as a matter of law.

Madelaine Chocolate argues that the district court improperly allowed the jury to consider evidence of Great Northern’s uncommunicated subjective intent concerning the meaning of the policy and the scope of coverage. It asserts that such evidence is not legally cognizable under New York contract principles, which focus on objective manifestations of intent, and that its admission improperly influenced the jury’s verdict.

Madelaine Chocolate maintains that the policy’s Windstorm Endorsement, with its own ACC clause, conflicts with or at least creates a significant ambiguity when read alongside the Flood Exclusion’s ACC clause. According to Madelaine Chocolate, the endorsement effectively defines a covered peril and extends coverage to losses caused by windstorm (including wind-driven rain) regardless of other contributing causes, which should have broadened coverage or, at minimum, created an ambiguity that must be resolved in its favor.

With respect to its Rule 59 motion, Madelaine Chocolate argues that the admission of evidence relating to Great Northern’s subjective intent and the manner in which the district court framed the parties’ competing interpretations of the Windstorm Endorsement caused the jury to reach a seriously erroneous result or produced a miscarriage of justice, thus warranting a new trial.

Madelaine Chocolate further contends that under the law-of-the-case doctrine, Great Northern should not have been permitted at trial to argue that the Windstorm Endorsement merely modified deductibles and waiting periods for windstorm losses and did not affect the Flood Exclusion’s operation. Madelaine Chocolate interprets the prior Second Circuit remand as having effectively rejected or limited that interpretation, arguing that allowing Great Northern to present it to the jury contravened the appellate court’s earlier mandate.
appellee_arguments: Great Northern argues that under New York law, once the district court found the policy ambiguous and considered extrinsic evidence, the case appropriately went to the jury, and its burden at trial was to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the parties intended to exclude coverage for storm-surge losses. Great Northern maintains that the evidence presented—including the insured’s decision years earlier to discontinue excess-flood coverage, the insured’s disclosure to a third party listing only National Flood Insurance Program coverage when asked about flood insurance, and the loss-control report distinguishing between windstorm and flood hazards—was sufficient for a reasonable jury to conclude that the parties did not intend the policy to cover storm-surge losses.

Great Northern contends that evidence of its internal or uncommunicated understandings was properly admitted in the context of resolving an ambiguous contract term at trial, because such evidence, while not controlling, can shed light on the history of negotiations and on the parties’ objective conduct. It asserts that New York law permits the use of such extrinsic evidence once ambiguity is found, and that the jury was properly instructed to decide whether the parties understood and intended that the policy would not cover storm-surge losses.

Regarding the Windstorm Endorsement, Great Northern argues that the endorsement’s function is to address deductibles and waiting periods for windstorm-related losses and that it does not alter or supersede the Flood Exclusion. At trial, Great Northern presented this interpretation to the jury, along with evidence that industry practice and the parties’ conduct were consistent with a separation between windstorm coverage and flood or storm-surge exclusions.

On the Rule 59 issue, Great Northern maintains that the evidence and instructions given to the jury were proper and that there was no basis for the district court to conclude that the jury’s verdict was seriously erroneous or a miscarriage of justice. It argues that even if there were any arguable evidentiary errors, they were harmless and did not affect the outcome of the trial.

As to the law-of-the-case doctrine, Great Northern argues that the prior Second Circuit remand order did not decide how the Windstorm Endorsement should ultimately be interpreted, nor did it determine whether the policy was ambiguous as a matter of law or what the parties intended regarding coverage for storm-surge losses. Instead, the appellate court simply directed the district court to consider the potential interaction between the Windstorm Endorsement’s ACC clause and the Flood Exclusion. Great Northern therefore contends it was free on remand and at trial to argue that the endorsement only affected deductibles and waiting periods and did not modify the scope of coverage defined by the Flood Exclusion.

issue_1.reasoning: Reviewing the Rule 50 denial, the appellate court must view the trial record in the light most favorable to Great Northern and ask only whether a reasonable jury could find for the insurer. The record contained several pieces of objective extrinsic evidence supporting Great Northern’s interpretation: (1) Madelaine’s prior purchase and later discontinuance of excess-flood coverage, indicating an understanding that flood-type losses required separate insurance; (2) Madelaine’s disclosure to a third party that it had only NFIP flood insurance, with no mention of flood coverage under the Great Northern policy; and (3) a Great Northern loss-control report that treated windstorm and flood as distinct hazards, consistent with a separation between windstorm coverage and flood exclusions. Under New York law, once ambiguity is found and extrinsic evidence is admitted, the insurer’s burden at trial is to persuade by a preponderance of the evidence, not to show that its reading is the only conceivable one. Given the objective evidence from both sides, a reasonable jury could conclude the parties did not intend coverage for storm-surge (flood-type) losses. That is sufficient to defeat judgment as a matter of law, so the district court’s denial of the Rule 50 motion is affirmed.

issue_2.reasoning: Evidentiary rulings are reviewed deferentially. New York law bars uncommunicated subjective intent from the threshold ambiguity determination, but once the court has already found ambiguity and sent the meaning to the jury, it may admit a broad range of extrinsic evidence bearing on intent, so long as it relates to negotiations or objective conduct and is not used to contradict clear policy language. The summary indicates the court first determined ambiguity as a matter of law by examining the policy and then, at trial, admitted evidence including Great Northern’s internal materials in the context of industry practice, underwriting, and loss-control communications. That sort of evidence can permissibly illustrate how the parties treated windstorm versus flood in practice and thus bears on their mutual understanding. There is no indication the district court allowed the jury to decide ambiguity itself or to rely solely on undisclosed subjective beliefs detached from negotiations or conduct. Under these circumstances, the appellate court is unlikely to find an abuse of discretion in allowing the jury to consider this evidence.

issue_3.reasoning: A new trial under Rule 59 is warranted only if the verdict is seriously erroneous or a miscarriage of justice. The jury had a developed evidentiary record from both sides concerning the parties’ intent and the function of the Windstorm Endorsement and the Flood Exclusion. The central alleged errors—admission of evidence of Great Northern’s subjective intent and the way the competing interpretations of the endorsement were presented—track the arguments rejected under Issue 2 and concern matters within the district court’s evidentiary and case-management discretion. The jury’s decision in favor of Great Northern is supported by objectively probative evidence (prior flood coverage decisions, third-party disclosures, and risk reports). Even if some evidentiary decisions were arguable, there is no showing that they rendered the trial fundamentally unfair or that the verdict was unsupported by the record. The district court therefore did not abuse its discretion in denying the Rule 59 motion.

issue_4.reasoning: Application of the law-of-the-case doctrine and interpretation of the appellate mandate are reviewed de novo. The earlier Second Circuit decision vacated summary judgment and remanded expressly so the district court could consider the effect of the Windstorm Endorsement’s ACC clause and its interaction with the Flood Exclusion; it did not hold that the endorsement superseded the exclusion or that Great Northern’s reading was foreclosed. Nor did it resolve the ultimate interpretation of the policy or the parties’ intent. On remand, the district court found ambiguity, admitted extrinsic evidence, and allowed both interpretations to go to the jury, including Great Northern’s argument that the endorsement only adjusted deductibles/waiting periods and did not expand coverage for flood-type losses. Because the prior appellate decision did not decide that interpretive question, the law-of-the-case doctrine did not bar Great Northern from advancing its position at trial, and the district court properly permitted it to do so.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The case posture—a jury verdict for the insurer following a prior remand focused narrowly on interaction between an endorsement and an exclusion—strongly favors affirmance. The district court, complying with the remand, found ambiguity, denied summary judgment to both parties, and submitted the matter to a jury with extrinsic evidence from both sides. On appeal, Madelaine’s principal attacks either recharacterize the insurer’s trial burden as effectively requiring it to prove its interpretation was the only plausible one, or seek to re-litigate evidentiary and interpretive issues that lie within the district court’s discretion and that the earlier appellate mandate did not resolve. The record described contains several pieces of concrete, objective evidence from which a reasonable jury could find that the parties did not intend coverage for storm-surge (flood-type) losses, defeating the Rule 50 challenge. The evidentiary rulings and denial of a new trial are reviewed for abuse of discretion and are supported by the broad latitude courts have in admitting extrinsic evidence once ambiguity is established and in assessing whether any errors affected the fairness of the trial. Finally, the prior remand left the ultimate interpretation of the Windstorm Endorsement and its interplay with the Flood Exclusion open, so the law-of-the-case doctrine does not bar Great Northern’s trial arguments. Collectively, these considerations make it likely that the appellate court affirms on all issues.

parties.appellant: StandWithUs Center for Legal Justice (a legal arm of a California-based membership organization dedicated to combatting antisemitism), and MIT students Katerina Boukin and Marilyn Meyers, all as plaintiffs in the district court
parties.appellee: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), defendant in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background:
The case arises out of events at MIT during the 2023–2024 academic year following the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack on Israel and ensuing war in Gaza. Plaintiffs allege that anti-Israel and pro-Palestinian activism and protests at MIT created an antisemitic and anti-Israeli hostile environment for Jewish and Israeli students and that MIT failed to respond adequately.

On October 7, 2023, Hamas attacked Israel, killing hundreds of civilians and taking hostages. That same day, the MIT Coalition Against Apartheid (CAA), then a recognized student group, reposted tweets asserting, among other things, that Palestinians could not "invade" Palestine, framing events as a response to Israeli military activity and blockade, and criticizing references to Palestinians entering "Israeli territory."

On October 8, 2023, CAA and another student group, Palestine@MIT, emailed all undergraduates a "Joint Statement on the Current Situation in Palestine." The statement blamed "the Israeli regime" for the violence, denounced the "Israeli occupation" and "racist apartheid system," affirmed "the right of all occupied people to resist oppression and colonization," and was signed "[u]ntil liberation." An Instagram post indicated support from the MIT Black Graduate Student Association and MIT Reading for Revolution.

On October 10, 2023, pro‑Palestinian students chalked "Free Palestine" and "Occupation on Gaza" outside a vigil organized by Jewish students. On or about October 17, 2023, a CAA student emailed all student‑group members claiming Israel had bombed the al‑Ahli Arab Hospital and killed over 500 people; plaintiffs allege this account was later discredited. Jewish students who attempted to share contrary information online were criticized by peers; one unidentified student felt unable to continue in a study group due to that criticism.

On October 19, 2023, CAA led a rally outside the MIT Student Center. Chants included "Palestine will be free, from the river to the sea!" and "There is only one solution! Intifada revolution!" Plaintiff Meyers and another Jewish student were approached by an attendee who raised the front wheels of his bicycle at them and stated, referring to Holocaust victims, "Your ancestors didn't die to kill more people." Plaintiffs allege this rally caused Jewish and Israeli students, including plaintiffs, to feel unsafe or unwelcome. MIT was aware of the rally through reports and security monitoring.

Four days later, CAA staged a walkout in which protestors left class, disrupted some classes by shouting and unfurling Palestinian flags, and gathered in Lobby 7, a heavily trafficked passageway frequently used by plaintiffs Boukin and Meyers. Lobby 7 was not a designated protest area. The following week, CAA organized a "Die In" in Lobby 7 and posted pictures of Gazans on lecture halls and buildings. MIT did not stop the "Die In."

On November 2, 2023, CAA held a protest outside the offices of Jewish professors and MIT’s Israel internship program, MISTI. Protestors rattled office door handles, chanted "From the river to the sea" and "MISTI, MISTI, you can't hide," and accused MISTI of "genocide." Staff reported feeling alarmed and intimidated. Plaintiffs do not allege that Jewish or Israeli students were present during this event.

Plaintiffs allege MIT did not send police or discipline student participants at any of these four early protests. Six days after the November 2 protest, MIT issued a communication tightening rules on campus protests, postering, and free expression, including rules against disrupting living, working, and learning spaces and restricting large banners and flags.

On November 9, 2023, CAA, Coalition for Palestine, and others led another protest in Lobby 7 involving MIT faculty, staff, and members of the public. Chants included "From the river to the sea," "Resistance is justified," and calls for "intifada." A Jewish student recording the protest was shoved by an unidentified protester. MIT Hillel advised Jewish students not to engage directly with protestors for safety reasons and suggested avoiding Lobby 7.

At noon, about four hours after that protest began, MIT officials warned protestors they could be disciplined if they did not leave Lobby 7 within 15 minutes. A group of Jewish counter‑protestors left, but the pro‑Palestinian protestors stayed. President Sally Kornbluth later wrote to the MIT community that the protest was disruptive, violated MIT policies, and raised concerns about potential violence. She announced that students who remained past the deadline would be suspended from non‑academic campus activities on an interim basis and referred to an Ad Hoc Complaint Response Team for final adjudication. MIT did not publicly state whether further discipline was imposed. The head of the Department of Urban Studies and Planning emailed students promising support for students involved in the protest.

Before February 26, 2024, CAA held a protest outside MIT's Institute Discrimination and Harassment Response (IDHR) office, after which IDHR issued no‑contact orders between CAA members and IDHR staff. In mid‑February 2024, CAA held another protest in Lobby 7, with large flags and chants of "From the River to the Sea, Palestine will be free!" The next day, MIT suspended CAA’s status as a recognized student group.

Plaintiffs allege wider campus turmoil. On November 14, 2023, MIT announced a "Standing Together Against Hate" initiative to combat antisemitism, but some Jewish and Israeli faculty later resigned from the committee, believing it was insufficiently addressing antisemitism. In the November/December 2023 Faculty Newsletter, Professor Michel DeGraff published an opinion piece supporting pro‑Palestinian protestors, describing Israeli actions as "war crimes" and "genocide" against Palestinians, and suggesting racism might underlie MIT’s focus on antisemitism rather than islamophobia, ending with "from the river to the sea, from Gaza to MIT."

In December 2023, the MIT Women’s and Gender Studies Department and MIT Coalition for Palestine co‑hosted an event inviting students to a book club on a work by Palestinian activist Ahed Tamimi, who had allegedly posted a statement online threatening settlers and referencing Hitler. On December 6, 2023, Israeli‑American author Miko Peled, in a talk organized by CAA and MIT Coalition for Palestine, allegedly encouraged attendees to go to MIT Hillel to confront Jewish students about Gaza and joked about not being permitted to say "From the river to the sea," prompting that chant from students.

On December 13, 2023, lecturer Mauricio Karchmer publicly resigned from MIT, stating he could no longer teach those who condemned his Jewish identity or support for Israel’s right to exist in peace. In January 2024, a non‑Jewish student emailed MIT complaining about comments by an Interfaith Chaplain and Spiritual Advisor to the Indigenous Community at an interfaith event, where the chaplain allegedly said Palestinians were oppressed by "white European colonizers." Shortly thereafter, MIT Israel Alliance, of which at least one plaintiff was a member, emailed MIT administration complaining that MIT was failing to deter discriminatory and harassing behavior toward Jewish and Israeli students and stating that some Jewish students had relocated or chosen to stay in Israel as a result.

On March 7, 2024, plaintiffs filed their initial federal complaint. That same month, pro‑Palestinian student activists allegedly began a campaign emailing faculty whose research related to Israel, accusing them of being complicit in Israel’s "crimes against humanity" and urging them to stop Israel‑related projects and reject future contracts with the Israeli military and similar entities. Activists also contacted students of these faculty, asking them to "reflect" on their professors’ receipt of Israeli funding. CAA and Graduates for Palestine posted on Instagram, publicly naming faculty whose research was funded by Israel and stating their information came from an internal MIT grant management tool that plaintiffs say is normally restricted to faculty and staff.

Plaintiffs allege that throughout spring 2024 MIT permitted "antisemitic posters" to remain on campus, including a poster depicting two cuffed fists with the statement "No to Zionism and Racism" that purportedly hung for about a month.

On April 21, 2024, pro‑Palestinian protestors established an encampment on Kresge Lawn, a central campus area adjacent to MIT Hillel. Approximately 30 students and 15 tents participated initially. Signs at the encampment included statements characterizing Zionism as apartheid, genocide, murder, and a racist ideology, calling it a "death cult," and equating police, the Ku Klux Klan, and the Israeli Defense Forces ("IOF"). CAA used social media to call for support of the encampment, declared solidarity with Palestinians, criticized MIT’s "complicity" in the conflict, and urged support for a referendum calling for a permanent ceasefire and severing MIT’s ties with the Israeli military. CAA also asserted they would "continue to be loud" and not be deterred.

Plaintiffs allege that Jewish students, disturbed by the encampment and protests, moved a Passover seder from Hillel to an off‑campus location and sought permission to attend classes remotely. A graduate student emailed MIT’s President and other administrators complaining that the encampment created a hostile environment making it difficult for Jewish and Israeli students to work or study and requesting assurances that MIT would not "both sides" the encampment. Chancellor Melissa Nobles responded that MIT understood the concerns and was pursuing constructive dialogue with protestors, asking for patience and urging the student and peers not to counter‑protest.

The encampment remained from April 21 to May 10, 2024. About a week in, President Kornbluth released a public video and statement acknowledging that the encampment violated campus rules for demonstrations while stating it had so far been peaceful. She indicated participating students would face disciplinary action, described an agreement with protestors to limit noise after 7:30 p.m., and directed campus police to monitor the encampment around the clock. She indicated she believed the protestors’ chants were protected speech under MIT’s free expression principles, but that the encampment needed to end soon. She rejected calls to curtail the academic freedom of faculty engaged in Israel‑related research or funded by Israeli sources.

When the encampment continued, MIT installed high fencing around it on May 3, 2024, to contain it. On May 4, journalists recorded protestors chanting slogans in Arabic which, according to plaintiffs, could be translated as "From water to water, Palestine is Arab!"; "Palestine is free, Israel out"; "We want to talk about the obvious, we don't want to see Zionists"; "The iron gates of Al Aqsa, open for the martyr!"; and "From water to water, death to Zionism!" Plaintiffs do not allege MIT was informed of the translations or understood their meaning.

On May 6, 2024, the encampment still active, MIT informed protestors that if they did not leave by 2:30 p.m., they would face discipline. Protest organizers responded via social media by calling more people to join. An individual jumped the fence, prompting a broader surge in which more protestors entered the encampment area, and by that evening about 150 protestors were present.

On May 7, 2024, MIT Hillel had planned an Israel‑related celebration on Kresge Lawn but relocated because of the encampment. On May 8, protestors escalated activities by blocking the entrance and exit of the Stata Center garage and defacing or discarding Israeli and American flags. The next day, they again blocked access to the garage and shut down nearby Vassar Street, preventing MIT community members from entering and exiting; nine students were arrested.

On May 10, 2024, MIT cleared the encampment; ten students who remained were arrested. MIT issued a public statement asserting that freedom of expression did not protect continued use of a shared campus resource in violation of longstanding rules and provided a timeline of events to explain its decision.

Separately, plaintiffs allege a series of specific antisemitic incidents or statements during this period, including: protestors allegedly blocking plaintiff Boukin from entering Lobby 7 on one occasion because she was Jewish while allowing others to pass; denying her entry to the encampment area on one occasion on that basis; CAA members allegedly heckling a visibly Jewish individual; a graduate student tweet allegedly comparing Jews to Nazis; and advice by an invited speaker to confront Jewish students at Hillel. Plaintiffs also reference an incident in which a man allegedly urinated on Hillel after an MIT protest, although they acknowledge the attached report described him as someone with paranoid beliefs and not affiliated with MIT.

procedural_history.claims_brought: On March 7, 2024, plaintiffs filed an initial complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts alleging that MIT engaged in antisemitic and anti‑Israeli discrimination in violation of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. On May 17, 2024, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint adding claims under the Ku Klux Klan Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1986 (predicated on an alleged conspiracy under 42 U.S.C. § 1985(3)), as well as state‑law claims under Massachusetts common law for breach of contract (based on alleged failure to uphold university policies protecting Jewish and Israeli students) and negligence (for allegedly failing to protect students from antisemitic harassment).
procedural_history.district_court_decision: MIT moved to dismiss the amended complaint under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) for failure to state a claim. The district court held that plaintiffs had not plausibly alleged a Title VI hostile environment/harassment claim against MIT because they failed to allege severe, pervasive, and objectively offensive harassment based on race or national origin to which MIT was deliberately indifferent. The court further concluded that plaintiffs had not stated a viable claim under 42 U.S.C. §§ 1985(3) and 1986 because they did not adequately allege a conspiracy with the requisite discriminatory purpose or sufficient overt acts of racially motivated violence or rights deprivation, and that their Massachusetts common‑law claims should not be heard once the federal claims were dismissed.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appeal the district court’s Rule 12(b)(6) dismissal of their amended complaint.
