SRFR identified several types of costs and risks it associated with keeping unvaccinated firefighters in their roles: (1) health and safety risks to firefighters and to the public they serve, including high‑risk populations such as the Monroe Correctional Complex inmates and hospital patients; (2) operational burdens from the large number of exemption requests—close to one quarter of the firefighting workforce— and the risk that outbreaks or extensive sick leave could severely limit SRFR’s ability to provide emergency services; (3) financial risks from increased absenteeism and related staffing issues; (4) the potential loss of a contract with the Washington Department of Corrections (DOC), which generated almost $400,000 in annual revenue and which required proof of vaccination for on‑site contractor personnel, with DOC indicating it had not identified reasonable on‑site accommodations for unvaccinated contractors; and (5) potential uninsured liability exposure, because SRFR’s insurance policy included a communicable disease exclusion and the insurer advised that it would not defend or indemnify SRFR if sued over an allegation that an unvaccinated employee transmitted COVID‑19.

Plaintiffs, for their part, contended that they could have been safely accommodated through masking, testing, social distancing, shift assignments, separate sleeping arrangements and restrooms for unvaccinated personnel, and other measures, and they pointed to periods before and after the October 2021 to May 2022 mandate window—when SRFR operated without a vaccination requirement—as evidence that alternatives were workable. They also noted that other fire departments in the region allowed unvaccinated firefighters to continue working and that at least one plaintiff was hired by a neighboring department while on leave from SRFR and worked alongside SRFR firefighters under a mutual‑aid agreement.

procedural_history.claims_brought: In November 2022, the eight firefighter plaintiffs filed suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington against SRFR, Fire Chief Kevin O’Brien, and unnamed defendants. They asserted two causes of action: (1) failure to accommodate their religious beliefs, in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et seq.); and (2) violation of the Washington Law Against Discrimination (WLAD) based on an alleged failure to provide reasonable religious accommodations. Plaintiffs sought, among other relief, a declaration that, under the circumstances, a leave of absence does not constitute a lawful reasonable accommodation under Title VII or WLAD, as well as damages and other appropriate relief. The parties later stipulated to the dismissal of Chief O’Brien as a defendant.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: SRFR moved for summary judgment, arguing that plaintiffs’ Title VII and WLAD claims failed because accommodating their requests for exemption from the COVID‑19 vaccination requirement would have imposed an undue hardship on SRFR’s business. Plaintiffs moved for partial summary judgment, contending that SRFR had failed to reasonably accommodate their religious objections to vaccination. The district court assumed, without scrutinizing the specifics of plaintiffs’ religious beliefs, that plaintiffs had bona fide religious objections and that they had established a prima facie case of religious discrimination under Title VII. The court then analyzed whether SRFR could have reasonably accommodated plaintiffs’ religious objections without undue hardship. It found, based on the undisputed evidence including expert medical testimony, that allowing unvaccinated firefighters to work in patient‑care roles would significantly increase the risk of COVID‑19 transmission even with masks and PPE, because such measures are effective only when used and could not always be used by firefighters. The court determined that unvaccinated firefighters were at higher risk of contracting and transmitting COVID‑19 despite masking, PPE, testing, and social distancing, and that the fact that 46 out of 192 firefighters requested religious exemptions increased the hardship and risks associated with maintaining them in frontline roles while living and working in shared fire stations. The court evaluated the WLAD claim under the same, more demanding federal undue hardship standard. Concluding that the record showed undue hardship in accommodating the requested vaccine exemptions, the district court granted summary judgment for SRFR and denied plaintiffs’ motion. It entered final judgment in favor of SRFR.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appealed the final judgment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. On appeal, they challenge the district court’s grant of summary judgment to SRFR and denial of their own motion for partial summary judgment on their Title VII and WLAD religious accommodation claims, including the district court’s conclusion that SRFR could not reasonably accommodate their requests for exemption from the COVID‑19 vaccination requirement without undue hardship.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in concluding, at the summary judgment stage, that SRFR met its burden under Title VII and WLAD to show that it could not reasonably accommodate plaintiffs’ religious objections to COVID‑19 vaccination without incurring an undue hardship on the conduct of its business, thereby justifying SRFR’s decision to remove unvaccinated firefighters from frontline roles and offer leave‑based options instead.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Title VII, to establish a failure‑to‑accommodate religious discrimination claim, a plaintiff must first make a prima facie showing that: (1) he has a bona fide religious belief, the practice of which conflicts with an employment duty; (2) he informed his employer of the belief and conflict; and (3) he was discharged, threatened, or otherwise subjected to an adverse employment action because of his inability to comply with the conflicting job requirement. Once the plaintiff makes this showing, the burden shifts to the employer to prove either that it initiated good‑faith efforts to reasonably accommodate the employee’s religious practice or that it could not reasonably accommodate that practice without undue hardship on the conduct of the employer’s business. Under Groff v. DeJoy, ‘undue hardship’ under Title VII is established when, considering all relevant factors—including the nature, size, and operating costs of the employer’s business and the specific accommodation at issue—granting the accommodation would result in a burden that is substantial in the overall context of the employer’s business, involving substantial increased costs or a burden rising to an excessive or unjustifiable level. WLAD’s religious accommodation standard is interpreted in harmony with federal law and, at the time relevant here, Washington courts looked to federal Title VII precedent and have since adopted the substantial cost test.

appellant_arguments: Plaintiffs contend that SRFR failed to provide them with reasonable accommodations for their sincerely held religious objections to the COVID‑19 vaccine, and instead offered only unpaid or leave‑based options, which they argue are not lawful reasonable accommodations under Title VII or WLAD in the circumstances of this case.

They argue that SRFR overstated the health and safety risks posed by allowing unvaccinated firefighters to continue working while using alternative mitigation measures such as masking, periodic COVID testing, social distancing, modified station living arrangements (e.g., grouping unvaccinated firefighters together on shifts, providing separate bedrooms and restrooms), and other protocols. They assert that they were able to safely perform their duties and that they did not transmit COVID‑19 to co‑workers or members of the public.

Plaintiffs challenge the district court’s reliance on SRFR’s expert medical declaration and contend that the record included anecdotal and practical evidence showing that masking, PPE, and other measures were successfully used before and after the seven‑month period in which SRFR enforced its vaccine mandate. They emphasize that SRFR had operated during earlier stages of the pandemic without a mandatory vaccination policy and later allowed unvaccinated firefighters to return to patient‑care roles in May 2022.

They maintain that many of SRFR’s asserted hardships—such as potential increased absenteeism, the risk of losing the Monroe Correctional Complex contract, and possible uninsured liability—were speculative or hypothetical rather than supported by concrete evidence of actual or imminent burdens, and therefore did not satisfy the heightened post‑Groff standard for undue hardship.

Plaintiffs assert that SRFR failed to adequately explore individualized accommodations or less restrictive alternatives on a case‑by‑case basis, relying instead on a blanket policy that unvaccinated firefighters could not remain in frontline roles, despite other fire departments in the region allowing unvaccinated personnel to continue working under similar or greater risks.

They argue that the district court improperly resolved disputed factual issues about the reasonableness and effectiveness of proposed accommodations and the severity of the burdens on SRFR at the summary judgment stage, instead of allowing a jury to assess those fact‑intensive questions under the new Groff undue hardship standard.
appellee_arguments: SRFR argues that even assuming plaintiffs had bona fide religious objections and established a prima facie case, SRFR met its burden to show that it could not reasonably accommodate their requests to remain unvaccinated in frontline firefighting and EMS roles without incurring undue hardship on its operations and business under Title VII and WLAD.

SRFR emphasizes the nature of its mission as a critical emergency services provider that responds to thousands of medical calls annually and serves vulnerable populations, including incarcerated individuals and hospital patients, in close physical proximity, often in confined indoor spaces and shared fire station living quarters. It contends that these working conditions made the risks of COVID‑19 transmission particularly acute and made continuous masking and social distancing infeasible.

Relying on unrebutted expert testimony from Dr. Lynch, SRFR asserts that vaccination was the single most effective measure to reduce COVID‑19 transmission and severe outcomes, and that testing, masking, and social distancing were insufficient substitutes for vaccination in the fire station and EMS context, especially given that masks cannot be worn at all times and that tests have limitations. SRFR notes that plaintiffs provided no medical expert evidence to challenge this conclusion.

SRFR points out that a significant portion of its workforce—46 out of 192 firefighters—initially requested religious exemptions, and that granting accommodation to that many unvaccinated frontline employees would substantially increase the risk of outbreaks, workforce shortages, and impaired emergency response capacity, imposing an operational burden that meets the substantial‑cost threshold required for undue hardship.

It further argues that it faced concrete financial risks, including likely increased absenteeism and overtime or backfilling costs, the potential loss of a lucrative Department of Corrections contract requiring on‑site contractor vaccination (which generated nearly $400,000 annually), and a realistic risk of uninsured liability due to its insurance policy’s communicable disease exclusion and the insurer’s warning that COVID‑19 transmission claims involving unvaccinated personnel would not be covered.

SRFR maintains that it engaged in good‑faith efforts to accommodate employees by negotiating and implementing the MOU, which allowed unvaccinated firefighters to remain employed while using accrued leave, provided unpaid leave options, protected their rehire rights, and provided for their return if governmental requirements changed. It argues that under Title VII and WLAD, employers are not required to provide an employee’s preferred accommodation, only a reasonable one that avoids undue hardship, and that leave‑based accommodations can qualify as reasonable under the circumstances.

SRFR contends that the district court properly applied the Groff undue hardship standard, considered all relevant factors (including health, safety, operational, and financial burdens), and correctly determined that no reasonable jury could conclude that accommodating plaintiffs in their requested frontline roles would not impose undue hardship, making summary judgment appropriate.

issue_1.reasoning:
The appeal challenges a grant of summary judgment on Title VII and WLAD religious-accommodation claims, so the Ninth Circuit reviews de novo, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the firefighters. Even under Groff’s heightened standard, SRFR presented substantial, largely undisputed evidence that keeping a sizable number of unvaccinated firefighters (46 of 192) in close-quarters, patient-facing roles during the Delta/Omicron period would impose a substantial burden in the overall context of its business.

SRFR relied on detailed, unrebutted medical expert testimony from Dr. Lynch that vaccination was significantly more effective than masking/testing/distancing in this particular environment, and that those measures were not viable substitutes because they could not be used continuously and tests had accuracy and timing gaps. The record also showed actual practice: firefighters did not and could not mask or distance consistently in stations, on calls, or while sleeping and eating. Plaintiffs offered only lay declarations and anecdotal assertions, not countervailing expert evidence, to dispute the medical risks or comparative effectiveness of their preferred measures.

Beyond health and safety, SRFR documented operational and financial impacts well within Groff’s concept of ‘substantial in the overall context’: (1) risk of serious spread within a critical emergency-services workforce if nearly a quarter remained unvaccinated; (2) risk of impaired response capacity from outbreaks and related absenteeism; (3) concrete contractual risk with the DOC, which affirmatively required vaccination of on‑site contractor personnel and could not identify workable alternatives; and (4) realistic uninsured liability exposure given the communicable-disease exclusion and the insurer’s express warning. These were not wholly speculative; they were tied to existing contracts, insurance terms, and the then‑current public‑health environment.

The firefighters’ showing that SRFR previously and later operated without a mandate, and that some neighboring agencies used different approaches, raises at most policy disagreements, not a triable question on whether SRFR’s own assessment of its risks and burdens was unreasonable or pretextual. Groff does not require an employer to adopt the least restrictive regime in the market or to wait for an actual outbreak or lawsuit before relying on substantial, evidence‑based risk assessments.

On the accommodation side, SRFR made individualized inquiries, bargained for a tailored MOU, and provided a structured regime of paid leave, unpaid leave, rehire protections, and a pathway back when conditions changed. Title VII does not guarantee an employee’s preferred accommodation, and leave can be a reasonable accommodation, particularly where the only alternative proposed by the employees (remaining unvaccinated in frontline roles) has been shown to create undue hardship. The record does not show specific, feasible, frontline assignments or station arrangements that would both maintain emergency coverage and materially mitigate the risks identified by SRFR’s unrefuted expert evidence.

Given this evidentiary posture, no genuine dispute of material fact appears on the dispositive questions: (a) whether keeping unvaccinated firefighters in frontline EMS/fire roles during the relevant period would create substantial health, operational, and financial burdens in the overall context of SRFR’s business, and (b) whether SRFR offered at least one reasonable accommodation. The district court did not weigh credibility or resolve conflicting expert evidence; rather, plaintiffs simply failed to produce competent evidence that would allow a reasonable jury to reject SRFR’s undue‑hardship showing under Groff. Accordingly, de novo review should result in affirmance on both the Title VII and WLAD claims.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The dispositive issue is whether SRFR met its burden, under the post‑Groff ‘substantial burden in the overall context of the business’ standard, to show undue hardship from accommodating plaintiffs’ request to remain unvaccinated frontline firefighters, and whether the leave‑based scheme was a lawful reasonable accommodation. The record contains robust, specific evidence from SRFR—especially unrebutted medical expert testimony about disease transmission in this particular work setting, coupled with concrete operational, contractual, and insurance-related burdens—that comfortably satisfies Groff’s more demanding test. Plaintiffs’ contrary showing consists largely of anecdotal experience, comparisons to other agencies, and argument that SRFR’s concerns were speculative, without medical or economic expert support. That evidentiary gap makes it unlikely a reasonable jury could find that accommodating their requested exemption in frontline roles would not impose substantial burdens.

Further, SRFR’s negotiated MOU and individualized meetings demonstrate good‑faith efforts, and Title VII/WLAD do not require employers to maintain employees in their preferred roles when those roles themselves create undue hardship; leave can constitute a reasonable accommodation in such circumstances. Because these conclusions are grounded in undisputed or one‑sided evidence rather than credibility determinations, the de novo summary‑judgment review strongly favors affirmance on all claims, leading to an overall affirmance of the district court’s judgment.

parties.appellant: Capitol Records, LLC; Caroline Records, Inc.; Virgin Records America, Inc.; EMI Blackwood Music Inc.; EMI April Music Inc.; EMI Virgin Music, Inc.; Colgems‑EMI Music, Inc.; EMI Virgin Songs, Inc.; EMI Gold Horizon Music Corp.; EMI Unart Catalog Inc.; Stone Diamond Music Corporation; EMI U Catalog Inc.; Jobete Music Co., Inc. (all current or former EMI affiliates; original role: plaintiffs/rightsholders of musical sound recordings and musical compositions)
parties.appellee: Vimeo, Inc. (aka Vimeo.com), and Connected Ventures, LLC (original role: defendants/operators of the Vimeo online video‑sharing platform)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
The plaintiffs are music companies and music publishers that own or control copyrights in a catalog of sound recordings and musical compositions, all affiliated with or formerly affiliated with EMI. The defendants (collectively, Vimeo) operate vimeo.com, an online video‑sharing platform founded in 2004. Vimeo is a popular website that allows registered users to upload videos. By 2007, Vimeo had about 40,000 registered users; by 2012, approximately 12.3 million users were posting roughly 43,000 new videos per day.

On Vimeo, registered users can upload videos, add tags and descriptions, and make their videos either private or publicly viewable. Private videos can be viewed only by specifically authorized accounts or those with a password; non‑private videos can be streamed by anyone with internet access and, unless disabled by the uploader, can be downloaded. Other users can comment on, “like,” subscribe to groups, and create or follow channels organized around themes.

Vimeo offers free and paid subscription tiers. Most revenue comes from subscription fees. Vimeo also sells advertising on the site; some ads are directly contracted with advertisers and are paid per view, while others are served through Google AdSense and generate revenue per click. Beginning in 2011, Vimeo, through contracts with certain rightsholders (primarily smaller labels not including any plaintiff here), operated a virtual music store from which users could purchase licenses for particular non‑major‑label music, with Vimeo earning commissions on those sales.

Vimeo imposes content and upload rules. It represents itself as a platform for user‑created content and forbids users from uploading videos that were not created at least in part by the uploader. Vimeo’s Terms of Service require users not to upload infringing content and not to post content inconsistent with specified restrictions. Certain categories of videos are disallowed, including advertising spots (commercials, infomercials, product promotions), real estate walkthroughs, abusive or sexually explicit content, and, beginning in 2008, most “gameplay” videos. Vimeo also bars uploads of movies, TV shows, and trailers. To register, users must agree to those Terms of Service, and each upload is accompanied by reminders of the self‑created‑content requirement and other restrictions.

Vimeo does not pre‑screen all videos, but it engages in some curation and moderation. Members of Vimeo’s "Community Team" sometimes post likes and comments, upload their own videos, join or create groups and channels, and promote user videos by placing them in prominent locations such as the Vimeo blog or the "Staff Picks" channel. Staff may also remove videos, and in some cases user accounts, for violations of the Terms.

Vimeo also deploys automated tools ("Mod Tools") to help identify potentially problematic content. These tools can, for example, flag videos with unusually high view counts, search for current film titles, locate videos roughly the length of a typical 30‑ or 60‑minute television show, and identify users uploading unusually large numbers of videos in a short time. Content flagged by such tools is manually reviewed by staff. Additionally, users can "flag" videos they believe violate the Terms of Service; community moderators then review the flagged material and decide whether to remove it.

Vimeo has at times encouraged certain types of user‑generated content. In 2006, Vimeo’s founder created and posted a video of himself lip‑synching to a song while walking, then synced that video with recorded music and labeled the practice "lip‑dubbing." He invited users to create similar lip‑dub videos. At a company party, Vimeo employees made a lip‑dub video that became popular. Lip‑dubbing then became a trend; Vimeo created a "Lip Dub Stars" channel. A lip balm company paid Vimeo to advertise on that channel and sponsored a lip‑dub contest.

Regarding employees’ awareness of copyright practices, some Vimeo employees themselves created and posted videos, including videos that used music owned by plaintiffs, without securing licenses. Around 2009, Vimeo’s legal staff instructed employees not to include copyrighted music in the background of videos they created. Vimeo used a scripted response for user inquiries about using copyrighted music, stating that adding third‑party copyrighted content to a video "generally (but not always) constitutes copyright infringement." Plaintiffs introduced evidence that in a few instances employees supplemented the scripted response with informal encouragements such as "off the record . . . Go ahead and post it. I don’t think you’ll have anything to worry about." Vimeo characterizes those responses as isolated, unauthorized, and contrary to company policy. In connection with the 2011 launch of its virtual music store, Vimeo published a blog post acknowledging that music licensing can be "confusing" and "painful."

The dispute here centers on user‑uploaded videos that incorporate recordings of musical performances whose rights are owned or controlled by plaintiffs (referred to as the "Videos‑in‑Suit"). For purposes of summary judgment, Vimeo conceded that the videos in question contained plaintiffs’ music and that the uses were infringing. It is undisputed that plaintiffs never licensed Vimeo or Vimeo’s users to use this music and that Vimeo never paid plaintiffs for such use. In 2008, EMI sent Vimeo a cease‑and‑desist letter demanding removal of 173 specified videos using EMI recordings and compositions and requesting that Vimeo "immediately take appropriate action to ensure that all other EMI‑owned or ‑controlled works are removed from the Site." Vimeo removed the 173 specified videos. Internal emails among Vimeo employees afterward contained disparaging references to EMI personnel. After the initial letter, EMI sent additional DMCA takedown notices, with which Vimeo complied.

The videos that remain at issue on appeal are 281 user‑uploaded videos, uploaded between 2006 and 2013, that include recordings owned or controlled by plaintiffs and with which Vimeo employees interacted in some way (for example, by commenting on them, liking them, promoting or demoting them, or placing them in a community channel). These do not include videos uploaded by Vimeo employees themselves.

procedural_history.claims_brought: On December 10, 2009, plaintiffs filed an initial complaint in the Southern District of New York against Vimeo and related entities asserting copyright infringement based on 199 specified videos that allegedly used music owned or controlled by plaintiffs without authorization. Plaintiffs sought to hold Vimeo liable for direct and/or secondary copyright infringement arising from user‑uploaded videos containing plaintiffs’ sound recordings and compositions. In May 2012, plaintiffs moved to amend their complaint to add more than 1,000 additional allegedly infringing videos.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
The district court (Judge Ronnie Abrams) denied without prejudice the 2012 motion to amend, granting leave to renew after resolution of summary judgment. On September 7, 2012, Vimeo moved for summary judgment, asserting protection under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) safe harbor in 17 U.S.C. § 512(c). On November 16, 2012, plaintiffs cross‑moved for partial summary judgment that Vimeo was not entitled to the safe harbor.

On September 18, 2013, the district court issued a summary judgment decision. It held that Vimeo did not have the "right and ability to control" the infringing material within the meaning of § 512(c)(1)(B) and therefore was not excluded from the safe harbor on that ground. It further held that as to 55 of the 199 original videos – those with which Vimeo employees had interacted – there was a triable issue of fact as to whether Vimeo had actual or "red flag" knowledge of infringement, and thus summary judgment could not be granted to Vimeo for those videos. For 144 videos containing pre‑1972 sound recordings, the court granted partial summary judgment to plaintiffs, reasoning that the DMCA safe harbor did not apply to pre‑1972 recordings. It granted summary judgment to Vimeo on the remaining videos.

On reconsideration, the district court granted summary judgment to Vimeo with respect to an additional 17 videos. It then granted plaintiffs leave to amend and add 1,476 videos to the case. The court certified three questions for interlocutory appeal to the Second Circuit: (1) whether the DMCA safe harbor applies to pre‑1972 sound recordings; (2) whether Vimeo had knowledge or awareness of infringing content (actual or red flag knowledge); and (3) whether Vimeo had a general policy of willful blindness to infringement of sound recordings.

On interlocutory appeal (Capitol Records, LLC v. Vimeo, LLC ("Vimeo I")), the Second Circuit held that the DMCA safe harbor extends to pre‑1972 recordings and vacated the district court’s grant of partial summary judgment to plaintiffs on the pre‑1972 videos. It also vacated the denial of summary judgment to Vimeo on red flag knowledge and articulated a standard for red flag knowledge, indicating that Vimeo would be entitled to summary judgment unless plaintiffs could present evidence that Vimeo personnel either knew a particular video was infringing or knew facts that would make infringement obvious to an ordinary person without specialized knowledge of music or copyright law. The court also affirmed the district court’s conclusion that Vimeo was not willfully blind to infringement.

On remand, the parties identified 307 videos remaining in dispute and renewed cross‑motions for summary judgment. Applying the standard articulated in Vimeo I, the district court granted Vimeo summary judgment on 281 videos, holding that plaintiffs had failed to show that Vimeo had red flag knowledge of infringement for those videos. It further held that there was a genuine issue of material fact regarding 26 videos that had been uploaded by Vimeo employees, concerning their eligibility for the safe harbor (including whether they were stored "at the direction of a user"). To facilitate an appealable final judgment, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the 27 claims related to those 26 employee‑uploaded videos, with the stipulation preserving plaintiffs’ ability to reinstitute those claims if the judgment were vacated or reversed in relevant part. On November 1, 2021, the district court entered final judgment dismissing all of plaintiffs’ remaining claims with prejudice.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appeal the November 1, 2021 final judgment, challenging the district court’s grant of summary judgment to Vimeo on 281 user‑uploaded videos. Specifically, they contest the district court’s determinations that (1) Vimeo remained entitled to the § 512(c) safe harbor because plaintiffs had not produced sufficient evidence of actual or red flag knowledge of infringement for the videos‑in‑suit, and (2) Vimeo lacked the "right and ability to control" infringing activity in a manner that would disqualify it from safe harbor protection under § 512(c)(1)(B), including the court’s application of the "substantial influence" standard derived from Viacom and related cases.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Vimeo is disqualified from the DMCA § 512(c) safe harbor for the 281 user‑uploaded videos because Vimeo allegedly had actual or "red flag" knowledge of infringement and failed to act expeditiously to remove or disable access to the material.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 17 U.S.C. § 512(c)(1)(A), a service provider qualifies for the safe harbor if it (i) does not have actual knowledge that the material or activity is infringing; (ii) in the absence of actual knowledge, is not aware of facts or circumstances from which infringing activity is apparent ("red flag" knowledge); or (iii) upon obtaining such knowledge or awareness, acts expeditiously to remove or disable access to the material. As interpreted by Viacom Int’l, Inc. v. YouTube, Inc., 676 F.3d 19 (2d Cir. 2012), actual knowledge is subjective knowledge of specific infringement, and red flag knowledge is subjective awareness of facts making specific infringement objectively obvious to a reasonable person. Vimeo I further clarifies that the relevant reasonable person is an ordinary person without specialized knowledge of music or copyright law, operating under similar circumstances as the service provider’s employees, and that plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the provider lost safe harbor protection by having actual or red flag knowledge without expeditiously removing the material.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Vimeo is disqualified from the DMCA § 512(c) safe harbor for the videos‑in‑suit because it allegedly received a financial benefit directly attributable to infringing activity while having the "right and ability to control" such activity within the meaning of § 512(c)(1)(B).
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 17 U.S.C. § 512(c)(1)(B), a service provider is not entitled to safe harbor if it receives a financial benefit directly attributable to the infringing activity "in a case in which the service provider has the right and ability to control such activity." In Viacom, the Second Circuit held that "right and ability to control" requires "something more" than the mere ability to remove or block access to materials; it can be shown where a provider exerts "substantial influence" over user activities or induces infringement, with Cybernet and Mavrix identified as examples of potentially qualifying conduct. The burden is on plaintiffs to prove that the provider’s control, coupled with a directly attributable financial benefit, disqualifies it from the safe harbor.

appellant_arguments: On knowledge and red flag awareness, plaintiffs argue that Vimeo had awareness of facts and circumstances from which infringing activity was apparent for the 281 videos‑in‑suit with which its employees interacted. They contend that employees watched, commented on, liked, promoted, or categorized videos that plainly contained popular, copyrighted sound recordings owned or controlled by plaintiffs, and that an ordinary person in the employees’ position would have recognized the infringing nature of the use. Plaintiffs point to Vimeo’s internal and public statements that using third‑party copyrighted music without permission "generally" constitutes infringement, and to evidence that some Vimeo employees themselves posted videos with copyrighted background music without licenses and were later instructed by Vimeo’s legal team not to do so, as demonstrating that staff had particular experience and awareness regarding music licensing and the infringing character of such uses.

Plaintiffs further argue that Vimeo’s 2008 cease‑and‑desist correspondence from EMI, listing specific infringing videos and demanding removal of all EMI‑owned or ‑controlled works, put Vimeo on specific notice that user‑uploaded videos containing EMI’s music were unauthorized. They analogize to EMI Christian Music Grp., Inc. v. MP3tunes, LLC, asserting that once Vimeo was subjectively aware that EMI had not authorized digital distribution of its catalog on Vimeo, the presence of EMI‑owned recordings in user videos rendered the infringement objectively obvious. Plaintiffs also rely on Vimeo’s 2011 blog post acknowledging that music licensing is "confusing" and "painful" as evidence that Vimeo knew many users would not have gone through the licensing process, making unlicensed use apparent.

On fair use, plaintiffs maintain that Vimeo personnel had sufficient "legal acumen" about copyright law, based on company training and scripted communications with users, to understand that commonplace uses such as lip‑synching, dancing, and other background uses of full musical tracks in user videos are not fair use in typical circumstances. They contend that when employees viewed and curated videos embodying such uses of well‑known sound recordings, infringement would have been apparent to a reasonable Vimeo employee, satisfying the red flag standard.

On the "right and ability to control" issue, plaintiffs embrace the "substantial influence" standard and argue that Vimeo’s editorial and curatorial activities over user content meet or exceed that threshold. They emphasize that Vimeo exercises editorial judgment by evaluating and promoting certain user videos (e.g., via Staff Picks, blog features, and featured channels) and demoting or removing other videos, actively shaping what content is highlighted and how users experience the platform. They characterize this editorial judgment as being directed at the same user activity that gives rise to infringement—user uploads of videos with copyrighted music—and argue that Vimeo’s influence over which videos are visible, desirable, or permitted alters user incentives and effectively controls infringing activity.

Plaintiffs also stress Vimeo’s content rules that prohibit non‑original content (e.g., movies, TV, trailers, and most gameplay videos) while encouraging other popular formats such as lip‑dub videos. They argue that these rules show Vimeo exerting a higher level of control than simple host neutrality, akin to the control found sufficient in Cybernet. They maintain that Vimeo’s use of Mod Tools to surface and review videos with certain characteristics, coupled with human moderation decisions, demonstrates ongoing, systematic oversight of user submissions, which, when combined with Vimeo’s economic interest in attracting and retaining users via attractive content, amounts to "substantial influence" over infringing activity.

Regarding financial benefit, plaintiffs allege that Vimeo profits directly from the presence and popularity of infringing videos because such content attracts users, encourages subscription upgrades, increases site traffic, and generates associated advertising revenue. They argue that where infringing videos are featured, promoted, or allowed to remain on the platform under Vimeo’s editorial control, the resulting viewership and monetization represent financial benefits directly attributable to the infringing activity within the meaning of § 512(c)(1)(B).
appellee_arguments: On knowledge and red flag awareness, Vimeo contends that plaintiffs bear the burden of showing loss of safe harbor and have not met it. Vimeo does not dispute that its employees knew that the videos contained copyrighted music, but it argues that under Vimeo I and Viacom, that is insufficient. Vimeo maintains that plaintiffs have not shown that any Vimeo employee actually knew a particular video was infringing or was aware of facts making infringement objectively obvious to an ordinary person without specialized knowledge of music or copyright law. Vimeo emphasizes that its employees are not required by the DMCA to investigate or verify if a particular use is licensed or fair use, and that knowledge of general licensing difficulties or industry practices does not make lack of authorization obvious for any specific video.

Vimeo argues that the existence of its licensed music store beginning in 2011 means that a reasonable Vimeo employee could not assume that user‑uploaded videos with music were unlicensed; users had a mechanism to purchase licenses, and some users claimed to have obtained authorization directly from rightsholders. Vimeo asserts that even if EMI’s 2008 cease‑and‑desist letter put it on notice that certain listed videos were infringing, it did not establish that all future uses of EMI music lacked authorization, particularly given the possibility of later licensing arrangements. Vimeo relies on the DMCA’s § 512(m) provision, which states that service providers have no general duty to monitor or affirmatively seek facts indicating infringing activity, and contends that plaintiffs’ theory would effectively impose such a duty.

With respect to fair use, Vimeo maintains that its employees, who do not possess specialized legal training, cannot reasonably be expected to distinguish reliably between infringing uses and potential fair uses of copyrighted music in user videos. Vimeo asserts that any general internal guidance or scripted user responses about copyright risks do not transform its staff into copyright experts capable of immediately identifying infringement, especially in legal areas where reasonable experts and courts themselves may disagree. Vimeo therefore argues that plaintiffs have not shown that employees had awareness of facts making infringement, as opposed to potential fair use or licensed use, objectively obvious for the videos‑in‑suit.

On the "right and ability to control" element, Vimeo argues that its capabilities and practices fall far short of the "substantial influence" standard identified in Viacom. Vimeo concedes that it can and does remove or block content, but it asserts that mere ability to remove content, or general content restrictions, are insufficient as a matter of law to constitute the requisite control. Vimeo distinguishes its operations from the more intrusive regimes in cases like Cybernet and Mavrix, where the service provider dictated site layout, pre‑screened every user submission, and rejected a large portion of them. Vimeo notes that it does not pre‑approve all user uploads and that its curation activities—such as liking videos, adding them to Staff Picks, or featuring them—affect only a very small fraction of the millions of videos uploaded and do not constrain what users may upload in the first instance.

Vimeo maintains that its content rules (e.g., prohibiting movies, TV shows, trailers, pornography, and most gameplay videos; requiring that content be at least partly user‑created) are standard site‑maintenance and brand‑defining measures, not exercises of control over infringement. It argues that such rules are aimed at avoiding illegality and tailoring the platform’s aesthetic and audience appeal, not directing or controlling infringing activity. Vimeo also asserts that its Mod Tools focus on characteristics such as video length or popularity, not on specific infringing content, and that monitoring for limited categories of prohibited content does not amount to the type of comprehensive, coercive guidance or pre‑screening that would constitute substantial influence over user activities.

Regarding financial benefit, Vimeo does not dispute that it earns revenue from subscriptions and advertisements connected to overall site traffic, but it argues that plaintiffs have not shown a "financial benefit directly attributable to" any specific infringing activity. Vimeo contends that its revenue is driven by the general operation of the service and user engagement across millions of videos, not by particular infringing videos, and that any benefit is too attenuated to meet the statutory requirement, especially absent the predicate showing that it had the right and ability to control the infringing activity as defined by § 512(c)(1)(B).

issue_1.reasoning:
The question is whether plaintiffs produced sufficient evidence to create a triable issue of fact on Vimeo’s actual or red-flag knowledge for the 281 user‑uploaded videos, under the red‑flag standard articulated in Viacom and refined in Vimeo I. That is a summary‑judgment question of law, reviewed de novo.

Vimeo I already held that (1) generalized awareness that infringement occurs on the service and (2) awareness that videos contain copyrighted music are not enough; plaintiffs must show Vimeo personnel knew a specific video was infringing or were aware of facts making its infringing nature obvious to an ordinary person without specialized copyright knowledge. Vimeo I also stressed that the DMCA imposes no duty to monitor or investigate and that red‑flag knowledge cannot be premised on assumptions about licensing in the industry.

Here, plaintiffs principally rely on: employee ‘likes,’ comments, or curation of the videos; the obvious presence of well‑known sound recordings; the 2008 EMI cease‑and‑desist letter; Vimeo staff’s general familiarity with licensing problems; and isolated ‘off‑the‑record’ comments by employees. None of that, as to the 281 videos, shows that any particular employee actually knew the use was unauthorized or that the facts visible on the face of the video made infringement—not merely use of copyrighted music—objectively obvious. Under Vimeo I, an ordinary Vimeo employee could not, without more, infer lack of a license or lack of fair use simply from the presence of a popular song, especially after Vimeo had introduced a mechanism for users to obtain licenses and where some users claimed to have permissions. EMI’s 2008 letter specifically identified certain videos (which Vimeo removed) but did not transform every subsequent posting of EMI music into obvious infringement as a matter of law, particularly given the possibility of later licensing deals.

The district court applied the Vimeo I standard and concluded that, for these 281 videos (which, notably, excluded employee‑uploaded videos), plaintiffs’ evidence did not rise above generalized inferences and did not identify video‑specific facts that would compel an ordinary person to recognize obvious infringement. Given the heavy guidance in Vimeo I and the DMCA’s § 512(m) no‑monitoring principle, that conclusion is well within the governing precedent. The appellate court is likely to hold that plaintiffs have failed, as a matter of law, to carry their burden to show loss of safe harbor via actual or red‑flag knowledge and therefore affirm summary judgment on this ground.

issue_2.reasoning:
Whether Vimeo has the ‘right and ability to control’ infringing activity so as to lose safe‑harbor protection under § 512(c)(1)(B), and whether the asserted financial benefits are ‘directly attributable’ to such activity, are legal issues resolved on summary judgment and reviewed de novo.

Under Viacom, ‘right and ability to control’ requires something more than the ordinary ability to remove or block access to material; the provider must exert ‘substantial influence’ over user activity, akin to directing, pre‑screening, and tightly regulating submissions as in Cybernet, or materially inducing infringement. Routine content policies, discretionary curation of a small subset of content, and use of tools to detect rule‑violating content fall short of that threshold.

Plaintiffs’ arguments focus on Vimeo’s editorial and curatorial activities (Staff Picks, featured channels, likes, comments), content rules (forbidding certain categories while fostering user‑created formats like lip‑dubs), and Mod Tools used to surface potentially problematic material. But those are, in substance, typical platform‑governance and brand‑management functions. Vimeo does not dictate the substance of user submissions, require pre‑approval of all uploads, design or operate users’ own sites, or condition participation on a detailed, coercive content program as in Cybernet. Nor is there evidence of inducement of copyright infringement comparable to Grokster; encouraging a user‑created lip‑dub genre is not the same as encouraging unlicensed use of copyrighted music.

Because plaintiffs cannot show the requisite ‘substantial influence’ over infringing activity, they cannot satisfy the control prong of § 512(c)(1)(B). That alone defeats their attempt to disqualify Vimeo from the safe harbor on this ground. In addition, their financial‑benefit theory is highly attenuated—Vimeo’s revenues derive from overall site usage rather than specific infringing videos, and plaintiffs point to no evidence tying particular infringements to discrete revenue streams. The appellate court is likely to agree that plaintiffs have not adduced evidence from which a reasonable jury could find both ‘right and ability to control’ in the Viacom sense and a ‘financial benefit directly attributable’ to the infringing activity. Accordingly, summary judgment on this issue is properly affirmed.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The case is a remand from an earlier Second Circuit decision (Vimeo I) that already set a stringent framework favoring service‑provider immunity for user‑generated content platforms absent specific evidence of actual or red‑flag knowledge or substantial control. The district court’s post‑remand judgment closely tracked that guidance: it excluded the employee‑uploaded videos (where safe‑harbor eligibility remained factually disputed), and granted summary judgment only on the remaining 281 user‑uploaded videos where plaintiffs relied on generalized inferences about licensing and employee sophistication.

Under Vimeo I, those generalized inferences about industry practices, obviousness of popular music, and internal awareness of licensing issues are insufficient to satisfy plaintiffs’ burden to show loss of safe harbor. The DMCA’s explicit no‑monitoring rule (§ 512(m)) further undercuts any argument that Vimeo was obliged to assume non‑licensing and investigate each instance of copyrighted music. As to § 512(c)(1)(B), Viacom and the cited analogues (Cybernet, Mavrix) define ‘right and ability to control’ narrowly, requiring a level of pre‑screening, direction, or inducement that Vimeo’s relatively modest curation, content guidelines, and automated tools do not reach. Given these precedents and the procedural posture (summary judgment after remand with clear appellate instructions), the more likely outcome is that the appellate court affirms the district court’s grant of summary judgment on both knowledge and control grounds, leaving Vimeo within the DMCA safe harbor for the 281 user‑uploaded videos at issue.

parties.appellant: Peter Schuman and William Coplin, plaintiffs and named class representatives (terminated former Atmel employees seeking ERISA severance benefits)
parties.appellee: Microchip Technology Incorporated; Atmel Corporation; Atmel Corporation United States Severance Guarantee Benefit Program (defendants, alleged ERISA fiduciaries/plan sponsor/plan seeking to enforce releases and defeat ERISA claims)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Atmel Corporation, a technology company, anticipated a potential merger and created an employee severance benefits plan (the "Plan") governed by ERISA. The Plan promised significant cash severance intended, according to Atmel’s communications to employees, to "ease concerns" about job security in the event of a corporate transaction.

The Plan’s severance benefits were contingent on several conditions. First, the Plan would expire on November 1, 2015, unless an "Initial Triggering Event" occurred prior to that date. An Initial Triggering Event was defined to occur only if Atmel entered into a definitive agreement on or before November 1, 2015, that would result in a "Change of Control" of the company. If an Initial Triggering Event occurred by that deadline, the Plan would remain in effect for the next eighteen months. Second, assuming an Initial Triggering Event occurred, employees could receive benefits only if (A) a Change of Control actually occurred, and (B) their employment was terminated without "Cause" by Atmel or its successor within 18 months of the execution date of the definitive agreement. A key interpretive dispute later arose over whether the eventual Change of Control had to involve the same company with which Atmel entered into a definitive agreement on or before November 1, 2015.

In September 2015, Atmel entered into a definitive agreement with Dialog Semiconductor for Dialog to acquire Atmel. This agreement was reached before the November 1, 2015 Plan deadline. Before that merger closed, Microchip Technology Inc. submitted a competing acquisition offer. In January 2016, Atmel agreed to be acquired by Microchip instead. Between the Dialog agreement and the announcement of the Microchip agreement, an Atmel human resources executive told employees that the Plan would provide benefits for those terminated without Cause in connection with a Change of Control of the company, explicitly including an acquisition by either Dialog or Microchip. After the Microchip agreement was reached, Atmel’s human resources department circulated a "Frequently Asked Questions" document, evidence of record indicating that Microchip reviewed and approved it, which stated that Microchip would honor the Atmel Plan. Microchip’s merger with Atmel closed in April 2016.

Soon after the merger closed, Microchip terminated Peter Schuman and William Coplin, without cause. At that time, Microchip did not offer them the severance benefits they contend were promised under the Plan. Instead, Microchip offered severance packages that Schuman and Coplin allege were significantly lower than those Plan benefits. As a condition of receiving these lesser payments, Microchip required them to sign releases of all potential claims. Letters accompanying the proposed releases stated that Atmel and Microchip were making the offer "in part to resolve any current disagreement or misunderstanding regarding severance benefits previously offered" by Atmel. Microchip informed Atmel employees that the more generous benefits under the Plan were not available because the Plan had expired. Microchip’s position was that the Plan expired when the Dialog transaction—which had been the definitive agreement entered into before November 1, 2015—failed to result in a finalized merger, and that the subsequent Microchip transaction therefore did not trigger Plan benefits. Schuman and Coplin signed the releases.

Schuman and Coplin later took the position that, contrary to Microchip’s representations, the Plan had not expired and remained in effect at the time of the Microchip transaction and their terminations. They allege that Microchip, as a fiduciary, knew or should have known that the Plan still applied and that its representations to the contrary, and its obtaining of releases in exchange for lesser payments, constituted a breach of ERISA fiduciary duties. They also contend the releases are unenforceable under ERISA for those reasons.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
Schuman and Coplin filed a class-action complaint against Microchip Technology Inc., Atmel Corporation, and the Atmel Corporation U.S. Severance Guarantee Benefit Program, on behalf of approximately 200 similarly situated former Atmel employees who had also signed releases. The complaint alleged violations of ERISA, including breach of fiduciary duty and denial of benefits, and challenged the enforceability of the releases that class members signed in exchange for reduced severance benefits. According to the district court’s description, Schuman and Coplin alleged that Microchip breached its fiduciary duties by misinterpreting the Plan as having expired and by encouraging them and other employees to sign releases in exchange for reduced severance while Microchip allegedly knew or should have known that the Plan remained valid and that employees were still entitled to more generous benefits.

In a separate but related action, a group of nine former Atmel employees who had not signed releases also sued Microchip, alleging similar ERISA violations, including denial of benefits and breach of fiduciary duty based on Microchip’s interpretation and administration of the Plan.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
In the separate action brought by nine employees who had not signed releases (Berman v. Microchip), the district court initially found that the Plan’s key language regarding "Change of Control" and "definitive agreement" unambiguously meant that the Plan had not expired by the time of the Microchip merger and that Microchip had breached its fiduciary duties. On interlocutory appeal, the Ninth Circuit held that the Plan language was ambiguous and remanded for further proceedings to resolve its meaning; that case later settled, leaving the Plan’s definitive interpretation unresolved.

In the Schuman/Coplin class action, the district court certified a class of approximately 220 members (with later discovery showing that five of those members had not in fact signed releases, an issue the court recognized remained unresolved). The case was stayed pending the expected trial in Berman. After Berman settled, Microchip renewed its motion for summary judgment in the Schuman/Coplin case. Microchip argued, per the district court’s description, that Schuman and Coplin had knowingly and voluntarily waived their rights to pursue Plan claims and that those releases disposed of the named plaintiffs’ ERISA claims. Schuman and Coplin argued that even if their execution of the releases was knowing and voluntary in a traditional sense, the releases were nonetheless unenforceable because Microchip violated its ERISA fiduciary duties by obtaining the releases in exchange for sharply reduced severance payments while misrepresenting the availability of Plan benefits.

The district court adopted and applied a six-factor "knowing and voluntary" test used by the First and Second Circuits (considering the employee’s education and business sophistication; the roles of the employer and employee in determining the waiver’s provisions; the clarity of the agreement; the time to study the agreement; whether the employee had independent advice such as counsel; and the consideration for the waiver). Using these six factors and evaluating the "totality of the circumstances" in that framework, the court concluded that Schuman and Coplin understood the terms and consequences of the releases and signed them willingly. In applying this test, the district court expressly did not consider evidence of Microchip’s alleged breach of fiduciary duties or alleged improper conduct in obtaining the releases as part of the totality analysis. On that basis, the court granted summary judgment against the named plaintiffs Schuman and Coplin and in favor of Microchip on their claims.

As to the non-named class members who had signed releases, the district court found that the six-factor test was too individualized to allow a class‑wide determination that all releases were knowing and voluntary. Because class certification had been premised in part on treating the enforceability of releases on a class‑wide basis and because the parties had not briefed that six-factor test at the certification stage, the court ordered the parties to show cause why the class should or should not be decertified.

Separately, for the class members (including some non-named plaintiffs) asserting breach-of-fiduciary-duty claims, the district court addressed whether Microchip breached its fiduciary duties by misinterpreting the Plan as expired when it allegedly knew or should have known the Plan remained in effect. The court found there was at least one material factual dispute about Microchip’s knowledge of the Plan and its intended interpretation and therefore denied Microchip’s motion for summary judgment as to those non-named plaintiffs’ fiduciary-duty claims.

The district court then entered a partial final judgment under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(b) in favor of Microchip and against Schuman and Coplin. It certified for appellate review the legal question of what standard should apply to determine the enforceability of the releases signed by Schuman, Coplin, and most class members. The court explained it needed guidance on whether it had properly adopted the First/Second Circuit six‑factor test or should instead have considered Microchip’s alleged fiduciary breach in its enforceability analysis. The court stayed the remainder of the case, including issues concerning non-named class members and potential decertification, pending appeal.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed:
Schuman and Coplin appeal the district court’s grant of summary judgment against them based on the enforceability of their releases, and specifically the district court’s adoption and application of the six‑factor "knowing and voluntary" test that did not include consideration of allegedly improper fiduciary conduct. The district court certified for appeal the question of what legal test the court should apply in determining the enforceability of ERISA releases like those signed by Schuman and Coplin and the majority of class members.

Microchip cross‑appeals the district court’s denial of summary judgment as to the non-named plaintiffs and the accompanying conclusion that the judgment against Schuman and Coplin did not automatically extinguish the claims of the unnamed class members. Microchip seeks review of the district court’s refusal to extend the summary judgment ruling against the named plaintiffs to the rest of the certified class.

issues_on_appeal.description: What legal test governs the enforceability of releases or waivers of ERISA claims, specifically whether the district court should have considered alleged fiduciary misconduct by the employer/plan fiduciary as part of the totality‑of‑the‑circumstances inquiry into whether an employee’s release of ERISA claims was entered into knowingly and voluntarily.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: ERISA requires that plan fiduciaries act solely in the interest of participants and beneficiaries and for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits and defraying reasonable plan expenses. Fiduciary duties under ERISA incorporate common-law trust principles, including the duty of loyalty, a duty to disclose accurate and material information, and a duty to deal fairly with beneficiaries. Courts evaluating releases of ERISA claims examine whether the waiver is knowing and voluntary under the totality of the circumstances. Various circuits have adopted multi-factor tests for this inquiry: the First and Second Circuits use a non-exhaustive six-factor test focusing on education and sophistication, role in negotiating the waiver, clarity of the agreement, time to review, access to counsel, and consideration; the Seventh and Eighth Circuits employ eight- or nine-factor tests that include these elements and additionally require consideration of improper fiduciary conduct and the employee’s knowledge of rights under the plan. Prior Ninth Circuit precedent (e.g., Vizcaino v. Microsoft Corp.) suggested, without resolving, that waivers of ERISA claims must withstand "special scrutiny designed to prevent potential employer or fiduciary abuse" and must be knowing and voluntary.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court’s entry of partial final judgment under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(b) on the claims of Schuman and Coplin, and its accompanying certification of the legal question about the enforceability standard, complied with the requirements for Rule 54(b) certification and provided a proper basis for appellate jurisdiction.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Rule 54(b), when an action involves multiple claims or multiple parties, the district court may direct the entry of a final judgment as to one or more, but fewer than all, claims or parties only if it expressly determines that there is no just reason for delay. Appellate review of a Rule 54(b) certification examines "juridical" concerns de novo, including whether the claims are sufficiently separate to avoid impermissible piecemeal appeals, and reviews the district court’s equitable determination (prejudice, delay, efficiency) for abuse of discretion. Precedent such as Curtiss-Wright Corp. v. General Electric Co., Noel v. Hall, Wood v. GCC Bend, LLC, Jewel v. National Security Agency, Texaco, Inc. v. Ponsoldt, and United States v. Gila Valley Irrigation District explains that certification should serve judicial administrative interests and avoid duplicative proceedings while recognizing that genuinely distinct claims may be certified for early appeal.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the court of appeals has pendent appellate jurisdiction over Microchip’s cross‑appeal seeking review of the district court’s denial of summary judgment as to unnamed class members and the effect of the judgment against Schuman and Coplin on the class.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: An order granting only partial summary judgment is generally not a final appealable order under 28 U.S.C. § 1291. Pendent appellate jurisdiction may allow review of otherwise nonappealable orders only when the issues on cross‑appeal are inextricably intertwined with, or their resolution is necessary to decide, the issues properly before the court. Cases such as Meredith v. Oregon, Cunningham v. Gates, Burlington Northern & Santa Fe Railway Co. v. Vaughn, and Arc of California v. Douglas state that issues are not inextricably intertwined if they require application of separate and distinct legal standards that turn on different factors. The collateral order doctrine permits immediate appeal of a small category of orders that conclusively determine an important issue separate from the merits and that would be effectively unreviewable on appeal from a final judgment, under standards such as those articulated in Flanagan v. United States and United States v. Tillman.

appellant_arguments: Schuman and Coplin argue that the district court applied the wrong legal standard to evaluate the enforceability of their releases. They contend that ERISA requires "special scrutiny" of waivers of ERISA claims to prevent employer or fiduciary abuse and that this scrutiny must include consideration of any alleged breach of fiduciary duty or improper conduct by the fiduciary in connection with obtaining the release. By adopting the First/Second Circuit six‑factor test without any express consideration of fiduciary misconduct or misrepresentations about Plan status, the district court, in their view, failed to account for core ERISA fiduciary obligations, such as the duty to disclose material information and to act solely in participants’ interests.

They assert that Microchip breached its fiduciary duties by misinterpreting the Plan as expired, or at least by taking a position on Plan expiration that it knew or should have known was incorrect, and by representing to employees that the Plan benefits were unavailable while simultaneously obtaining broad releases in exchange for reduced severance. They claim that Microchip had earlier communications—including the HR executive’s assurances and the FAQ document—that indicated the Plan would be honored in connection with a Dialog or Microchip acquisition, and that this history undercuts Microchip’s later position that the Plan had expired. In their view, this alleged misconduct and the resulting informational imbalance must be part of the court’s evaluation of whether the releases were truly knowing and voluntary.

Schuman and Coplin also argue that the enforceability of releases in a class context must recognize that employees relied on the employer’s representations about Plan validity and benefits, and that a purely individualized voluntariness test that ignores fiduciary breaches undermines ERISA’s protective purposes. They urge adoption of a test similar to that used by the Seventh and Eighth Circuits, which explicitly require courts to consider whether the release was induced by improper fiduciary conduct and whether employees were aware of their rights and relevant facts when they signed.

On the jurisdictional issue, Schuman and Coplin support the district court’s Rule 54(b) certification, arguing that the test for enforceability of ERISA releases is a distinct legal question whose resolution will materially shape the remainder of the litigation, including class treatment, and that an immediate appeal aids efficient resolution. They do not argue in favor of extending appellate jurisdiction to Microchip’s cross‑appeal and take the position that Microchip’s attempt to litigate class‑wide issues regarding unnamed plaintiffs’ claims is beyond the scope of the certified order.
appellee_arguments: Microchip argues that the district court correctly applied a widely accepted totality‑of‑the‑circumstances "knowing and voluntary" test for releases of ERISA claims, using the six non-exhaustive factors recognized by the First and Second Circuits. Microchip contends that nothing in ERISA requires courts to collapse the separate inquiries of fiduciary breach and waiver enforceability or to adopt a special, threshold invalidity rule whenever breach is alleged. It maintains that courts may assess whether a release is enforceable under a traditional voluntariness analysis and that alleged fiduciary breaches can be addressed, if necessary, through separate substantive ERISA claims.

Microchip asserts that Schuman and Coplin are well-educated, experienced professionals, that the release language was clear, that they had time to consider the agreements and the opportunity to consult counsel, and that they received consideration for the releases. In Microchip’s view, these and the other factors demonstrate that the releases were knowingly and voluntarily executed. Microchip therefore supports the district court’s decision to treat the releases as valid to bar the named plaintiffs’ ERISA claims, without interjecting a separate "improper conduct" factor into the voluntariness analysis.

Regarding the Rule 54(b) certification, Microchip challenges the propriety of the certification, arguing that the district court’s order risked piecemeal appeals and that the judgment on Schuman and Coplin’s claims is not sufficiently distinct from issues still pending for unnamed class members. Microchip suggests that the claims are interrelated and should be reviewed together rather than through an interlocutory appeal based on a partial judgment.

In its cross‑appeal, Microchip argues that the district court should have extended its summary judgment ruling against Schuman and Coplin to the rest of the class members who signed similar releases, and that the denial of summary judgment as to unnamed class members was error. Microchip contends that once the district court concluded that the named plaintiffs’ releases were enforceable, that determination should have been given class‑wide effect, extinguishing the claims of members who executed the same or substantially similar releases. To obtain appellate review now, Microchip invokes pendent appellate jurisdiction and the collateral order doctrine, arguing that the effect of the named plaintiffs’ judgment on the unnamed class members is sufficiently intertwined with, or effectively determined by, the enforceability question presented on appeal.

issue_1.reasoning: The question is purely legal: what test governs enforceability of ERISA waivers. Under ERISA and Ninth Circuit precedent (e.g., Vizcaino) waivers of ERISA rights must receive ‘special scrutiny’ to guard against fiduciary abuse and are evaluated under a totality-of-the-circumstances standard. Other circuits’ multifactor tests are expressly non‑exhaustive, and the Seventh and Eighth Circuits specifically require courts to consider whether the release was induced by improper conduct and whether the employee knew of pertinent rights and facts. Here, the district court expressly declined to consider alleged fiduciary misconduct or misrepresentation in its totality analysis and limited itself to the six First/Second Circuit factors. That approach is in tension with ERISA’s core fiduciary obligations—the duty of loyalty, accurate disclosure, and fair dealing—and with the notion of ‘special scrutiny’ of ERISA waivers. A standard that ignores whether the fiduciary misled participants about the very benefits being released cannot be reconciled with those principles. The appellate court is likely to hold that, at minimum, the totality inquiry must include whether the release was tainted by a breach of fiduciary duty or material misrepresentation in obtaining it. Because the district court applied an incomplete legal standard and granted summary judgment on that basis, the judgment enforcing Schuman and Coplin’s releases must be reversed and remanded for application of the correct standard.

issue_2.standard_of_review: mixed (juridical separateness de novo; no-just-reason-for-delay abuse of discretion)
issue_2.reasoning: The Rule 54(b) judgment is final as to Schuman and Coplin: their claims were fully resolved by enforcement of their releases. The remaining claims (principally those of unnamed class members and a handful of individuals whose release status is disputed) turn on similar factual background but are not identical; they involve separate parties and will require individualized application of the voluntariness standard, even under an expanded totality test that includes fiduciary misconduct. The certified question—what legal standard governs the enforceability of ERISA releases—is a discrete, controlling legal issue whose resolution will materially shape the remaining proceedings (class scope, decertification, and merits). Early resolution serves judicial economy by avoiding potentially massive, misdirected factual development if the wrong legal standard were applied. Under Curtiss‑Wright and Ninth Circuit cases like Noel and Wood, the district court’s assessment that there was ‘no just reason for delay’ is within the range of reasonable case‑management judgments, and the risk of truly duplicative piecemeal appeals is limited because once the legal standard is clarified, subsequent appeals will address its application to different parties, not relitigation of the standard itself. Thus the 54(b) certification is proper and provides appellate jurisdiction over the Schuman/Coplin judgment.

issue_3.standard_of_review: de novo (scope of appellate jurisdiction / pendent appellate jurisdiction; collateral order doctrine)
issue_3.reasoning: Microchip seeks review of the denial of summary judgment as to unnamed class members and the district court’s refusal to extend the named‑plaintiff judgment to the entire class. That order is interlocutory and not final under § 1291. Pendent appellate jurisdiction is narrow in the Ninth Circuit; it applies only when the otherwise nonappealable issue is inextricably intertwined with, or necessary to resolve, the issue properly before the court. Here, the legal standard for enforceability of ERISA releases (issue 1) can be decided without determining whether summary judgment should have been granted as to all class members or whether the named‑plaintiff judgment has automatic class‑wide preclusive effect. The class‑scope and unnamed‑member issues involve different legal questions about class procedure, predominance, individualized factors, and possibly variations in circumstances of execution; they are not ‘inextricably intertwined’ in the Meredith/Cunningham sense. Nor do they satisfy the collateral order doctrine: the denial of summary judgment and refusal to extend the judgment class‑wide are not effectively unreviewable on appeal from a final judgment. Accordingly, there is no pendent appellate jurisdiction over Microchip’s cross‑appeal, and that portion must be dismissed.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The core merits holding—the standard for evaluating ERISA releases—is very likely to be reversed. The district court adopted a six‑factor ‘knowing and voluntary’ test but expressly refused to consider alleged fiduciary misrepresentation and misuse of informational asymmetry, even though ERISA fiduciary law and prior Ninth Circuit hints in Vizcaino call for special scrutiny of waivers and emphasize fiduciaries’ duties of loyalty and truthful disclosure. Other circuits’ more expansive multifactor approaches and trust‑law principles further support requiring courts to address whether the waiver was procured through fiduciary breach or material misrepresentation as part of the totality analysis. Applying the wrong legal standard on summary judgment compels reversal and remand. 

On jurisdiction, however, the district court’s Rule 54(b) certification is supported by precedent: Schuman and Coplin’s claims are conclusively resolved, and the legal standard for waiver enforceability is distinct and controlling; immediate review advances efficiency, and the district court’s ‘no just reason for delay’ finding is not an abuse of discretion. Thus appellate jurisdiction properly exists over the named‑plaintiff judgment. By contrast, Microchip’s effort to obtain immediate review of the denial of summary judgment as to unnamed class members and the class‑wide effect of the releases does not satisfy the stringent requirements for pendent appellate or collateral‑order jurisdiction; those issues are not necessary to decide the certified legal standard and may be reviewed after final judgment. The likely result, therefore, is a mixed disposition: (1) reversal of the summary judgment enforcing Schuman and Coplin’s releases and remand with instructions to apply a totality‑of‑the‑circumstances standard that includes potential fiduciary misconduct; (2) affirmance of the propriety of Rule 54(b) certification; and (3) dismissal of Microchip’s cross‑appeal for lack of jurisdiction.

parties.appellant: Andrea J. Campbell, Attorney General of Massachusetts; eleven Massachusetts County District Attorneys (Berkshire, Bristol, Cape and Islands, Essex, Hampden, Middlesex, Norfolk, Northwestern, Plymouth, Suffolk, and Worcester); Thomas G. Ambrosino, Administrator of the Massachusetts Trial Court; and John Mawn, Jr., Massachusetts State Police Interim Superintendent (collectively, state or “Commonwealth defendants,” originally sued as defendants in the district court).
parties.appellee: Jennifer Cotto, Jamie Kimball, David Cummings, Todd Moton, and Travis Moran, each on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated (putative plaintiff class; original plaintiffs in the district court). Additional named plaintiffs in the district court, who are not appellees on this appeal, included Stacy Foster, Jonathan Riley, and Nicole Westcott, also suing on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated.

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Beginning around 2004, two Massachusetts state forensic chemists, Annie Dookhan and Sonja Farak, engaged in criminal misconduct in state drug laboratories. Their conduct included tampering with drug evidence, falsifying drug test results, and committing perjury in state drug prosecutions. This misconduct lasted for approximately a decade and affected tens of thousands of drug cases.

Once Farak’s and Dookhan’s misconduct was uncovered, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court (SJC) undertook systemic remedial measures in the state criminal system. Over 30,000 criminal drug convictions tainted by the chemists’ misconduct were vacated and dismissed with prejudice.

Two individuals whose convictions had been vacated because of Dookhan’s misconduct litigated, in state court, federal due process claims seeking return of various monetary exactions and assets linked to their now-invalid criminal convictions. They demanded the return of fees, victim-witness assessments, restitution, fines, and court costs, as well as of any property that had been seized and forfeited under Massachusetts’s civil forfeiture statute, Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 94C, § 47 (the “State Act”). In Commonwealth v. Martinez, the SJC determined that the Fourteenth Amendment’s Due Process Clause required automatic repayment of most monetary amounts collected as a consequence of the now-vacated convictions, but did not require the automatic return of property forfeited in civil forfeiture proceedings.

With respect to forfeited assets, the SJC reasoned that forfeiture judgments obtained under the civil statute were not simply a direct consequence of the criminal convictions because the forfeiture orders were based on a separate finding—probable cause of a nexus between the property and drug activity—which did not depend on a criminal finding of guilt. As a result, the court held that individuals seeking to undo forfeiture judgments and recover forfeited property must pursue individualized relief by filing motions for relief from judgment under Massachusetts Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b), rather than receiving automatic return of property. The Martinez plaintiffs did not seek certiorari review of that decision in the U.S. Supreme Court.

The plaintiffs in the present federal case are individuals whose drug convictions were among those vacated due to the chemists’ misconduct and who had property forfeited under the State Act in connection with their drug cases. They contend that, even after their convictions were vacated, state and local officials have continued to withhold their previously forfeited property. They assert that this continued withholding violates the Eighth Amendment (excessive fines) and the Fourteenth Amendment (due process), particularly in light of the SJC’s mass vacatur of their underlying criminal convictions.
