stage2_decision.reasoning: All appealed issues arise from a summary judgment record anchored by video and largely undisputed facts showing a lawful traffic stop; a lawful command to exit; noncompliance; and active physical resistance. Under New Hampshire’s resisting statute, those facts support probable cause, defeating the wrongful-arrest, false-imprisonment, and retaliatory-arrest claims. The same factual matrix (nighttime, association of location with criminal activity, confined space, resistance, and bracing) makes it likely the First Circuit would agree that the level and sequence of force were within the Graham range of objective reasonableness. In any event, even assuming some excess, the law was not clearly established at a sufficiently specific level to preclude qualified immunity. Finally, the plaintiff’s municipal-liability theories rest on a single incident and do not identify a concrete training deficiency, pattern of similar abuses, or prior notice to the City, which is insufficient under Monell and analogous state negligence standards. Taken together, these considerations support affirmance of the district court’s judgment on all issues.

parties.appellant: Juan B. Pujol Moreira (in his personal capacity and as personal representative and administrator of the Estate of Nieves Pujol), Maria Julia Pujol Moreira, Ines Maria Pujol Faget (as personal representative and executor of the Estate of Arcadio Joaquin Pujol Izquierdo), Sara L. Pujol (as personal representative and administrator of the Estate of Laureano Pujol Rojas), Luis R. Pujol Rojas, Ana H. Fraga, Lorenzo Perez Pujol, Francisco Pujol Meneses, Pilar M. Pujol Meneses, Raul Pujol Meneses, Sucesores de Don Carlos Nuñez y Dona Pura Galvez, Inc. d/b/a Banco Nuñez, and numerous individual Nuñez family successors (as personal representatives/administrators/executors of various estates and as individual successors) – all plaintiffs in the district courts and plaintiffs‑appellants on appeal, asserting Helms‑Burton Act claims as successors‑in‑interest to Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez.
parties.appellee: Société Générale, S.A. d/b/a Société Générale Americas, and BNP Paribas, S.A. – defendants in the district courts and defendants‑appellees on appeal, alleged traffickers in confiscated Cuban bank assets. (Other banks were originally named in some pleadings but are not appellees in this appeal.)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
In 1960, Fidel Castro’s communist regime in Cuba seized several privately owned Cuban banks and absorbed their assets into Banco Nacional de Cuba (BNC), Cuba’s centralized primary financial institution. Among the seized banks were Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez, which in 1958 controlled assets valued at approximately $25.1 million and $105.1 million respectively. Many former owners and their families fled Cuba and later became United States nationals, maintaining claims to these confiscated assets.

In 1996, Congress enacted the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act, commonly known as the Helms‑Burton Act, codified at 22 U.S.C. §§ 6021–6091. Title III of the Act creates a private cause of action for U.S. nationals who hold claims to property confiscated by the Cuban government on or after January 1, 1959, allowing them to sue any person who "traffics" in that confiscated property. The Act defines "traffics" broadly, to include, when done knowingly and intentionally and without authorization from the U.S. national who holds the claim to the property: (i) selling, transferring, distributing, dispensing, brokering, managing, or otherwise disposing of confiscated property, or purchasing, leasing, receiving, possessing, obtaining control of, managing, using, or otherwise acquiring or holding an interest in such property; (ii) engaging in a commercial activity using or otherwise benefiting from confiscated property; or (iii) causing, directing, participating in, or profiting from such trafficking by another person, or engaging in such trafficking through another person. The Act expressly identifies its purposes as strengthening international sanctions against the Castro government, encouraging a transition to democracy in Cuba, protecting U.S. national security against Cuban threats and theft of U.S. property, and protecting U.S. nationals against confiscatory takings and wrongful trafficking in confiscated property.

The Act contains several temporal and remedial limitations. Section 6084 provides that an action under § 6082 may not be brought more than two years after the trafficking giving rise to the action "has ceased to occur." Separately, § 6085(c) authorizes the President to "suspend the right to bring an action" under Title III for six‑month periods, renewable upon specified findings and reports to Congress, and § 6085(d) permits the President to rescind any such suspension. From the Act’s effective date in 1996 until May 2019, successive Presidents continuously exercised this suspension authority, so the private right of action (Title III) remained dormant for approximately 23 years.

In May 2019, President Trump allowed the suspension to lapse and Title III to take effect. Thereafter, numerous Title III suits were filed nationwide, including the actions at issue in this consolidated appeal.

The plaintiffs here are successors‑in‑interest to the confiscated assets of Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez. They allege that Société Générale (SocGen) and BNP Paribas (Paribas), both large French multinational banks, wrongfully trafficked in the confiscated banking assets by providing financing, credit facilities, and access to hard currency to BNC and other Cuban entities, thereby using and benefiting from the plaintiffs’ confiscated property without authorization or compensation.

Alleged conduct through 2010:

• BNP Paribas – Plaintiffs allege that from at least 2000 to 2010, Paribas offered U.S.-dollar financing to Cuban entities primarily through eight credit facilities operated with the involvement of BNC and other Cuban banks. Through these facilities, Paribas allegedly processed more than $1.747 billion in U.S.-dollar transactions, commonly routed through Paribas’s New York branch. One facility allegedly financed a Cuban entity’s purchase of oil in U.S. dollars from the Netherlands via bank‑to‑bank transfers typically involving New York. Paribas allegedly gave Cuban banks access to U.S. dollars by opening U.S.-dollar accounts for them. Paribas later admitted to much of this conduct in a June 27, 2014 guilty plea in the United States to conspiracy to violate U.S. sanctions laws.

• Société Générale – Plaintiffs allege that between 2000 and 2010, SocGen operated at least twenty U.S.-dollar‑denominated credit facilities for or involving Cuban entities, six of which involved loans directly or indirectly to BNC. Through these facilities, SocGen allegedly processed at least 2,500 transactions valued at approximately $13 billion, all via New York‑based financial institutions. As part of one facility, SocGen, in conjunction with another French bank alleged to be Paribas, purportedly provided a $40 million revolving line of credit to finance importation of crude oil from the Netherlands by a Cuban government‑owned corporation. SocGen admitted similar conduct in a 2018 deferred‑prosecution agreement in which it consented to the filing of an information charging it with conspiracy to violate U.S. sanctions laws.

According to plaintiffs, these credit facilities, U.S.-dollar accounts, and related transactions with BNC and other Cuban banks involved or depended on the confiscated assets and banking infrastructure of Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez, thereby constituting trafficking in the plaintiffs’ confiscated property and generating substantial profits for the banks while excluding plaintiffs from any benefit.

Alleged conduct after 2010 and through at least 2018–2020:

Plaintiffs assert that after Paribas’s 2014 guilty plea and SocGen’s 2018 deferred‑prosecution agreement, the banks continued trafficking in their confiscated property, though in ways intended to avoid direct U.S.-dollar exposure. They allege that the banks continued to provide BNC and other Cuban entities with credit facilities similar to the pre‑2010 ones, except that the newer facilities excluded U.S.-dollar transactions to avoid U.S. law. Following demand letters sent by plaintiffs in 2019 and 2020, plaintiffs allege that neither defendant represented that it would cease extending credit facilities to BNC, providing BNC with access to U.S. dollars, or otherwise trafficking in confiscated property.

As to Paribas specifically, plaintiffs allege that, according to a former Paribas compliance officer, Paribas routinely provided parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland, including in 2020. Plaintiffs claim that through such deliveries of cash, BNC continued to access international markets and conduct transactions it otherwise could not have conducted. Plaintiffs further allege that Paribas: (1) provided banking services to a German company that made payments into a BNC account until at least 2020, enabling the purchase of fuel from a Cuban government‑owned airline; (2) provided a loan, still being repaid in early 2020, to a French company that sold locomotives and rolling stock to a Cuban entity; and (3) through a subsidiary, invested in Melbana Energy between 2018 and 2020, which in turn entered contracts with a Cuban state‑affiliated steelmaker. The operative Pujol complaint additionally alleges that until at least December 2018, Paribas provided banking services to RaFin, S.A., an investment firm controlled by the Cuban military. Plaintiffs allege on information and belief that BNC was involved in at least some of these transactions because BNC is the primary financial institution through which foreign companies conduct business in or with Cuba.

As to SocGen, plaintiffs allege, based on a SocGen employee who had helped create SocGen’s "Cover Procedures" used to conceal U.S.-dollar‑denominated transactions with BNC, that SocGen continued to profit from providing Cuban entities access to foreign currency until at least September 2019. Plaintiffs allege, again on information and belief, that BNC was involved in these transactions because it is the primary financial institution for foreign companies doing business in or with Cuba. They infer that SocGen thereby continued to give BNC access to U.S. dollars and other foreign currencies that BNC and Cuba otherwise could not have accessed, and that SocGen profited from these activities.

Overall, plaintiffs contend that both banks knowingly and intentionally engaged in commercial activities that used or benefited from the confiscated assets and banking business of Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez, without the authorization of the U.S. nationals who are successors‑in‑interest to those banks, and that their trafficking activities continued into the period immediately preceding suit.

procedural_history.claims_brought: The plaintiffs brought private civil damages actions under Title III of the Helms‑Burton Act, 22 U.S.C. § 6082(a)(1)(A), alleging that Société Générale and BNP Paribas trafficked in property confiscated by the Cuban government (the assets and business of Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez) in violation of 22 U.S.C. § 6023(13)(A). Plaintiffs sought to recover for alleged trafficking over multiple years, including both pre‑2010 and post‑2010 conduct, and invoked pre‑suit demand provisions under § 6082(a)(3)(D) for potential increased liability. No other substantive causes of action beyond Helms‑Burton Title III claims are described in the excerpt.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
Pujol Actions:

• Filing and initial claims – On November 9, 2020, the Pujol plaintiffs (successors to Banco Pujol) filed their original complaint in the Southern District of New York (Judge Jesse M. Furman) against SocGen and Paribas (Pujol I). A related second action (Pujol II) by a subset of the Pujol plaintiffs against the same defendants was later filed and consolidated procedurally with Pujol I, with Pujol II stayed pending resolution of Pujol I.

• First dismissal – The Pujol plaintiffs amended once. On November 24, 2021, Judge Furman dismissed the once‑amended complaint without prejudice. The court held that plaintiffs had Article III standing but that their Helms‑Burton claims, which were then based only on conduct through 2010, were untimely under 22 U.S.C. § 6084. The court construed § 6084 as a statute of repose that could not be equitably tolled and found no applicable statutory tolling provisions in the Act.

• Second Amended Complaint – Plaintiffs then filed a Second Amended Complaint adding allegations of SocGen’s and Paribas’s conduct from 2018 and later, in an effort to plead timely trafficking within two years of filing. SocGen and Paribas again moved to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6).

• Second dismissal as to SocGen – On January 23, 2023, Judge Furman granted the motion to dismiss with prejudice as to SocGen. The court found the new, post‑2010 allegations concerning SocGen’s dealings with Cuban entities to be conclusory and insufficient to plausibly plead trafficking under the Helms‑Burton Act, thus failing to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6).

• Proceedings as to Paribas – The district court likewise viewed the new allegations against Paribas (other than the cash‑parcel allegation) as conclusory, but ordered further briefing on two issues: (1) whether the allegation that Paribas delivered parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland in or around 2020 satisfied the statutory definition of "trafficking" and (2) whether the court could exercise personal jurisdiction over Paribas in connection with that allegation.

• Final dismissal as to Paribas – On February 16, 2023, the district court dismissed the claims against Paribas with prejudice. The court held that the cash‑parcel allegation did not plausibly satisfy the Helms‑Burton Act’s statutory definition of "trafficking" and therefore failed to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6). In light of its merits ruling, the court did not reach the personal jurisdiction question. On March 15, 2023, the court dismissed the stayed Pujol II action with prejudice based on the dismissal of the operative complaint in Pujol I.

Sucesores Action:

• Filing and transfer – The Sucesores plaintiffs (successors to Banco Nuñez) first served a demand letter on SocGen on June 10, 2019 and then filed suit in the Southern District of Florida (Judge Darrin P. Gayles) against SocGen and other defendants (since voluntarily dismissed). SocGen moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, and the case was consensually transferred to the Southern District of New York on February 4, 2020 (Judge Kimba M. Wood initially, later reassigned to Judge Mary Kay Vyskocil).

• Demand to Paribas and Second Amended Complaint – On February 19, 2020, the Sucesores plaintiffs sent a demand letter to Paribas. On September 11, 2020, they filed a Second Amended Complaint naming both SocGen and Paribas as defendants, alleging trafficking based on conduct through 2010.

• First dismissal – On December 22, 2021, the district court dismissed the Second Amended Complaint without prejudice. The court held, among other things, that the plaintiffs had standing but that they had not plausibly pleaded that SocGen and Paribas acted "knowingly and intentionally," as required by the statutory definition of "traffics" in 22 U.S.C. § 6023(13)(A).

• Third Amended Complaint and final dismissal – Plaintiffs then filed a Third Amended Complaint (the operative Sucesores TAC), adding allegations materially identical to the new post‑2010 allegations in the Pujol Second Amended Complaint, aimed at curing scienter and timeliness deficiencies. On March 30, 2023, Judge Vyskocil dismissed the Third Amended Complaint with prejudice under Rules 12(b)(2) and 12(b)(6). The court held that: (a) with the exception of the allegation that Paribas delivered parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland, the new allegations also failed to plausibly plead that defendants did business with BNC after they were put on notice of alleged trafficking; (b) all claims predicated on SocGen conduct before July 2017 and Paribas conduct before September 2018 were untimely under § 6084, construed as a statute of repose; and (c) the court lacked personal jurisdiction over Paribas in New York regarding any claim arising from the cash‑parcel allegation.

In both the Pujol and Sucesores cases, the district courts recognized plaintiffs’ Article III standing, applied § 6084 to bar claims based on earlier conduct as untimely, and held that remaining, ostensibly timely allegations, including the cash‑parcel allegation, did not adequately plead trafficking, and in Sucesores, that there was no personal jurisdiction over Paribas for the cash‑parcel claim.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed:
On this consolidated appeal, the Pujol and Sucesores plaintiffs challenge multiple aspects of the district courts’ rulings:

1. Time‑bar/construction of § 6084 – Plaintiffs appeal the district courts’ determinations that 22 U.S.C. § 6084 is a statute of repose rather than a statute of limitations, and that, as such, it barred claims based on defendants’ alleged trafficking that ceased more than two years before each defendant was first named in the relevant complaint.

2. Tolling and effect of presidential suspensions – Plaintiffs appeal the conclusion that § 6084 is not subject to equitable tolling and that the presidential suspensions of Title III between 1996 and 2019 under § 6085(c) did not toll or extend the two‑year period under § 6084.

3. Sufficiency of the pleadings (trafficking) – Plaintiffs appeal the Rule 12(b)(6) dismissals for failure to state a claim, including the district courts’ findings that: (a) the added post‑2010 allegations in the Second Amended Pujol complaint and Third Amended Sucesores complaint were conclusory and did not plausibly allege that SocGen and Paribas continued to traffic in plaintiffs’ confiscated property within the repose period; (b) the allegation that Paribas delivered parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland did not plausibly satisfy the Act’s definition of "trafficking"; and (c) in Sucesores, plaintiffs failed adequately to plead that defendants acted "knowingly and intentionally" as required by § 6023(13)(A).

4. Personal jurisdiction – In the Sucesores action, plaintiffs appeal the Rule 12(b)(2) dismissal for lack of personal jurisdiction over Paribas in New York with respect to claims arising from the cash‑parcel allegation.

5. Standing – Although the district courts found standing, the appellate opinion identifies as an issue for decision whether plaintiffs have Article III standing to bring Helms‑Burton Act claims, and the standing rulings form part of the issues presented and addressed on appeal.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the plaintiffs, as successors‑in‑interest to Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez, have Article III standing to pursue Helms‑Burton Act claims against Société Générale and BNP Paribas based on alleged trafficking in their confiscated property.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To establish Article III standing, a plaintiff must allege (1) an injury in fact that is concrete, particularized, and actual or imminent; (2) a causal connection (injury fairly traceable) between the injury and the challenged conduct of the defendant; and (3) redressability, meaning it is likely that the injury will be redressed by a favorable judicial decision. At the pleading stage, courts accept all material allegations as true and construe the complaint in the plaintiff’s favor (Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins; Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife; Thole v. U.S. Bank; TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez). The court also considers whether a statutory cause of action corresponds closely to harms traditionally recognized at common law, such as unjust enrichment.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether 22 U.S.C. § 6084, which provides that an action under § 6082 "may not be brought more than 2 years after the trafficking giving rise to the action has ceased to occur," is a statute of limitations (potentially subject to equitable tolling) or a statute of repose (not subject to judicial equitable tolling and cutting off liability two years after the defendant’s last culpable act).
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Courts distinguish statutes of limitations from statutes of repose based on text, structure, and purpose. Statutes of limitations typically run from accrual (when the plaintiff can sue and obtain relief) and may be equitably tolled where a plaintiff diligently pursues rights but is prevented from suing by extraordinary circumstances. Statutes of repose run from the date of the defendant’s last culpable act or omission, create a fixed bar on future liability after a legislatively determined period, and are not subject to judicial equitable tolling but only to legislative exceptions. Relevant authorities include CTS Corp. v. Waldburger, Cal. Pub. Emps.’ Ret. Sys. v. ANZ Securities, Inc., Police & Fire Ret. Sys. of City of Detroit v. IndyMac MBS, Inc., and similar Second Circuit precedents. Statutory language such as running from the last culpable act and phrasing like "may not be brought" or "shall not be brought" are indicators of a statute of repose.

issues_on_appeal.description: If § 6084 is a statute of repose, whether the presidential suspensions of Title III between 1996 and 2019 under 22 U.S.C. § 6085(c)(1)–(2), and the President’s authority to rescind suspensions under § 6085(d), operate as legislative tolling provisions that extend or suspend the running of the two‑year time period in § 6084.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Because a statute of repose can be modified or tolled only by legislative action, the question is whether the text of the related statutory provisions expressly or by necessary implication creates an exception to repose. Section 6085(c) allows the President to "suspend the right to bring an action" for six‑month periods upon certain findings and reports to Congress, and § 6085(d) permits the President to "rescind" any suspension. Statutory interpretation principles require courts to begin with the text, give effect to all provisions, avoid supplying omissions, and consider statutory structure and purpose. Distinct terms (e.g., "suspend" vs. "cease") are presumed to carry different meanings when used in different contexts within the same statute. Courts also rely on the distinction between a plaintiff’s right to sue and a defendant’s right to repose, and examine whether a suspension of the right to sue necessarily alters the repose period.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the specific allegation that Paribas delivered parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland in or around 2020 constitutes "trafficking" in the plaintiffs’ confiscated property within the meaning of 22 U.S.C. § 6023(13)(A).
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To qualify as "trafficking," Paribas’s alleged cash deliveries must plausibly fall within one or more statutory categories: (i) dealing in confiscated property itself (selling, transferring, managing, using, or otherwise holding an interest in confiscated property); (ii) engaging in a commercial activity using or otherwise benefiting from confiscated property; or (iii) causing, directing, participating in, or profiting from another person’s trafficking in confiscated property, or engaging in trafficking through another person. The pleadings must include factual allegations, not mere speculation, that tie the cash deliveries and any related commercial transactions to the plaintiffs’ confiscated property or to BNC’s use of that property in a manner that benefits Paribas.

issues_on_appeal.description: In the Sucesores action, whether the Southern District of New York can exercise personal jurisdiction over BNP Paribas for claims arising from the 2020 cash‑parcel allegation, consistent with New York’s long‑arm statute and constitutional due process.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Rule 12(b)(2), plaintiffs must make a prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction. New York’s long‑arm statute (CPLR § 302) requires that the defendant transact business within the state or commit certain acts giving rise to the claim within or affecting the state. Constitutional due process requires that defendants have minimum contacts with the forum such that the maintenance of the suit does not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. For specific jurisdiction, the claim must arise out of or relate to the defendant’s contacts with the forum. Courts assess the defendant’s forum‑related conduct and its connection to the particular cause of action.

appellant_arguments: Standing: Plaintiffs contend they suffered a concrete, particularized injury because defendants allegedly used, exploited, and derived profit from their confiscated bank assets without permission or compensation, depriving them of the economic benefits of their property. They analogize this harm to unjust enrichment, a historically cognizable cause of action, and argue that SocGen’s and Paribas’s alleged trafficking is fairly traceable to plaintiffs’ inability to benefit from the property. They assert that monetary damages under the Helms‑Burton Act would redress this injury.

Nature of § 6084: Plaintiffs argue that § 6084 should be construed as a statute of limitations, not a statute of repose. They emphasize that the statute is part of a remedial scheme aimed at deterring ongoing trafficking and compensating victims, and that the operative language can be read as incorporating a continuing‑violation concept given that "trafficking" is defined to include ongoing and participatory conduct (such as profiting through another person’s trafficking and engaging in commercial activities benefiting from confiscated property). They contend that the two‑year period should be subject to equitable tolling, particularly because presidential suspensions made it impossible to sue until 2019.

Tolling by presidential suspensions: Even if § 6084 is deemed a statute of repose, plaintiffs argue that presidential suspensions under § 6085(c) legislatively tolled the two‑year period. They rely on the statutory terms "suspend" and "rescind," arguing that "suspend the right to bring an action" naturally implies a temporary interruption of both the right and associated deadlines, such that time during suspensions should not count toward the two‑year limit. They argue that "rescind" suggests restoring the status quo ante, i.e., that when a suspension is lifted, any previously existing ability to sue is revived with the clock picking up where it left off. They further rely on contemporaneous executive statements (e.g., President Clinton’s 1996 statement that liability would be established "irreversibly" during the suspension period and suits could be brought immediately after the suspension is lifted) to show that all branches understood the suspensions as preserving, rather than extinguishing, potential Title III liability during the suspension years.

Timeliness and continuing trafficking: Plaintiffs argue that, even under a strict reading of § 6084, their claims are timely because they plausibly alleged that SocGen’s and Paribas’s trafficking did not "cease" more than two years before suit but continued at least into 2018–2020. They contend that the post‑2010 allegations, including continued credit facilities (albeit in non‑U.S. currencies), continued provision of access to foreign currency, and continued involvement with BNC‑linked transactions, show a continuing course of trafficking that extended into the repose period. Thus, the two‑year period should run from cessation of these later activities, making their 2019 and 2020 filings timely.

Plausibility of trafficking allegations: Plaintiffs argue that the district courts misapplied the pleading standard by discounting their factual allegations as conclusory. They emphasize that they pled specific historical conduct acknowledged in Paribas’s guilty plea and SocGen’s deferred‑prosecution agreement, including U.S.-dollar credit facilities and BNC’s central role in Cuba’s financial system. They argue that it is reasonable to infer that similar non‑U.S.-dollar facilities continued and that BNC remained involved, particularly given its status as Cuba’s primary financial institution and information from insider employees and compliance officers. They assert that pleading "upon information and belief" is appropriate here because many transactional details lie within the banks’ exclusive control.

Cash‑parcel allegation against Paribas: Plaintiffs maintain that Paribas’s alleged deliveries of parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland in 2020 constitute "trafficking" under § 6023(13)(A). They contend that providing cash to BNC is a commercial activity that enables BNC to use confiscated bank assets and infrastructure, and that Paribas benefits from and profits from BNC’s use of those assets. They argue that the Act’s broad definition of trafficking is intended to capture indirect and facilitative conduct, including causing or profiting from another’s use of confiscated property, and that detailed allegations about what BNC did with the currency are not required at the pleading stage.

Scienter: In response to earlier rulings that they had not adequately pled that defendants acted "knowingly and intentionally," plaintiffs argue that the banks’ admitted sanctions‑evading schemes, guilty pleas and deferred‑prosecution agreements, and the use of "cover procedures" to conceal transactions with BNC support a strong inference that the banks knew they were dealing with BNC and Cuban state entities and intentionally designed structures to facilitate such dealings. They assert that these factual allegations cure any scienter deficiency.

Personal jurisdiction (Sucesores): In Sucesores, plaintiffs argue that the New York court has personal jurisdiction over Paribas because Paribas historically routed relevant U.S.-dollar transactions through New York financial institutions and maintained a New York branch, and because its alleged conduct is sufficiently connected to New York to satisfy both New York’s long‑arm statute and due process. They contend that the cash‑parcel transactions and continued dealings with BNC and Cuban entities are part of a broader course of dealing that involved and targeted U.S. financial markets, including New York, thereby establishing the necessary contacts and nexus to the claims.
appellee_arguments: Standing: SocGen and Paribas challenged standing in the district courts, arguing that plaintiffs had not suffered a concrete injury attributable to them because the harm from the 1960 confiscations was caused by the Cuban government, not by the banks’ later financing activities, and that any alleged unjust enrichment by the banks was too attenuated to constitute a particularized, concrete injury in fact traceable to defendants’ conduct. They contended that alleging a bare statutory violation is insufficient for Article III standing absent a traditionally recognized concrete harm.

Nature of § 6084: Defendants argue that the plain language of § 6084, which runs from when "the trafficking giving rise to the action has ceased to occur" and provides that an action "may not be brought" more than two years thereafter, fits the Supreme Court’s description of a statute of repose. They emphasize that the time period runs from the defendant’s last culpable act (cessation of trafficking), not from claim accrual or discovery, and that the mandatory "may not be brought" language admits of no equitable exceptions. Accordingly, § 6084 sets a fixed outer boundary on liability and is not subject to equitable tolling, even if plaintiffs were unable to sue while presidential suspensions were in place.

No tolling from presidential suspensions: Defendants argue that presidential suspensions under § 6085(c) affect only plaintiffs’ right to sue (Title III’s private cause of action) and do not modify or toll the separate repose provision in § 6084. They note that §§ 6085(c)–(d) are silent about the repose period and therefore cannot be read to extend it. They further argue that interpreting suspensions as tolling repose would effectively rewrite the statute, contradict the notion that statutes of repose are not subject to equitable considerations, and undermine Congress’s purpose of providing certainty and finality to potential defendants after a defined period. Defendants also contend that executive statements, such as President Clinton’s 1996 statement, cannot alter the statute’s meaning.

Timeliness and cessation of trafficking: Defendants argue that, under § 6084 as a statute of repose, any trafficking activity between 2000 and 2010 indisputably ceased more than two years before they were first named in the complaints (between 2019 and 2020). Therefore, any claims based on that historical conduct are time‑barred. They contend that plaintiffs’ attempts to characterize trafficking as continuing into the repose period are unsupported by non‑conclusory facts. The pre‑2010 conduct, even if wrongful, cannot support liability once the two‑year repose period has expired.

Plausibility and specificity: Defendants argue that the later‑period allegations (post‑2010) are too vague and conclusory to meet the plausibility standard. They emphasize that plaintiffs do not identify specific post‑2010 transactions with BNC, continuation or renewal of the earlier credit facilities, or concrete facts connecting alleged dealings with Cuban or third‑country entities to BNC or to the plaintiffs’ confiscated property. They contend that plaintiffs’ reliance on "upon information and belief" and on BNC’s status as Cuba’s "primary" financial institution is insufficient to plausibly allege that BNC actually participated in the alleged transactions or that defendants used or benefited from the specific confiscated assets at issue.

      SocGen specifically argues that plaintiffs’ allegations that it "continued" to provide access to foreign currency to Cuban entities rely solely on a whistleblower’s generalized statements and speculative inferences that BNC must be involved, without concrete factual support. Paribas argues similarly regarding alleged dealings with German and French companies, Melbana Energy, and RaFin, asserting that plaintiffs fail to allege any particular transaction involving BNC or the confiscated assets, and that the necessary facts are not uniquely within defendants’ control given plaintiffs’ purported access to insider sources.

Cash‑parcel allegation: Paribas argues that the allegation that it delivered parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland does not meet the statutory definition of "trafficking" because plaintiffs do not allege that the cash itself was confiscated property, nor do they allege facts showing that Paribas engaged in commercial activity "using or otherwise benefiting from" plaintiffs’ confiscated property. Paribas contends that the complaint does not specify what BNC did with the cash, whether BNC used confiscated property in connection with such deliveries, or whether Paribas profited from trafficking by BNC involving the plaintiffs’ property. Without such factual detail, Paribas argues, plaintiffs fail to plausibly allege any of the statutory prongs of trafficking under § 6023(13)(A).

Scienter: Defendants argue that plaintiffs have not plausibly alleged that any post‑2010 dealings were undertaken "knowingly and intentionally" as trafficking in confiscated property as required by § 6023(13)(A). They contend that plaintiffs impermissibly infer scienter from past sanctions‑related wrongdoing, without factual allegations that defendants knew they were dealing with the specific confiscated assets of Banco Pujol or Banco Nuñez or that they intended to exploit those assets. Defendants argue that knowledge of dealing with Cuban entities subject to sanctions is not equivalent to knowledge of trafficking in particular confiscated property for Helms‑Burton purposes.

Personal jurisdiction (Sucesores): In Sucesores, Paribas argues that New York courts lack personal jurisdiction over it for claims arising from the alleged 2020 cash‑parcel deliveries because those deliveries allegedly occurred in Switzerland and involved BNC and Cuban commerce, not New York. Paribas contends that these alleged acts neither occurred in New York nor were directed at New York, and therefore do not satisfy New York’s long‑arm statute or due process requirements. It argues that its historical use of New York correspondent accounts for pre‑2010 U.S.-dollar transactions is unrelated to the specific cash‑parcel claim and cannot support specific jurisdiction for that claim.

issue_1.reasoning: The injury alleged—loss of the economic use and benefit of identified property interests while others allegedly exploit those same assets for profit—maps closely onto historically cognizable property and unjust‑enrichment injuries. Plaintiffs plausibly allege that defendants’ alleged trafficking in the very banking businesses and assets confiscated from Banco Pujol and Banco Nuñez deprived them of the economic benefit of those assets. That harm is concrete and particularized, fairly traceable to the defendants’ alleged use and exploitation of the confiscated property (not just to Castro’s original expropriation), and redressable through the damages remedy specifically created by Title III. Given modern standing precedents and the statute’s explicit protection of U.S. nationals’ property interests, the appellate court is likely to agree with the district courts that Article III standing exists.

issue_2.reasoning: Section 6084 begins the two‑year period when “the trafficking giving rise to the action has ceased to occur,” i.e., from the defendant’s last culpable act, not from accrual or discovery. It then says an action “may not be brought” thereafter. Under Supreme Court and Second Circuit precedent, that structure and language correspond to a statute of repose: it sets an absolute outer limit keyed to the defendant’s conduct, not the plaintiff’s ability to sue, and uses categorical ‘may not be brought’ phrasing. The statutory text contains no discovery rule and no equitable exceptions. Applying standard interpretive principles, the more natural reading is that § 6084 is a repose provision not subject to equitable tolling. The district courts’ construction therefore is likely to be upheld.

issue_3.reasoning: Sections 6085(c)–(d) empower the President to “suspend the right to bring an action” and to “rescind” that suspension, but they say nothing about tolling, pausing, or extending the § 6084 period, and they do not alter the trigger (“has ceased to occur”) or the bar (“may not be brought”) in § 6084. A statute of repose can be displaced only by clear legislative direction. Reading presidential suspension of a cause of action as implied tolling of repose would conflate a plaintiff’s right to sue with the legislatively granted right to repose, and would effectively re‑write § 6084’s bright‑line cutoff. The text uses “suspend” in relation to the “right to bring an action,” not to the time bar. Legislative history or executive statements cannot supply a tolling rule absent clear statutory language. The appellate court is therefore likely to agree that presidential suspensions did not toll the § 6084 repose period.

issue_5.reasoning: The cash‑parcel allegation must plausibly fit one of the statutory ‘trafficking’ categories and be tied to plaintiffs’ confiscated property. The complaints allege that Paribas delivered parcels of U.S. currency to BNC in Switzerland, but do not allege: (i) that the cash itself was confiscated property; (ii) what BNC did with the cash; (iii) how the deliveries used or otherwise benefited from the specific confiscated Banco Pujol or Banco Nuñez assets; or (iv) how Paribas caused, directed, or profited from any BNC trafficking in those particular assets. The pleading relies on generalized assertions about BNC’s role as Cuba’s central bank, rather than non‑conclusory factual linkage to the specific confiscated property. Under Twombly/Iqbal, this is insufficient to state a plausible Helms‑Burton “trafficking” claim. The district courts’ Rule 12(b)(6) dismissals of this theory are therefore likely to be affirmed.

issue_6.reasoning: For the 2020 Swiss cash‑parcel theory, the alleged conduct occurred abroad and is not tied to Paribas’s New York branch or any New York‑based transaction. New York’s long‑arm statute and due process require that the specific claim “arise out of or relate to” the defendant’s forum contacts. Plaintiffs’ jurisdictional theory relies primarily on Paribas’s historical pre‑2010 New York‑routed dollar transactions, but those are both temporally and causally distinct from the later Swiss cash‑parcel deliveries that form the only timely claim. Such prior contacts cannot, by themselves, support specific jurisdiction for a different, later, foreign‑centered course of conduct. Because plaintiffs did not plead a sufficient nexus between the 2020 cash‑parcel conduct and New York, the district court’s conclusion that it lacked personal jurisdiction is likely to be upheld.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The core legal questions—classification of § 6084 as a statute of repose and whether presidential suspensions toll that period—turn on statutory text and structure that align closely with Supreme Court definitions of repose statutes. The text focuses on the defendant’s last culpable act, uses unconditional ‘may not be brought’ language, and contains no tolling mechanism; § 6085(c)–(d) speak only to the availability of the cause of action, not to modifying repose. An appellate panel in the Second Circuit is therefore likely to agree with the district courts that (1) § 6084 is a statute of repose, and (2) the long presidential suspension does not toll or restart the repose clock. That holding time‑bars all claims based on the detailed pre‑2010 conduct.

For the remaining, ostensibly timely allegations, the complaints offer thin, largely inferential assertions—often on information and belief—that post‑2010 conduct involved BNC and plaintiffs’ confiscated assets, without concrete transactional facts. Under Twombly and Iqbal, and given that Helms‑Burton’s ‘trafficking’ definition still requires a plausible factual nexus between the alleged activity and the specific confiscated property, the appellate court is likely to hold that the district courts correctly found the pleadings conclusory. The cash‑parcel allegation, standing alone, is especially attenuated: the cash is not alleged to be confiscated property, and there is no non‑speculative allegation tying Paribas’s deliveries to the use of the specific confiscated bank assets for Paribas’s benefit. That failure in pleading the statutory elements, plus the lack of New York‑related conduct for the Swiss cash‑parcel theory in Sucesores, supports affirmance on both the merits and jurisdictional grounds.

While Article III standing is likely to be recognized—because the statute protects a concrete property interest and the alleged unjust enrichment is sufficiently concrete and redressable—that recognition does not save plaintiffs’ claims from dismissal on timeliness and sufficiency grounds. Because every challenged aspect of the district courts’ rulings is likely to be upheld, the overall result on appeal is an affirmance of the judgments in favor of Société Générale and BNP Paribas.

parties.appellant: Brian Fischer (Commissioner of the New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision), Anthony J. Annucci (Deputy Commissioner and Counsel to the New York State Department of Correctional Services), and Terrence X. Tracy (Chief Counsel to the Division of Parole), all sued in their individual and official capacities as state corrections/parole officials and defendants in the district court. They are Defendants-Appellants-Cross-Appellees on appeal.
parties.appellee: Jesus Santiago, a former state and federal criminal defendant who was under New York post-release supervision and federal supervised release. He is the civil rights plaintiff in the district court and Plaintiff-Appellee-Cross-Appellant on appeal.

stage1_summary.factual_background:
From 2000 to 2001, Jesus Santiago committed several state and federal felonies in New York and Virginia.

1. New York state charges and plea
- In January 2000, Santiago shot someone in the leg with a handgun in Brooklyn, New York.
- He was indicted in Kings County Supreme Court on two counts of assault, two counts of criminal possession of a weapon, and one count of criminal possession of a loaded firearm.
- He was released on bond pending trial but fled New York.

2. Federal conviction in Virginia
- About a year and a half later, Santiago was arrested in Virginia on separate federal charges.
- He was indicted in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.
- In November 2001, he pled guilty to possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute and was sentenced to 37 months of imprisonment and four years of supervised release.
- Conditions of his federal supervised release included regularly reporting to his federal probation officer and submitting to drug testing.

3. Return to New York and state plea/sentencing
- While incarcerated federally in December 2001, Santiago wrote to the New York state court seeking to resolve his pending Brooklyn charges.
- In January 2002, he was transferred from federal custody in Virginia to New York state custody.
- On May 3, 2002, while still serving his federal sentence, Santiago pled guilty in Kings County Supreme Court before Justice Sheldon Greenberg to one count of criminal possession of a weapon.
- During the plea, Justice Greenberg explained that, in exchange for the plea, the court promised: (1) the minimum determinate prison term for a Class C violent felony of three and a half years, to run concurrently with his federal sentence from January 2, 2002; and (2) a five-year term of post-release supervision (PRS) as mandated for a Class C felony.
- Santiago affirmed multiple times on the record that he understood and agreed to this plea arrangement, including the five-year PRS term. The Kings County District Attorney’s Office also agreed.
- Santiago asked to be sentenced immediately, but Justice Greenberg said he could not do so until receipt of the presentence report and scheduled sentencing for two weeks later.
- On May 14, 2002, because Justice Greenberg was unavailable after a car accident, Justice Gustin Reichbach conducted the sentencing hearing.
- The minutes or transcript of that sentencing could not later be located. The parties later stipulated that Santiago received a three-and-a-half-year prison term at that hearing and that there was no mention of post-release supervision.
- After sentencing, a court clerk completed a "Sentence and Order of Commitment" form, recording the 3.5-year concurrent prison term starting January 2, 2002. The form had no place to record PRS, and no PRS term was written in.

4. DOCS custody and calculation of sentence
- In April 2004, Santiago was released from federal custody and transferred to the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) to serve the balance of his concurrent state sentence.
- DOCS calculated his remaining state prison term to expire on May 29, 2005.
- DOCS assumed that the sentencing court had imposed the statutory PRS term, because New York law (as amended in 1998 for violent felonies) made a period of PRS mandatory following determinate sentences for such offenses. DOCS therefore treated Santiago as subject to a mandatory five-year PRS period following his prison term.

5. Conditional release and overlapping supervision
- On November 5, 2004, Santiago was conditionally released from state prison approximately seven months early.
- Under New York law, a conditionally released inmate’s remaining prison time is held in abeyance, and a violation of supervision conditions can result in reincarceration with no credit for time spent in violation until reincarcerated or restored to supervision.
- As a result, about seven months of Santiago’s imprisonment term was held in abeyance while he served what DOCS understood to be a mandatory PRS term.
- During this period, Santiago was simultaneously serving his state PRS and his federal supervised release from the 2001 federal conviction.
- Both the state PRS and federal supervised release required him to report to a probation officer, submit to drug testing, and remain in New York State.
- Within about a year, Santiago moved to Virginia in violation of both his state PRS and federal supervised release conditions.

6. Virginia arrests and federal violation
- On October 30, 2005, Virginia local authorities arrested Santiago on charges relating to brandishing a firearm and possession of marijuana. He was released from local custody on November 17, 2005. It appears neither federal nor New York authorities were notified of this arrest or release at the time.
- In October 2006, federal authorities again arrested Santiago in Virginia for violating his federal supervised release terms.
- The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia found he had violated federal supervised release conditions and sentenced him to eight months’ imprisonment followed by 30 additional months of supervised release.

7. 2007–2008 New York reincarceration on PRS violation
- After serving that new federal term, Santiago was transferred to New York on June 12, 2007.
- New York officials charged him with violating his state PRS by absconding to Virginia and committing new crimes in 2005 and 2006.
- An administrative law judge for the state Division of Parole sustained these charges and ordered Santiago returned to DOCS custody to be incarcerated until February 2, 2008.
- Because February 2, 2008, fell on a Saturday, Santiago was released from state prison on February 1, 2008.
- After release, he remained subject to both federal supervised release and state PRS, whose conditions again prohibited leaving New York.
- By approximately February 6, 2008, only a few days after his release, Santiago had departed New York and returned to Virginia in violation of both federal and state supervision conditions.

8. Additional Virginia convictions and federal violation (post‑2008)
- About two months later, Virginia authorities arrested Santiago on the outstanding 2005 charges for brandishing a firearm and marijuana possession.
- He pled guilty in Virginia state court to possession of marijuana with intent to distribute and was sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment with eight years suspended, conditioned on one year of supervised probation.
- While serving that Virginia sentence, in June 2008 Santiago appeared again in the Eastern District of Virginia on charges that he violated the federal supervised release that had begun when he left New York in February 2008.
- The federal court found he violated those terms and sentenced him to seven months’ imprisonment and two additional years of supervised release.

9. Earley and subsequent New York legislative/judicial developments
- In 2006, the Second Circuit decided Earley v. Murray, holding that a New York state court imposing a determinate prison sentence must orally pronounce any PRS term in the defendant’s presence, and that a PRS term not pronounced in court is a nullity, even if required by statute.
- Earley indicated that when DOCS discovered a missing oral pronouncement of a mandatory PRS term, its proper course was to inform the state and allow the state to seek correction through judicial proceedings, not to administratively add or enforce PRS.
- Earley’s reasoning affected thousands of New York sentences where PRS may not have been orally imposed. At that time, however, only courts, prosecutors, or defendants could initiate resentencing; DOCS and the Division of Parole (DOP) had no statutory authority to refer cases on their own.
- Many state officials and offices did not promptly act to adjust affected sentences. Some district attorneys, including in Kings County, resisted efforts to strike or correct administratively imposed PRS and challenged Earley-based relief.
- New York state courts sometimes held that DOP was obligated to enforce PRS despite Earley and often declined to transfer matters to the sentencing courts for resentencing when DOCS or DOP requested it. A declaratory judgment action filed by DOCS and DOP seeking a systematic procedure for resentencing was not granted the requested injunctive relief.
- In April 2008, the New York Court of Appeals decided People v. Sparber and Garner v. DOCS, holding that state statutes required the sentencing judge to orally pronounce PRS in open court and that the remedy for a failure to do so was to vacate the sentence and remit for resentencing.
- In June 2008, the New York legislature enacted a statute (N.Y. Corr. Law § 601-d) authorizing DOCS and DOP to refer defendants with potentially unpronounced PRS terms back to sentencing courts for resentencing. Under this procedure, DOCS/DOP would notify the court and the defendant; the court would determine if PRS had in fact been pronounced, and if not, schedule a resentencing where the court could impose a corrected sentence with or without PRS, consistent with N.Y. Penal Law § 70.85.

10. 2010 return to New York and resentencing
- In September 2010, Santiago was released from federal prison in Virginia and transferred back to New York on charges that he had violated his state PRS conditions in February 2008 by leaving the state.
- By this time, the 2008 legislation authorizing DOCS/DOP referrals for resentencing was in effect.
- Based on that law, DOP referred Santiago to the state court to review whether his PRS should remain in force.
- On December 15, 2010, Santiago and the Kings County District Attorney’s Office appeared before Justice Reichbach.
- Santiago requested resentencing without a PRS term, and the District Attorney’s Office consented.
- Justice Reichbach orally resentenced Santiago without a term of PRS and issued a written order reflecting that disposition.
- Following that resentencing, Santiago was released.

11. Later criminal history noted in the record
- In May 2012, the federal court in the Eastern District of Virginia sentenced Santiago to nine months’ imprisonment for violating federal supervised release.
- In November 2012, he was charged in Virginia state court with additional crimes, pled guilty to issuing a bomb threat and to assault, and was incarcerated in Virginia until May 2015.

Overall, Santiago’s civil claims center on two distinct periods in which New York enforced a PRS term that had not been pronounced at his 2002 sentencing: (a) his incarceration from June 12, 2007 to February 1, 2008, following a PRS-violation hearing; and (b) his incarceration from September to December 2010 before his 2010 resentencing without PRS.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
In May 2012, Jesus Santiago filed a civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York. He sued various New York state corrections and parole officials, ultimately including Brian Fischer (Commissioner of DOCS/DOCCS), Anthony J. Annucci (Deputy Commissioner and Counsel to DOCS), and Terrence X. Tracy (Chief Counsel to the Division of Parole). Santiago alleged that state officials violated his constitutional rights by enforcing a term of post-release supervision that had not been orally pronounced at his 2002 sentencing, in violation of Earley and related due process principles. He sought compensatory and punitive damages for periods of incarceration he claimed were unlawful, principally his 2007–2008 incarceration for PRS violations and his September–December 2010 incarceration prior to resentencing.

The core theory was that DOCS and DOP administratively treated him as subject to a PRS term that the sentencing judge never orally imposed, causing him to be supervised, violated, and reincarcerated under an invalid PRS term.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
Summary judgment stage (2017):
- The parties cross-moved for summary judgment.
- The district court identified Fischer, Annucci, and Tracy as personally involved in the alleged constitutional deprivation and denied them summary judgment on that ground.
- The court held that these defendants were entitled to qualified immunity for conduct occurring before the Second Circuit's Earley decision (2006) and before June 12, 2007, because during that period Santiago was either not in New York custody or Earley had not yet clarified the constitutional issue, and he would not have been available for resentencing.
- The court held they were not entitled to qualified immunity for the period from June 12, 2007 (when Santiago reentered New York custody) through February 6, 2008 (when he absconded again), during which DOCS and DOP enforced the unpronounced PRS against him.
- The court again granted qualified immunity to the defendants for the period after Santiago’s return to New York in September 2010, reasoning that by then the officials took prompt and objectively reasonable steps—using the new statutory procedure—to refer him to state court for resentencing, leading to his December 2010 resentencing without PRS. On that basis, the court dismissed his damages claims related to incarceration from September to December 2010.

Pretrial evidentiary rulings (2022):
- The district court scheduled a jury trial on the remaining claims relating to the 2007–2008 incarceration.
- In motions in limine filed in July 2022, defendants sought to introduce evidence that legal and administrative impediments (including state law, the positions of district attorneys, and actions of state courts) limited their ability to unilaterally release inmates or obtain resentencing after Earley, and that these impediments affected what they could do for Santiago between June 2007 and February 2008. They argued this evidence was relevant to causation and to their state of mind for punitive damages.
- Defendants also moved to adjourn the trial pending Second Circuit decisions (Vincent v. Annucci and Aponte v. Perez) addressing similar issues.
- At an October 2022 status conference, the district court indicated it would not allow evidence of such impediments, stating it viewed the evidence as irrelevant because it believed causation was already resolved and the jury would only determine damages. The court stated the jury would be told that the defendants had custody of Santiago after Earley and did not send him back for resentencing.
- In November 2022, the court reiterated that it would exclude evidence of impediments, even when offered to show defendants’ subjective understanding that they lacked authority to release Santiago or initiate resentencing.
- Defendants argued that such evidence was at least relevant to punitive damages (showing absence of evil motive or reckless indifference). They submitted a 2008 governor’s memorandum indicating that court participation was crucial to resolving PRS issues and that, in many cases, missing sentencing minutes made it impossible for DOCS/DOP to know whether PRS had been properly imposed, thus requiring judicial resolution.
- The district court issued a written order (Santiago v. Fischer, Nov. 25, 2022) holding that defendants could not introduce evidence of their understanding that they lacked legal authority to release Santiago or refer him to court. The court reasoned that such evidence risked confusing the jury and that the issues of liability and causation had already been extensively litigated and determined in prior Second Circuit cases.

Trial (November 2022):
- The case proceeded to a jury trial limited to claims arising from Santiago’s incarceration from June 12, 2007 to February 1, 2008.
- Consistent with the in limine ruling, the jury did not hear detailed testimony about legal or administrative obstacles posed by state law, prosecutors, or courts to releasing Santiago or referring him for resentencing. Nor did they hear full evidence of the defendants’ understanding of their authority post‑Earley.
- The jury heard evidence that DOCS and DOP treated Santiago as subject to a PRS term that had not been orally pronounced, that he was reincarcerated for PRS violations between June 2007 and February 2008, and that defendants did not initiate any resentencing or release during that period.
- In closing, Santiago’s counsel argued that defendants could have promptly referred him for resentencing or released him after Earley, and that they nonetheless failed to act. Defendants were limited in their ability to rebut this with evidence of impediments.
- The jury returned a verdict awarding Santiago $100,000 in compensatory damages and $750,000 in punitive damages for the 2007–2008 period.

Post‑trial motion (Rule 50/59) (2023):
- Defendants filed a renewed motion for judgment as a matter of law or, alternatively, for a new trial.
- While the motion was pending, the Second Circuit issued Vincent v. Annucci (Vincent II), which addressed the need to consider whether legal or practical impediments limited what corrections officials could do to release or resentencing inmates with administratively imposed PRS terms, and emphasized the plaintiff’s burden to prove causation of damages.
- In supplemental briefing, defendants argued that, in light of Vincent II, a new trial was required because the district court had prevented them from presenting evidence of impediments, thus relieving Santiago of his burden to prove that their conduct caused the length of his incarceration.
- The district court denied the motion (Santiago v. Fischer, Apr. 16, 2023). It concluded that Vincent II did not require a new trial because, in its view, defendants had testified about their understanding, experiences, and perceived obstacles in complying with Earley and about steps taken specifically as to Santiago’s PRS sentence.
- The court found that defendants had offered testimony about logistical processes and perceived impediments (needing court orders to modify sentences, lack of sentencing minutes, efforts to create databases of illegal PRS sentences, and efforts to work with county officials), and that the jury was entitled to disbelieve their explanations and to find that their delay reflected unreasonable noncompliance.
- The court also upheld the punitive damages award, finding that, based on the trial evidence, the jury could decide whether defendants’ delay in complying with Earley showed callous and reckless disregard of Santiago’s rights and caused his injuries. The court characterized additional testimony about New York’s PRS statute (“Jenna’s Law”) as of marginal relevance and potentially confusing.

As a result of these rulings, the district court’s final posture was:
- Liability and damages (including punitive damages) were imposed on Fischer, Annucci, and Tracy for the 2007–2008 incarceration based on enforcement of an unpronounced PRS term and failure to secure resentencing or release.
- Claims relating to the September–December 2010 incarceration were dismissed on summary judgment on the basis of qualified immunity, with the court finding the officials’ conduct in 2010 was objectively reasonable given the steps they took to obtain resentencing under the 2008 statute.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed:
On appeal, the defendants (Fischer, Annucci, and Tracy) and Santiago each challenge different aspects of the district court’s rulings:

- Defendants’ appeal:
  1. They challenge the district court’s evidentiary rulings excluding evidence of legal and administrative impediments (including state prosecutors’ and courts’ responses to Earley and the defendants’ understanding of their authority) that allegedly prevented or limited their ability to unilaterally release Santiago or secure resentencing after Earley. They argue that excluding this evidence improperly limited their defense on causation and state of mind (especially as to punitive damages).
  2. They challenge the denial of their post‑trial motion for judgment as a matter of law or for a new trial, contending that under Vincent II and related precedents, Santiago had the burden to prove that their conduct, rather than independent impediments, caused his incarceration and that the jury could not properly assess causation or punitive damages intent without the excluded evidence.
  3. They also contest the district court’s denial of qualified immunity for the 2007–2008 period, arguing that in light of Earley, Sparber, Garner, later clarifications in Vincent, and the particular facts of Santiago’s case (including his awareness of PRS at the plea and systemic resistance by other state actors), a reasonable official might not have known that continuing to enforce PRS or delaying action pending further legal clarification was unlawful.

- Santiago’s cross‑appeal:
  1. He challenges the district court’s grant of summary judgment in favor of the defendants on his claims relating to his incarceration from September to December 2010, arguing that the court wrongly concluded the defendants were entitled to qualified immunity for that period.
  2. He contends that prior Second Circuit decisions (including Betances and Hassell) preclude granting qualified immunity based on post‑Earley remedial efforts and that the same principles governing the 2007–2008 period should apply to his 2010 incarceration, when PRS continued to be enforced in his case until his December 2010 resentencing.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred by excluding evidence of legal and administrative impediments—such as the positions of state prosecutors, state courts, and governing state law—that allegedly limited or prevented defendants from unilaterally releasing Santiago or securing his resentencing between June 12, 2007 and February 1, 2008, and whether that exclusion improperly affected the jury’s determinations on causation of damages and on the defendants’ state of mind for punitive damages.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Evidentiary rulings and denial of a motion for a new trial are reviewed for abuse of discretion. A district court abuses its discretion if its decision rests on an error of law or a clearly erroneous assessment of the evidence. An evidentiary error is harmless only if the appellate court can say with fair assurance that the judgment was not substantially swayed by the error. Under § 1983, the plaintiff bears the burden of proving each element, including that the constitutional violation caused actual injury. Where unlawful confinement is alleged, the court must reconstruct what would have occurred had proper procedure been followed, and when the same adverse action would have occurred even absent the constitutional violation, only nominal damages are available. Punitive damages under § 1983 require proof that the defendant’s conduct was motivated by evil motive or intent or involved reckless or callous indifference to federally protected rights.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly denied qualified immunity to defendants for their conduct during Santiago’s June 12, 2007 to February 6, 2008 incarceration based on the enforcement of a PRS term that was not orally imposed at sentencing, in light of Earley and subsequent Second Circuit and New York decisions, and notwithstanding defendants’ arguments that Santiago had notice of PRS at his plea and that legal impediments and other state actors’ resistance constrained their options.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Qualified immunity shields officials from liability unless (1) they violated a federal statutory or constitutional right, and (2) the right was clearly established at the time of the challenged conduct. A right is clearly established when, at the time of the officer's conduct, the law was sufficiently clear that every reasonable official would understand that what he is doing is unlawful, typically requiring that existing precedent squarely govern the specific facts at issue. The analysis focuses on the specific factual situation the officials faced, and whether a reasonable official would have believed the conduct to be lawful in light of precedent like Earley, Betances, Vincent, and similar cases.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court’s grant of summary judgment based on qualified immunity for Santiago’s claims arising from his incarceration from September to December 2010 was consistent with Second Circuit precedent, given that he continued to be detained under PRS until resentenced without PRS in December 2010 and that defendants argued they took prompt, reasonable steps using the newly available statutory procedure to secure his resentencing once he returned to New York.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine dispute of material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. The availability of qualified immunity is a question of law reviewed de novo. The same two‑part qualified immunity framework applies: whether a constitutional right was violated and whether the right was clearly established at the time. Prior circuit decisions (e.g., Betances, Hassell, Vincent, Aponte) inform whether officials could reasonably believe that their remedial steps, taken after Earley and after legislative and judicial developments in 2008, would shield them from liability for continued enforcement of unpronounced PRS terms.

appellant_arguments: Defendants contend the district court improperly excluded critical evidence of "impediments"—including state statutory constraints, the resistance of district attorneys and courts to implementing Earley, and the absence of a mechanism for DOCS or DOP to initiate resentencing before the 2008 legislation. They argue this evidence was directly relevant to whether they could have lawfully released Santiago or obtained his resentencing between June 2007 and February 2008. Without it, the jury was left with an incomplete and misleading picture suggesting that they simply ignored Earley, which affected both causation and punitive damages.

They argue that, under Vincent II, plaintiffs in § 1983 cases must prove that the defendant’s conduct, rather than independent legal or practical barriers, caused the alleged unlawful detention. The excluded evidence would have shown that other actors (courts, prosecutors) and legal rules could have prevented or delayed Santiago’s release or resentencing even if defendants had taken additional steps. Thus, the exclusion relieved Santiago of his burden to prove causation and improperly allowed the jury to assume that prompt release or resentencing was feasible and legally available.

Regarding punitive damages, defendants maintain that evidence of their efforts to comply with Earley—such as consulting with the Office of Court Administration, engaging with district attorneys who opposed striking PRS, trying to create comprehensive databases of affected inmates, and seeking judicial guidance—was essential to show the absence of evil motive or reckless indifference. They argue that, without hearing about these efforts and the legal uncertainty, the jury could wrongly infer that their delay was a deliberate or callous refusal to comply with federal law.

On qualified immunity for the 2007–2008 period, defendants argue that Earley did not clearly establish the unlawfulness of their particular conduct in Santiago’s circumstances. Unlike Earley and similar cases, Santiago was expressly told during his plea that he would receive a five-year PRS term and agreed to that sentence. The later sentencing judge then imposed the prison term without mentioning PRS, and the commitment order did not list PRS. Defendants argue that it was not clearly established that continuing to enforce a statutorily mandated PRS term under these atypical circumstances was unconstitutional, especially while many state courts continued to require enforcement of PRS and resisted Earley’s implementation.

They further assert that, prior to the 2008 legislative amendment, DOCS and DOP lacked statutory authority to refer cases like Santiago’s for resentencing on their own, and their attempts to obtain judicial clarification were rebuffed. They contend that a reasonable official could believe that enforcing mandatory PRS until courts or prosecutors acted was lawful, given the ambiguity created by conflicting state-court rulings and the absence of a clear, administratively available remedy.

Regarding the 2010 incarceration, defendants state that once Santiago returned to New York in September 2010, they promptly used the new statutory procedures to refer him for resentencing, leading to his December 2010 resentencing without PRS and release. They argue that these prompt, objectively reasonable steps demonstrate that they did not cause any extended unlawful detention beyond what the law and procedural requirements would have imposed, and that any liability for this period should be evaluated with full consideration of the same types of impediments discussed for 2007–2008.
appellee_arguments: Santiago argues that the core constitutional violation is the enforcement of a PRS term that was never orally imposed by the sentencing court in 2002, contrary to Earley and later New York Court of Appeals decisions. He maintains that DOCS and DOP were on notice after Earley that administratively imposed PRS was unlawful, yet they continued to treat him as subject to PRS, used that PRS to reincarcerate him between June 2007 and February 2008, and again detained him under PRS in 2010 until a court finally resentenced him without PRS.

He contends that Second Circuit precedent—including Betances, Vincent, Hassell, and Aponte—has already established that continuation of administratively imposed PRS after Earley was unconstitutional, and that state corrections and parole officials were not entitled to qualified immunity for continuing to enforce such PRS terms. He points out that these cases hold that subsequent remedial efforts or perceived resistance by other actors do not excuse the initial constitutional violation or provide a basis for qualified immunity.

On the evidentiary issue, Santiago maintains that the district court did allow defendants to testify about their understanding of Earley, their internal processes, and their perceived obstacles in identifying and remedying illegal PRS sentences, and that the jury was able to assess this testimony and reject it. He argues that further detailed evidence about wider litigation over Earley, or about other officials’ resistance, was marginally relevant at best and risked confusing the jury or encouraging it to revisit liability and causation issues that had already been litigated and, in his view, effectively determined in prior appellate decisions.

He argues that the jury reasonably concluded that defendants had the ability and obligation to act after Earley to prevent his unconstitutional incarceration but unreasonably delayed doing so, and that this delay supported both compensatory damages (for the period of incarceration that should have been avoided) and punitive damages (for reckless or callous disregard of his rights). Allowing defendants to rely on broad evidence of systemic resistance or legal uncertainty, he argues, would improperly dilute their responsibility to comply with clearly established federal law.

Regarding the 2010 period, Santiago asserts that the district court’s grant of qualified immunity and dismissal of his 2010-incarceration claims conflicts with Second Circuit case law, particularly Hassell’s statement that officials cannot escape liability by pointing to belated remedial measures taken after Earley. He argues that the same principles that barred qualified immunity for the 2007–2008 period apply equally to the 2010 incarceration, because he remained detained under a PRS term that had never been orally imposed until his December 2010 resentencing.

He further maintains that, even if defendants eventually used the new statutory resentencing mechanism, they should be held liable for any period during which they continued to enforce an unconstitutional PRS term before that resentencing occurred, and that his claims for damages related to the 2010 incarceration should proceed to trial rather than being barred at summary judgment.

issue_1.reasoning: The district court’s in limine ruling broadly excluded much of the very category of evidence that Vincent II later held to be central to the causation inquiry in Earley-type PRS cases: what legal and practical impediments actually constrained DOCS/DOP’s ability to release or secure resentencing, and what defendants reasonably believed their authority to be. The judge repeatedly stated that causation and liability were already essentially determined and that the jury was only to decide damages, then barred defendants from introducing evidence about their understanding (and the broader legal landscape) to rebut plaintiff’s narrative that they simply could have released him or obtained resentencing. That was a legal error as to the proper scope of the plaintiff’s burden on causation and of the relevance of this evidence to both compensatory and punitive damages under Vincent II and related cases. Given that causation and punitive intent were heavily contested, and that the closing argument squarely asserted that defendants could have ‘just sent him back’ or released him, the exclusion was not harmless; it likely affected both the size of compensatory damages and, especially, the large punitive award. A new trial is therefore required on the 2007–2008 claims.

issue_2.reasoning: For the June 12, 2007–February 6, 2008 period, Earley (2006) had already made clear in this Circuit that administratively imposed PRS not orally pronounced is a nullity and that DOCS/DOP may not themselves add or enforce such PRS; their proper course is to alert the courts. Later decisions like Betances, Vincent, Hassell, and Aponte confirm that by the post‑Earley period at issue, it was clearly established that continuing to enforce such PRS or reincarcerating on it violated the prisoner’s rights, even amid state‑court resistance or statutory gaps. The unusual feature that Santiago had been told about PRS at his plea does not meaningfully distinguish this case—Earley and Sparber/Garner focus on the need for an oral pronouncement at sentencing, not on plea‑colloquy expectations. Nor do systemic obstacles or lack of a perfect remedial mechanism change what a reasonable official would understand about the unlawfulness of continuing to punish someone under an unpronounced component of a sentence. Thus, while state of mind and impediments are relevant to damages and perhaps causation, they do not entitle defendants to qualified immunity for that 2007–2008 enforcement; the denial of qualified immunity for that period should stand.

issue_3.reasoning: As to the September–December 2010 incarceration, the material facts are undisputed: by then, the 2008 statute expressly authorized DOCS/DOP referrals; when Santiago re‑entered state custody, the Division of Parole used that mechanism, obtained a resentencing hearing, and he was resentenced (without PRS) and released within a few months.
