Ángel Forteza-García was indicted in the District of Puerto Rico in March 2003. The indictment charged him with five counts, of which Count One and Count Three are relevant here.

Count One charged Forteza with aiding and abetting a violation of 18 U.S.C. § 2114(a). Although § 2114(a) is often referred to as the federal mail robbery statute because it criminalizes the robbery of custodians of United States mail, it also reaches the robbery of any person who has lawful charge of money or other property of the United States. The indictment alleged that Forteza and his codefendants assaulted a government informant, who had lawful custody of money provided by the government for the purpose of a controlled purchase of a firearm. The alleged purpose of the assault was to rob the informant of that money. Count One further alleged that, in effecting or attempting to effect this robbery, the victim was wounded and his life was put in jeopardy when he was shot several times, which resulted in his death. Those allegations tracked the aggravated portion of § 2114(a), which increases the penalty where, in effecting or attempting to effect the robbery, the custodian is wounded or his life is put in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon.

Count Three charged Forteza with aiding and abetting a violation of 18 U.S.C. § 924(j). Section 924(j) makes it a crime to cause the death of a person through the use of a firearm in the course of committing a violation of § 924(c). Section 924(c), in turn, criminalizes using or carrying a firearm during and in relation to any crime of violence or drug trafficking crime, or possessing a firearm in furtherance of such an offense. Count Three alleged that the § 2114(a) offense described in Count One was committed by possessing, using, or carrying a firearm during and in relation to that crime of violence, and that in the course of that crime of violence the victim was unlawfully killed with malice aforethought through the use of a firearm, by knowingly, willfully, deliberately, maliciously, and with premeditation shooting the victim and causing his death.

Forteza pleaded guilty in September 2003 to only Count Three, the § 924(j) count, which by its terms realleged and incorporated by reference the § 2114(a) conduct described in Count One. In exchange, the government agreed to drop the remaining four charges, including the § 2114(a) count, and to recommend a sentence below the statutory maximum for a § 924(j) violation. He was sentenced to 324 months in prison, followed by five years of supervised release. The change-of-plea colloquy and plea agreement materials showed that Count Three identified its predicate crime of violence as assaulting an individual who lawfully had charge or custody of United States money with intent to rob, steal, or purloin that money, as set forth in Count One, and that Count One alleged the victim was wounded and his life put in jeopardy by being shot several times, causing his death.

The later collateral challenge centers on the statutory definition of a "crime of violence" in § 924(c)(3), which includes, under the "force clause" in § 924(c)(3)(A), any felony that has as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against the person or property of another, and formerly included, under the "residual clause" in § 924(c)(3)(B), felonies that by their nature involve a substantial risk that physical force may be used in the course of committing the offense.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
After his 2003 guilty plea and sentencing on Count Three (§ 924(j)), Forteza pursued a direct appeal of his conviction and sentence, which was unsuccessful. In 2006, he filed his first motion for post-conviction relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2255 in the District of Puerto Rico. That petition asserted that his conviction and sentence were unconstitutional based on prosecutorial misconduct, judicial misconduct, and ineffective assistance of counsel. The district court denied that initial § 2255 petition, and Forteza did not appear to appeal that ruling.

In 2017, Forteza sought authorization from the First Circuit to file a second or successive § 2255 petition. He asserted that his § 924(j) conviction was unconstitutional in light of intervening Supreme Court precedent, specifically United States v. Davis, 588 U.S. 445 (2019). Davis held that the residual clause of § 924(c)(3)'s crime-of-violence definition — covering felonies that by their nature involve a substantial risk that physical force may be used — was unconstitutionally vague. Forteza argued that, in light of Davis, his predicate offense for § 924(j) could only qualify as a crime of violence, if at all, under the force clause in § 924(c)(3)(A), and that the predicate offense here, a § 2114(a) offense, did not meet the force-clause definition.

The First Circuit granted permission in 2020 for Forteza to file this second or successive § 2255 petition. He then filed the § 2255 motion now at issue, contending that his § 924(j) conviction was unconstitutional under Davis because the underlying § 2114(a) offense did not categorically have as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force as required by § 924(c)(3)(A).
procedural_history.district_court_decision: On the second § 2255 petition, the District Court for the District of Puerto Rico determined that the § 2114(a) offense forming the predicate for Forteza's § 924(j) conviction was an aggravated variant of the § 2114(a) crime and that this aggravated variant necessarily included as an element the use of physical force sufficient to satisfy § 924(c)(3)(A)'s force clause. The court concluded that, based on the indictment and plea materials, Forteza's conviction rested on a § 2114(a) offense involving wounding and placing the victim's life in jeopardy by the use of a dangerous weapon. The district court further noted that, under binding First Circuit precedent, any argument that a conviction predicated on aiding and abetting such an offense would not qualify under the force clause was foreclosed. The district court therefore denied the § 2255 petition and also denied a certificate of appealability.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Forteza appealed from the district court's denial of his second § 2255 petition, challenging the conclusion that his § 924(j) conviction remains valid after Davis. On appeal, he contests the district court's determination that his predicate § 2114(a) offense was the aggravated form of mail robbery, that this aggravated form qualifies as a crime of violence under § 924(c)(3)(A)'s force clause, and that aiding and abetting that offense does not alter its status as a crime of violence. He also appeals the denial of a certificate of appealability, which the Court of Appeals subsequently granted limited to his Davis-based challenge to the constitutionality of his § 924(j) conviction.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, in light of United States v. Davis, Forteza's conviction under 18 U.S.C. § 924(j) is unconstitutional because the predicate § 2114(a) offense does not qualify as a "crime of violence" under § 924(c)(3)(A)'s force clause.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To sustain a § 924(j) conviction, the government must prove that the defendant caused the death of a person through the use of a firearm in the course of committing a violation of § 924(c). For § 924(c) to apply, the predicate must be a "crime of violence" as defined in 18 U.S.C. § 924(c)(3). After Davis invalidated the residual clause, the government must rely on § 924(c)(3)(A)'s 'force clause,' which requires that the predicate felony have as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against the person or property of another. Under the categorical or modified categorical approach, courts examine the statutory elements of the predicate offense (and, if the statute is divisible, the specific element set forming the offense of conviction as shown by Shepard-approved documents) to determine if the offense categorically requires such force.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the record of conviction establishes that Forteza's predicate § 2114(a) offense was the aggravated variant of mail robbery (involving wounding or putting the victim's life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon), as opposed to the simple form, for purposes of the categorical analysis under § 924(c)(3).
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Determining which part of a divisible statute formed the basis of conviction is a question of fact reviewed for clear error. Courts may look to a limited set of 'Shepard documents' such as the charging document, written plea agreement, plea colloquy transcript, and any explicit factual findings by the trial judge to which the defendant assented. The court must identify, using these materials, which statutory elements the defendant necessarily admitted in pleading guilty. Factual findings are disturbed only if, upon review of the entire record, there is a strong, unyielding belief that a mistake has been made. Legal conclusions about whether the identified offense qualifies as a crime of violence are reviewed de novo.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard_additional: The question of whether an offense qualifies as a crime of violence is treated as a purely legal question.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the aggravated form of § 2114(a) is divisible among its alternative aggravating circumstances (wounding the victim, putting the victim's life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon, or committing a subsequent offense) such that the court may isolate the particular aggravator forming Forteza's offense of conviction for crime-of-violence analysis.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under the categorical approach, a statute is 'divisible' if it sets out one or more elements of the offense in the alternative, effectively defining multiple crimes. When a statute is divisible, courts apply the modified categorical approach, consulting Shepard documents to determine which statutory alternative formed the basis of the defendant's conviction, and then evaluate that specific offense under the relevant federal definition (here, § 924(c)(3)(A)'s force clause). If the alternatives are means rather than elements, the statute is treated as indivisible and evaluated as a unit.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether committing the predicate § 2114(a) offense as an aider and abettor, rather than as a principal, affects whether that offense qualifies as a "crime of violence" under § 924(c)(3)(A).
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: 18 U.S.C. § 2 provides that anyone who aids, abets, counsels, commands, induces, or procures the commission of an offense is punishable as a principal. In determining whether a predicate offense is a crime of violence, courts consider the elements of the substantive offense. Prior Circuit precedent addresses whether aiding-and-abetting liability changes the crime-of-violence analysis, and the appellate panel applies that precedent as controlling law.

appellant_arguments: After United States v. Davis invalidated § 924(c)(3)(B)'s residual clause as unconstitutionally vague, the predicate offense for his § 924(j) conviction must qualify as a crime of violence under the force clause in § 924(c)(3)(A). He contends that his underlying § 2114(a) offense does not satisfy that clause because § 2114(a) does not, in all of its forms, have as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against the person or property of another.

He asserts that § 2114(a), as relevant here, delineates only two offenses: a simple, indivisible variant defined by the language before the semicolon (assaulting, robbing, or attempting to rob a custodian of federal property with intent to rob or steal) and an aggravated, indivisible variant defined by all of the language following the semicolon (wounding, putting life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon, or committing a subsequent offense). In his view, the aggravated variant can be committed either by wounding or jeopardizing the victim's life during a robbery or by merely committing the simple mail robbery offense more than once, which he argues can occur without the degree of force required by § 924(c)(3)(A). Thus, even the aggravated variant is not categorically a crime of violence.

He contends that the record does not clearly show that his predicate § 2114(a) offense was the aggravated form. Because he pleaded guilty only to Count Three (§ 924(j)), and Count Three does not, on its face, set out the aggravating elements of wounding or putting life in jeopardy under § 2114(a), he argues that his offense must be treated as premised on the simple form of § 2114(a), which he says does not require the requisite level of physical force.

He further argues that any references to a firearm, shooting, and the victim’s death in Count Three relate only to the elements of the § 924(j) offense (causing death through use of a firearm in the course of a § 924(c) violation) and not to any aggravating element of the § 2114(a) predicate. He maintains that the § 924(j) elements should not be conflated with § 2114(a)'s aggravated offense elements.

He disputes that the text of Count One is properly incorporated into Count Three for purposes of identifying the predicate offense. Even if it is incorporated, he maintains that Count One does not, in his view, clearly establish which specific form of § 2114(a) he was convicted of, or that any particular aggravating circumstance was necessarily admitted in his guilty plea.

He contends that the aggravated variant of § 2114(a) is indivisible as between wounding, placing the victim's life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon, and committing a subsequent offense of mail robbery. Because, in his reading, one way of committing the aggravated variant (subsequent offense) does not require violent force, he argues that the entire aggravated variant cannot be treated as a categorical crime of violence.

He argues that because his § 2114(a) liability was based on aiding and abetting rather than acting as a principal, the offense, as applied to him, should not be treated as a crime of violence under § 924(c)(3)(A). He suggests that aiding-and-abetting liability can be premised on conduct that does not itself involve the direct use, attempted use, or threatened use of violent physical force, thereby undermining the classification of his conviction as a crime of violence.

He asserts that to succeed on his Davis-based § 2255 challenge, he need only show that the predicate offense could be committed without the requisite force, emphasizing the categorical nature of the inquiry, and he maintains that he has done so with respect to § 2114(a) as he interprets it.
appellee_arguments: The government argues that § 2114(a) is a divisible statute that sets out multiple distinct offenses. In its view, the text before the semicolon encompasses three simple variants: (1) robbery of a custodian of federal property, (2) assault of such a custodian with intent to rob, and (3) attempted robbery. The text after the semicolon sets out at least two distinct aggravated variants corresponding to (a) wounding the custodian while committing or attempting to commit the simple offense and (b) putting the custodian's life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon while committing or attempting to commit the simple offense. The reference to a subsequent offense, the government contends, is a sentencing factor enhancing punishment for any § 2114(a) offense based on recidivism, not a separate offense element.

From this framework, the government contends that the robbery-based, wounding-based, and putting-life-in-jeopardy-based § 2114(a) offenses each has as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of violent physical force. Therefore, each of those variants qualifies as a crime of violence under § 924(c)(3)(A)'s force clause. The government maintains that, so long as Forteza's predicate offense was one of these variants, it can properly support his § 924(j) conviction.

The government contends that the Shepard documents, including the indictment and plea record, show that Forteza's predicate § 2114(a) offense was an aggravated variant involving wounding the victim and putting his life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon. It emphasizes that Count Three expressly identifies the predicate crime of violence as the § 2114(a) assault 'as set forth in Count One,' and that Count One specifically alleges that the victim was wounded and his life was put in jeopardy by being shot several times, causing his death. The government argues that this incorporation by reference makes clear which elements formed the basis of the conviction.

The government maintains that the plea agreement's integration clause does not preclude reliance on the indictment language because Count Three, which is part of the plea, expressly incorporates Count One's allegations. Therefore, the aggravating elements of wounding and placing the victim's life in jeopardy are within the four corners of the plea and were necessarily admitted by Forteza when he pleaded guilty to Count Three.

It argues that, under prior Circuit precedent, the aggravated portion of § 2114(a) (wounding or putting the victim’s life in jeopardy by a dangerous weapon) is divisible from the other statutory components and qualifies categorically as a crime of violence under § 924(c)(3)(A). The government contends that any argument to the contrary has already been rejected by the Circuit and that Forteza has not developed a new basis to distinguish his case.

As to aiding-and-abetting liability, the government relies on binding Circuit precedent holding that aiding and abetting a crime of violence is itself a crime of violence because an aider and abettor is punishable as a principal under 18 U.S.C. § 2 and must share the requisite intent and facilitate the commission of the substantive offense. It asserts that this precedent forecloses any argument that the aiding-and-abetting nature of Forteza's predicate § 2114(a) offense removes it from the crime-of-violence category.

The government argues overall that, even after Davis, Forteza’s § 924(j) conviction remains valid because the predicate § 2114(a) offense, as shown in the record, falls squarely within § 924(c)(3)(A)'s force clause, and that the district court correctly applied the categorical and modified categorical approaches in reaching that conclusion.

issue_1.reasoning: Whether a predicate offense qualifies as a § 924(c)(3)(A) crime of violence is a legal question reviewed de novo. The aggravated § 2114(a) variants that involve wounding the victim or putting the victim’s life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon inherently require the intentional use of violent physical force against the person of another. Post‑Davis, numerous circuits have held that such aggravated robbery-type offenses fall within the force clause. Given the indictment’s explicit allegation that the victim was shot several times, wounding him and putting his life in jeopardy, causing death, and that Count Three incorporates Count One “as set forth in Count One,” the predicate here is an aggravated § 2114(a) offense that necessarily includes violent force as an element. Accordingly, Davis does not invalidate the § 924(j) conviction, and the district court’s conclusion that the predicate is a crime of violence under § 924(c)(3)(A) is properly affirmed.

issue_2.standard_of_review: clear error (for which part of the statute formed the basis of conviction); de novo (for whether that offense is a crime of violence)
issue_2.reasoning: Using the modified categorical approach, the district court relied on Shepard documents—primarily the indictment and plea materials. Count Three, the count of conviction, expressly identifies the predicate as the § 2114(a) assault “as set forth in Count One,” and Count One in turn alleges that, in the course of the robbery, the custodian was wounded and his life was put in jeopardy when he was shot several times, resulting in his death. Forteza pled guilty to Count Three as drafted; there is no indication that any part of these incorporated allegations was disclaimed or modified at the plea. On this record, the finding that the predicate was the aggravated § 2114(a) variant involving wounding and jeopardy to life by a dangerous weapon is not clearly erroneous. Once that variant is identified, its crime‑of‑violence status is a legal question answered in the government’s favor (as in Issue 1).

issue_3.reasoning: Divisibility is a question of statutory interpretation reviewed de novo. The structure of § 2114(a) and the government’s reading align with how courts have generally treated similar robbery statutes: the basic offense (rob/assault/attempt to rob a custodian of federal property) is set out before the semicolon; distinct aggravated offenses (wounding the victim, or putting the victim’s life in jeopardy by use of a dangerous weapon during the basic offense) appear after the semicolon; and the ‘subsequent offense’ language functions as a recidivist enhancement rather than a separate, non‑violent means of committing an aggravated offense. Prior First Circuit precedent has treated the aggravated portion (wounding/putting life in jeopardy by a dangerous weapon) as divisible and as defining a separate aggravated offense. In light of that precedent and the statute’s text and penalties, the panel will almost certainly hold that the aggravated variants are divisible from the simple offense and that the “subsequent offense” clause is a sentencing factor, not an alternative non‑violent element. Thus, the court may isolate the wounding/jeopardy‑by‑weapon variant and assess it under § 924(c)(3)(A).

issue_4.reasoning: Whether aiding‑and‑abetting liability affects crime‑of‑violence status is a legal question governed by circuit precedent. Under 18 U.S.C. § 2, an aider and abettor is punishable as a principal, and First Circuit authority—consistent with the majority of circuits—holds that aiding and abetting a crime of violence is itself a crime of violence because the elements of the substantive offense define the predicate for § 924(c), and aiding and abetting does not alter those elements. The aider and abettor must share the requisite intent and facilitate the commission of the underlying violent offense; the inquiry for § 924(c)(3)(A) focuses on the elements of that offense, not on whether a particular accomplice personally performed the violent act. The district court correctly treated Forteza’s aiding‑and‑abetting conviction under § 2114(a) as no different from a principal conviction for crime‑of‑violence purposes.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The key to the appeal is whether, after Davis, Forteza’s § 924(j) conviction can still rest on a valid § 924(c) predicate. The Shepard documents make clear that the predicate was an aggravated § 2114(a) offense in which the custodian of federal funds was shot several times, wounding him and putting his life in jeopardy, causing death. Under the modified categorical approach, that aggravated variant is properly isolated and treated as a distinct offense. The aggravated wounding/jeopardy‑by‑weapon variant of § 2114(a) necessarily involves the use of violent physical force and thus qualifies under § 924(c)(3)(A)’s force clause. First Circuit precedent supports both the divisibility of § 2114(a) and the treatment of its aggravated portion as a categorical crime of violence, as well as the rule that aiding and abetting such a crime remains a crime of violence. Given those precedents and the factual allegations incorporated into the count of conviction, the district court’s denial of § 2255 relief is likely to be fully affirmed on all issues.

parties.appellant: Angel Diaz, state prisoner and petitioner in a federal habeas corpus proceeding under 28 U.S.C. § 2254
parties.appellee: Marlyn Kopp, Superintendent of Sing Sing Correctional Facility (successor custodian to the former Sullivan Correctional Facility superintendent), respondent in the habeas proceeding

stage1_summary.factual_background: Angel Diaz has been in the custody of the New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision (DOCCS) since September 5, 1990. In mid‑2020, during the COVID‑19 pandemic, Diaz was incarcerated at Sullivan Correctional Facility in Fallsburg, New York. Proceeding pro se, Diaz filed a federal habeas corpus petition on July 3, 2020, alleging that his continued incarceration in DOCCS custody during the COVID‑19 pandemic subjected him to unconstitutional conditions of confinement. Diaz asserted that, because of the "fundamental nature" of DOCCS prison environments, he and other prisoners were being "deliberately unnecessarily placed" at risk of contracting COVID‑19. He alleged that the physical layout and operation of New York state prisons made it impossible for inmates to practice effective social distancing or otherwise comply with public health measures necessary to mitigate the spread of COVID‑19. Diaz claimed he had high blood pressure and morbid obesity, conditions he alleged placed him at heightened risk of serious harm or death if he contracted COVID‑19. He contended that DOCCS had no plan to protect medically vulnerable inmates like him and that it would be "virtually impossible" for DOCCS to operate any of its facilities in a manner that would adequately protect him from COVID‑related risks. Based on those allegations, Diaz claimed that no DOCCS facility could constitutionally confine him during the pandemic and that the only adequate remedy for the alleged Eighth Amendment violations was his immediate release from DOCCS custody.

procedural_history.claims_brought: On July 3, 2020, Diaz filed a pro se petition in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York under 28 U.S.C. § 2254, seeking a writ of habeas corpus. He asserted that his incarceration in DOCCS facilities during the COVID‑19 pandemic violated the Eighth Amendment because the State could not provide constitutionally adequate conditions of confinement in any of its facilities, given his medical vulnerabilities and the alleged impossibility of ensuring safe COVID‑19 mitigation measures in prison. He requested immediate release from custody as the sole remedy. Diaz simultaneously pursued a state habeas petition and, while he exhausted his state remedies, the federal petition was stayed.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: After Diaz exhausted state remedies, the federal District Court (Judge Román) lifted the stay and referred the § 2254 petition to a magistrate judge. The magistrate judge recommended that the petition be denied on the ground that Diaz’s claim was not cognizable in habeas corpus and instead had to be brought, if at all, as a civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, because it challenged only conditions of confinement rather than the validity or duration of his conviction or sentence. Diaz objected to the recommendation. The District Court adopted the magistrate judge’s reasoning and held that Diaz’s petition did not state a cognizable habeas claim because he was not challenging the validity of his confinement or the duration of his sentence; rather, he was complaining about the circumstances and conditions of confinement. The court indicated that to the extent Diaz sought relief other than release from custody based on those allegations, he could pursue such relief in a separate § 1983 civil action. The District Court dismissed the § 2254 petition and denied Diaz a certificate of appealability.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Diaz sought to appeal the District Court’s dismissal of his § 2254 petition and its conclusion that his challenge to allegedly unconstitutional COVID‑19‑related conditions of confinement could not proceed via federal habeas corpus. The Second Circuit granted a certificate of appealability in 2023, limited to the question whether the District Court properly concluded that Diaz’s request for release from prison, based on alleged unconstitutional conditions of confinement, must proceed under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and not under habeas corpus. After the certificate was granted and Diaz, now represented by appointed counsel, filed his opening brief, Sullivan Correctional Facility was closed and Diaz was transferred to Sing Sing Correctional Facility. The State did not seek prior permission from the Court of Appeals under Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 23(a) before transferring Diaz. The case caption initially continued to name the former Sullivan superintendent as respondent; the Court later directed the Clerk to amend the caption to substitute the Superintendent of Sing Sing as respondent. On appeal, there were also threshold disputes about mootness in light of Diaz’s transfer and the closing of Sullivan, and about whether Diaz’s originally pro se petition properly alleged a system‑wide challenge to confinement in any DOCCS facility or instead challenged only conditions at Sullivan.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether a state prisoner’s claim that alleged unconstitutional conditions of confinement arising from the COVID‑19 pandemic require his release from all available DOCCS facilities is cognizable under 28 U.S.C. § 2254 as a habeas corpus claim, or whether such a claim must instead be brought exclusively under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 as a civil rights action challenging prison conditions.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Supreme Court precedent, habeas corpus is the exclusive federal remedy for a state prisoner who challenges the fact or duration of confinement and seeks immediate or speedier release (e.g., Preiser v. Rodriguez; Heck v. Humphrey), while 42 U.S.C. § 1983 is generally used to challenge conditions of confinement. The Supreme Court has described challenges to the very fact or duration of custody as lying within the 'core of habeas' (e.g., Wilkinson v. Dotson). The unresolved question, noted in cases such as Preiser, Boumediene v. Bush, and Ziglar v. Abbasi, is the extent to which conditions‑of‑confinement challenges that, if successful, would necessarily require release can be pursued via habeas corpus. The Second Circuit also applies a rule that pro se pleadings must be liberally construed to raise the strongest arguments they suggest.

issues_on_appeal.description: Assuming Diaz’s claim is cognizable in habeas, whether his petition sufficiently alleged, in a non‑conclusory and factually plausible manner, that (a) his medical conditions placed him at an extreme risk of serious harm or death from COVID‑19, and (b) DOCCS was incapable of providing constitutionally adequate protection from COVID‑19 in any of its facilities, such that his continued confinement necessarily violated the Eighth Amendment and required his release.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To state a claim for habeas relief under § 2254, the petitioner must allege facts showing that he is 'in custody in violation of the Constitution or laws or treaties of the United States' (28 U.S.C. § 2254(a)). Petitions must contain specific factual allegations, not merely conclusory assertions, sufficient to make the claim plausible; conclusory allegations are insufficient. See Rules Governing § 2254 Cases, Rules 2(c)(2) and 4; Dory v. Commissioner of Correction of State of N.Y. (requiring factual detail sufficient to avoid summary dismissal). Under Eighth Amendment standards for conditions‑of‑confinement claims, a prisoner must typically show (1) an objectively serious risk of harm and (2) that prison officials acted with deliberate indifference to inmate health or safety.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Diaz’s transfer from Sullivan Correctional Facility to Sing Sing Correctional Facility, and the subsequent closure of Sullivan, rendered his appeal moot, and how his originally pro se petition should be construed in light of later representations by appointed counsel on appeal.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Article III of the Constitution limits federal courts to live cases or controversies. A case becomes moot when events occur that make it impossible for the court to grant any effective relief. In the Second Circuit, an inmate’s transfer from a prison facility generally moots claims for declaratory or injunctive relief directed at officials of the transferring facility (e.g., McCray v. Lee; Thompson v. Choinski). There is an exception to mootness for disputes 'capable of repetition, yet evading review,' which requires that (1) the challenged action is, by its nature, too short in duration to be fully litigated before cessation, and (2) there is a reasonable expectation that the same complaining party will be subjected to the same action again. Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 23(a) governs transfer of custody of a habeas petitioner during the pendency of an appeal and generally requires that the custodian not transfer custody without court permission if the petitioner seeks release and the matter is pending on appeal. Courts also must liberally construe pro se filings, while respecting the principle of party presentation when litigants are represented by counsel.

appellant_arguments: Diaz contends that his claim is properly brought as a habeas corpus petition under 28 U.S.C. § 2254 because he challenges the legality of his continued confinement itself, not merely the conditions in a particular facility. He argues that, due to the COVID‑19 pandemic and his specific medical vulnerabilities (high blood pressure and morbid obesity), any continued incarceration in a DOCCS facility subjects him to a substantial risk of serious harm that constitutes cruel and unusual punishment. Because, as alleged, no set of conditions in any DOCCS facility can adequately mitigate that risk, he maintains that the only constitutionally sufficient remedy is his release from custody, which places his claim at the 'core of habeas.'

He emphasizes that as the master of his petition he has limited his request for relief to release from custody, rather than seeking changes to prison conditions or damages, and that this requested remedy confirms that the appropriate vehicle is habeas rather than a § 1983 civil rights action. He also invokes the principle that pro se pleadings must be liberally construed, arguing that the District Court should have read his petition as raising the strongest possible argument—that his confinement in any DOCCS facility during the pandemic is unconstitutional—rather than narrowly as a conditions claim specific to Sullivan.

On the merits of his Eighth Amendment theory, Diaz maintains that his underlying health conditions significantly increase his risk of severe illness or death from COVID‑19, and that DOCCS has no adequate plan to protect medically vulnerable inmates from infection given the inherently congregate and restrictive nature of prison environments. He asserts, in general terms, that effective social distancing and other mitigation measures are impossible in New York state prisons and that, as a result, his continued custody during the pandemic is inherently unsafe and unconstitutional.

As to mootness, Diaz argues that his transfer from Sullivan to Sing Sing and the closure of Sullivan do not moot his claim because his petition challenges system‑wide DOCCS confinement during the COVID‑19 pandemic, not only conditions at Sullivan. He contends that the relief he seeks—release from DOCCS custody—remains available despite the transfer, and that the case therefore presents a live controversy. He further notes that DOCCS transferred him without first seeking permission from the Court of Appeals under Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 23(a), and he urges that such a transfer should not be allowed to defeat appellate jurisdiction or moot his claim. Alternatively, in some of his briefing he suggests that resolution of the habeas‑versus‑§ 1983 question is important to provide guidance to similarly situated prisoners and that the Court should address that statutory question notwithstanding changes in his institutional placement.
appellee_arguments: The State argues that Diaz’s claims are not cognizable in a habeas corpus petition under § 2254 because they challenge only the conditions of his confinement and not the validity of his conviction, the lawfulness of the sentence imposed, or the fact or duration of his custody in the conventional sense. According to the State, challenges to prison conditions—including claims about medical care, exposure to communicable diseases, and facility‑specific practices—must be brought, if at all, in a civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, not via federal habeas. The State relies on the District Court’s view that Diaz is complaining about the circumstances of confinement rather than the basic legality or length of custody.

On jurisdiction and mootness, the State contends that events occurring after Diaz filed his petition have rendered the case moot. It asserts that Diaz’s petition, properly understood, challenges conditions specific to Sullivan Correctional Facility 'under pandemic conditions.' Since Sullivan has been closed and Diaz transferred to another institution, the State argues that the Court of Appeals can no longer grant effective relief directed at those conditions or that facility. The State emphasizes that prison wardens do not control conditions at facilities they do not manage, and thus a writ directed to the former Sullivan superintendent would not provide Diaz any practical relief. It cites circuit precedent holding that an inmate’s transfer from a facility generally moots claims for injunctive or declaratory relief against officials of the transferring facility.

The State also previously moved to dismiss the appeal on the ground that the factual circumstances surrounding the COVID‑19 pandemic had 'dramatically changed' since Diaz filed his petition, arguing that these changed conditions undermined the basis for his claim of ongoing unconstitutional risk. It maintains that Diaz has not alleged any specific facts about current conditions or COVID‑19‑related risks at Sing Sing or at other DOCCS facilities, and therefore any system‑wide challenge is unsupported. In its view, Diaz’s allegations are conclusory and speculative, lacking concrete factual detail or evidence regarding DOCCS’s current policies, mitigation measures, or the actual risk posed to Diaz at his present facility.

With respect to the sufficiency of the pleading, the State contends that Diaz’s petition does not meet the requirements of the Rules Governing § 2254 Cases because it offers only generalized assertions about prison environments and DOCCS’s alleged inability to protect vulnerable inmates. The State argues that, even if such a theory could in principle support habeas relief, Diaz failed to allege specific facts demonstrating that no DOCCS facility can safely house him or that DOCCS officials are acting with deliberate indifference to a substantial risk of serious harm. The State also raises federalism and statutory concerns, suggesting that allowing state prisoners to challenge conditions via habeas in this manner could circumvent limitations and remedial structures in the Prison Litigation Reform Act that apply to § 1983 conditions‑of‑confinement lawsuits.

issue_1.reasoning: Whether a claim is cognizable in habeas is a legal question reviewed de novo. Diaz does not challenge a single prison’s day‑to‑day operations but alleges that, given his medical vulnerabilities and the nature of DOCCS facilities during the pandemic, the State cannot constitutionally confine him anywhere and that the only possible remedy is release. Supreme Court cases (Preiser, Heck, Wilkinson) distinguish challenges to the ‘fact or duration’ of custody—core habeas—from conditions‑of‑confinement suits under § 1983, but they leave open whether some conditions claims that necessarily require release may proceed in habeas. Here Diaz seeks only release and alleges that no set of conditions in any DOCCS facility can constitutionally confine him. That is best understood as a challenge to the legality of his custody itself, not merely to prison conditions at a particular facility. Especially given the obligation to construe his pro se petition liberally, the appellate court is likely to hold that such a claim is cognizable in habeas and that the district court erred in dismissing on the categorical ground that conditions‑of‑confinement claims can never proceed under § 2254 when the sole requested relief is release.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether the petition states a claim sufficient to survive summary dismissal under Rules 2(c)(2) and 4 of the § 2254 Rules is reviewed de novo. Even assuming cognizability, Diaz must plead specific, non‑conclusory facts showing he is in custody in violation of the Constitution and that release necessarily follows. His petition offers generalized assertions: that prisons inherently preclude effective social distancing, that DOCCS lacks an adequate plan, and that it would be ‘virtually impossible’ to protect him anywhere. He alleges only that he has high blood pressure and morbid obesity, without concrete factual detail about (1) the actual COVID‑19 conditions and mitigation measures in DOCCS at the time; (2) specific failures by officials evidencing deliberate indifference; or (3) why no facility or combination of measures could constitutionally house him. Under Eighth Amendment standards and pleading requirements (Dory and the § 2254 Rules), such broad, speculative allegations are insufficient to plausibly show that no constitutionally adequate confinement is possible and that release is the only remedy. The court is therefore likely to affirm the denial of the petition on the alternative ground that it fails to state a plausible constitutional claim warranting habeas relief.

issue_3.reasoning: Mootness is a jurisdictional question reviewed de novo. Diaz seeks release from DOCCS custody based on alleged system‑wide unconstitutionality of his confinement during the pandemic; his transfer from Sullivan to Sing Sing and the closure of Sullivan do not extinguish the possibility of that relief. Article III mootness rules for conditions claims against a particular facility or warden (McCray, Thompson) are less apt where the relief sought—release—operates on the custodian having current custody, who has been substituted under Rule 23. The transfer does not make it impossible to grant effective relief; the court can still order release if a violation is shown. The State’s objection goes more to the sufficiency of Diaz’s system‑wide allegations than to mootness. Although evolving pandemic conditions might undercut the merits, they do not eliminate the live controversy about the legality of his ongoing custody. The court is likely to hold that the appeal is not moot and that the improper failure to seek leave under Rule 23(a) cannot be used to defeat appellate jurisdiction.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The panel is likely to reject the district court’s broad categorical ruling that Diaz’s claim cannot proceed in habeas simply because it arises from conditions of confinement; given his exclusive request for release and his allegation that no DOCCS facility can constitutionally house him, the claim fits within the class of custody‑legality challenges that can be cognizable in habeas when the only possible remedy is release. That legal question is reviewed de novo, and Supreme Court precedent leaves room for such claims. The appeal is not moot because Diaz remains in DOCCS custody and the court can still order the release he seeks; transfer and facility closure affect only facility‑specific injunctive claims, not a system‑wide challenge to the legality of custody itself. However, even with liberal construction of his pro se pleading, Diaz’s habeas petition is thin and conclusory. It does not contain the specific factual allegations about DOCCS’s actual COVID‑19 measures, conditions at facilities, or deliberate indifference necessary to plausibly show that no DOCCS facility could constitutionally confine him and that release is required. Under § 2254 and the Eighth Amendment standards, the appellate court can affirm denial of the writ on that alternative ground while clarifying the availability of habeas for this narrow kind of claim. The resulting disposition is mixed: the court reverses the district court’s reasoning on cognizability and mootness but ultimately affirms the denial of habeas relief because the petition fails on the merits or at the pleading stage, leaving the overall judgment (no habeas relief) intact but on different grounds.

parties.appellant: Martin Flanagan, qui tam relator and original plaintiff under the False Claims Act
parties.appellee: Fresenius Medical Care Holdings, Inc., d/b/a Fresenius Medical Care North America, original defendant

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Fresenius Medical Care Holdings, Inc. is the largest dialysis services provider in the United States, treating nearly 190,000 patients annually in about 2,400 outpatient dialysis clinics. Chronic kidney disease involves progressive loss of kidney function; end-stage renal disease (ESRD), or stage 5 chronic kidney disease, requires dialysis or transplant. At the end of 2017, approximately 750,000 patients in the United States had ESRD. Many ESRD patients undergo regular dialysis, often three times per week at outpatient clinics, and may receive injectable medications during treatment.

The federal government finances a large portion of ESRD treatment through Medicare and Medicaid. All ESRD patients are eligible for Medicare, administered by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS). Medicare is the primary payer for more than 80% of ESRD patients' dialysis costs, with annual expenditures exceeding $40 billion. Medicare reimburses outpatient dialysis providers at a composite monthly rate per patient, covering dialysis treatments, certain laboratory tests, and drugs. Providers submit one monthly reimbursement claim per patient, which includes various data; CMS contractors process and pay these claims directly to ESRD treatment facilities. Dialysis facilities must also submit annual Medicare cost reports certifying compliance with applicable laws and regulations and reporting information such as medical directors’ hours.

Medicaid, jointly funded by federal and state governments and administered by states under federal oversight, pays costs for some ESRD patients who do not qualify for Medicare or for services not covered by Medicare. States submit forms to CMS seeking federal matching funds, including data arising from Medicaid claims. The federal government may later recoup any improperly paid funds by reducing future payments to the state.

Martin Flanagan worked for Fresenius for about twenty-nine years, most recently as Director of Acute Market Development for its Western Business Unit. In that role, he negotiated contracts under which Fresenius provided dialysis to hospital inpatients and, according to his allegations, observed an extensive kickback scheme designed to induce referrals of ESRD patients to Fresenius outpatient clinics.

According to the amended complaint, Flanagan alleges several categories of conduct by Fresenius intended to induce referrals:

1. **Hospital contracts**: Beginning around 2007, Fresenius sought exclusive contracts with hospitals to provide inpatient dialysis care. Mid-level managers, including Flanagan, were instructed to obtain hospital contracts "at any cost" because such contracts were allegedly important for securing referrals of discharged inpatients to Fresenius outpatient clinics. To induce hospitals to contract, Fresenius allegedly accepted below-cost rates, limited fees that would otherwise be passed to hospitals, and declined to enforce certain cost-increasing provisions, thereby budgeting for and incurring losses on some contracts with larger hospitals. Internal messaging to marketing directors in 2009–2010 allegedly emphasized that losing a hospital contract meant losing referrals. When Flanagan raised concerns in 2010 that below-cost contracts appeared to be purchasing referrals, he was told not to complain and that such contracts reflected standard business practice. Flanagan alleges that other employees nationwide had similar experiences when raising concerns.

2. **Medical director relationships**: Fresenius separately contracted with hospital nephrologists to serve as medical directors for its outpatient dialysis facilities, a role required by Medicare regulations, which call for a medical director to devote sufficient time to clinic oversight (with regulatory guidance suggesting roughly one-quarter of a standard 40-hour workweek). Flanagan alleges Fresenius targeted physicians who could refer large numbers of patients, compensated them at levels often more than double those paid by its primary competitor in the same localities, and informally tied compensation to the size and growth of the clinics' patient census. Fresenius allegedly reported medical directors as working 8–10 hours per week but did not require time records. Based on his observations, Flanagan alleges that medical directors in practice spent little or no time at the clinics and often only performed brief monthly document reviews requiring a signature. He also alleges Fresenius did not track the services performed. Medical director contracts contained non-compete, non-solicitation, and non-disparagement provisions; directors seeking to leave allegedly had to negotiate buyouts of the non-compete provisions.

3. **Free or below-cost services to hospitals and physicians**: The amended complaint alleges that Fresenius provided various free or below-cost services to hospitals and physician practices, characterized as benefits intended to secure referrals. These include:
   - The "Bridge Program," which provided free services to hospitals, including a Fresenius employee to perform certain tasks and to channel ESRD patients to Fresenius outpatient clinics. The services allegedly had an annual value exceeding $10,000 per hospital.
   - A "Treatment Options Program," framed as an educational program for interested hospitals, physicians, and community organizations but also allegedly used to promote Fresenius outpatient services.
   - "Value added services" or "services beyond the rate" for hospitals and patients, such as free nursing services, in-service training, transportation to and from dialysis treatments, and patient education.
   - "Practice management services" offered to physician practices at free or below-cost rates, including specialty advisory services and technology solutions, and a free recruiting service for nephrology fellows and practicing physicians. Fresenius allegedly communicated to participating physicians that early referrals to Fresenius clinics could be profitable for their practices. Some physicians using these services entered into Confidentiality Agreements and Business Associate Agreements, pursuant to which Fresenius provided additional free resources.

4. **Lease arrangements**: Fresenius allegedly entered into long-term, guaranteed leases at above–fair-market rental rates for office space in physician-owned buildings, with terms sometimes extending 15 years and including annual escalators. Conversely, when leasing office space in buildings it owned to its medical directors, Fresenius allegedly provided below–fair-market rental rates.

5. **Joint venture agreements**: Starting in 2007, Fresenius began forming joint ventures with nephrologists and other physicians to co-own and co-manage outpatient dialysis facilities, giving partners a share of profits and losses. Fresenius allegedly expected and pressured joint-venture partners to refer patients to the jointly owned clinics, and the agreements included non-compete clauses that made it difficult for physicians to leave the ventures.

Flanagan characterizes the above practices collectively as a fraudulent kickback scheme aimed at increasing referrals to Fresenius outpatient dialysis clinics and generating claims to federal healthcare programs.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
In March 2014, Flanagan filed a sealed qui tam complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland under the False Claims Act (FCA), 31 U.S.C. § 3729(a)(1)(A) and (B). He alleged that Fresenius (1) knowingly presented, or caused to be presented, false or fraudulent claims for payment to federal healthcare programs by operating an illegal kickback scheme, and (2) knowingly made or used false records or statements material to such false or fraudulent claims. The alleged predicate violations included offers or payments of remuneration to hospitals and physicians in violation of the Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS), 42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b(b), to induce referrals for services reimbursable by Medicare and Medicaid. The original complaint allegedly satisfied the FCA’s filing requirements by being filed under seal and providing notice to the government.

The complaint remained sealed while the Department of Justice investigated and decided whether to intervene. In June 2020, the United States declined to intervene, and the complaint was unsealed. In January 2021, Fresenius moved to dismiss. In February 2021, in response, Flanagan filed an amended complaint. The amended complaint reasserted FCA claims under §§ 3729(a)(1)(A) and (B) and added more than 100 pages of new factual allegations and additional schemes not described in the original complaint, including detailed allegations about joint ventures, free services, and other financial arrangements.

In the amended complaint, Flanagan alleged that Fresenius defrauded the government by: (a) knowingly offering remuneration to hospitals in the form of no-cost or below-cost items and services (including free discharge planners and other support) in connection with inpatient dialysis for ESRD patients, at least one purpose of which was allegedly to secure outpatient referrals to Fresenius clinics, in violation of the AKS and outside any safe harbor; and (b) knowingly offering remuneration to physicians, at least in part to reward or induce referrals to Fresenius outpatient clinics, including through medical director agreements allegedly above fair market value or commercially unreasonable, free patient education and practice management services, lease agreements alleged to be commercially unreasonable and not at fair market value, and joint-venture arrangements in outpatient dialysis clinics that were allegedly commercially unreasonable and not at fair market value.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
After transfer of venue, the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts addressed several issues raised by Fresenius in a renewed motion to dismiss under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 9(b), 12(b)(1), and 12(b)(6).

The district court first examined FCA pre-suit filing requirements under 31 U.S.C. § 3730(b)(2). It noted that the original complaint, which had been filed under seal and provided to the government, complied with those requirements. The amended complaint, however, added approximately 125 pages of allegations and multiple new claims, including those relating to joint ventures and provisions of free services to physicians and hospitals, but was not filed under seal and was not served on the government for a new intervention decision. The court concluded that the new claims in the amended complaint did not satisfy the FCA’s mandatory filing prerequisites and dismissed them on that basis.

As an alternative basis as to the joint venture claims, the district court found they were also barred by the FCA’s public-disclosure bar, 31 U.S.C. § 3730(e)(4), and the first-to-file rule, 31 U.S.C. § 3730(b)(5). The court compared Flanagan’s joint venture allegations to those in an earlier case, United States ex rel. CKD Project v. Fresenius Med. Care Holdings, which had been filed and unsealed prior to Flanagan’s amended complaint. The court determined that the earlier complaint publicly disclosed substantially similar joint-venture allegations, that Flanagan’s new allegations did not materially add to those public disclosures for purposes of the public-disclosure bar, and that the same alleged scheme had already been the subject of the prior action for purposes of the first-to-file rule. The court held these were additional grounds barring the new joint venture claims.

Independently, the district court addressed whether the amended complaint satisfied Rule 9(b)’s heightened pleading standard for fraud. It found that, although the pleading was lengthy and detailed concerning the general operation of government reimbursement programs and Fresenius’s alleged kickback scheme, it failed to include particularized allegations of specific false claims submitted for payment. With respect to Medicare claims, which Fresenius submitted directly to the federal government, the court observed that the amended complaint did not identify any specific false claim, nor did it provide representative or sample claims illustrating falsity and connection to the alleged schemes. The court also questioned whether the amended complaint sufficiently alleged causation between the alleged AKS violations and the submission of claims under the FCA’s "resulting from" language, but it ultimately resolved the motion on Rule 9(b) grounds, determining that the complaint did not describe the false claims, or the alleged false records and statements, with the requisite specificity. The court therefore dismissed the remaining FCA claims for failure to satisfy Rule 9(b).

In January 2023, Flanagan moved for reconsideration and sought leave to file a second amended complaint. The district court denied both motions. Regarding leave to amend, the court noted the case’s age (nearly nine years), the fact that Fresenius had filed three motions to dismiss challenging the lack of particularized false-claim allegations, and the absence of a timely corrective amendment. The court characterized the delay as extensive and found that allowing another amendment at that point would cause prejudice to Fresenius, citing both the length of the litigation and the repeated failure to cure identified deficiencies. On that basis, it denied the motion to amend.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Flanagan filed a timely notice of appeal challenging three district court orders: (1) the order granting Fresenius’s motion to dismiss his amended complaint; (2) the order denying his motion for reconsideration; and (3) the order denying his motion for leave to file a second amended complaint. On appeal, he contends that the district court erred in dismissing his FCA claims under Rule 9(b) and related pleading standards and abused its discretion in denying leave to amend.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the amended complaint in this FCA qui tam action adequately alleged, with the particularity required by Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 9(b), that Fresenius submitted or caused the submission of false or fraudulent claims or false records/statements to federal healthcare programs based on alleged AKS violations, including whether it sufficiently pled but-for causation for claims asserted under the "resulting from" theory.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A Rule 12(b)(6) dismissal is reviewed de novo, separating well-pleaded factual allegations from conclusory statements and determining whether the facts plausibly support liability. Fraud claims, including FCA claims, are subject to Rule 9(b)’s heightened pleading requirement, which demands that the circumstances constituting fraud be stated with particularity (the "who, what, when, where, and how" of the alleged fraud). Under the FCA, 31 U.S.C. § 3729(a)(1)(A) and (B), a plaintiff must allege knowing presentation of false or fraudulent claims or knowing use of false records or statements material to such claims. For FCA liability predicated on AKS violations under 42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b(g), and under this circuit’s interpretation, the "resulting from" language requires but-for causation—that the claim would not have been submitted but for the illegal kickback. For false-record/false-statement claims under § 3729(a)(1)(B), the plaintiff must allege that the defendant knowingly made or used a false record or statement material to a false or fraudulent claim and intended the government to rely on that false statement as a condition of payment.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion in denying Flanagan’s post-judgment motion for leave to file a second amended complaint after dismissal of the amended complaint.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Denials of leave to amend are reviewed for abuse of discretion. Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(a), leave to amend should be freely given when justice so requires, but may be denied for reasons such as undue delay, bad faith, dilatory motive, repeated failure to cure deficiencies by prior amendments, undue prejudice to the opposing party, or futility. Courts in this circuit recognize that even undue delay alone can justify denial and disfavor a "wait and see" approach in which a plaintiff, having sufficient information, withholds amendments until after an adverse ruling on an earlier complaint.

appellant_arguments: Flanagan argues that the district court misapplied Rule 9(b) and the FCA pleading standards. He contends that the amended complaint, which added extensive details concerning Fresenius’s relationships with hospitals and physicians, sufficiently described the structure, purposes, and operation of the alleged kickback scheme and its connection to government reimbursement. He maintains that the complaint adequately identified the types of claims submitted to Medicare and Medicaid and the mechanisms by which allegedly tainted referrals resulted in dialysis treatments billed to federal programs, thereby meeting the particularity requirements for FCA claims.

Regarding causation under the AKS "resulting from" theory, Flanagan initially argued that but-for causation was not required but, after this circuit’s intervening decision in United States v. Regeneron Pharms., Inc., acknowledges that but-for causation is the governing standard. He contends, however, that the amended complaint meets this standard by alleging specific compensation relationships with particular physicians that were designed to and did, in fact, induce referrals, focusing in particular on allegations relating to one physician (Dr. Stephen Tilles), his roles as medical director, his compensation, and the volume of referrals attributed to him.

On his false-record/false-statement theory under 31 U.S.C. § 3729(a)(1)(B), Flanagan asserts that the complaint alleges Fresenius’s annual cost reports and certifications falsely represented compliance with the AKS and misstated medical directors’ hours, and that Fresenius intended the government to rely on these documents as conditions of payment. He argues that such allegations are sufficient to state a claim without separately pleading but-for causation, because this subsection does not incorporate the "resulting from" language.

As to the denial of leave to amend, Flanagan contends the district court abused its discretion by focusing on the age of the case rather than actual prejudice to Fresenius or the absence of justification for delay. He emphasizes that no discovery had taken place and no trial date had been set, so permitting amendment would not meaningfully prejudice Fresenius. He further argues that he only obtained critical claims data necessary to plead the false claims and causation elements after the district court granted the motion to dismiss, so he could not reasonably have made the proposed amendments earlier.
appellee_arguments: Fresenius argues that the amended complaint fails to satisfy Rule 9(b) because it does not identify specific false claims submitted to Medicare or Medicaid that were tainted by the alleged kickback arrangements. Fresenius contends that detailed descriptions of corporate practices and generalized assertions about how claims are typically submitted are not sufficient; the relator must plead representative claims or equivalent particularized facts linking the alleged kickbacks to actual claims for payment.

On causation, Fresenius maintains that, under the AKS and this circuit’s decision in Regeneron, Flanagan was required to plead facts showing that the alleged kickbacks were the but-for cause of specific claims. Fresenius asserts that the complaint alleges, at most, correlation between financial relationships and referrals, but does not allege that any physician (including Dr. Tilles) would not have referred patients to Fresenius absent the challenged arrangements, nor that any identified claims would not have been submitted but for the alleged remuneration.

Regarding the false-record/false-statement theory under § 3729(a)(1)(B), Fresenius argues that the complaint lacks particular allegations of what specific statements or certifications it submitted, how they were false, and how they were material to payment decisions, beyond broad assertions that it submitted cost reports and certifications annually. It contends that generalized allegations of intent to bill federal programs for all treatments, combined with high-level descriptions of regulatory forms, do not meet Rule 9(b) standards.

On the motion to amend, Fresenius argues that the district court acted within its discretion in denying leave due to undue delay and prejudice. Fresenius notes that the litigation had been pending for nearly nine years; that it had filed three motions to dismiss, each highlighting the absence of particularized false-claim allegations; and that Flanagan failed to cure these deficiencies despite having ample notice of them. Fresenius maintains that allowing yet another amendment after dismissal would unfairly prolong the litigation and increase costs, and that Flanagan did not adequately explain when he sought the claims data or why it could not have been obtained and incorporated earlier.

issue_1.reasoning:
Under de novo review, the amended complaint must satisfy Rule 9(b) by pleading with particularity the existence of false or fraudulent claims (or false records/statements) and, for AKS-based theories under § 3729(a)(1)(A), but-for causation between the kickbacks and those claims. The complaint, as described, is long and detailed about Fresenius’s business practices and alleged kickback structures, but the district court found (and the appellee emphasizes) that it did not identify specific false claims or provide representative examples with the necessary who/what/when/where/how tying the schemes to actual Medicare/Medicaid claims. Post‑Regeneron, this circuit requires but-for causation under the AKS “resulting from” language; the allegations about Dr. Tilles and others appear to show correlations (financial ties plus large referral volumes) rather than facts plausibly indicating that, absent the remuneration, specific claims would not have been submitted. That kind of inferential gap typically leads courts in FCA cases to affirm Rule 9(b) dismissals. 

For the § 3729(a)(1)(B) false‑record/false‑statement theory, the relator still must plead the particulars of the false statements and their materiality to payment. The summary indicates only generalized assertions that annual cost reports and certifications falsely represented AKS compliance and medical directors’ hours, without specific identification of which reports, what precise misstatements they contained, and how those misstatements were material to any particular payment decision. Appellate courts regularly treat such generalized descriptions as inadequate under Rule 9(b). Given the complaint’s failure to tie detailed scheme allegations to particular false claims or concretely described false records, and the circuit’s relatively strict approach in FCA/AKS pleading post‑Regeneron, the most likely result is that the appellate court agrees with the district court that Rule 9(b) is not satisfied and affirms dismissal on that ground without needing to disturb the district court’s causation discussion.

issue_2.reasoning:
The district court denied leave to file a second amended complaint after dismissal, citing the age of the case (nearly nine years), multiple prior motions to dismiss that had consistently flagged the absence of particularized false‑claim allegations, and the relator’s repeated failure to cure those deficiencies. Within this circuit, undue delay and repeated failure to fix identified problems are accepted grounds to deny leave, even apart from concrete trial-prejudice, and courts disfavor a wait‑and‑see strategy in which a plaintiff withholds stronger factual allegations until after losing on a motion to dismiss. Here, the court made an on‑the‑record, case‑specific assessment: it highlighted both the long pendency and the relator’s history of not curing the same defect. That is well within the range of reasonable discretionary judgments.

The relator’s argument that there was no real prejudice because there had been no discovery and no trial date, and that he obtained claims data only after dismissal, is unlikely to carry the day. Appellate courts typically require a concrete explanation of why critical information could not have been obtained earlier with diligence, and the record as summarized indicates the district court was not persuaded on that point. Given the deferential abuse‑of‑discretion standard and the presence of classic Rule 15(a) factors (undue delay; repeated failure to cure), the appellate court is likely to hold that the denial of leave to amend was within the district court’s discretion and affirm.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
Both issues present patterns that appellate courts often resolve in favor of affirmance. On the Rule 9(b) question, the amended complaint is described as rich in ‘scheme’ detail but thin on specific tainted claims and on concrete, particularized false statements in cost reports and certifications. In this circuit, FCA complaints are frequently dismissed where they do not identify actual claims or provide representative examples, especially after an intervening decision (Regeneron) has clarified a stringent but‑for causation requirement for AKS‑based FCA theories. The appellant’s reliance on broad descriptions of business practices, coupled with an emphasis on overall referral volumes and one exemplar physician, is unlikely to satisfy those standards on de novo review.

On the amendment issue, the record reflects nearly a decade of litigation, three dismissal motions highlighting the same core defect, and a district court that expressly grounded its denial in undue delay, repeated failure to cure, and prejudice from further extension. Under the abuse‑of‑discretion standard, and given this circuit’s willingness to affirm denials of leave based on delay and repeated deficiencies alone, it is improbable that an appellate panel would find an abuse. Accordingly, the most plausible overall outcome is that the First Circuit (or the relevant circuit) affirms the dismissal and the denial of leave to amend in full.

parties.appellant: Eduardo Teles de Menezes (naturalized U.S. citizen; original plaintiff; sponsoring parent) and his son, Carlos Eduardo Rodrigues Menezes (noncitizen visa beneficiary; original plaintiff)
parties.appellee: Marco Rubio, in his official capacity as Secretary of State, and Ryan Rowlands, in his official capacity as Consul General of the U.S. Consulate General in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (federal officials; original defendants). The Secretary of State and Consul General were automatically substituted pursuant to Fed. R. App. P. 43(c)(2).

stage1_summary.factual_background:
The case concerns the family-based immigrant visa process for Carlos Eduardo Rodrigues Menezes, sponsored by his father, Eduardo Teles de Menezes.

Carlos, a noncitizen, was admitted to the United States on a tourist visa on January 20, 2013. He lived with his father Eduardo in Massachusetts for several years, attended and graduated from high school there, and later studied at Target International Student Center on a student visa.

On December 9, 2017, Eduardo obtained lawful permanent resident (LPR) status. On January 12, 2018, when Carlos was 20 years old, Eduardo filed a Form I-130, Petition for Alien Relative (the "Visa Petition"), with USCIS to sponsor Carlos for an immigrant visa in the F2A category (children under 21 of LPRs). USCIS approved the petition on August 12, 2019, after approximately one year and seven months of processing. At the time of approval, a visa number in the F2A category was immediately available for Carlos.

Following this approval and visa availability, Carlos submitted an immigrant visa application to the Department of State, and the U.S. Consulate in Rio de Janeiro scheduled him for an in-person immigrant visa interview on October 15, 2021.

Before that interview occurred, Eduardo naturalized as a U.S. citizen on May 27, 2021.

Carlos attended the scheduled consular interview in October 2021. Several months later, on March 4, 2022, the Rio de Janeiro consulate sent Carlos an email (the "March 4 Email"). The email stated that, based on Eduardo's naturalization date, Carlos was "not eligible for the Child Status Protection Act (CSPA) since he was over 21 years old when the petitioner naturalized." The email further stated that Carlos's application was now classified in the F1 category (adult sons and daughters of U.S. citizens) and that his visa category was "not current." It explained that applicants then being called for interviews in the F1 category were those whose petitions were filed on or before December 1, 2014, whereas Carlos's petition had been filed on January 12, 2018.

Carlos and Eduardo allege that, under the Child Status Protection Act (CSPA), Carlos remained a "child" (under 21 for statutory purposes) on the date of Eduardo's naturalization, despite his biological age having passed 21 during the process. They assert that, properly applying the CSPA age-calculation rules for F2A beneficiaries, Carlos's statutory age should have been treated as under 21 when Eduardo naturalized, so that the petition should have converted to the "immediate relative" category (children of U.S. citizens), which is not numerically capped and for which visas are always available. They contend that instead the government reclassified the petition into the F1 category, placing Carlos into a numerically capped queue with a much longer wait, thereby significantly delaying adjudication of his visa application.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
In 2023, Eduardo and Carlos filed the operative complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Secretary of State and the Consul General in Rio de Janeiro. They challenged the Department of State's and consulate's treatment of Eduardo's approved I-130 petition and Carlos's visa classification following Eduardo's naturalization.

The complaint:
- Identified as the relevant "final agency action" the reclassification of Eduardo's petition, as reflected in the March 4, 2022 consular email stating that Carlos was not CSPA-eligible and that his case was now in the F1 category and not current.
- Alleged that this reclassification violated the Child Status Protection Act because, under the CSPA's age-calculation formula, Carlos should have been treated as under 21 on the date of Eduardo's naturalization and therefore should have been classified as an "immediate relative" of a U.S. citizen.
- Asserted that the reclassification was contrary to law and arbitrary and capricious in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A), (D).
- Asserted a constitutional claim under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.

As relief, plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment that Carlos is the "immediate relative" of his U.S.-citizen father entitled to classification in that category, or, in the alternative, an order requiring the government to reinstate Eduardo's petition in the F2A category.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
On February 13, 2023, the defendants moved to dismiss under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1) and 12(b)(6). They argued that the doctrine of consular nonreviewability barred judicial review of what they characterized as the consular officer's decision to deny or refuse Carlos's immigrant visa, and that, even if limited review were available, the consular officer had provided a facially legitimate and bona fide reason for the action by citing and applying the CSPA. Plaintiffs opposed, arguing that their suit challenged only the erroneous reclassification of Eduardo's I-130 petition and not a visa denial, so consular nonreviewability did not apply, and further that the reclassification violated the CSPA's age-out protections.

On January 18, 2024, the district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, concluding that the doctrine of consular nonreviewability precluded review of the challenged action. The court did not specify whether the dismissal was under Rule 12(b)(1) or Rule 12(b)(6), and it did not reach the merits of plaintiffs' statutory or constitutional claims, including their CSPA arguments about the lawfulness of the reclassification.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs timely appealed to the First Circuit. On appeal, they challenge the district court's dismissal of their complaint based on consular nonreviewability and seek review of (1) whether the doctrine of consular nonreviewability applies to their challenge to the reclassification of Eduardo's approved I-130 petition and the resulting delay in adjudicating Carlos's visa, and (2) whether, on the merits, the reclassification from the F2A category to the F1 category, rather than to the immediate-relative category, is contrary to the CSPA and thus unlawful under the APA and the Constitution.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the doctrine of consular nonreviewability bars judicial review of plaintiffs' challenge, where they allege not a final denial of an immigrant visa but an unlawful reclassification of an approved family-based visa petition (and consequent suspension or delay of visa adjudication) by the Department of State and the consulate.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The doctrine of consular nonreviewability generally precludes judicial review of a consular officer's decision to deny a visa, treating such decisions as final and conclusive. Following Department of State v. Muñoz, 602 U.S. 899 (2024), the doctrine is not jurisdictional but goes to the merits. Courts examine whether the challenged agency action is in substance a visa denial by a consular officer or instead a different kind of agency action, such as petition adjudication, classification, or suspension, which may fall outside the doctrine. Where consular nonreviewability applies but constitutional rights of U.S. persons are implicated, some precedent limits review to whether the denial was based on a facially legitimate and bona fide reason.

issues_on_appeal.description: Assuming review is not barred, whether the reclassification of Eduardo's I-130 petition from the F2A (child of an LPR) category to the F1 (adult son of a U.S. citizen) category, instead of converting it to an immediate-relative petition, violated the Child Status Protection Act and thus the APA and Due Process Clause.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard:
