The appeal thus presents questions about whether Sberbank is entitled to presumptive immunity under the FSIA and/or ATA, whether the FSIA commercial‑activity exception applies to Sberbank’s alleged conduct, and whether that exception applies in the ATA context.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Sberbank qualifies as presumptively immune under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act because it is an "agency or instrumentality" of the Russian Federation, including whether post‑filing changes in ownership (from majority ownership by the Central Bank of the Russian Federation to majority ownership by the Russian Ministry of Finance) are relevant to determining instrumentality status.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: FSIA §§ 1603(a)–(b), 1604: a "foreign state" includes an "agency or instrumentality" that is a separate legal person a majority of whose shares are owned by a foreign state or its political subdivision. Under Second Circuit precedent in Bartlett v. Baasiri, FSIA immunity may attach when an entity becomes a foreign‑state instrumentality after suit is filed. Courts assess whether an owner such as a central bank or ministry is a political subdivision by applying the "core functions" test (Garb v. Republic of Poland), examining whether its primary functions are governmental rather than commercial.

issues_on_appeal.description: Assuming Sberbank is presumptively immune under the FSIA, whether the FSIA’s commercial‑activity exception in 28 U.S.C. § 1605(a)(2) abrogates that immunity based on Sberbank’s alleged conduct in facilitating financial transfers for DPR‑related entities through U.S. correspondent accounts.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: FSIA § 1605(a)(2) (commercial‑activity exception): a foreign state is not immune in any case "in which the action is based upon a commercial activity carried on in the United States by the foreign state." FSIA § 1603(d) defines "commercial activity" as a regular course of commercial conduct or a particular commercial transaction or act, with commercial character determined by the nature of the act rather than its purpose. Under Saudi Arabia v. Nelson and Republic of Argentina v. Weltover, a state engages in commercial activity when it acts as a private market participant, not as a sovereign regulator. Under OBB Personenverkehr AG v. Sachs, an action is "based upon" the particular conduct that is the gravamen (core) of the suit.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Sberbank is also presumptively immune from ATA liability under 18 U.S.C. § 2337(2), which bars ATA claims against a "foreign state, an agency of a foreign state, or an officer or employee of a foreign state or an agency thereof," and specifically whether the term "foreign state" in § 2337(2) incorporates the FSIA’s broader definition that includes agencies and instrumentalities.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: ATA § 2337(2) (immunity provision) and ATA § 2333 (civil cause of action). FSIA § 1603(a) defines "foreign state" for purposes of Chapter 97 to include agencies or instrumentalities; Amerada Hess and Republic of Austria v. Altmann hold that the FSIA provides the comprehensive framework and sole basis for civil jurisdiction over foreign states, requiring immunity determinations to conform to FSIA principles. Statutory‑interpretation canons regarding consistent meaning of terms across related statutes, the presumption against surplusage, and in pari materia reading of FSIA, ATA, and JASTA apply. The First Circuit’s Ungar decision treats ATA and FSIA immunity as functionally equivalent.

issues_on_appeal.description: If Sberbank is presumptively immune under the ATA as a foreign state or its agency/instrumentality, whether the FSIA’s commercial‑activity exception nevertheless applies to an ATA action, such that Sberbank’s alleged commercial banking conduct in the United States would abrogate immunity in this ATA suit.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: FSIA § 1602 (preamble) directs that claims of foreign states to immunity in civil cases be decided in conformity with FSIA principles, including the restrictive theory of sovereign immunity and explicit exceptions such as § 1605(a)(2). The Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act (JASTA) added FSIA § 1605B and ATA § 2333(d)(2), partially overriding ATA immunity for certain terrorism‑related claims, and expresses a purpose to provide the broadest possible basis for victims to seek relief against entities that provide material support to terrorism. Canons addressing whether a later, more specific statute impliedly repeals or limits a comprehensive earlier scheme are relevant, as is the rule that repeals by implication are disfavored.

appellant_arguments: FSIA instrumentality status and timing: Sberbank contends it is presumptively immune under the FSIA because it is a separate legal person whose majority shares are owned by an organ or political subdivision of the Russian Federation. At the time the action was filed, the Central Bank of the Russian Federation held a majority stake, and Sberbank argues that the Central Bank was itself a political subdivision or organ of the Russian Federation. After April 30, 2020, the Russian Ministry of Finance acquired a majority stake in Sberbank, and Sberbank argues that, under Bartlett v. Baasiri, post‑filing changes in ownership that confer foreign‑state status must be recognized for FSIA purposes. It rejects any limitation based on alleged gamesmanship in the Ministry of Finance acquisition.

FSIA commercial‑activity exception inapplicability: Sberbank argues that the commercial‑activity exception does not apply because the gravamen of Plaintiffs’ case is the DPR’s overseas attack on MH17, not financial activity in the United States. It characterizes any use of U.S. correspondent accounts as incidental, ministerial banking functions and asserts that the alleged two transfers totaling $300 through U.S. correspondent accounts cannot plausibly constitute the core conduct of the lawsuit, nor form a sufficient factual basis to show that Sberbank’s U.S.‑based conduct was the commercial activity upon which the action is based. Sberbank maintains that the alleged wrongful acts, including provision of funds to DPR supporters and the subsequent missile attack, occurred abroad.

ATA immunity: Relying on 18 U.S.C. § 2337(2), Sberbank contends that the ATA independently bars civil claims against a "foreign state" and its agencies, and that the term "foreign state" there incorporates the FSIA’s definition, which includes agencies and instrumentalities. Sberbank argues that ATA immunity therefore extends to instrumentalities like itself, as majority‑owned by a foreign state through its ministry or central bank, and that the district court erred in treating ATA immunity as coextensive with FSIA immunity only to then apply FSIA exceptions.

No commercial‑activity exception in ATA context: Sberbank argues that even if FSIA principles determine whether it is a "foreign state" for ATA purposes, the ATA sets out a separate and more specific immunity framework that is distinct from the FSIA’s exceptions. It notes that the ATA does not reference the FSIA’s commercial‑activity exception and that Congress, when amending the ATA and FSIA via JASTA, provided an explicit ATA‑specific exception to ATA immunity for certain terrorism‑related claims but did not state that the FSIA commercial‑activity exception applies to ATA suits. Sberbank contends that, under canons of statutory construction, the later, more specific ATA immunity provision should control over the more general FSIA framework in the terrorism context, and that recognizing FSIA commercial‑activity exceptions within ATA suits would effectively constitute an implied partial repeal of § 2337(2).

Scope of alleged knowledge and wrongdoing: Sberbank disputes the sufficiency of Plaintiffs’ allegations that it had actual knowledge or was deliberately indifferent to DPR fundraising and terrorism. It asserts that the complaint relies heavily on media reports and generalized allegations, and contends that even if it operated correspondent accounts and processed routine banking transactions, such activity is not inherently wrongful or sufficient to constitute material support to terrorism under the ATA without more specific evidence tying Sberbank’s U.S.‑based conduct to the MH17 attack.
appellee_arguments: Instrumentality status and timing under FSIA: Plaintiffs initially argued that, under Dole Food Co. v. Patrickson, an entity’s status as an agency or instrumentality should be determined at the time the action is filed, so only the Central Bank’s ownership at filing should matter. They contend that any post‑filing acquisition of shares by the Russian Ministry of Finance should not retroactively confer immunity. Even in light of Bartlett v. Baasiri, they argue that Sberbank’s change in ownership reflects litigation‑motivated "gamesmanship" by Russia designed to manufacture FSIA immunity mid‑suit and that such strategic acquisitions should not be permitted to confer instrumentality status or should at least warrant further factual development on whether the change was engineered to avoid liability.

Application of the FSIA commercial‑activity exception: Plaintiffs argue that the gravamen of their claims is Sberbank’s commercial financial activity in the United States—specifically, the operation of correspondent accounts and authorization of money transfers in New York for DPR‑related fundraising entities—rather than the DPR’s eventual attack on MH17. They emphasize that Sberbank, acting as a private commercial bank, facilitated a global crowdfunding operation that channeled funds through U.S. correspondent accounts to DPR supporters, with alleged knowledge of DPR’s terrorist activities. They contend that use of correspondent accounts and execution of payment orders are quintessential commercial banking activities not involving sovereign powers, and that these activities occurred in the United States and are the particular conduct on which the ATA claims are based. They further assert that the two identified $300 transfers are non‑exclusive examples, that the complaint plausibly alleges a much larger volume of DPR‑directed transfers routed through U.S. accounts, and that they have been constrained by limited pre‑discovery access to transaction data.

ATA immunity narrower than FSIA: Plaintiffs argue that the ATA’s immunity provision, 18 U.S.C. § 2337(2), is textually narrower than the FSIA because it immunizes only a "foreign state" and an "agency of a foreign state" and does not mention instrumentalities. They contend that importing the FSIA’s definition of "foreign state" into the ATA would render the phrase "an agency of a foreign state" superfluous and improperly extend ATA immunity to entities Congress did not intend to shield. Plaintiffs note that FSIA § 1603(a) by its terms defines "foreign state" only "for purposes of" Chapter 97 of Title 28 and does not automatically govern usage in Title 18. They maintain that "foreign state" in § 2337(2) should be read independently, so that entities like Sberbank, which they characterize as an instrumentality rather than an "agency" as that term is used in Title 18, are not covered by ATA immunity.

FSIA as comprehensive regime; application of commercial‑activity exception to ATA suits: Plaintiffs maintain that, consistent with Amerada Hess and Altmann, the FSIA supplies the comprehensive and exclusive framework for civil sovereign‑immunity determinations, including in ATA cases, and that claims of foreign‑state immunity, whatever the underlying cause of action, must be resolved in conformity with FSIA principles and exceptions. They argue that assertions of immunity under the ATA are "functionally equivalent" to FSIA immunity claims, as recognized by the First Circuit in Ungar v. Palestinian Liberation Organization, and that, therefore, if Sberbank is treated as a foreign state or instrumentality under the FSIA for ATA purposes, it must also be subject to the same FSIA exceptions, including § 1605(a)(2)’s commercial‑activity exception. Plaintiffs contend there is no textual or legislative basis to conclude that Congress intended ATA immunity to override or supplant the FSIA’s restrictive theory of sovereign immunity or its commercial‑activity exception, and that JASTA’s purpose and structure support broad civil remedies for terrorism victims, not reduced accountability for foreign sovereigns engaged in commercial support for terrorism.

Link between Sberbank’s U.S. conduct and alleged terrorism: Plaintiffs argue that Sberbank’s alleged conduct in using U.S. correspondent accounts to route funds to DPR‑related entities with knowledge of DPR’s terrorist activities falls squarely within the ATA’s prohibitions on providing material support and financing to terrorists. They maintain that the wrongful act in this case is the financial facilitation itself—"moving money for a fee" to known or suspected terrorist actors—carried out, in significant part, through banking operations in the United States, and that the MH17 attack is a downstream consequence of that financial support. They analogize their claims to cases such as Rodriguez v. Pan American Health Organization, where a court focused on the alleged financial intermediary conduct in the United States as the gravamen of the suit when determining the applicability of the commercial‑activity exception.

issue_1.reasoning: The question whether Sberbank is an FSIA 'agency or instrumentality' is a legal one reviewed de novo. The district court held that (a) ownership is measured at filing, and (b) at filing the Central Bank’s majority ownership made Sberbank an instrumentality because the Central Bank is a political subdivision under the core‑functions test. That analysis is consistent with Dole Food and Second Circuit precedent (Garb), and Bartlett v. Baasiri only adds that post‑filing acquisitions can also confer immunity; it does not negate immunity that already exists at filing. The record indicates the Central Bank’s core functions (monetary policy, currency issuance, financial stability) are predominantly governmental, so treating it as a political subdivision is well supported. Any ‘gamesmanship’ argument about the later transfer to the Ministry of Finance is largely moot if Sberbank already qualified at the time of filing. The appellate court is likely to agree that Sberbank is presumptively immune under FSIA § 1604.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether the commercial‑activity exception applies is a mixed law‑and‑fact question but, at the Rule 12(b)(1) stage on the pleadings, is treated essentially de novo. The district court found the gravamen of the claim is Sberbank’s operation and use of U.S. correspondent accounts to process DPR‑directed transfers, not the DPR’s firing of the missile itself. Under Weltover and Nelson, using correspondent accounts and executing wire transfers is classic commercial activity: the bank is acting like a private market participant, not as a sovereign. Under Sachs’s gravamen analysis, the core conduct for which Sberbank is sued is that commercial banking activity, alleged to have occurred, in part, in New York. The fact that plaintiffs presently identify only two specific $300 transfers is not dispositive at the pleading stage, because they plausibly allege a large crowdfunding operation routed through those accounts and explain that the details of additional transfers are in Sberbank’s control. The district court’s conclusion that the action is 'based upon' commercial activity carried on in the United States by Sberbank fits the statutory text and Supreme Court precedent, so the commercial‑activity exception properly abrogates FSIA immunity on the pleadings.

issue_3.reasoning: Interpretation of ATA § 2337(2) is purely legal and reviewed de novo. The district court treated ATA immunity as functionally equivalent to FSIA immunity and interpreted 'foreign state' in § 2337(2) in light of FSIA principles. The statutory text in § 2337(2) bars suits against a 'foreign state, an agency of a foreign state, or an officer or employee of a foreign state or an agency thereof.' If 'foreign state' were automatically imported wholesale from FSIA § 1603(a) (which already includes agencies and instrumentalities), then adding 'an agency of a foreign state' would be surplusage, a result disfavored by canons of construction. Moreover, FSIA § 1603(a) by its terms defines 'foreign state' 'for purposes of this chapter' (Title 28, Chapter 97) and does not govern Title 18 unless Congress says so. The more coherent reading is that ATA § 2337(2) defines its own immunity category and at least does not automatically expand immunity beyond what FSIA would recognize once FSIA’s exceptions are applied. Amerada Hess and Altmann emphasize FSIA as the comprehensive regime for civil immunity; they do not suggest that a separate Title 18 provision can override FSIA’s exceptions sub silentio. The district court’s approach, which prevents § 2337(2) from enlarging immunity beyond FSIA’s contours, is therefore likely to be upheld.

issue_4.reasoning: Whether FSIA exceptions, including the commercial‑activity exception, limit immunity in an ATA action is a question of statutory interpretation reviewed de novo. FSIA § 1602 states that claims of foreign sovereign immunity in U.S. courts are to be decided 'in conformity with the principles set forth in this chapter,' i.e., including § 1605’s exceptions. Amerada Hess describes FSIA as providing the sole basis for obtaining jurisdiction over a foreign state in civil cases. Reading ATA § 2337(2) to create a freestanding, broader immunity untethered from FSIA’s exceptions would conflict with that regime and would amount to an implied repeal of FSIA § 1605(a)(2) in the terrorism context, which courts strongly disfavor absent clear congressional intent. JASTA’s structure reinforces that Congress sought to enhance, not contract, civil accountability for terrorism‑related conduct, and when Congress wanted to create terrorism‑specific immunity rules (e.g., FSIA § 1605B, ATA § 2333(d)(2)), it did so explicitly. There is no indication Congress meant ATA § 2337(2) to insulate foreign‑state commercial banking activities from FSIA’s well‑established exceptions. The district court’s holding that any ATA‑based claim of sovereign immunity must still be analyzed subject to FSIA’s exceptions, including the commercial‑activity exception that applies here, is therefore likely to be affirmed.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The appeal turns entirely on questions of sovereign immunity, which are reviewed de novo. On the threshold FSIA status question (issue 1), the district court’s reasoning tracks Supreme Court and Second Circuit authority: Sberbank is majority‑owned by an entity (the Central Bank) whose core functions are governmental, making Sberbank an 'agency or instrumentality' of the Russian Federation at the time of filing. Bartlett’s holding on post‑filing acquisitions, if anything, reinforces immunity; it does not undermine the district court’s earlier‑in‑time analysis. Both parties seem to accept that, if the Central Bank is a political subdivision, presumptive FSIA immunity attaches.

On issue 2, the court’s application of the commercial‑activity exception is doctrinally solid. The nature of the alleged conduct—operating correspondent accounts and executing wire transfers in New York for DPR‑related fundraisers—is quintessential commercial banking, not the exercise of sovereign authority. Under Sachs, the gravamen analysis focuses on the defendant’s conduct that directly underlies the claim. Here, the ATA claims are framed around Sberbank’s knowing provision of financial services; the missile launch is the downstream injury. At the pleading stage, the court may credit plaintiffs’ allegations that many DPR‑related transfers flowed through U.S. accounts; the identification of only two specific $300 transfers does not defeat the plausibility of broader U.S.‑based commercial activity.

Issues 3 and 4 involve statutory interpretation of the ATA in relation to the FSIA. The district court’s view—that ATA immunity is construed consistently with FSIA and cannot expand sovereign immunity beyond the limits and exceptions Congress established in FSIA—is strongly supported by Amerada Hess, Altmann, FSIA’s § 1602 preamble, and by Ungar’s reasoning that ATA and FSIA immunity are functionally equivalent. Reading 'foreign state' in § 2337(2) to incorporate the FSIA definition wholesale would make 'agency of a foreign state' redundant and would imply that Congress silently overrode FSIA’s commercial‑activity exception in terrorism cases, a result inconsistent with canons against surplusage and against implied repeals. JASTA’s focus on broadening remedies for terrorism victims further militates against interpreting § 2337(2) as a super‑immunity shield that survives FSIA exceptions.

Given these considerations, the appellate court is likely to affirm the district court’s denial of Sberbank’s Rule 12(b)(1) motion in full, leaving the case to proceed on the merits under the ATA with FSIA immunity abrogated by the commercial‑activity exception.

parties.appellant: Julio A. Rodríguez‑Méndez, criminal defendant in the underlying federal case and § 2255 petitioner
parties.appellee: United States, criminal prosecutor in the underlying federal case and respondent to the § 2255 motion

stage1_summary.factual_background:
In November 2004, Julio A. Rodríguez‑Méndez participated in a carjacking in Puerto Rico while in possession of a firearm. His conduct led to successive prosecutions in Puerto Rico’s Commonwealth courts and in the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. 

First, in the Commonwealth court, Rodríguez was charged with robbery of a motor vehicle in violation of Article 173B of the Puerto Rico Penal Code, P.R. Laws Ann. tit. 33 § 4279b (repealed 2004), and carrying a weapon without a license in violation of Article 5.04 of the Puerto Rico Weapons Law, P.R. Laws Ann. tit. 25, § 458c (repealed 2013). He pled guilty to these Commonwealth offenses and received a sentence of twelve years' imprisonment.

Following this Commonwealth conviction, a federal grand jury indicted Rodríguez on three counts arising from the same 2004 carjacking incident: (1) aiding and abetting a carjacking, in violation of 18 U.S.C. §§ 2 and 2119; (2) aiding and abetting the use of a firearm during and in relation to a crime of violence, in violation of 18 U.S.C. §§ 2 and 924(c); and (3) unlawful possession of a firearm by a felon (felon‑in‑possession), in violation of 18 U.S.C. §§ 922(g)(1) and 924(a)(2). 

The indictment further alleged that Rodríguez qualified as an armed career criminal under the Armed Career Criminal Act (ACCA), 18 U.S.C. § 924(e), on the basis of at least three prior convictions for robbery of a motor vehicle under Article 173B. A presentence investigation report identified these ACCA predicates as convictions under Article 173 (armed robbery), but the parties later agreed they were actually for robbery of a motor vehicle under Article 173B.

Rodríguez pled guilty in federal court to the felon‑in‑possession count. In exchange, the government dismissed the remaining federal charges. 

Article 173B of the Puerto Rico Penal Code, under which Rodríguez previously had been convicted, defined motor‑vehicle robbery as unlawfully appropriating a motor vehicle belonging to another, taking it from the person or the person's possession, in his or her immediate presence and against his or her will, through "the use of violence or intimidation," while "using an object capable of causing grave bodily injury." Puerto Rico law, through Article 174 (P.R. Laws Ann. tit. 33, § 4280, repealed 2004), defined "intimidation" broadly to include threats not only against a person but also against property.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
After being federally indicted, Rodríguez pled guilty to the federal felon‑in‑possession charge under 18 U.S.C. § 922(g)(1), and the government dismissed the aiding and abetting carjacking and § 924(c) firearm charges. Because of his prior Article 173B motor‑vehicle‑robbery convictions, the sentencing court treated him as an armed career criminal under 18 U.S.C. § 924(e), which increased the statutory penalties for the § 922(g)(1) offense. In November 2006, the district court sentenced him to 216 months' imprisonment on the felon‑in‑possession conviction, applying the ACCA enhancement. Rodríguez filed a notice of direct appeal but voluntarily dismissed it in October 2008 and did not seek collateral relief within one year of the conviction becoming final.

Subsequently, there were two major legal developments: (1) in June 2015, the Supreme Court decided Johnson v. United States (Johnson II), holding that the ACCA's residual clause was unconstitutionally vague; and (2) in June 2016, the Supreme Court decided Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle, holding that Puerto Rico and the United States are the same sovereign for double‑jeopardy purposes and barring successive prosecutions by those two governments for the same offense.

Approximately three months after Sánchez Valle, Rodríguez, proceeding pro se, filed a motion under 28 U.S.C. § 2255 in the District of Puerto Rico seeking to vacate his federal felon‑in‑possession conviction on double jeopardy grounds. After counsel was appointed, he amended the § 2255 motion to add a separate challenge to his ACCA enhancement, arguing that, in light of Johnson II, his three prior Article 173B motor‑vehicle‑robbery convictions no longer qualified as ACCA predicate offenses.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
On the double jeopardy claim, the district court concluded that double jeopardy did not bar Rodríguez’s federal felon‑in‑possession prosecution following his Puerto Rico firearm conviction. The court reasoned that Rodríguez had failed to satisfy what it described as the "stone set privity requirement" necessary for his double‑jeopardy theory. 

On the ACCA claim, the district court examined whether Rodríguez's prior Article 173B convictions were "violent felonies" under the ACCA after Johnson II. The court held that Article 173B offenses did qualify as ACCA predicates under the ACCA's force clause because the offense required that the defendant commit motor‑vehicle robbery "using an object capable of causing grave bodily injury," which the court interpreted as satisfying the requirement that the offense have "as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against the person of another." Accordingly, the district court upheld the ACCA enhancement and denied the § 2255 motion in full. It also declined to issue a certificate of appealability on either claim.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Rodríguez appealed the denial of his § 2255 motion. He challenges (1) the district court’s rejection of his double‑jeopardy claim attacking his federal felon‑in‑possession conviction in light of Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle, and (2) the district court’s determination that his prior Puerto Rico Article 173B motor‑vehicle‑robbery convictions qualify as ACCA predicate offenses after Johnson II, and thus its refusal to disturb his ACCA‑enhanced 216‑month sentence. The Court of Appeals granted certificates of appealability on both the double‑jeopardy and ACCA issues.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Rodríguez’s federal felon‑in‑possession conviction under 18 U.S.C. § 922(g)(1), following his Puerto Rico convictions arising from the same 2004 carjacking incident (including a conviction for carrying a weapon without a license under Article 5.04 of the Puerto Rico Weapons Law), violates the Double Jeopardy Clause as construed in Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle because it constitutes a successive prosecution by the same sovereign for the same offense.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment prohibits multiple prosecutions for the same offense by the same sovereign. After Sánchez Valle, Puerto Rico and the United States are considered a single sovereign for double‑jeopardy purposes. Whether successive prosecutions are for the "same offence" is determined under the Blockburger "same elements" test, which asks whether each statutory offense requires proof of a fact that the other does not. If each requires proof of an element that the other does not, they are considered separate offenses even if based on the same conduct.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Rodríguez’s prior Puerto Rico convictions for robbery of a motor vehicle under Article 173B of the Puerto Rico Penal Code qualify as "violent felonies" under the ACCA, thus supporting his armed career criminal designation and the resulting enhanced sentence for his § 922(g)(1) conviction.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 18 U.S.C. § 924(e)(1), a defendant convicted under § 922(g) is subject to ACCA’s enhanced penalties if he has three prior convictions for a "violent felony" or "serious drug offense" committed on different occasions. A "violent felony" is defined in § 924(e)(2)(B) as a crime punishable by more than one year that either (i) has as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against the person of another (force clause), or (ii) is burglary, arson, extortion, or involves the use of explosives (enumerated offense clause). After Johnson II, the residual clause cannot be used. Courts employ the categorical approach, focusing on the elements of the prior offense, not the facts, to determine whether the least culpable conduct criminalized by the statute necessarily involves the use, attempted use, or threatened use of violent physical force against the person of another or matches the elements of a generic enumerated offense. If a statute is indivisible and encompasses conduct that does not satisfy either the force clause or the generic elements of an enumerated offense, it cannot serve as an ACCA predicate.

appellant_arguments: On double jeopardy, Rodríguez argues that, under Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle, Puerto Rico and the United States are a single sovereign for double‑jeopardy purposes, so his Commonwealth convictions for motor‑vehicle robbery and for carrying a weapon without a license, followed by a federal felon‑in‑possession prosecution based on the same 2004 carjacking and firearm possession, amount to unconstitutional successive prosecutions for the same offense. He emphasizes that the state and federal prosecutions relied on the same underlying conduct and evidence, and contends that Blockburger should not be applied "rigidly" in his case because the criminal statutes at issue were enacted by different legislative bodies (the Puerto Rico legislature and Congress) but target the same core wrongdoing—preventing certain individuals from possessing firearms.

On the ACCA issue, Rodríguez asserts that, after Johnson II invalidated the ACCA residual clause, his Article 173B motor‑vehicle‑robbery convictions no longer qualify as ACCA "violent felonies." Applying the categorical approach, he contends that Article 173B’s element of committing the offense "through the use of violence or intimidation" is indivisible and too broad. In particular, because Puerto Rico law (Article 174) defines "intimidation" to include threats against property as well as persons, the least culpable conduct under Article 173B includes intimidation of property only, which does not require the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against the person of another as required by the ACCA force clause. He also argues that Article 173B does not match any ACCA enumerated offense: it is not generic extortion because it does not require that the victim’s consent to part with property be induced, and any taking can be wholly against the victim’s will; and, by its terms, it is a robbery statute focused on non‑consensual takings, not on extortionate inducement of consent. He further maintains (in an argument the appellate court notes but does not resolve in detail) that Article 173B can be violated with a mens rea of recklessness, which would also fall outside the ACCA’s definition of a violent felony.
appellee_arguments: On double jeopardy, the government defends the district court’s rejection of the claim but on different grounds than the district court. It argues first that Rodríguez’s § 2255 double‑jeopardy claim fails because Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle does not apply retroactively on collateral review, so he cannot rely on Sánchez Valle to invalidate his previously final conviction. Alternatively, the government contends that even if Sánchez Valle were applied retroactively and Puerto Rico and the United States are treated as one sovereign, there is no double‑jeopardy violation under Blockburger because federal felon‑in‑possession under 18 U.S.C. § 922(g)(1) and carrying a firearm without a license under Puerto Rico’s Article 5.04 are different offenses. Citing prior circuit precedent (United States v. Almonte‑Núñez), the government notes that § 922(g)(1) requires proof that the defendant is a prohibited person (a felon) and that the firearm traveled in or affected interstate commerce, neither of which Article 5.04 requires, while Article 5.04 requires proof that the firearm was unlicensed, which § 922(g)(1) does not.

On the ACCA issue, the government argues that Rodríguez was properly designated an armed career criminal. It maintains that Article 173B motor‑vehicle robbery qualifies as a violent felony under the force clause because the statute requires that the perpetrator use "an object capable of causing grave bodily injury" and commit the offense "through the use of violence or intimidation." The government asserts that even where intimidation under Puerto Rico law might involve threats directed at property, in the context of a carjacking carried out with a dangerous object, any such threat effectively constitutes a threat of physical force against the person present during the robbery. In the alternative, the government argues that Article 173B qualifies under the ACCA’s enumerated offense clause as the generic offense of extortion. It characterizes Article 173B carjackings accomplished through intimidation (including intimidation directed at property) as situations in which the victim acquiesces and parts with the vehicle "against his/her will" due to the perpetrator’s threats, and it contends that this dynamic amounts to obtaining property from another with his or her consent induced by wrongful use of force, fear, or threats, which matches the generic definition of extortion. The government relies on decisions from other circuits that view the distinction between takings "against the victim’s will" and takings with consent induced by threats as insubstantial for purposes of the extortion definition, and urges that Article 173B falls within that generic extortion category.

issue_1.reasoning: The question is purely legal: whether the federal § 922(g)(1) felon‑in‑possession prosecution following the Puerto Rico Article 5.04 conviction is barred as the “same offence” under the Double Jeopardy Clause after Sánchez Valle. Even assuming (without deciding) that Sánchez Valle applies retroactively on collateral review, the Blockburger test is dispositive. Section 922(g)(1) requires proof that the defendant is a felon and that the firearm traveled in or affected interstate commerce; Article 5.04 requires proof that the weapon was unlicensed. Each offense thus has elements the other does not. The First Circuit has already recognized this mismatch of elements in a similar Puerto Rico–federal pairing (e.g., Almonte‑Núñez). The fact that both prosecutions arise from the same conduct and that both statutes aim in a broad sense at firearm possession does not override Blockburger’s same‑elements test. Nor is there any special doctrinal exception allowing a more “flexible” approach merely because the statutes come from different legislatures that now count as a single sovereign. On de novo review, the federal and Commonwealth offenses are not the same under Blockburger, so there is no double‑jeopardy violation, and denial of relief on this claim is affirmed, even if the district court’s “privity” rationale was incorrect.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether a prior conviction is a “violent felony” under ACCA is a legal question reviewed de novo and resolved under the categorical approach. Article 173B defines motor‑vehicle robbery as a taking “through the use of violence or intimidation” using an object capable of causing grave bodily injury, and Puerto Rico Article 174 expressly defines “intimidation” to include threats to property, not just to persons. The least culpable conduct covered by Article 173B therefore includes a non‑consensual vehicle taking accomplished by threatening only to damage property (for example, threatening to smash the car or burn a nearby building) while brandishing a dangerous object, without any threat of force against a person. Under Johnson I and the ACCA force clause, “physical force” must be force against the person of another; intimidation directed solely at property does not satisfy § 924(e)(2)(B)(i). Because the statute is not textually divisible as between intimidation of persons and intimidation of property, the categorical approach requires considering this non‑qualifying least‑culpable conduct, and the prior convictions therefore cannot be counted via the force clause. Nor does Article 173B categorically match generic extortion under the enumerated‑offense clause: generic extortion requires obtaining property with the victim’s consent induced by wrongful threats, whereas Article 173B robbery, by its terms, targets takings from the person or her possession “against his or her will,” i.e., non‑consensual robberies. That structural difference between robbery (taking against the will) and extortion (consent induced by threat) is substantive, not a trivial semantic distinction. With the residual clause unavailable after Johnson II, Article 173B cannot be an ACCA predicate. The district court’s reliance on the dangerous‑object requirement does not cure the overbreadth regarding the target of intimidation. Accordingly, on de novo review, the ACCA designation and 216‑month sentence must be set aside, and the denial of § 2255 relief on this issue is reversed.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The double‑jeopardy challenge turns entirely on Blockburger. Existing First Circuit precedent and the clear element differences between § 922(g)(1) and Puerto Rico Article 5.04 make it very likely the court will find no “same offence,” irrespective of any retroactivity debate about Sánchez Valle, and thus affirm denial of relief on that claim (even if the district court’s reasoning is corrected). By contrast, after Johnson II the only viable ACCA bases are the force clause and enumerated‑offense clause. Puerto Rico’s Article 173B incorporates an intimidation definition that plainly reaches threats to property alone, so the minimum conduct criminalized does not require force or threatened force against the person of another, as ACCA’s force clause demands. And the statute, on its face, describes robbery by non‑consensual taking, not extortion by consent induced by threats. Under the categorical approach, those features render Article 173B overbroad and not a match for either clause. Appellate courts in similar settings have increasingly refused to recharacterize broad robbery‑type statutes as generic extortion simply because threats can induce acquiescence. That makes reversal on the ACCA issue and remand for resentencing without the ACCA enhancement substantially more likely, producing a mixed outcome: conviction and rejection of the double‑jeopardy claim affirmed, ACCA enhancement reversed.

parties.appellant: Lorna Orabona, plaintiff and former employee (Mortgage Development Officer) of Santander Bank, N.A.
parties.appellee: Santander Bank, N.A., defendant and former employer of Orabona

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Lorna Orabona began working as a Mortgage Development Officer (MDO) for Sovereign Bank in 2008. In 2013, Santander Bank, N.A. acquired Sovereign, and Orabona became a Santander employee. She was paid entirely on commission and was described as one of the top five MDO performers nationwide for Santander. Her commission earnings were approximately $525,000 in 2020 and $680,000 in 2021.

On or about January 18, 2022, Orabona informed her Santander supervisor that she had an offer of employment from Citizens Bank but was still considering remaining at Santander and wished to renegotiate her compensation. According to her, the supervisor responded that he wanted her to stay and would speak with his superiors to work something out.

On January 21, 2022, a Santander employee based in Spain, who was not her supervisor and did not work in her department, together with a Santander HR employee and a Santander IT employee, called Orabona and informed her that her employment was being terminated effective immediately for cause. The stated reason was that she had forwarded company emails from her Santander work email address to her personal email account. Orabona states in an affidavit that she was told all of her benefits, including healthcare, would cease immediately. She further avers that she was told if she took further actions such as appealing her termination or applying for benefits, Santander would report to the Nationwide Multistate Licensing System (NMLS) that she had committed misconduct, allegedly in an attempt to have her license revoked.

Santander’s Rule 30(b)(6) corporate witness, Michael Pagano, testified that typically a manager communicates a termination to an employee and a member of the Employment Relations team (based in the United States) supports that communication, answers questions, and explains what to expect from a benefits standpoint after separation.

There is a factual dispute regarding when Orabona began employment with Citizens Bank. Orabona’s affidavit states she did not accept Citizens’ offer or begin employment there until January 24, 2022, after her termination by Santander. Santander points to Orabona’s NMLS registration, which reflects a Citizens employment start date of January 18, 2022.

Orabona states she received no prior warning or reprimand regarding the forwarding of emails before her termination. She claims she forwarded company emails to her personal account because she was working remotely during the COVID-19 state of emergency since March 2020; she says the emails were encrypted and did not contain personal information. She also asserts that other Santander employees working remotely similarly forwarded company emails to their personal accounts and were neither reprimanded nor terminated. She characterizes the forwarded emails as mortgage pre‑approval letters for client referrals, and she does not deny that they contained confidential client and Santander business information.

In the latter part of the fourth quarter of 2021, and prior to Orabona’s termination, Santander decided to completely exit the U.S. residential mortgage market. This decision was expected to lead to layoffs of all MDOs in the residential mortgages department, which included Orabona’s role. On or about February 1, 2022, a few days after Orabona’s January 21 termination, Santander officially announced a large national layoff in its residential lending department that terminated all MDOs in that department and eliminated Orabona’s position.

Orabona contends that the reasons Santander provided for her termination were pretextual and that the timing of her January 21, 2022, termination was selected to make her ineligible for severance benefits that would be available in connection with the February 1, 2022, layoff. She alleges that a potential severance payment to her would have been significant given her high earnings and that Santander terminated her for cause and concealed the planned large‑scale layoff to deprive her of eligibility for benefits, including severance.

On December 9, 2021, before her termination, Santander’s HR department emailed Orabona a link to a summary of the 2020 Form 5500 for the Santander U.S. Enterprise Severance Policy (the "Severance Policy"). The record also contains Forms 5500 for the Severance Policy for 2020, 2021, and 2022, the Severance Policy in effect from July 21, 2021 through July 17, 2022, and Santander’s Code of Conduct as of December 16, 2021.

The Severance Policy provides that Santander’s current policy is to provide severance benefits to full- or part-time employees whose positions are involuntarily terminated as a result of certain events, including workforce reduction or position elimination. It further states that employees are not entitled to severance benefits if their employment is terminated for certain reasons, including misconduct or violation of company policies, procedures, practices, or the Code of Conduct.

The Code of Conduct includes policies about employee use of corporate assets and expressly prohibits sending, forwarding, or transmitting Santander U.S. information to a personal email account, personal messaging application, or similar platform for any reason. It states that employees who violate the Code may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination, and emphasizes that employment at Santander U.S. is generally at will.

The Severance Policy specifies conditions for receiving severance once an employee is found eligible and qualified, including execution of a separation agreement and remaining in the employee’s position through the termination date. It provides that no severance benefits are paid to an employee who resigns before the termination date. For employees earning commissions, the severance pay calculation is based on the greater of (1) a benefits-pay amount used to determine salary-related benefits in the year of termination, or (2) the average, annualized earnings over the prior 6 to 24 months based on time in the commissioned role, with certain reductions (to 80% or 65% of average earnings) for higher-earning employees above specified income thresholds. The policy reserves to Santander "sole discretion" to decide whether any employee will receive severance benefits, the terms and conditions for such payment, whether those conditions are satisfied, and the amount of severance.

The Severance Policy also provides that all claims for benefits must be made in writing to HR within 60 days of the event giving rise to the claim, and that an employee may appeal any denial by submitting a written request for review within 60 days after receiving the denial. It states that an employee must exhaust the claims and appeal process before filing suit.

Santander’s 30(b)(6) witness testified that any employee, including one terminated for cause, may file a claim with HR seeking severance benefits if the employee believes they are still entitled to severance. Orabona concedes that she did not take any steps to appeal her termination or apply for benefits. She attributes this failure to her reliance on the alleged statements during the January 21, 2022, termination call that she was ineligible for benefits and that Santander would report her to the NMLS for misconduct if she took further action, such as appealing or applying for benefits.

The summary judgment record reflects a dispute over whether Santander normally provides a separation guide to terminated employees and whether such a guide was provided to Orabona. Orabona says she did not receive one. Santander’s 30(b)(6) witness testified that the separation guide, where given, contains information about matters like COBRA coverage and life insurance conversion but does not reference the Severance Policy.

The core of Orabona’s lawsuit is her allegation that Santander, facing a planned large‑scale layoff that would have triggered a significant severance payout to her under the Severance Policy, falsely characterized her termination as "for cause" and concealed the layoff in order to deprive her of eligibility for severance and other benefits.

procedural_history.claims_brought: On June 22, 2023, Orabona filed suit against Santander in Rhode Island Superior Court. After limited discovery and amendment, she asserted four state-law causes of action: (1) breach of implied contract and covenant of good faith and fair dealing, (2) wrongful termination, (3) fraud and intentional misrepresentation, and (4) negligent misrepresentation. In each count she sought damages to be proven at trial, plus reasonable attorney's fees and costs, punitive damages, and other relief deemed appropriate. Her theory across these claims was that Santander wrongfully and pretextually terminated her for cause to interfere with her continued employment and to avoid paying severance benefits and other employee benefits.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
Santander removed the case to the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island. It initially moved to dismiss all claims for failure to state a claim and on the ground that the claims were preempted by ERISA. Santander attached to its motion a version of the Severance Policy. Orabona opposed, disputing the authenticity and applicability of the version Santander submitted and requesting discovery to determine the actual terms of any ERISA plan and whether it qualified as an ERISA plan. The district court denied Santander’s motion to dismiss without prejudice and allowed both parties limited discovery focused on the applicability and authenticity of the potential ERISA plan.

After this discovery, Orabona filed an amended complaint asserting the four state-law claims described above. Santander then filed a combined motion to dismiss the amended complaint for failure to state a claim and for summary judgment based on ERISA preemption. Santander argued that Orabona’s claims were preempted because each count "relates to" the ERISA-governed Severance Policy and would require reference to the plan to determine liability and damages.

On September 25, 2024, the district court issued a Memorandum and Order granting summary judgment to Santander on ERISA preemption grounds. The court concluded that all of Orabona’s state-law claims were preempted by ERISA § 514(a), 29 U.S.C. § 1144(a). It reasoned that the fraud and negligent misrepresentation claims were preempted because the natural measure of damages would be the value of severance benefits defined by the Severance Policy, and it relied in part on Otero Carrasquillo v. Pharmacia Corp. For the breach of implied contract and wrongful termination claims, the district court noted that Orabona had conceded that severance benefits would be part of the consequential damages she sought. The court concluded that calculating her damages on those claims would require reference to the Severance Policy.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Orabona appeals the district court’s entry of summary judgment in favor of Santander. She challenges the determination that her state-law claims are preempted by ERISA under § 514(a) and, relatedly, contends that her claims should not be barred as attempts to obtain relief that falls within ERISA’s civil enforcement scheme.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Orabona’s state-law claims for breach of implied contract and covenant of good faith and fair dealing, wrongful termination, fraud and intentional misrepresentation, and negligent misrepresentation are expressly preempted by ERISA § 514(a), 29 U.S.C. § 1144(a), on the ground that they "relate to" Santander’s ERISA-governed Severance Policy.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under ERISA § 514(a), ERISA "shall supersede any and all State laws insofar as they may now or hereafter relate to" any ERISA plan, 29 U.S.C. § 1144(a). A state law relates to an ERISA plan if it has a "connection with or reference to" such a plan. Courts examine whether adjudicating the state claim would require evaluating or interpreting the terms of the ERISA plan to determine liability or damages, and look beyond formal labels to the actual facts and theory of the claim.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, to the extent Orabona’s state-law claims seek to recover severance benefits or other relief for the alleged denial or interference with severance benefits under Santander’s Severance Policy, those claims are preempted because they duplicate, supplement, or supplant ERISA’s exclusive civil enforcement remedies under § 502(a), 29 U.S.C. § 1132(a), including claims analogous to those under ERISA § 510, 29 U.S.C. § 1140.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: ERISA § 502(a), 29 U.S.C. § 1132(a), provides the exclusive civil enforcement mechanisms for participants to recover benefits due under the terms of a plan, to enforce rights under the plan, or to seek appropriate equitable relief to enforce plan terms or ERISA provisions. State-law causes of action that duplicate, supplement, or supplant these remedies are preempted because they conflict with Congress’s intent to make ERISA’s enforcement scheme exclusive; claims alleging discharge for the purpose of interfering with the attainment of plan benefits are covered by ERISA § 510, 29 U.S.C. § 1140, and are enforceable solely through § 502(a).

appellant_arguments: Orabona asserts that her state-law claims do not have the requisite connection with or reference to an ERISA plan to warrant express preemption under § 514(a). She contends that any need to reference the Severance Policy is incidental, relating at most to calculating a portion of her damages, and that reference to an ERISA plan solely for damages does not, by itself, require preemption.

She argues that her breach of implied contract, covenant of good faith and fair dealing, and wrongful termination claims are based on Santander’s allegedly wrongful and pretextual termination procedures and motives, including alleged threats concerning reporting her to the NMLS, rather than on rights conferred by the Severance Policy itself.

She maintains that her fraud and negligent misrepresentation claims arise from Santander’s alleged false statements and concealment of the planned layoff and her eligibility for benefits, and that these are independent state-law torts that should not be displaced by ERISA. She contends that these claims do not seek to enforce plan terms but to remedy separate misconduct by the employer.

She relies on decisions from other circuits for the proposition that mere reference to an ERISA plan to calculate damages, without more, is insufficient to create ERISA preemption and that state-law claims based on general employment law duties can coexist with ERISA.

She further argues that her claims do not fall within ERISA’s civil enforcement scheme because she is not simply seeking benefits due under the plan, but also other categories of damages (including punitive damages and other consequential losses) arising from wrongful termination, fraud, and misrepresentation.
appellee_arguments: Santander argues that each of Orabona’s state-law claims is expressly preempted under ERISA § 514(a) because they all rest on the allegation that Santander terminated her for cause to deprive her of severance benefits under the Severance Policy. According to Santander, to determine liability on any of these claims, the court must evaluate and interpret the ERISA-governed Severance Policy and associated Code of Conduct provisions, including eligibility criteria, the effect of termination "for cause," and the plan’s discretionary provisions.

Santander contends that the Severance Policy is an ERISA plan, as shown by the plan document, Forms 5500 filed with the Department of Labor from 2020 to 2022, and related materials, and that the authenticity of these materials was not genuinely disputed after discovery.

Santander maintains that the damages Orabona seeks flow principally, if not entirely, from the severance benefits she claims she would have received absent the alleged wrongful termination, so adjudicating the state claims would necessarily involve consulting the Severance Policy to quantify damages.

Santander further argues that, to the extent Orabona seeks to recover severance benefits or other relief for the alleged interference with or denial of those benefits, her claims fall squarely within ERISA’s civil enforcement provisions, particularly § 502(a)(1)(B) (actions to recover benefits) and remedies for violations of § 510 (interference with attainment of plan rights). Santander asserts that permitting state-law claims here would impermissibly duplicate or supplement ERISA’s exclusive remedial scheme.

Santander also notes that, under the Severance Policy, Orabona was required to submit a written claim for benefits to HR and, if necessary, appeal any denial before bringing suit, and that she admittedly did not invoke these procedures, although employees terminated for cause are allowed to file claims if they believe severance is owed. Santander suggests that Orabona’s failure to use the plan’s administrative process underscores that she is attempting an improper end-run around ERISA by recharacterizing what is effectively a benefits dispute as state-law tort and contract claims.

issue_1.reasoning:
Whether ERISA § 514(a) preempts these state-law causes of action is a pure question of law, reviewed de novo. On the summary-judgment record, the severance arrangement is plainly an ERISA plan: there is a written Severance Policy, Forms 5500 filed for multiple years, and an ongoing administrative scheme for determining eligibility, the amount of benefits (with income-based formulas and reductions), and claims/appeals procedures. After limited discovery targeted at those points, the authenticity and ERISA status of the plan are no longer seriously contestable.

The core factual theory of every claim is that Santander pretextually labeled the termination as ‘for cause’ and concealed a pending RIF in order to deprive Orabona of severance and related benefits that otherwise would have been triggered. Liability for the implied-contract, good‑faith, wrongful‑termination, fraud, and negligent‑misrepresentation counts all turns on whether it was wrongful for Santander to treat her as ineligible for severance and to threaten her about pursuing benefits. That inquiry necessarily requires determining what the Severance Policy actually provides—who is eligible, what ‘for cause’ and ‘misconduct’ mean under the plan and Code of Conduct, and whether she in fact stood to receive severance in connection with the February 1 layoff.

The measure of damages is likewise inextricably tied to the plan: the centerpiece of her claimed harm is the loss of a ‘significant’ severance payment, calculated only by applying the Severance Policy’s commission‑based formula, thresholds, and discretionary components. Under First Circuit precedent such as Otero‑Carrasquillo v. Pharmacia Corp., where the natural measure of damages for state tort or contract claims is the amount of ERISA benefits allegedly lost, those claims ‘relate to’ the plan and are expressly preempted. Here, her attempt to characterize severance as only one component of damages does not change that her theory of liability and primary economic loss is anchored in the Severance Policy.

Nor can the need to interpret the Code of Conduct be cabined as a purely non‑ERISA employment issue. The Code is expressly incorporated into the plan’s eligibility and ‘for cause’ provisions, and determining whether the alleged misconduct justified denial of severance will require construing those plan-related standards. Given that adjudicating these state claims would require more than a mere arithmetic reference to the plan and would instead entail evaluating eligibility, exclusions, and discretionary determinations under the Severance Policy, they have the requisite ‘connection with or reference to’ an ERISA plan and are preempted under § 514(a).

issue_2.reasoning:
Whether the claims are displaced by ERISA’s exclusive civil enforcement mechanism under § 502(a) is also a legal question reviewed de novo. Orabona’s factual narrative maps directly onto causes of action that ERISA itself provides: she alleges she was fired early, and for pretextual ‘for cause’ reasons, to prevent her from receiving severance and associated employee benefits that would have been due in connection with a planned layoff. That is functionally a § 510 interference theory (‘discharge... for the purpose of interfering with the attainment of any right’ under a plan), enforceable exclusively via § 502(a).

Her requested relief—back pay or front pay tied to lost employment plus the ‘significant’ severance and other benefits she says she would have received under the Severance Policy—is, at bottom, an attempt to recover plan benefits and to redress an alleged interference with the attainment of those benefits. Dressing that theory in the garb of wrongful termination, fraud, or negligent misrepresentation does not change its substance. Under Supreme Court and First Circuit authority, state-law claims that duplicate, supplement, or supplant § 502(a)(1)(B) and § 510 remedies are completely preempted.

That she also pleads punitive and other consequential damages does not rescue the claims from preemption; allowing those additional remedies would expand and alter ERISA’s carefully reticulated remedial scheme, precisely what § 502(a) forbids. Likewise, her failure to exhaust the plan’s internal claims and appeals procedures, while potentially relevant to a future ERISA action, underscores that she is seeking an end‑run around ERISA by recasting what is essentially a benefits‑interference dispute as a suite of state tort and contract claims. Because the gravamen of her suit is denial and interference with severance benefits due under an ERISA plan, the district court correctly held that those claims are within ERISA’s civil enforcement field and therefore preempted.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Both issues present legal questions on undisputed plan documents after focused discovery. The summary judgment record shows that Santander maintained an ERISA-governed severance plan and that all of Orabona’s state-law theories are built around the assertion that Santander manipulated the timing and characterization of her termination to deprive her of severance benefits and other plan-related advantages. Determining liability and, especially, the primary measure of her damages would require interpreting and applying that Severance Policy and its incorporated Code of Conduct, not merely consulting it in a peripheral way. Under established preemption doctrine, those close connections mean her claims ‘relate to’ the plan within § 514(a). At the same time, the complaint’s theory fits squarely within the domain of ERISA’s own causes of action—recovery of benefits and protection against interference with benefit rights—so allowing these state-law claims would impermissibly supplement and expand ERISA’s exclusive remedies under § 502(a). On this record, an appellate court is likely to conclude that the district court correctly granted summary judgment on ERISA preemption grounds and to affirm across the board.

parties.appellant: Joseph R. Capen, an individual Massachusetts resident and original plaintiff; National Association for Gun Rights, a nonprofit membership organization and original plaintiff
parties.appellee: Andrea Joy Campbell, in her official capacity as Attorney General of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, original defendant

stage1_summary.factual_background:
The case concerns a constitutional challenge to provisions of the Massachusetts firearms statute, Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 140, § 131M, commonly referred to as the Massachusetts assault weapons and large-capacity magazine ban (the "Massachusetts Ban" or the "Ban"). The Ban makes it a crime to sell, offer to sell, transfer, or possess an "assault weapon" or a "large capacity feeding device" (LCM) that was not lawfully possessed on September 13, 1994. A first violation by a person not licensed under § 122 is punishable by a fine of $1,000 to $10,000, or imprisonment from one to ten years, or both; a second offense carries higher fines and longer imprisonment terms.

The statute defines "assault weapon" by incorporating the definition of a "semiautomatic assault weapon" that appeared in the now-lapsed federal Public Safety and Recreational Firearms Use Protection Act, 18 U.S.C. § 921(a)(30), as of September 13, 1994, and by listing specific models (e.g., Avtomat Kalashnikov (AK) models, UZI, Galil, Beretta AR70, Colt AR-15, certain Fabrique National rifles, certain SWD models, Steyr AUG, INTRATEC TEC series, and revolving cylinder shotguns such as the Street Sweeper and Striker 12). Under the incorporated federal definition, a "semiautomatic assault weapon" includes: (1) certain named models; (2) a semiautomatic rifle with a detachable magazine and at least two of several listed military-style features (such as a folding or telescoping stock, pistol grip, bayonet mount, flash suppressor or threaded barrel, or grenade launcher); (3) a semiautomatic pistol with a detachable magazine and at least two listed features (such as a magazine attaching outside the pistol grip, threaded barrel for attachments, barrel shroud, heavy weight, or being a semiautomatic version of an automatic firearm); and (4) a semiautomatic shotgun with at least two listed features (folding/telescoping stock, pistol grip, fixed magazine capacity over five rounds, or ability to accept a detachable magazine).

The Massachusetts statute defines a "large capacity feeding device" as a fixed or detachable magazine, box, drum, feed strip, or similar device capable of accepting, or readily convertible to accept, more than ten rounds of ammunition or more than five shotgun shells, or as a large capacity ammunition feeding device under the federal 1994 act. The definition excludes attached tubular devices designed to accept and operate only with .22 caliber ammunition.

According to the record described in the opinion, the Massachusetts Ban targets two main categories of items: (1) "assault weapons" (including certain semiautomatic rifles, pistols, and shotguns with specified features, and several named models such as the Colt AR‑15) and (2) large capacity feeding devices. The Commonwealth's evidence, including expert submissions, characterizes rifles such as the AR-15 as lightweight, accurate, semiautomatic rifles capable of rapid fire, originally derived from a design for the U.S. military, with high-velocity ammunition that can penetrate typical building materials and cause severe bodily injury. One Commonwealth expert states that the AR‑15's need for two-handed operation and its ability to fire ammunition that easily penetrates common household construction materials undercut any perceived advantage over handguns for home self-defense. The record also includes expert material that semiautomatic rifles cause on average substantially more deaths and injuries in mass shootings than "regular" firearms, and that the AR‑15’s combination of high bullet velocity, relatively manageable recoil, and rapid rate of fire enhances its lethality, with those effects further compounded when used with LCMs.

Appellant Joseph R. Capen is a law-abiding Massachusetts resident who alleges that, but for a credible threat of prosecution under § 131M, he would purchase firearms and magazines covered by the Ban (described in the pleadings as "Banned Firearms" and "Banned Magazines") to keep in his home for self-defense and other lawful purposes. The National Association for Gun Rights alleges it is a nonprofit whose members include Massachusetts residents who are law-abiding citizens and who likewise would purchase firearms and magazines covered by the Ban for self-defense and other lawful purposes but refrain from doing so due to the threat of enforcement. The Association’s president submitted a declaration stating in general terms that the members on whose behalf the action is brought are Massachusetts residents and law-abiding U.S. citizens; the complaint itself does not identify a specific member whose interests are affected.

The Attorney General of Massachusetts, through public statements and legislative history cited in the record, has framed the purpose of the Ban as reducing criminal access to particularly dangerous firearms and magazines and addressing public safety concerns associated with mass shootings and gun violence, including the use of assault weapons and large-capacity magazines to inflict multiple casualties quickly. A 2004 gubernatorial press release quoted then-Governor Mitt Romney as stating that "deadly assault weapons have no place in Massachusetts" and that the Ban was intended to make it harder for criminals to obtain such weapons and to help keep Massachusetts streets and neighborhoods safe.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
On September 7, 2022, Capen and the National Association for Gun Rights filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Massachusetts Attorney General in her official capacity. They sought: (1) a declaratory judgment that Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 140, § 131M is facially unconstitutional under the Second Amendment; or, in the alternative, (2) a declaratory judgment that § 131M is unconstitutional as applied to law-abiding adults seeking to acquire, use, transfer, or possess arms that are in common use by the American public for lawful purposes. The complaint requested preliminary and permanent injunctions prohibiting enforcement of § 131M's provisions relating to assault weapons and large capacity feeding devices. Initially, the complaint also named the Governor of Massachusetts as a defendant, but the parties later stipulated to dismiss the Governor from the case. The plaintiffs challenged three aspects of the statutory scheme: two definitional provisions (the definitions of "assault weapon" and "large capacity feeding device" in § 121) and one enforcement provision (§ 131M’s prohibition on sale, transfer, and possession).

On November 9, 2022, plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction ("PI Motion") seeking to preliminarily enjoin enforcement of the Ban as to both the assault-weapon and LCM restrictions while the case was litigated on the merits. The Attorney General, on behalf of the Commonwealth, opposed the PI Motion. The Commonwealth also raised standing objections in its Answer, arguing that the plaintiffs had not sufficiently alleged an injury in fact, particularly with respect to the Association.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
On December 21, 2023, the district court (Judge F. Dennis Saylor IV) denied the plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction. Applying the preliminary injunction standard used in the First Circuit, the court assessed (1) the plaintiffs’ likelihood of success on the merits, (2) the likelihood of irreparable harm absent an injunction, (3) the balance of hardships, and (4) the public interest. The court treated likelihood of success on the merits as a necessary condition. Focusing on the Second Amendment issues under the framework articulated by the Supreme Court in District of Columbia v. Heller and New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. Bruen, the district court framed the core question as whether Massachusetts’s restrictions on assault weapons and LCMs are consistent with the Nation’s historical tradition of firearm regulation, particularly the historical tradition of regulating "dangerous and unusual" weapons.

As to assault weapons, the district court assumed, without deciding, that the weapons proscribed by the Act are "bearable arms" falling somewhere within the scope of the Second Amendment. The court then found, based on the record before it, that the banned assault weapons, including the Colt AR‑15, are "dangerous and unusual" in the sense that they are unreasonably dangerous and unusual for ordinary citizens to use for lawful purposes such as self‑defense. The court emphasized the design and features of the AR‑15, finding that the intrinsic characteristics of assault weapons make them poor self-defense weapons compared to typical semiautomatic handguns and that the injuries they inflict can be catastrophic and far exceed the destructive power of such handguns. The court acknowledged that an AR‑15 could be useful in some self-defense scenarios but regarded that as comparable to the potential self-defense utility of other powerful weaponry, such as machine guns or automatic grenade launchers, which have historically been subject to regulation. On that basis, the court concluded that the assault-weapon prohibition is consistent with historical traditions of regulating dangerous and unusual weapons.

Regarding large capacity feeding devices, the district court noted an absence of specific guidance from the Supreme Court or the First Circuit on whether magazines constitute "arms" for Second Amendment purposes. Instead of resolving that question directly, the court identified historical analogues, including founding-era restrictions on the storage and use of gunpowder and early twentieth-century bans or restrictions addressing high-capacity magazines and similar devices, and concluded that there is a historical tradition supporting regulation of devices analogous to LCMs. The court did not explicitly find that LCMs themselves were "dangerous and unusual" in the same manner as assault weapons but determined that the historical record of regulation, including both powder storage laws and early magazine restrictions, supported the constitutionality of the LCM provisions.

Synthesizing these conclusions, the district court held that the Massachusetts Ban was likely consistent with the Second Amendment and determined that the plaintiffs had not demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits of either their assault-weapon challenge or their LCM challenge. Finding this dispositive on the preliminary injunction analysis, the court denied the PI Motion without relying on the other preliminary injunction factors.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The plaintiffs filed a timely interlocutory appeal under 28 U.S.C. § 1292(a)(1) from the district court’s order denying their Motion for Preliminary Injunction. They challenge the district court’s conclusion that they failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of their Second Amendment claims and, specifically, the court’s determinations that (1) the Ban’s restrictions on assault weapons, including the AR-15 and certain semiautomatic handguns, are consistent with the historical tradition of firearm regulation, and (2) the Ban’s restrictions on large capacity feeding devices are consistent with that same historical tradition. They seek appellate review of the denial of preliminary injunctive relief and of the constitutional analysis underlying that denial. The appeal also implicates, as a threshold matter, Article III standing for each plaintiff, though the Attorney General did not press standing on appeal; the court of appeals discusses standing to confirm its own jurisdiction, focusing in particular on whether Capen and the Association have alleged sufficient injury in fact at the preliminary injunction stage.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the plaintiffs demonstrated a sufficient likelihood of success on the merits of their Second Amendment challenge to Massachusetts’s statutory prohibitions on the sale, transfer, and possession of "assault weapons," including semiautomatic rifles such as the Colt AR‑15 and certain semiautomatic handguns, so as to warrant preliminary injunctive relief.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under the preliminary injunction standard, the movant must show (1) a likelihood of success on the merits, (2) irreparable harm absent preliminary relief, (3) that the balance of hardships tips in its favor, and (4) that an injunction is in the public interest. Likelihood of success on the merits is a necessary condition. For the Second Amendment merits analysis, the applicable framework derives from District of Columbia v. Heller, New York State Rifle & Pistol Ass’n v. Bruen, and United States v. Rahimi. Bruen directs courts first to determine whether the Second Amendment’s plain text covers the regulated conduct, which, if so, presumptively protects that conduct. The burden then shifts to the government to justify its regulation by showing consistency with the Nation’s historical tradition of firearm regulation. This historical-analogue inquiry looks to "how" and "why" historic regulations burdened the right to armed self-defense and compares them to the modern regulation, recognizing that analogues need not be precise historical twins. Heller also identifies a historical tradition of prohibiting the carrying of "dangerous and unusual" weapons not in common use for lawful purposes, and notes that the right is not unlimited.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the plaintiffs demonstrated a sufficient likelihood of success on the merits of their Second Amendment challenge to Massachusetts’s statutory restrictions on large capacity feeding devices (magazines capable of holding more than ten rounds of ammunition or more than five shotgun shells), in light of the historical record and prior circuit precedent addressing similar bans.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The same four-factor preliminary injunction standard applies, with likelihood of success on the merits as a necessary condition. On the Second Amendment merits, Bruen and Rahimi provide the governing test: if the Second Amendment’s plain text covers the conduct (possession, acquisition, or use of magazines), the regulation is presumptively invalid unless the government can demonstrate that it is consistent with the Nation’s historical tradition of firearm regulation. The historical-analogue approach focuses on similarity in how and why the law burdens the right to armed self-defense. First Circuit precedent in Ocean State Tactical, LLC v. Rhode Island applied this framework to a nearly identical ban on large capacity magazines and concluded, at the preliminary injunction stage, that the historical record strongly supported the constitutionality of that type of restriction. Under the law-of-the-circuit doctrine, subsequent panels are bound by prior panel decisions closely on point unless superseded by controlling authority.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, and to what extent, the plaintiffs’ facial challenge to the Massachusetts Ban is viable under the applicable standard for facial challenges, particularly in light of the focus on specific weapons (like the AR‑15) and the breadth of the Ban’s coverage, which includes various models and weapon types beyond those specifically addressed by the plaintiffs.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A facial challenge generally requires the challenger to establish that no set of circumstances exists under which the statute would be valid, or that the statute is unconstitutional in all of its applications. Supreme Court cases such as United States v. Salerno, United States v. Rahimi, Moody v. NetChoice, LLC, and Bucklew v. Precythe emphasize that facial challenges are disfavored, that courts should consider whether a statute is constitutional in at least some of its applications, and that a showing of invalidity in all applications is required for a facial challenge to succeed.
