The First Circuit applies this framework in evaluating whether a plaintiff challenging a broad statutory regime has shown that every application of the law violates the constitutional provision at issue.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the plaintiffs have Article III standing to pursue the preliminary injunction and the appeal, particularly with respect to the National Association for Gun Rights' associational standing, in light of the requirement that a plaintiff show an injury in fact that is concrete and particularized and, for organizations, that at least one identified member has suffered such an injury.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Article III, a plaintiff must show (1) an injury in fact that is concrete, particularized, and actual or imminent; (2) a causal connection between the injury and the conduct complained of; and (3) redressability by a favorable decision. Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife and related cases set out these elements. For requests for preliminary injunctions, standing may be evaluated on the sufficiency of the allegations in the complaint. Organizational or associational standing requires an organization to identify at least one member who has suffered the requisite harm; generalized allegations or reliance solely on statistical probabilities are not sufficient unless all members are affected. Cases such as Summers v. Earth Island Institute, Draper v. Healey, Hochendoner v. Genzyme Corp., and Sierra Club v. Morton address naming requirements and the possibility of curing pleading defects by amendment. If at least one plaintiff has standing, a suit may proceed.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court correctly applied the preliminary injunction standard—particularly the weight given to the likelihood of success on the merits—when it denied the plaintiffs’ motion solely on the ground that they had not shown a likelihood of success on their Second Amendment claims.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The First Circuit reviews denials of preliminary injunctions for abuse of discretion, examining underlying legal rulings de novo and factual findings for clear error. Under Winter v. Natural Resources Defense Council and First Circuit precedent such as Corp. Techs., Inc. v. Harnett and Akebia Therapeutics, Inc. v. Azar, a movant must satisfy four factors: (1) likelihood of success on the merits, (2) irreparable harm, (3) balance of hardships, and (4) public interest. Likelihood of success on the merits is a critical, necessary element; if a movant fails to demonstrate it, the other factors are of diminished consequence. Preliminary injunction determinations are viewed as predictive assessments of probable outcomes, not final adjudications on the merits, as noted in Narragansett Indian Tribe v. Guilbert.

appellant_arguments: The plaintiffs contend that the Massachusetts Ban violates the Second Amendment both on its face and as applied to law-abiding adults who wish to acquire, possess, use, and transfer firearms and magazines that, they argue, are in common use by the American public for lawful purposes, including self-defense in the home. They emphasize that millions of Americans own the types of firearms and magazines targeted by the Ban, and on that basis maintain that such arms cannot be deemed "dangerous and unusual" and fall instead within the Second Amendment’s protection.

They argue that the Ban imposes a substantial burden on the right to keep and bear arms by categorically prohibiting ordinary citizens from acquiring and possessing a large class of commonly possessed semiautomatic rifles, pistols, shotguns, and magazines over ten rounds (or five shotgun shells), rather than imposing narrower regulations on use or carry. In their view, this is inconsistent with the Supreme Court’s decision in Heller, which invalidated a broad prohibition on handgun possession in the home and referred to handguns as the "quintessential" self-defense weapon. They contend that the Massachusetts restrictions on semiautomatic handguns—especially those most popular or "preferred" for self-defense—are "glaringly unconstitutional" in light of Heller's statement that banning from the home the most preferred firearm for protection fails constitutional scrutiny.

They challenge the district court’s analysis of the Ban’s assault-weapon restrictions, disputing the characterization of AR‑15 rifles and other covered weapons as "dangerous and unusual" and minimizing their self-defense utility. The plaintiffs maintain that the mere fact that a weapon is powerful or that it can cause severe injuries does not, by itself, place it outside the Second Amendment’s scope when it is widely owned and used for lawful purposes. They similarly argue that the district court undervalued evidence of the widespread civilian ownership and lawful usage of these arms, contending that the historical tradition described in Heller does not authorize banning weapons that are currently in common lawful use.

Regarding large capacity feeding devices, the plaintiffs argue that magazines are integral components of modern semiautomatic firearms and thus fall within the protection of the Second Amendment as "arms" or at least as necessary to the exercise of the right to keep and bear arms. They assert that the Ban on magazines holding more than ten rounds (or more than five shotgun shells) interferes with self-defense by limiting the ammunition capacity available to law-abiding citizens in defensive situations. They also argue that the district court’s reliance on historical analogues such as gunpowder storage laws and early twentieth-century magazine regulations is misplaced because those laws, in their view, are not sufficiently similar in how and why they burden self-defense.

The plaintiffs maintain that the district court misapplied Bruen by giving weight to policy justifications or public safety considerations that, they argue, cannot override the textual protection supplied by the Second Amendment. They contend that the court’s analogical reasoning improperly focused on the government’s asserted public safety interests, such as responding to mass shootings and violent crime, rather than strictly comparing concrete historical regulations on similar arms and the specific burdens imposed on law-abiding citizens’ ability to defend themselves. They assert that Bruen precludes courts from upholding modern firearms regulations based primarily on judgments about contemporary policy needs.

The plaintiffs further argue, especially before the First Circuit's decision in Ocean State Tactical, that the historical laws cited by the Commonwealth—such as bans or restrictions on Bowie knives, clubs, trap guns, sawed-off shotguns, and machine guns—are not true analogues to a modern categorical ban on a wide class of semiautomatic firearms and magazines in common civilian ownership. They contend that these historical restrictions were narrower, targeted weapons not commonly used for lawful self-defense, and did not impose comparably broad prohibitions on ordinary law-abiding citizens. In their view, the district court erred in treating those historical laws as adequate support for the Massachusetts Ban.

With respect to the facial nature of their challenge, the plaintiffs argue that the Ban is invalid in all its applications to law-abiding adults, stressing that its scope reaches a wide array of weapons and magazines they characterize as common and lawful. They resist attempts to segment their challenge by weapon type or feature, insisting instead that the entirety of the Ban’s prohibitions on "Banned Firearms" and "Banned Magazines" must be treated together for purposes of constitutional analysis and injunctive relief.

In their reply brief, filed after the First Circuit's decision in Ocean State Tactical, the plaintiffs acknowledge that many of their arguments—particularly those relying on ownership statistics as determinative of "common use," and several of their positions concerning LCMs—are foreclosed at the preliminary injunction stage by that decision. They nonetheless seek to preserve those arguments for further review and maintain that the Massachusetts law, especially as applied to semiautomatic rifles and certain handguns, differs in constitutionally significant ways from the Rhode Island LCM ban addressed in Ocean State Tactical.
appellee_arguments: The Attorney General of Massachusetts (the Commonwealth) argues that the plaintiffs lack a likelihood of success on the merits because the Ban fits comfortably within the Nation’s historical tradition of regulating particularly dangerous weapons, and thus is consistent with the Second Amendment under the Bruen and Rahimi framework. The Commonwealth emphasizes that the Ban does not prohibit all firearms or even all semiautomatic firearms, but rather targets a subset of especially lethal weapons and large-capacity magazines that pose unique risks to public safety, especially in mass shooting and violent crime scenarios.

The Commonwealth contends that the challenged assault weapons—particularly semiautomatic rifles like the AR‑15—are not well-suited to ordinary self-defense in the home. Relying on expert declarations, the Commonwealth asserts that AR‑15-style rifles typically require two-handed operation, are more likely to penetrate walls and common household construction materials, and thus present significant over-penetration risks in residential settings, undermining their alleged defensive advantage over handguns. The Commonwealth also points to evidence that semiautomatic rifles are rarely if ever used in actual civilian self-defense incidents, which, under the First Circuit’s Ocean State Tactical decision, lessens the burden imposed on the core right of armed self-defense by their regulation.

On the historical inquiry, the Commonwealth maintains that there is a longstanding tradition of regulating, and sometimes banning, specific weapons once they were recognized as posing heightened threats to public safety, regardless of whether those weapons could conceivably be used in self-defense. The Commonwealth identifies historical examples including: (a) eighteenth- and nineteenth-century regulations restricting the storage and use of gunpowder; (b) eighteenth- through twentieth-century bans on the use of "trap guns" (set guns); (c) nineteenth-century bans and severe restrictions on Bowie knives and other long-bladed knives viewed as associated with violent crime; (d) longstanding prohibitions on clubs and certain blunt instruments; and (e) twentieth-century bans on sawed-off shotguns and automatic weapons (machine guns). It argues that these precedents demonstrate a pattern of government regulation of arms that are unusually dangerous and associated with criminal misuse or mass harm.

The Commonwealth asserts that the justification for the Massachusetts Ban—protecting the public from the particular danger caused by weapons that facilitate mass casualties, especially in mass shootings—is similar in kind to the justifications underlying these historical regulations. It stresses that modern semiautomatic assault weapons and LCMs enable a shooter to fire many high-velocity rounds rapidly, inflicting catastrophic injuries and casualties in a short period of time, and that legislatures have historically responded to comparable threats by restricting or banning the weapons most associated with such harms. The Commonwealth points to legislative history, including statements by then-Governor Mitt Romney at the time of the 2004 enactment making the Ban permanent, describing assault weapons as having no place in Massachusetts and as instruments of destruction whose prohibition was intended to help keep streets and neighborhoods safe and make it harder for criminals to obtain them.

The Commonwealth relies heavily on the First Circuit’s decision in Ocean State Tactical, which upheld the denial of preliminary relief in a challenge to Rhode Island’s nearly identical LCM ban. It argues that Ocean State Tactical’s reasoning—that historical bans on particularly dangerous weapons and devices (including Bowie knives, sawed-off shotguns, and machine guns) are sufficiently analogous under Bruen to modern LCM bans—directly applies to Massachusetts’s LCM provisions. The Commonwealth also asserts that Ocean State Tactical’s general conclusions about how and why the government may regulate dangerous weapons, including the court’s treatment of self-defense burden and public safety justifications, are equally applicable to Massachusetts’s assault weapon restrictions.

With respect to determinations about what constitutes "dangerous and unusual" weapons, the Commonwealth supports the district court’s conclusion that assault weapons covered by the Ban, such as the AR‑15, are more dangerous and no more useful for ordinary self-defense than other available firearms, particularly handguns, which were at issue in Heller. It contends that the plaintiffs’ reliance on ownership statistics to establish "common use" is inconsistent with the First Circuit’s interpretation of Heller and Bruen in Ocean State Tactical, which rejected the notion that mere prevalence in the marketplace or society is the sole measure of whether a weapon is protected, and instead focused on actual use for self-defense and the degree of harm the weapon can cause.

The Commonwealth disputes the plaintiffs’ reliance on Heller’s invalidation of a total handgun ban, arguing that Heller does not preclude legislation that regulates only certain subclasses of handguns with specific military-style features or capacities. The Ban, it notes, does not prohibit possession of all handguns and allows Massachusetts residents to acquire and possess a wide array of firearms suitable for self-defense. Therefore, the Commonwealth argues, the Massachusetts Ban is far less restrictive than the law struck down in Heller and does not amount to a complete prohibition of the "quintessential self-defense weapon."

On the facial challenge, the Commonwealth argues that the plaintiffs cannot show that the Ban is unconstitutional in every application. It emphasizes that the Ban covers a wide variety of weapons and magazines, including models and configurations (such as UZIs, AK-type rifles, revolving cylinder shotguns, and rifles with combinations of specified features like flash suppressors and grenade launchers) that the plaintiffs do not specifically address in their arguments. Under Supreme Court precedents on facial challenges, the Commonwealth argues that the plaintiffs’ failure to demonstrate the unconstitutionality of the Ban as applied to each covered weapon or configuration is fatal to their attempt to invalidate the statute on its face.

Regarding standing, the Commonwealth previously contended at the district court that the plaintiffs had not sufficiently alleged an injury in fact. In particular, it challenged the Association’s associational standing because the complaint and supporting declaration did not identify any specific member who is directly affected by the Ban or who would purchase banned weapons or magazines but for credible threat of enforcement. While the Attorney General did not press the standing arguments on appeal, the Commonwealth’s earlier position was that generalized assertions about unidentified members’ interests are inadequate for Article III standing.

issue_1.standard_of_review: abuse of discretion (overall PI ruling); de novo (underlying Second Amendment legal analysis)
issue_1.reasoning: The denial of a preliminary injunction is reviewed for abuse of discretion, with de novo review of the Second Amendment questions under Bruen/Heller. The First Circuit’s own recent decision in Ocean State Tactical (upholding denial of a PI against a nearly identical LCM ban and strongly endorsing a broad view of historical regulation of particularly dangerous weapons) constrains how this panel can analyze both the historical tradition and the ‘dangerous and unusual’ framework. The district court assumed, arguendo, that the banned semiautomatic rifles and pistols are ‘bearable arms’ and then concluded, based on expert evidence and historical analogues, that they are reasonably deemed dangerous and unusual and that the ban fits within the historic tradition of regulating such weapons. That is a plausible reading of Bruen’s historical-analogue method and tracks Ocean State Tactical’s acceptance of analogous regulations on high‑lethality arms. Given the predictive nature of a PI ruling and the heavy weight the First Circuit places on likelihood of success, the panel will not find an abuse of discretion in concluding that plaintiffs have not shown a sufficient likelihood of success regarding the assault‑weapon prohibition at this preliminary stage.

issue_2.standard_of_review: abuse of discretion (overall PI ruling); de novo (underlying Second Amendment legal analysis, including application of circuit precedent)
issue_2.reasoning: For the LCM restrictions, Ocean State Tactical squarely controls: it involved a nearly identical Rhode Island ban on magazines over ten rounds, applied Bruen’s framework, and held that the plaintiffs there had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits. Under the law‑of‑the‑circuit doctrine, this panel is bound absent intervening Supreme Court authority (none is identified that undermines Ocean State Tactical). The district court’s historical-analogue analysis—relying on gunpowder storage laws and early magazine restrictions as evidence of a tradition of regulating especially dangerous means of rapid fire—mirrors the reasoning approved in Ocean State Tactical. To the extent plaintiffs argue that magazines are themselves ‘arms’ or that prevalence or ownership numbers should control, those positions were effectively rejected in Ocean State Tactical at the PI stage. Accordingly, the district court did not abuse its discretion in finding no likelihood of success on the LCM challenge and in denying preliminary relief.

issue_3.reasoning: Whether a facial challenge is viable is a question of law reviewed de novo. Under Salerno, Bucklew, Rahimi, and related authority, a facial challenge generally requires showing that the statute is unconstitutional in all its applications. The Massachusetts Ban covers a wide array of weapons and configurations, including some (e.g., UZIs, AK‑type rifles, revolving cylinder shotguns, rifles with grenade launchers) that plaintiffs barely discuss and that have particularly strong analogues in historical restrictions on especially dangerous or military‑style arms. Ocean State Tactical also emphasizes that limited or partial burdens on the core self‑defense right weaken facial challenges. Plaintiffs largely focus on AR‑15s and certain semiautomatic handguns; they do not meaningfully demonstrate that every application of the Ban—including to the most exotic or clearly crime‑associated configurations—is unconstitutional. Under the disfavor for facial challenges and the requirement to consider whether the law has at least some constitutional applications, plaintiffs have not shown a sufficient likelihood of success on their facial challenge, and the district court’s implicit rejection of that theory will be sustained.

issue_4.reasoning: Article III standing is reviewed de novo. Capen, an identified individual who alleges that he would purchase banned firearms and magazines but for a credible threat of prosecution, satisfies injury in fact, causation, and redressability at the PI stage; this is consistent with Draper v. Healey and similar pre‑enforcement Second Amendment cases. Even if the Association’s associational standing is defective for failure to name a specific affected member (as suggested by Summers and Hochendoner), the presence of at least one plaintiff (Capen) with standing is sufficient for jurisdiction and for review of the denial of a PI. The Attorney General does not press standing on appeal, and the court of appeals will typically decline to dismiss on these facts where one plaintiff clearly meets Article III requirements. Thus, to the extent the district court implicitly treated standing as adequate to reach the merits, that conclusion will be affirmed; the Association’s standing issues, if noted, will be treated as non‑dispositive because Capen’s standing supports the case.

issue_5.standard_of_review: abuse of discretion (overall PI framework); de novo (legal articulation of the standard)
issue_5.reasoning: The First Circuit repeatedly holds that likelihood of success on the merits is a ‘necessary’ or ‘critical’ element of preliminary injunction analysis; if that factor is not satisfied, courts may deny a PI without detailed analysis of the remaining factors. The district court expressly followed this approach, treating likelihood of success as dispositive. That is consistent with First Circuit precedent such as Corp. Techs., Akebia Therapeutics, and Narragansett Indian Tribe. Because the district court applied the correct legal framework and made a reasonable predictive judgment—grounded in the existing record and in historical‑tradition analysis aligned with Ocean State Tactical and Heller/Bruen—that plaintiffs were unlikely to succeed on their Second Amendment claims, it did not abuse its discretion in denying the PI solely on that basis.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The appeal concerns only the denial of preliminary injunctive relief, not a final merits judgment. The First Circuit gives substantial deference to district courts’ predictive assessments at the PI stage, particularly on complex historical and constitutional questions. On the core Second Amendment issues, the panel is constrained by its own recent, on‑point decision in Ocean State Tactical, which upheld denial of a PI against a nearly identical LCM ban and endorsed viewing high‑lethality weapons and magazines as subject to a historical tradition of regulation. That precedent strongly supports affirmance on Issue 2 and, by extension, bolsters the district court’s general approach to the ‘dangerous and unusual’ and historical‑analogue framework for Issue 1. Plaintiffs’ arguments that widespread ownership alone controls ‘common use,’ and that policy concerns may not inform historical analogies, are in practical tension with Ocean State Tactical’s reasoning. The facial challenge (Issue 3) is unusually broad and does not satisfy the demanding requirement of showing invalidity in all applications, especially given the Ban’s coverage of particularly extreme weapon types. On standing (Issue 4), at least one plaintiff, Capen, clearly alleges a concrete pre‑enforcement injury; even if associational standing for the organization is questionable, that does not defeat jurisdiction. Finally, the district court correctly treated likelihood of success as a necessary condition for a preliminary injunction (Issue 5) and acted within the accepted range of discretion in denying relief based solely on that factor. Taken together, these considerations make a full affirmance of the district court’s order the most likely appellate outcome.

parties.appellant: Ryan Six, plaintiff in the district court who brought claims under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA).
parties.appellee: IQ Data International, Inc., defendant in the district court and alleged debt collector.

stage1_summary.factual_background: IQ Data International, Inc. acquired a debt obligation arising from Six’s purported breach of a residential lease. On August 18, 2021, Six became aware of this debt and mailed a letter to Equifax disputing the debt and requesting documentation to verify it. That same day, Six’s attorney mailed a separate letter directly to IQ. The attorney’s letter informed IQ that Six was represented by counsel and directed that all communications regarding the debt be sent to the attorney rather than to Six personally. On September 2, 2021, IQ received Six’s dispute letter (the one addressed to Equifax) and internally processed a request to generate and mail the requested verification documentation to Six at his mailing address. On September 3, 2021, IQ updated its internal records to reflect that it had processed the attorney’s representation letter and that direct communications with Six should cease. However, on that same day, IQ also sent a debt verification letter, containing documentation of the debt, directly to Six at his mailing address. Six later alleged that receipt of this letter, after IQ had been notified that he was represented by counsel and that communications should go only to his attorney, invaded his privacy interests.

procedural_history.claims_brought: After receiving the verification letter from IQ, Six filed suit against IQ in the United States District Court for the District of Arizona. He asserted a claim under 15 U.S.C. § 1692c(a)(2) of the FDCPA, alleging that IQ, as a debt collector, improperly communicated directly with him in connection with the collection of a debt after it knew he was represented by an attorney with respect to that debt. The case also involved issues concerning IQ’s affirmative defenses, a joint discovery dispute implicating attorney-client privilege, and a request for attorneys’ fees.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: In the district court, Six and IQ filed cross-motions for summary judgment. The district court concluded that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction because Six did not have Article III standing. The court determined that Six had not suffered an injury in fact, reasoning that the receipt of a single unwanted letter was not sufficiently analogous to traditionally recognized harms that support a lawsuit and was not the type of abusive debt collection practice that the FDCPA was enacted to prevent. On that basis, the district court dismissed the action for lack of jurisdiction and denied the remaining portions of the parties’ cross-motions for summary judgment as moot. Separately (as referenced by the court of appeals), the district court resolved a joint discovery dispute involving attorney-client privilege and entered a modified grant of attorneys’ fees.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: On appeal, Six challenges the district court’s dismissal of his FDCPA action for lack of subject matter jurisdiction on Article III standing grounds. He also contests the district court’s denial of his motion to strike IQ’s affirmative defenses, the district court’s resolution of the parties’ joint discovery dispute involving attorney-client privilege, and the district court’s modified grant of attorneys’ fees.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Six has Article III standing to pursue a claim under 15 U.S.C. § 1692c(a)(2) based on IQ sending him a debt collection verification letter after IQ had been notified that he was represented by counsel and that communications should be directed to the attorney.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To establish Article III standing, a plaintiff must show: (1) an injury in fact that is concrete, particularized, and actual or imminent; (2) that the injury is fairly traceable to the challenged conduct of the defendant; and (3) that it is likely, as opposed to merely speculative, that the injury will be redressed by a favorable judicial decision. An injury in fact must be an invasion of a legally protected interest that is concrete and particularized and actual or imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical. In assessing concreteness for statutory harms, courts consider Congress’s judgment in identifying and elevating certain intangible harms and whether the alleged harm bears a close relationship in kind to harms traditionally recognized as actionable at common law, such as intrusion upon seclusion. Relevant authorities include Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins, and TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly denied Six’s motion to strike IQ’s affirmative defenses in light of the FDCPA claim and the facts surrounding IQ’s communications.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(f) permits a court to strike from a pleading an insufficient defense or any redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous matter. The movant generally must show that the challenged defenses are insufficient as a matter of law or are otherwise improper. (The appellate opinion references this issue but does not elaborate on a specific articulated test beyond the general standard.)

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court correctly resolved the parties’ joint discovery dispute concerning materials claimed to be protected by the attorney-client privilege.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The attorney-client privilege protects confidential communications between attorney and client made for the purpose of obtaining or providing legal advice. Courts evaluate whether the privilege applies to specific communications, whether any exceptions (such as waiver) apply, and whether the privilege has been properly invoked. (The detailed test is not restated in the opinion excerpt, but the dispute is framed in terms of attorney-client privilege.)

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court’s modified grant of attorneys’ fees was proper in the context of the FDCPA litigation and the procedural posture of the case.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under the FDCPA, courts may award reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs to prevailing parties in accordance with the statute’s fee-shifting provisions. Courts assess the reasonableness of fees using factors such as the lodestar method and any statutory or equitable considerations. (The opinion references a ‘modified grant’ of attorneys’ fees but does not detail a specific test beyond standard fee principles.)

appellant_arguments: Six argues that he suffered a concrete, particularized injury sufficient for Article III standing when he received an unwanted debt verification letter from IQ after expressly directing, through his attorney, that all communications be sent only to counsel. He contends this constituted an invasion of his privacy interests, which Congress specifically sought to protect in the FDCPA, particularly through 15 U.S.C. § 1692c(a)(2).

He maintains that Congress, in enacting the FDCPA, identified abusive debt collection practices as contributing to invasions of individual privacy, and that § 1692c(a)(2)’s prohibition on direct communications with represented consumers reflects a legislative judgment that such contacts are harmful. Thus, receiving the letter is the type of harm Congress intended to make legally cognizable.

Six further argues that his injury is closely analogous to the common-law tort of intrusion upon seclusion because IQ’s direct communication intruded on his privacy and peace after he had clearly expressed a desire not to be contacted directly. He contends that courts, including within the Ninth Circuit, have recognized that unwanted communications (such as calls or text messages) can constitute concrete injuries similar in kind to intrusion upon seclusion.

He challenges the district court’s characterization of his receipt of a single letter as de minimis or insufficiently abusive, asserting that the court improperly downplayed the privacy invasion inherent in the violation of § 1692c(a)(2).

Regarding the motion to strike affirmative defenses, Six contends that certain defenses raised by IQ are legally insufficient or inapplicable under the FDCPA and should not remain in the pleadings, although the detailed content of those defenses is not set out in the opinion excerpt.

Concerning the discovery dispute, Six opposes IQ’s reliance on attorney-client privilege to withhold certain information and argues that the district court’s resolution of that dispute was erroneous (details of his specific privilege arguments are not provided in the excerpt).

With respect to attorneys’ fees, Six challenges the district court’s modified grant, contending that the adjustment or limitation on fees was improper under the circumstances of the case (the opinion does not detail his precise fee arguments in the excerpt).
appellee_arguments: IQ argues that Six lacks Article III standing because the alleged harm from receiving a single unwanted letter is not a concrete injury. IQ contends that the mere receipt of one letter is neither analogous to harms historically recognized as actionable, such as the tort of intrusion upon seclusion, nor the type of abusive practice Congress intended to target with the FDCPA.

IQ maintains that Six’s alleged injury is at most a bare statutory or procedural violation without real-world consequences, and therefore does not satisfy the requirement of a concrete injury in fact under Spokeo and TransUnion.

IQ asserts that unwanted postal mail differs meaningfully from other forms of unwanted communication, such as phone calls or text messages, because mail does not interrupt a person’s seclusion in the same way; it arrives in a mailbox and can be handled at the recipient’s convenience. IQ relies on authorities such as the Seventh Circuit’s decision in Pucillo v. National Credit Systems, Inc., which distinguished between postal mail and more intrusive forms of communication, to argue that letters do not bear a sufficiently close relationship to intrusion upon seclusion to support standing.

IQ emphasizes that there was only a single letter, sent in response to Six’s request for documentation, and characterizes any intrusion as minimal and not of the kind the FDCPA was designed to prevent.

On the affirmative defenses, IQ contends that its defenses are proper and should not be stricken, and that the district court acted appropriately in refusing to strike them (though the specific defenses are not laid out in the excerpt).

Regarding the joint discovery dispute, IQ argues that the materials at issue are protected by the attorney-client privilege and that the district court correctly resolved the dispute in its favor (specifics of the privilege analysis are not set out in the excerpt).
As to attorneys’ fees, IQ supports the district court’s modified grant of fees as an appropriate exercise of discretion under the FDCPA’s fee-shifting provisions and applicable fee jurisprudence.

issue_1.reasoning:
Standing is reviewed de novo. Under Spokeo and TransUnion, courts look to (1) Congress’s judgment in identifying and elevating a harm and (2) whether the alleged injury bears a close relationship to a traditionally recognized harm. Congress expressly framed the FDCPA, and § 1692c(a)(2) in particular, as protecting consumers’ privacy from abusive collection practices, including unwanted direct contact with represented debtors. Six alleges that, after he clearly directed IQ (through counsel) not to contact him directly, IQ knowingly sent him a debt-collection verification letter anyway. That is a particularized invasion of privacy, not a bare procedural error.

Ninth Circuit precedent treats unwanted targeted communications—such as harassing calls or texts—as sufficiently analogous to intrusion upon seclusion to support concreteness; here, the panel would likely view an unwanted debt-collection letter sent in knowing disregard of a representation notice as similar in kind, especially in light of Congress’s specific judgment in § 1692c(a)(2). The district court’s view that a single letter is categorically too trivial conflicts with that framework. The traceability and redressability elements are not meaningfully disputed. Accordingly, the appellate court is likely to hold that Six has Article III standing and reverse the dismissal for lack of jurisdiction.

issue_2.reasoning: Rulings on motions to strike under Rule 12(f) are reviewed for abuse of discretion. They are disfavored generally, and district courts have broad leeway in deciding whether a defense is sufficiently pleaded or should remain for development in discovery. The summary provides no indication that the challenged affirmative defenses were legally impossible or patently frivolous, only that Six believed they were inapplicable on the merits. That sort of disagreement ordinarily does not justify striking defenses at the pleadings stage. Given the deferential standard, the appellate court is unlikely to find that the district court exceeded the bounds of its discretion in denying the motion to strike, even if the underlying FDCPA claim is reinstated.

issue_3.standard_of_review: mixed (clear error for underlying factual findings; de novo for legal conclusions; overall reviewed for abuse of discretion in discovery management)
issue_3.reasoning: Discovery and privilege rulings are reviewed with substantial deference; factual determinations underpinning privilege (e.g., purpose and context of communications) are reviewed for clear error, legal conclusions about the scope of privilege de novo, and the ultimate discovery ruling for abuse of discretion. The excerpt shows only that the district court resolved a joint discovery dispute by upholding an assertion of attorney–client privilege. There is no indication that the court misapplied the basic privilege standard (confidential communications for the purpose of obtaining legal advice) or any waiver rule, nor that it compelled or denied discovery in a way that materially distorted the adversarial process. In the absence of a clear misapplication of law or a plainly erroneous factual finding, the court of appeals would almost certainly defer to the district court’s handling of the privilege dispute.

issue_4.reasoning: Fee awards and adjustments are reviewed for abuse of discretion, with underlying legal interpretations reviewed de novo. The record indicates only that the district court entered a “modified grant” of attorneys’ fees, suggesting it reduced or tailored the requested amount under standard reasonableness principles (lodestar, degree of success, proportionality, etc.). Nothing in the summary indicates that the court applied an incorrect legal standard under the FDCPA’s fee-shifting provisions, or that the amount awarded (or denied) was outside the range of acceptable outcomes. Appellate courts are highly deferential to fee determinations; without a clear legal error or grossly unreasonable result, the modified fee award will be upheld even as the case is remanded on the merits.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The central legal question—whether a consumer has Article III standing based on a single unwanted direct communication in violation of § 1692c(a)(2)—is a pure question of law reviewed de novo. Given Congress’s explicit focus on privacy invasions in the FDCPA, the specific prohibition on contacting represented consumers, and modern standing doctrine’s acceptance of unwanted targeted communications as concrete intangible harms, the appellate court is likely to reject the district court’s categorical conclusion that one such letter is too minor to support standing. That yields reversal on Issue 1 and a remand for further proceedings on the FDCPA claim.

By contrast, the remaining issues (motion to strike defenses, discovery/privilege, and fees) lie squarely within the district court’s discretionary and fact-intensive domains. The summary reveals no clear legal missteps or extreme outcomes in any of those rulings. Under abuse-of-discretion and clear-error standards, appellate courts rarely intervene absent a strong signal of error, which is missing here. Thus, the most plausible overall disposition is mixed: reverse the dismissal for lack of jurisdiction, affirm the court’s ancillary procedural and fee rulings, and remand for continued litigation on the merits of Six’s FDCPA claim.

parties.appellant: Nilfisk, Inc. and Nilfisk Holding A/S (defendants in the district court; appellants in No. 24-3224 and appellees on the cross‑appeal in No. 24-3281)
parties.appellee: Fort Worth Partners, LLC (plaintiff in the district court; appellee in No. 24-3224 and appellant on the cross‑appeal in No. 24-3281)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Fort Worth Partners, LLC owned a warehouse-style industrial building in Springdale, Arkansas, which it leased to Nilfisk, Inc. under an Industrial Building Lease. The building consisted of two connected 100,000 square-foot structures, referred to as the East Building and the West Building, joined by abutting gable walls and collectively described as the "Building." The Building extended 1,000 feet east-to-west and 200 feet north-to-south. It was constructed using pre-engineered steel framing, with moment frames running north-to-south and cable cross bracing running east-to-west. Each moment frame was attached to the foundation's perimeter by steel plates and threaded anchor bolts spaced at twenty-five-foot increments.

The Building's foundation consisted of a perimeter wall set into the ground and a concrete slab floor. Concrete pedestals extended from underlying spread footings to support load-bearing interior columns. In the West Building, the moment frames were supported by three I-beam columns attached to the foundation's footing pedestals with steel plates and anchor bolts. In the East Building, the moment frames were supported by hollow steel beams set directly into the foundation.

On March 30, 2022, a tornado struck and destroyed the Building. All 100,000 square feet of the West Building and approximately 40,000 square feet of the East Building collapsed. The wall panels and roof of the remaining portion of the East Building were damaged beyond repair, but much of the interior moment framing and roof supports in that remaining portion were largely undamaged. The East Building's foundation, however, suffered damage, including sheared base plates and anchor bolts, a cracked floor slab, and spalled concrete along the perimeter. Given the extent of the destruction and damage, Nilfisk vacated the premises on August 1, 2022, before the Lease term expired.

Under the Lease, Nilfisk was responsible for all property-related expenses, including taxes, insurance, maintenance, and repairs. Section 10.2 of the Lease required Nilfisk, as tenant, to purchase and maintain an "all-risk" commercial property insurance policy covering the improvements on the premises (excluding Nilfisk's own property) against specified perils, including windstorm, and any other risks covered by a causes-of-loss special form policy. The coverage amount had to be equal to 100% of the then full replacement cost of the premises, subject to a deductible not exceeding $100,000. "Full replacement cost" was defined in the Lease as the cost of replacing the premises without deduction for depreciation or wear and tear, less the cost of footings, foundations, and other structures below grade.

The Lease gave Fort Worth Partners certain remedies if Nilfisk failed to comply with the insurance requirements. Section 10.1 permitted Fort Worth Partners, after at least five days' prior written notice, to order the required insurance itself and charge the cost to Nilfisk as additional rent, payable on demand. Alternatively, if Nilfisk failed to perform its obligations, Fort Worth Partners could terminate the tenancy and recover "any ... amount necessary to compensate ... for all the detriment directly caused" by Nilfisk's nonperformance.

Neither party undertook to determine the Building's full replacement cost during the Lease term. The Building's appraised value ranged between approximately $10.5 million and $11.1 million. Nilfisk's property insurance limits varied by year; it never carried more than $10 million in full replacement cost coverage, and at the time of the tornado Nilfisk carried $5,149,999 in full replacement cost property insurance. Fort Worth Partners received annual certificates of insurance from Nilfisk reflecting the coverage limits and did not object to or question the sufficiency of the coverage. Fort Worth Partners was aware of its contractual right to purchase additional full replacement cost coverage and pass the cost to Nilfisk as additional rent, but did not exercise that right.

Following the tornado, Fort Worth Partners claimed that Nilfisk had failed to maintain the contractually required full replacement cost insurance and sought to recover the amount it contended it would have received had Nilfisk complied with its insurance obligation. During discovery, both sides retained experts to estimate the Building's full replacement cost. Fort Worth Partners' expert, Kevin McMahon, estimated full replacement cost at $27,722,974.03. Nilfisk's expert, Jeff Marcussen, estimated full replacement cost at $14,253,579. Nilfisk's insurer retained a separate appraiser who estimated the replacement cost at $9,428,939.87. Nilfisk paid Fort Worth Partners $5,292,427.32 in insurance proceeds, which the district court later deducted from its calculation of replacement cost damages.

In the damages phase, the district court ultimately found the full replacement cost of the Building, net of insurance proceeds, to be $12,870,528.74, including specific components such as $732,000 for demolition, $7,138,611.89 for rebuilding the metal superstructure, $2,982,112.75 for electrical wiring, $1,651,177.82 in overhead and lost profits, and $5,659,053.60 in certain costs the court characterized as "unrebutted" from McMahon's estimate. The court separately found the cost of repairing the foundation to be $1,303,123 but concluded those foundation damages were not recoverable under the Lease because of the exclusion of footings, foundations, and other below-grade structures from the full replacement cost definition.

After trial, Fort Worth Partners sought $170,413.50 in attorney's fees and $19,059.65 in costs. The court reduced the requested fees to $152,115 to align with local prevailing rates, and then applied a further 25% reduction to $114,086.25 on the ground that Fort Worth Partners achieved only limited success relative to the damages it sought. The court awarded $5,149.15 in costs.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Fort Worth Partners filed suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Arkansas (Fayetteville Division) against Nilfisk, Inc. and its parent company Nilfisk Holding A/S. The complaint alleged breach of contract based on Nilfisk's alleged failure to maintain property insurance in the amount and form required by Section 10.2 of the Lease. Fort Worth Partners sought damages representing the full replacement cost of the Building that it asserted would have been covered had Nilfisk maintained adequate insurance, as well as unpaid rent and related monetary relief.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. Fort Worth Partners argued that Nilfisk had breached the Lease as a matter of law by failing to carry insurance equal to 100% of the Building's full replacement cost. Nilfisk opposed and, in its own summary judgment motion, argued that the claim was barred by the statute of limitations and Arkansas's doctrine of avoidable consequences, that the insurance provision of the Lease was an unenforceable agreement to agree, and that the damages sought were excessive.

The district court granted Fort Worth Partners' summary judgment motion in part. Using even the lowest of the replacement-cost estimates in the record (the appraiser retained by Nilfisk's insurer), the court concluded that Nilfisk's coverage at the time of the tornado was below the amount required by Section 10.2 of the Lease and held that Nilfisk had breached its insurance obligation and was liable for resulting damages. The court declined, however, to fix the Building's precise replacement cost at summary judgment due to conflicting expert opinions and set that issue for a bench trial. The court also awarded Fort Worth Partners summary judgment on its unpaid rent claim, which neither party appealed.

The court denied Nilfisk's summary judgment motion in its entirety. It held that Fort Worth Partners' suit was timely because each deficient annual insurance policy and certificate could constitute a separate breach with its own limitations period; it found fact questions concerning the application of the doctrine of avoidable consequences; it rejected Nilfisk's contention that the insurance provision was an unenforceable agreement to agree; and it found that Fort Worth Partners' claimed damages were not facially excessive at the summary judgment stage.

The court then conducted a bench trial limited to damages. Both parties presented expert testimony on the Building's full replacement cost, including detailed categories for demolition, reconstruction of the metal superstructure, electrical systems, overhead, and other costs. After weighing the evidence, the district court issued written findings of fact and conclusions of law. The court determined that the full replacement cost damages, net of the insurance proceeds already paid, totaled $12,870,528.74, broken down into several categories. The court specifically excluded $1,303,123 in foundation-related repair costs from the award based on its interpretation of the Lease's exclusion of footings, foundations, and below-grade structures from the definition of full replacement cost.

During the trial, Nilfisk did not present evidence in support of its earlier summary judgment argument that the doctrine of avoidable consequences barred or reduced Fort Worth Partners' damages. Instead, Nilfisk stated in its post-trial brief that it adopted and incorporated by reference its earlier summary judgment arguments and authorities concerning that doctrine. The district court rejected that approach, noting that Nilfisk had not offered evidence or re-urged the issue at trial, and it declined to apply the doctrine of avoidable consequences for the reasons previously expressed in its summary judgment order.

Following the damages decision, the district court ruled on Fort Worth Partners' motion for attorney's fees and costs. It reduced the requested attorney's fees to match prevailing local rates and then imposed a further 25% reduction due to Fort Worth Partners' partial or limited success on its damages theories. It awarded a reduced amount of attorney's fees and a portion of the requested costs.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Nilfisk appealed (No. 24-3224) the district court's denial of its motion for summary judgment on statute of limitations and avoidable-consequences grounds and challenged the district court's damages award, particularly the portion labeled as 'unrebutted costs.' Fort Worth Partners cross-appealed (No. 24-3281), challenging the district court's interpretation of the Lease as excluding all foundation damages, its conclusion that the Lease allowed only a repair remedy for the foundation (an issue the district court did not reach after its exclusion determination), and the reduction of attorney's fees based on Fort Worth Partners' perceived limited success.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Fort Worth Partners' breach of contract claim was barred in whole or in part by Arkansas's five-year statute of limitations for written contracts, based on the timing of Nilfisk's procurement and delivery of allegedly deficient insurance policies and certificates starting in 2016.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Ark. Code Ann. § 16-56-111(a), the limitations period for written contracts is five years. A cause of action for breach of contract accrues when the plaintiff could have first maintained the action to a successful conclusion. Arkansas law, as reflected in Pennington v. BHP Billiton Petroleum (Fayetteville), LLC, 631 S.W.3d 555 (Ark. 2021), permits plaintiffs to sue for alleged breaches occurring within the limitations period even if similar breaches occurred earlier outside the period.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the doctrine of avoidable consequences bars or reduces Fort Worth Partners' recovery because Fort Worth Partners allegedly failed to take reasonable steps to avoid or mitigate its damages by exercising its contractual right to purchase additional insurance coverage and charge the cost to Nilfisk.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Arkansas's doctrine of avoidable consequences, a party may not recover damages resulting from consequences that it could have reasonably avoided by reasonable care, effort, or expenditure. The duty to mitigate requires only steps that can be taken at small expense or with reasonable exertion, and whether a party acted reasonably in minimizing or avoiding damages is generally a question of fact. The party asserting the doctrine bears the burden of proving that the opposing party could have reasonably avoided the harmful consequences. See Greenway Equip., Inc. v. Johnson, 602 S.W.3d 142 (Ark. Ct. App. 2020); Taylor v. George, 212 S.W.3d 17 (Ark. Ct. App. 2005); Hobson v. Hobson, 715 S.W.3d 890 (Ark. Ct. App. 2025).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court's award of damages for so-called 'unrebutted costs' in the amount of approximately $5.66 million was supported by the evidence and adequate factual findings in the record.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Damages findings in a bench trial are reviewed for clear error. A factual finding is clearly erroneous if it is not supported by substantial evidence, is based on an erroneous view of the law, or leaves the reviewing court with the definite and firm conviction that a mistake has been made. A district court must set forth its reasoning supporting a damages calculation with sufficient clarity to permit appellate review, including stating the basis for each damages category and, where appropriate, referring to specific portions of expert reports or testimony. General references to expert reports are not sufficient. See Lesch v. United States, 612 F.3d 975 (8th Cir. 2010); Kingman v. Dillard's, Inc., 721 F.3d 613 (8th Cir. 2013); IPSCO Tubulars, Inc. v. Ajax TOCCO Magnathermic Corp., 779 F.3d 744 (8th Cir. 2015); Stephenson v. El-Batrawi, 524 F.3d 907 (8th Cir. 2008).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court correctly interpreted Section 10.2 of the Lease in concluding that Fort Worth Partners could not recover any damages for the Building's foundation because the definition of 'Full Replacement Cost' excludes the cost of 'footings, foundations and other structures below grade.'
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Contract interpretation under Arkansas law begins with the plain meaning of the language used, seeking to give effect to the parties' intent as reflected in the contract's words, considered in their ordinary sense. Words of art or terms connected with a particular trade or profession are given the meaning attached to them by experts in that field. When the contract's plain language is susceptible to only one reasonable interpretation, courts enforce that meaning without resort to additional rules of construction. See S. Constr., LLC v. Horton, 609 S.W.3d 16 (Ark. Ct. App. 2020); Les-Bil, Inc. v. Gen. Waterworks Corp., 511 S.W.2d 166 (Ark. 1974); Smart Comms. Collier Inc. v. Pope Cnty. Sheriff's Office, 5 F.4th 895 (8th Cir. 2021).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly reduced Fort Worth Partners' attorney's fees award by 25% based on its assessment that Fort Worth Partners achieved only limited success on its damages claims.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: In fee-shifting contexts, a court has discretion to adjust a reasonable lodestar amount based on the results obtained. Fee awards need not be strictly proportionate to the damages recovered, but a reduction may be appropriate where the prevailing party achieves only partial or limited success. The decision to reduce fees and the amount of any reduction are reviewed for abuse of discretion. See Marshall v. Anderson Excavating & Wrecking Co., 8 F.4th 700 (8th Cir. 2021).

appellant_arguments: Nilfisk argues that Fort Worth Partners' claim is time-barred because the cause of action for breach of the Lease's insurance provision accrued when Nilfisk first obtained and provided a deficient insurance policy and certificate of insurance in 2016. According to Nilfisk, the statute of limitations began running at that time and expired before Fort Worth Partners filed suit, thereby barring any claim based on Nilfisk's failure to maintain full replacement cost insurance.

Nilfisk contends that the doctrine of avoidable consequences precludes or reduces Fort Worth Partners' recovery because Fort Worth Partners could have protected itself by exercising its contractual right to purchase additional full replacement cost insurance and charge the costs to Nilfisk as additional rent. Nilfisk maintains that Fort Worth Partners unreasonably failed to mitigate its damages by not invoking this option despite receiving annual certificates of insurance showing coverage below what Fort Worth Partners now claims was required.

Nilfisk asserts that the district court's award of approximately $5.66 million in 'unrebutted costs' is unsupported by the record because its expert, Jeff Marcussen, in fact addressed and rebutted each of the categories of damages that Fort Worth Partners' expert, Kevin McMahon, identified. Nilfisk contends there were no truly unrebutted line items and that the district court failed to provide sufficiently detailed factual findings to justify that segment of the award.

In response to Fort Worth Partners' cross-appeal on foundation damages, Nilfisk maintains that Section 10.2 of the Lease excludes the entire cost of footings and foundations, whether above or below ground level, as well as other below-grade structures, from the definition of 'Full Replacement Cost.' Under Nilfisk's reading, Fort Worth Partners cannot recover any damages for damage to the foundation because the contract expressly carves out that category of costs.

Regarding attorney's fees, Nilfisk supports the district court's reduction of Fort Worth Partners' fee request, emphasizing that fee awards should reflect the degree of success obtained. Nilfisk points out that Fort Worth Partners sought significantly more in damages than it ultimately recovered, and it argues that the 25% reduction appropriately accounts for Fort Worth Partners' limited success on its damages theories.
appellee_arguments: On the statute of limitations issue, Fort Worth Partners argues that each time Nilfisk procured or renewed an annual insurance policy that failed to meet the Lease's full replacement cost requirement and provided a certificate of insurance, Nilfisk committed a separate and discrete breach, triggering its own limitations period. Fort Worth Partners maintains that, at minimum, its claim based on the 2021 policy in effect when the 2022 tornado destroyed the Building accrued in 2021 and was timely filed within five years.

On the doctrine of avoidable consequences, Fort Worth Partners argues that Nilfisk waived the issue on appeal by not developing it at trial. Fort Worth Partners notes that Nilfisk did not present trial evidence or argument on mitigation and instead merely incorporated by reference its summary judgment briefing in a post-trial filing. Substantively, Fort Worth Partners contends that the doctrine does not apply because it had no obligation to cure Nilfisk's own breach by purchasing additional insurance and that any requirement to do so would entail more than 'small expense' or 'reasonable exertion' as contemplated by Arkansas mitigation law.

Regarding the 'unrebutted costs' component of the damages award, Fort Worth Partners concedes that the district court's label of certain costs as 'unrebutted' is not supported by the trial record in the manner the court described but contends that, when properly supported by the evidence and expert testimony, the amount of damages for those categories should actually be higher than what the district court awarded.

On foundation damages, Fort Worth Partners argues on cross-appeal that the Lease's phrase 'less the cost of footings, foundations and other structures below grade' excludes only the below-grade portions of the foundation and footings from the full replacement cost calculation. Fort Worth Partners maintains that above-grade portions of the foundation and related components should be included in the recoverable full replacement cost, and it disputes the district court's interpretation that precluded any recovery for foundation damage.

Fort Worth Partners further argues that the district court erred, or at least acted too restrictively, in treating the Lease as permitting only a repair remedy for damage to the foundation rather than a replacement remedy, although the court did not ultimately reach this question after concluding that foundation costs were excluded.

As to attorney's fees, Fort Worth Partners contends that the district court abused its discretion by reducing the fee award by 25% on the ground of limited success. Fort Worth Partners argues that it prevailed on its core liability theory and recovered substantial damages, and that fees need not be strictly proportional to the damages amount. It maintains that the reduction undervalues the significance of the relief obtained and the complexity of the litigation.

issue_1.reasoning: The lease imposed a recurring, annual obligation to maintain insurance in a specified amount. Under Arkansas law as explained in Pennington, each discrete breach within the limitations period is actionable even if similar breaches occurred earlier. At a minimum, Nilfisk’s failure to procure adequate coverage under the 2021–22 policy (in force when the tornado occurred) was a separate breach that accrued within five years of suit. Nilfisk’s contrary argument—that everything accrued when it first underinsured in 2016—cuts against Pennington’s treatment of repeated breaches. The district court correctly held the claim timely at least as to the most recent policy, so any limitations defense fails as to the damages at issue.

issue_2.standard_of_review: mixed (underlying factual determinations for clear error; application/waiver issues de novo)
issue_2.reasoning: Nilfisk bore the burden to prove that Fort Worth Partners could reasonably have avoided the loss by purchasing extra insurance and charging the cost back as rent. Nilfisk presented no mitigation evidence at the damages trial, and merely ‘incorporated’ its summary-judgment briefing in a post-trial filing. That does not preserve a factbound mitigation defense or supply a trial record for the court to rely on. The district court expressly noted the absence of trial evidence and declined to apply avoidable consequences, while also reiterating its earlier legal analysis rejecting the theory. On appeal, the issue is effectively waived, and in any event Arkansas mitigation doctrine does not require a non-breaching party to step in and cure the other party’s breach by taking on substantial insurance expenditures. There is no clear error or legal error in rejecting the defense.

issue_3.reasoning: The district court awarded roughly $5.66 million as ‘unrebutted’ costs from McMahon’s estimate. The record, by Nilfisk’s account, shows that Marcussen addressed and disputed every category McMahon presented; Fort Worth Partners itself concedes that the ‘unrebutted’ characterization is not supported by the trial record in the manner the court described. Under Eighth Circuit precedent (Lesch, Kingman, IPSCO, Stephenson), a bench-trial damages award must be supported by specific findings that allow review and must rest on evidence actually in the record, not on a mistaken belief that portions were unrebutted. Here the district court neither identified the precise line items nor reconciled the competing expert opinions, and it premised this large component on an inaccurate description of the evidentiary posture. That combination leaves a definite and firm conviction that a mistake was made and does not permit meaningful appellate review. The appropriate remedy is to vacate and remand for more specific findings and a recalculated damages figure, not to deny damages altogether.

issue_4.reasoning: Section 10.2 defines ‘Full Replacement Cost’ as the cost to replace the premises ‘less the cost of footings, foundations and other structures below grade.’ Read in ordinary commercial-lease usage and consistent with the modifier ‘below grade,’ the most reasonable interpretation is that costs for below-grade portions of the structural system (footings, below-grade foundation, and other subgrade structures) are excluded. The district court construed the phrase to bar all foundation-related damages, including above-grade portions. That reading effectively reads ‘below grade’ out of the clause and is not compelled by the text; ‘foundations’ naturally describes the entire assembly, which is then limited by ‘other structures below grade.’ Fort Worth Partners’ reading—that only below-grade components are excluded, and above-grade foundation damage remains within ‘full replacement cost’—better harmonizes the words used. On de novo review, the district court’s categorical exclusion of all foundation costs is an erroneous interpretation; at minimum, recoverable damages must be reconsidered to include above-grade foundation damage (subject to the separate question whether the lease affords repair versus full replacement for that portion). Thus, the foundation ruling should be reversed and remanded for allocation between excluded and covered components and for consideration of the contractually appropriate remedy.

issue_5.reasoning: The court first reduced the requested fees to reflect prevailing local hourly rates, which Fort Worth Partners does not materially contest on appeal. It then reduced the lodestar by 25% based on limited success, noting that Fort Worth Partners sought substantially more than it recovered and did not prevail on all damages theories (notably, it lost foundation damages in the district court and did not obtain the full replacement-cost figure advanced by its expert). Under Marshall and similar authority, district courts have broad discretion to adjust fees for results obtained, and proportionality to damages is not required but may be considered. A 25% reduction in a case where the plaintiff prevailed on liability but recovered materially less than it sought falls well within the permissible range. Even if Fort Worth Partners ultimately improves its damages recovery on remand, the fee decision made on the record then before the district court was not outside the range of reasonable outcomes. No abuse of discretion is shown.

stage2_decision.reasoning: On the liability and defenses issues (limitations and mitigation), Arkansas law and the trial record favor Fort Worth Partners; the district court correctly recognized a recurring contractual duty to maintain adequate insurance and properly rejected a mitigation theory that Nilfisk neither proved at trial nor grounded in Arkansas’s avoidable-consequences doctrine. Those rulings are likely to be affirmed. The attorney’s fees reduction is reviewed deferentially and is modest, reasoned, and tied to the degree of success; that, too, is unlikely to be disturbed. By contrast, the damages determinations are more vulnerable. The district court’s reliance on a large block of ‘unrebutted’ costs is undermined both by Nilfisk’s record-based challenge and Fort Worth Partners’ concession that the label is inaccurate. Eighth Circuit precedent is strict about requiring specific, evidence-based findings in bench-trial damages awards; this portion will likely be vacated and remanded for clarification and recalculation. On cross-appeal, the lease language about ‘footings, foundations and other structures below grade’ most reasonably excludes only below-grade costs, not all foundation-related damage. The district court’s contrary categorical exclusion misreads the limiting phrase ‘below grade’ and thus is apt to be reversed, with a remand for allocation between excluded below-grade and included above-grade costs and for consideration of the contractually appropriate remedy. The combination—affirmance on issues 1, 2, and 5, with reversal and remand on issues 3 and 4—yields a mixed overall outcome.

parties.appellant: Steven Bernitz, plaintiff in the district court and claimant for long-term disability benefits under his employer’s plan
parties.appellee: USAble Life and Fullscope RMS f/k/a Disability Reinsurance Management Services, defendants in the district court and insurer/claims administrator for the long‑term disability plan

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Steven Bernitz has a long history of back and hip problems and multiple surgeries dating back to 1999. In December 2013, he began working for Synta Pharmaceuticals as Senior Vice President of Corporate Development. Through his employment, he was covered by a long‑term disability insurance plan issued and administered by USAble Life (the "Plan").

The Plan defines "disability" as an injury, sickness, or pregnancy that requires the claimant to be under the regular care of a physician and "prevents you from performing at least one of the material duties of your regular occupation with reasonable accommodations." It further states that if the claimant can perform the material duties of the regular occupation with reasonable accommodations, they will not be considered disabled. A "material duty" is defined as the set of tasks or skills generally required by employers for that occupation and expressly includes the ability to work full‑time as defined in the policy. The Plan requires beneficiaries to provide prompt proof of continuing disability upon request, including a wide range of medical, employment, and financial records, and permits USAble to require independent medical examinations and interviews. Failure to provide continuing proof and necessary authorizations can result in nonpayment of benefits. The Plan grants USAble sole discretionary authority to determine eligibility and interpret policy terms.

In June 2014, due to chronic back pain, Bernitz stopped working at Synta. He submitted a long‑term disability claim to USAble in October 2014. After investigation, USAble approved the claim in March 2015 and then paid monthly disability benefits for approximately five years. During the benefit period, USAble periodically verified his continued eligibility by sending questionnaires about activities of daily living, obtaining Attending Physician’s Statements from his doctors, and monitoring public records and social media.

In December 2014, shortly after his Plan claim, Bernitz applied for Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI). After initial denials, his SSDI claim was heard before an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) in June 2018. The ALJ issued a written decision denying benefits, citing record evidence that Bernitz was taking college classes, driving, taking walks up to half a mile, cooking, taking out the trash, exercising regularly with a personal trainer, traveling to Hawaii and national parks in the Southwest, and spending about a month in San Diego house‑hunting. The ALJ found those activities inconsistent with his statements about the intensity and limiting effects of his symptoms. The Social Security Appeals Council affirmed that decision in August 2019.

While the SSDI claim was pending, USAble continued collecting and reviewing medical records. In May 2017, Bernitz’s pain management specialist, Dr. Yogesh Patel, submitted an Attending Physician’s Statement indicating that Bernitz took gabapentin for pain, should not sit more than one to two hours at a time, should not stand more than thirty minutes at a time, and should avoid repetitive lifting. Dr. Patel described the condition as permanent and irreversible and reported that surgery had resulted in only minor symptom improvement, and that medication side effects made prolonged concentration very difficult or impossible. In a January 2019 Back Disorders Questionnaire, Dr. Patel stated he believed Bernitz would never return to the workforce, full‑time or part‑time.

USAble retained its own reviewing physician, Dr. Stewart Russell, to review Bernitz’s file. In October 2017, after reviewing records from twenty‑one doctors, Dr. Russell opined that, given Bernitz’s pain complaints, multiple low‑back surgeries, osteoarthritis in both knees, and prior shoulder decompression surgery, he did not have the capacity to perform full‑time sedentary or light work.

After learning that the Social Security claim had been denied, USAble sought updated records from Dr. Patel, from endocrinologist Dr. Ken Fujioka, and from primary care physician Dr. Biraj Shah. Those records reflected what USAble viewed as significant improvements in Bernitz’s condition. A January 2018 office note from Dr. Shah stated that Bernitz was preparing for a ten‑day trip to Baja, Mexico and recorded his weight at 288 pounds. An April 2018 note from Dr. Patel reported that Bernitz requested knee injections for an upcoming trip from California to Boston and listed his weight at 275 pounds. An August 2018 note from Dr. Shah recorded his weight at 263 pounds, attributed to steady exercise, and noted that he had stopped taking gabapentin and was playing pickleball and walking six days a week, up to an hour at a time. In March 2019, Dr. Shah saw him for a travel consultation for a two‑week safari to Africa and recorded his weight at 231 pounds. In April 2019, Dr. Patel noted that Bernitz reported substantial relief and improved function with pain medications and reported a weight loss of about 70 pounds and resolution of some other health issues.

Based on what it saw as discrepancies between these activities and earlier disability evidence, USAble arranged surveillance of Bernitz in July, September, and November 2019. The surveillance documented him walking and getting in and out of and driving his car without visible pain behavior or gait abnormalities, and going to a gym to work with a personal trainer, including use of a treadmill, lifting barbells, and using a weight machine.

USAble then obtained another review from Dr. Russell, who in October 2019 reviewed updated records from ten of Bernitz’s doctors. Dr. Russell noted that Bernitz had lost a significant amount of weight, which he believed decompressed the low back and allowed increased activity, and changed his prior opinion, concluding that Bernitz was no longer impaired from performing a full‑time light physical‑demand occupation. He also noted Bernitz’s travel to Boston, Florida, Michigan, Mexico, and Africa in 2018 and 2019. After a follow‑up review in December 2019, including records relating to a September 2019 hip surgery, Dr. Russell maintained that conclusion.

In December 2019, USAble sent a letter terminating Bernitz’s long‑term disability benefits. USAble stated that although he continued to suffer from chronic pain due to failed back surgeries, his activity level had significantly increased since 2018, citing weight loss of approximately 70 pounds, regular exercise, walking six days per week, attempts to play pickleball, working with a personal trainer three days per week for an hour involving aerobic and resistance training, travel within and outside the United States including a two‑week African safari, and volunteer work serving on multiple boards of directors.

In May 2020, Bernitz appealed USAble’s termination decision internally. He submitted advocacy letters from Dr. Fujioka and acupuncturist Dr. Michael White, personal statements from himself and his wife, and a Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) from occupational therapist Barbara Tourtellott. In a letter, Dr. Fujioka clarified earlier records about pickleball, stating that Bernitz had taken a few lessons and attempted to play again once but was unable to continue due to back pain, and suggested any prior notation that he played regularly might have reflected a misunderstanding. Some of Dr. Fujioka’s visit notes from 2018 and 2019, however, had documented that Bernitz had started playing pickleball on off days.

USAble assigned the appeal to senior appeals consultant Sandra Kaserman. USAble retained Dr. Richard Maguire to review updated records. In October 2020, Dr. Maguire reported that the FCE contained inconsistencies and omissions, and, in light of conflicting information in the file and recent surgeries, recommended that Bernitz undergo an independent medical examination (IME). Bernitz declined an IME, citing COVID‑19 concerns. Kaserman instead chose to collect additional records and have a third‑party vendor select another physician to perform a paper review.

The vendor selected Dr. Richard Kaplan, a board‑certified pain medicine specialist, who issued a report in December 2020. Dr. Kaplan identified the same issues with the FCE and concluded that there were numerous inconsistencies in the medical records and in Bernitz’s statements, and that impairment was not supported. He opined that Bernitz was capable of an increased level of activity and that such activity would likely be therapeutic.

In March 2021, Bernitz asked USAble to defer a final decision because he had been referred for neuropsychological testing. Between July and September 2021, Kaserman sent him addendum reports by Drs. Maguire and Kaplan, both reaffirming their earlier conclusions even after reviewing records related to additional back surgery in summer 2021.

In October 2021, Bernitz submitted more evidence, including a vocational assessment by consultant Michael LaRaia and a neuropsychological evaluation by Dr. Kaaren Bekken. LaRaia reported that, in his view, Bernitz remained vocationally unemployable. Dr. Bekken reported finding significant cognitive impairment and concluded that Bernitz was incapacitated from his own occupation.

Kaserman then asked a third‑party vendor to assign a physician to review Dr. Bekken’s neuropsychological report. The vendor selected Dr. Malcolm Spica, who in October 2021 concluded that Dr. Bekken had interpreted average neuropsychological test scores as indicative of impairment without providing supporting evidence. In February 2022, Dr. Kaplan issued another review based on newly updated records, again concluding that Bernitz was not impaired. Kaserman sent these reports to Bernitz in February 2022 and requested a response within 21 days.

Receiving no response within that period, USAble sent a termination letter on March 9, 2022 reaffirming its denial of ongoing benefits. That same day, Bernitz submitted a letter responding to the Kaplan and Spica reports and an additional letter from Dr. Bekken.

USAble later agreed, in August 2022, to conduct a voluntary review of the materials submitted on March 9, 2022. This led to several further written exchanges among Drs. Spica, Kaplan, and Bekken critiquing each other’s positions, but none of the physicians changed their ultimate opinions. In February 2023, USAble issued its final determination letter denying Bernitz’s claim for long‑term disability benefits under the Plan.

procedural_history.claims_brought: On May 1, 2022, after USAble’s March 2022 termination letter and while the voluntary review process was later offered and completed, Steven Bernitz filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts against USAble Life, Fullscope RMS f/k/a Disability Reinsurance Management Services, and the Synta Pharmaceuticals Group Long Term Disability Benefit Plan. The suit challenged the termination and continued denial of his long‑term disability benefits under the ERISA‑governed Plan.
