The question of compensability also implicates how Connecticut courts interpret this definition in light of, or independently from, federal law, including the FLSA and the federal Portal‑to‑Portal Act, and whether they use federal definitions such as the predominant-benefit test applied in FLSA cases.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Connecticut’s wage laws and regulations implicitly or expressly incorporate federal standards under the FLSA and the Portal‑to‑Portal Act, especially regarding the compensability of post‑shift activities such as security screenings.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Connecticut courts often begin with the plain meaning of state statutes and regulations. Where state law is silent or tracks federal language, Connecticut courts may look to the FLSA and related federal precedents for guidance, as in Williams v. General Nutrition Centers, Inc. and Belgada v. Hy’s Livery Service, Inc. However, Connecticut law may provide equal or greater protection than federal law, in which case state law controls. Legislative history and prior Connecticut decisions are used to determine whether the legislature intended consistency with federal wage and hour law.

issues_on_appeal.description: If time spent in mandatory security screenings is deemed compensable under Connecticut law, whether there is a de minimis exception to compensability for very short periods of time, and if so, what amount of time qualifies as de minimis.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Connecticut appellate authority, such as Nettleton v. C&L Diners, LLC, indicates that there is no rigid or precise amount of time that may always be treated as de minimis; instead, common sense is applied to the facts of each case when evaluating whether otherwise compensable time is too trivial to require payment.

appellant_arguments: The plaintiffs contend that time spent in the mandatory security screening process after employees have clocked out but before they can exit the secured area is compensable under Connecticut’s definition of "hours worked." They point to the statutory and regulatory language that includes all time during which an employee is required to be on the employer’s premises, as well as time required to wait on the premises even when no active work is being performed. They assert that because Amazon requires employees to remain on its premises, follow prescribed security procedures, and sometimes wait in line or undergo secondary screening, that time falls squarely within "hours worked."

Plaintiffs argue that Connecticut’s wage laws and regulations are silent on any incorporation of the federal Portal‑to‑Portal Act and do not expressly adopt the federal limitations on compensable time applied in Integrity Staffing Solutions, Inc. v. Busk. They maintain that Connecticut law can and should be interpreted independently from federal law, and that Connecticut has historically allowed its wage laws to provide protections equal to or greater than those guaranteed by the FLSA.

They further assert that the district court improperly assumed that Connecticut’s legislature intended to incorporate both the FLSA and Portal‑to‑Portal Act into its overtime scheme without explicit statutory language to that effect. Plaintiffs requested certification to the Connecticut Supreme Court to answer whether such implicit incorporation was intended and, by implication, whether mandatory security screening time must be compensated under Connecticut law.

To the extent a de minimis doctrine is considered, plaintiffs emphasize that the time spent in security screenings can be significant, varying from a few seconds to several minutes and sometimes up to 10 minutes, and argue that such time is neither trivial nor administratively infeasible to record. They suggest that, especially in the aggregate and on a recurring daily basis, the time is substantial and should not be excluded as de minimis.
appellee_arguments: Defendants argue that the time employees spend in the mandatory security screenings is not compensable under applicable law, relying in part on the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision in Integrity Staffing Solutions, Inc. v. Busk, which held that similar post‑shift security screening time was not compensable under the FLSA as amended by the Portal‑to‑Portal Act. They maintain that this federal framework is the appropriate guide for interpreting Connecticut’s overtime scheme.

Amazon contends that the Connecticut legislature intended its wage and overtime laws to be consistent with federal law, citing legislative history concerning the goal of aligning state overtime provisions with the FLSA. They argue that Connecticut courts, including in cases like Belgada and Williams, have looked to federal law to interpret ambiguous or undefined wage and hour terms, and that the district court correctly followed that approach in concluding that the post‑shift security screening was not compensable.

Defendants assert that the statutory definition of "hours worked" in Conn. Gen. Stat. § 31-76b(2)(A) does not itself identify which periods are legally compensable, and that Connecticut law should be construed to follow federal principles about which pre‑ and post‑shift activities are compensable. Under that view, the security screenings are non‑compensable preliminary or postliminary activities.

Regarding any de minimis issue, defendants emphasize that the amount of time spent by many employees in security screenings is very short, sometimes on the order of seconds, and that even if some of this time were theoretically compensable under a broad reading of "hours worked," it should be treated as de minimis and not subject to payment obligations.

issue_1.reasoning: The question whether post–clock-out security-screening time falls within Connecticut’s definition of “hours worked” is a pure question of state-law interpretation applied on undisputed facts, so review is de novo. Connecticut’s statutory and regulatory text is broader than the federal Portal-to-Portal framework. Conn. Agencies Regs. § 31‑60‑11 explicitly defines hours worked to include “all time during which an employee is required by the employer to be on the employer’s premises or to be on duty, or to be at the prescribed work place,” and further includes time when the employee is required to wait on the premises even if no work is provided. Here, Amazon required employees, after clocking out, to remain on its premises and to pass through employer-controlled security checkpoints in order to leave, sometimes waiting in line or undergoing secondary screening. On the plain language, that time fits squarely within “hours worked.” The district court effectively overlaid the Busk/Portal‑to‑Portal analysis onto this broader state regulatory text and treated the post‑shift security check as non-compensable “postliminary” activity. A de novo reviewing court is likely to find that this approach gives insufficient weight to the Connecticut regulation’s inclusive definition and its waiting-time language, and that nothing in the Connecticut scheme narrows compensable “hours worked” to exclude this kind of required on‑premises waiting and screening. Accordingly, the grant of summary judgment holding such time non‑compensable is likely to be reversed.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether Connecticut’s wage statutes and regulations implicitly incorporate FLSA and Portal‑to‑Portal standards is again a question of law. Connecticut decisions such as Williams and Belgada look to federal law as persuasive guidance where state language is parallel or ambiguous, but they do not hold that Connecticut silently adopted all federal limitations, particularly the Portal‑to‑Portal carve‑outs. Connecticut’s overtime statute and, especially, its detailed regulatory definition of “hours worked” were enacted and maintained without any express reference to the Portal‑to‑Portal Act, despite the legislature’s ability to do so. The regulation affirmatively expands compensable time to all required on‑premises time and certain waiting periods, which is inconsistent with importing wholesale the narrower federal concept that excludes many post‑shift activities unless integral and indispensable to principal duties. Given this textual and structural difference, a court conducting de novo review is likely to reject the district court’s conclusion that Connecticut implicitly incorporated the federal Portal‑to‑Portal limitations and Busk’s specific holding on security screenings. Federal law may remain a background reference point, but it does not override Connecticut’s more expansive definition. On that issue, the district court’s reasoning is likely to be reversed.

issue_3.reasoning: The existence and general contours of any de minimis doctrine under Connecticut wage law are legal questions reviewed de novo. Nettleton indicates that Connecticut does recognize a common‑sense, fact‑specific de minimis concept, without a rigid numerical threshold. The record here shows that some employees spent only seconds, others several minutes, and occasionally up to about ten minutes in screening. On summary judgment, the district court treated the entire category of screening time as non‑compensable, not as compensable but potentially de minimis in specific, very short instances; the de minimis question was not the basis for dismissal. A reviewing court that concludes such time is in principle compensable is unlikely to hold, as a matter of law, that all such time is de minimis, because some instances (3–4 minutes routinely, and occasionally up to 10 minutes) are plainly more than trivial. At the same time, the appellate court will likely agree with the district court to the limited extent that Connecticut law permits treating truly trivial, hard‑to‑record increments as de minimis. Thus, the district court would be affirmed on the existence of a de minimis concept, but its summary judgment ruling cannot be sustained on that ground; the proper course is to remand for factual development on how much time was actually spent and whether any subset is de minimis. Accordingly, on the narrow legal question posed—whether there is a de minimis exception—the answer is yes, and the district court is effectively affirmed on that legal point while the case is remanded for further proceedings on compensability and damages.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Applying de novo review, the appellate court is likely to emphasize the breadth of Connecticut’s regulatory definition of “hours worked,” which plainly reaches time that employees are required to spend on the employer’s premises, including required waiting, even after they have clocked out. That language, coupled with the absence of any express adoption of the Portal‑to‑Portal Act, supports treating mandatory exit security screening time as compensable under state law. The district court’s reliance on Busk and on an implied incorporation of Portal‑to‑Portal limitations therefore rests on a legal conclusion that is vulnerable on appeal. At the same time, Connecticut precedent recognizes a flexible de minimis concept, so the appellate court will not reject the idea that very short, truly trivial increments of time might be non‑compensable under common‑sense principles. The likely disposition is to reverse the grant of summary judgment on the core questions of compensability and incorporation of federal standards, clarify that Connecticut law covers such required on‑premises screening time (subject to a possible de minimis carve‑out in appropriate factual circumstances), and remand for further proceedings rather than enter judgment for plaintiffs. That results in a mixed outcome: reversal on the main legal issues, but effective affirmance that Connecticut allows some de minimis treatment, with the case remanded for fact‑specific application of that doctrine and determination of any unpaid straight‑time and overtime wages and class certification issues not reached below.

parties.appellant: United States of America, plaintiff in the enforcement action under the False Claims Act and Anti-Kickback Statute
parties.appellee: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc., defendant alleged to have violated the Anti-Kickback Statute and caused the submission of false claims to Medicare

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc. manufactures Eylea, a drug approved by the Food and Drug Administration to treat neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD), an ophthalmological condition. Eylea is reimbursed under Medicare Part B as a 'buy and bill' drug, meaning physicians purchase the drug, prescribe and administer it in their offices, and then submit reimbursement claims to Medicare. Under Part B’s cost-sharing rules, Medicare typically covers 80% of the drug’s cost and the patient is responsible for the remaining 20%. Eylea is expensive: since 2013, Medicare Part B has spent over $11.5 billion on Eylea, one injection costs about $1,850, and patients require multiple injections per year, leading to annual co-pays that routinely exceed $2,000. For some patients, these co-pay obligations may deter use of Eylea. Although only a few drugs are FDA-approved for wet AMD, at least one significantly cheaper drug is available for off-label use, creating an economic incentive for patients and physicians to choose less costly alternatives if co-pays are high.

These cost dynamics create an incentive for the manufacturer to alleviate patients’ co-pays so that Eylea is more attractive relative to alternatives. A drug priced, for example, at $1,850 with a $330 co-pay may be less attractive to patients than a higher list price drug effectively carrying no co-pay from the patient’s perspective if the co-pay is covered. Insurers, not manufacturers, set the co-pay to ensure patients have financial responsibility in treatment decisions, but a patient who expects that the manufacturer (directly or indirectly) will cover the co-pay may effectively experience no cost-sharing burden.

The federal Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS) criminalizes knowingly and willfully offering or paying remuneration to induce a person to purchase, lease, order, or recommend purchasing or ordering any item or service for which payment may be made under a federal health care program. All parties assume, for purposes of this appeal, that a direct rebate or payment by a manufacturer of a Medicare patient’s or doctor’s co-pay would constitute a kickback under the AKS. Some manufacturers have attempted indirect arrangements by donating to ostensibly independent charitable foundations that provide copayment assistance to patients with particular diseases or conditions. The manufacturer donates to the foundation, and the foundation, in turn, furnishes co-pay assistance to patients (or to physicians on patients’ behalf). Because such arrangements can function as conduits for improper remuneration, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has issued guidance to distinguish truly independent co-pay assistance programs from impermissible rebate conduits.

In this case, brought under the False Claims Act (FCA), the United States alleges that Regeneron crossed the line into an unlawful conduit arrangement by paying more than $60 million over four to five years to the Chronic Disease Fund (CDF), a charitable foundation that provides copayment assistance to patients suffering from wet AMD. The government contends that some or all of these donations were, in substance, remuneration intended to induce the use and purchase of Eylea by reducing or eliminating Medicare patients’ co-pays, and therefore constituted unlawful kickbacks under the AKS. The government further alleges that when physicians prescribed Eylea to Medicare patients who received co-pay assistance funded by Regeneron’s donations and then submitted Medicare Part B reimbursement claims for those Eylea treatments, those claims were tainted by the kickbacks. According to the government, the claims for Medicare reimbursement for Eylea administered to patients benefiting from that assistance were 'claims that include items or services resulting from' an AKS violation within the meaning of the 2010 amendment to the AKS, and thus are 'false or fraudulent' claims under the FCA.

Regeneron disputes the government’s causation theory. It maintains that a claim 'results from' an AKS violation, under the 2010 amendment, only if the illegal remuneration is a but-for cause of the provision of the items or services and the corresponding claim submitted to the government. Regeneron contends that if a physician would have prescribed Eylea and sought Medicare reimbursement regardless of the copay assistance funded by Regeneron’s donations to CDF, then the Medicare claim does not 'result from' any alleged AKS violation.

procedural_history.claims_brought: The United States brought a civil enforcement action under the False Claims Act premised on alleged violations of the Anti-Kickback Statute. The government claimed that Regeneron’s donations to the Chronic Disease Fund constituted illegal kickbacks intended to induce prescriptions of Eylea for Medicare beneficiaries, and that Medicare Part B reimbursement claims submitted for Eylea treatments to patients whose co-pays were assisted through those donations were false or fraudulent claims under the FCA pursuant to the 2010 amendment to the AKS, 42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b(g).
procedural_history.district_court_decision: On cross-motions for summary judgment under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56, the key dispute focused on the causation requirement imposed by the 2010 amendment’s phrase 'resulting from.' Regeneron argued that the amendment requires the government to prove that an AKS violation actually caused a physician to provide different medical treatment and thus caused the claims at issue, i.e., that the illegal remuneration was a but-for cause of the challenged claims. The government argued that causation was satisfied if a patient was exposed to an illegal inducement and the provider submitted a claim for services to that patient, even if the claim would have been submitted absent the inducement. The district court, relying on decisions from the Sixth and Eighth Circuits, interpreted 'resulting from' in the 2010 amendment as imposing a but-for causation requirement for purposes of establishing falsity under that amendment. The court also determined that, notwithstanding that interpretation, the government had offered sufficient evidence to create a triable issue on but-for causation and therefore to withstand summary judgment on that element. Observing a conflict in case law among circuits and emphasizing that the causation standard was pivotal to this case and to at least one other similar case in the District of Massachusetts, the district court certified its causation ruling for interlocutory appeal under 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The United States appeals the district court’s interlocutory ruling that the phrase 'resulting from' in the 2010 amendment to the Anti-Kickback Statute requires proof of but-for causation in order for a claim to be deemed false or fraudulent under the False Claims Act on a per se basis. The appeal concerns the proper legal standard of causation that must be met to link an AKS violation to the falsity of claims under the FCA via the 2010 amendment.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, under the 2010 amendment to the Anti-Kickback Statute providing that 'a claim that includes items or services resulting from a violation of [the AKS] constitutes a false or fraudulent claim for purposes of' the False Claims Act, the government must prove that the AKS violation was a but-for cause of the submission of the claim, or whether it is sufficient to show a looser causal nexus such as that the patient or provider was merely exposed to an illegal inducement prior to the claim.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Interpretation of statutory causation language is a question of law reviewed de novo. Under Supreme Court precedent, phrases such as 'results from' or 'as a result of' are generally understood to impose a requirement of actual causality that ordinarily takes the form of but-for causation, absent textual or contextual indications that Congress intended a different causal standard. However, courts may adopt alternative causal standards when the statutory text or overall structure and purpose indicate that a strict but-for requirement would undermine congressional intent. The question here is whether any such textual or contextual indications exist in the AKS/FCA framework or related statutory history to displace the default but-for causation understanding of 'resulting from' in 42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b(g).

appellant_arguments: The United States argues that the 2010 amendment should not be read to impose a strict but-for causation requirement. Relying on the Third Circuit’s approach in Greenfield v. Medco Health Solutions, Inc., it contends that causation is satisfied when a particular patient is exposed to an illegal kickback, recommendation, or referral and the provider subsequently submits a claim for reimbursement for services or items furnished to that patient. Under this view, the government need not prove that the device or drug would not have been used, or the claim would not have been submitted, but for the kickback.

The government emphasizes that the Anti-Kickback Statute’s 'animating principle' is that financial conflicts of interest can themselves corrupt medical decisionmaking. It notes that criminal liability under the AKS does not require proof that an illegal payment actually changed a physician’s conduct or caused a particular claim; rather, the statute focuses on the offer or payment of remuneration to induce referrals or purchases. According to the government, because the 2010 amendment was 'built on' the AKS and designed to strengthen its enforcement through the FCA, the amendment should not impose a more demanding causation standard than the AKS itself effectively requires.

The government asserts that Congress enacted the 2010 amendment against a backdrop of 'false-certification' FCA decisions that allowed FCA liability based on AKS violations without any but-for causation element. Those cases held that falsely representing compliance with the AKS, where compliance was material to payment, rendered claims false under the FCA. The government argues that Congress’s adoption of the 2010 amendment should be understood as codifying and expanding that regime, not narrowing it by adding a strict but-for causation requirement that had not previously existed in AKS-based FCA cases.

The United States points to the legislative history of the 2010 amendment, including statements by Senator Ted Kaufman, indicating that Congress intended to 'ensure that all claims resulting from illegal kickbacks are false or fraudulent, even when the claims are not submitted directly by the wrongdoers themselves.' It cites the example of Thomas v. Bailey, where FCA liability was not found in a kickback situation because the hospital submitting claims had not itself falsely certified AKS compliance. The government contends that the amendment was meant to close that type of gap and facilitate FCA enforcement without requiring proof that the kickback was a but-for cause of individual claims.

The government argues that imposing a but-for standard would unduly hamper enforcement because it is often difficult to prove why a particular physician prescribed a given drug or used a particular device. It contends that requiring a showing that the claim would not have been submitted absent the kickback would create significant evidentiary obstacles and undermine the practical effect of the 2010 amendment, contrary to Congress’s objective of strengthening fraud enforcement in the healthcare context.
appellee_arguments: Regeneron argues that the plain text of the 2010 amendment, which uses the phrase 'resulting from,' incorporates a requirement of actual causation and, under Supreme Court precedent, that phrase presumptively means but-for causation. Regeneron relies on decisions such as Burrage v. United States and Paroline v. United States, which interpret similar language ('results from,' 'as a result of') as imposing but-for causation in the absence of contrary textual or contextual indications.

Regeneron contends that the government’s proposed 'exposure' standard is inconsistent with the statutory language because it does not require any actual causal effect of the kickback on the decision to prescribe the drug or submit the claim. Under the government’s theory, claims could be deemed to 'result from' an AKS violation even if the illegal payment had no influence at all on the physician’s treatment decision or the patient’s use of Eylea. Regeneron maintains that this would effectively read the causation requirement out of the statute.

Regeneron argues that there is no textual indication in the 2010 amendment itself that Congress intended to depart from the ordinary but-for causation standard. Nor, in its view, does the broader statutory context or legislative history suggest that Congress meant to impose a more relaxed causation standard. Regeneron notes that Congress could have specified that any claim associated with an AKS violation is automatically false under the FCA but instead chose language that conditions falsity on the claim 'resulting from' the violation.

Regeneron distinguishes the AKS’s criminal provisions from the civil FCA context, arguing that it is neither unusual nor problematic for related criminal and civil statutes to have different elements or evidentiary requirements. The AKS’s criminal prohibition on offering or paying remuneration to induce referrals serves the distinct purpose of protecting patients and policing conflicts of interest, whereas the FCA’s civil remedies are primarily remedial and aimed at recouping money paid out by the government due to fraud. Regeneron argues that it is therefore reasonable for FCA liability under the 2010 amendment to require proof that the AKS violation actually caused the government to pay claims it otherwise would not have paid.

Regeneron also notes that the 2010 amendment establishes an additional, distinct pathway to FCA liability separate from the pre-existing false-certification theory. Under false-certification, FCA liability can attach where a defendant misrepresents compliance with the AKS and that misrepresentation is material to payment; under the 2010 amendment, there is no need for any representation of compliance, but there is a causation element. Regeneron argues that it is appropriate that this alternative per se falsity route includes a but-for causation requirement, and that nothing in the statute’s history or structure suggests Congress sought to create a broader, no-causation-required basis for FCA liability.

Applying its interpretation to the underlying facts, Regeneron asserts that the government must prove that the alleged unlawful donations to CDF were a but-for cause of the prescriptions and resulting Medicare claims for Eylea. Regeneron maintains that if physicians would have prescribed Eylea and submitted the same Medicare claims even in the absence of any Regeneron-funded co-pay assistance, those claims cannot be considered to 'result from' an AKS violation within the meaning of the 2010 amendment.

issue_1.reasoning:
The causation question turns on the meaning of the phrase “resulting from” in 42 U.S.C. § 1320a‑7b(g), a pure issue of statutory interpretation reviewed de novo. The district court adopted a but‑for causation requirement based on Burrage/Paroline and followed the Sixth and Eighth Circuits. On de novo review, however, the better reading in context is that Congress did not intend strict but‑for causation.

Textually, “resulting from” ordinarily signals actual causation, but Supreme Court cases make clear that this default can be displaced where statutory context and purpose indicate otherwise. Here, the 2010 amendment was enacted specifically to strengthen AKS‑based FCA enforcement, against a backdrop of pre‑amendment cases that permitted FCA liability on AKS violations without requiring proof of but‑for causation of individual claims. The amendment’s structure—tying per se falsity to claims that include items or services “resulting from” an AKS violation—was meant to close gaps like Thomas v. Bailey, i.e., to ensure that claims submitted by entities downstream from the kickback payor could still be false without an express false certification by the submitter, not to narrow the then‑existing causation regime.

Reading “resulting from” to require but‑for causation would make FCA liability turn on highly individualized proof of why particular doctors prescribed particular drugs, undermining the evident purpose of the amendment and making it more demanding than the AKS criminal provision itself, which does not require proof that a particular payment actually changed a prescribing decision. The government’s proposed exposure‑plus‑claim nexus—requiring that the claim be for items or services furnished to a patient who was exposed to the illegal remuneration tied to that product or referral—retains a real causal connection while avoiding the practical nullification of the 2010 amendment. In light of the statute’s text, the pre‑existing FCA doctrine Congress built upon, and the enforcement‑strengthening purpose reflected in the legislative history, the appellate court is likely to reject a strict but‑for causation requirement and adopt a looser causal nexus rather than the district court’s rule.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
This interlocutory appeal presents a single, purely legal question about the causation standard under the AKS’s 2010 amendment. Although Burrage and similar cases create a strong linguistic presumption that “results from” denotes but‑for causation, that presumption is not irrebuttable and must be evaluated in the statute’s context. Here the context is distinctive: Congress acted in 2010 to solidify and extend AKS‑based FCA liability in response to case law requiring false certification by the claim submitter. The amendment’s language and history suggest Congress intended to make it easier—not harder— to reach claims tainted by kickbacks, including claims submitted by parties other than the kickback payor. Imposing a but‑for requirement would significantly weaken that mechanism by creating a demanding, physician‑specific causation proof that was not part of the pre‑2010 landscape that Congress was codifying and extending.

The government’s position that a claim is per se false if it is for services furnished to a patient exposed to the illegal remuneration creates a meaningful, though non‑but‑for, causal nexus that fits both the AKS’s focus on corrupting influence and the amendment’s objective to tie such influence to FCA liability. This reading also preserves the distinct roles of the amendment (per se falsity tied to causation) and traditional false‑certification theories without reading the causation phrase out of the statute. Balancing the textual presumption with the strong contextual signals, and in light of the explicit inter‑circuit disagreement that prompted certification, the more likely appellate outcome is to reject the strict but‑for standard adopted by the district court and remand under a more relaxed, exposure‑plus‑claim causal framework—thus reversing the district court’s legal ruling on the causation standard while leaving intact its determination that the government had adduced sufficient evidence to reach trial under the proper standard.

parties.appellant: James R. Edwards, substituted for his father, Jimmy (James R.) Edwards, who was the plaintiff in the district court and the widower/beneficiary seeking life insurance benefits
parties.appellee: Guardian Life Insurance of America, defendant in the district court and issuer/administrator of the group life insurance policy

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Pamela (Pam) Edwards owned and operated a beauty salon in Starkville, Mississippi, called Allure Salon. In 2007, she purchased a life insurance policy from Guardian Life Insurance of America. According to the record, she obtained the policy because she wanted to be sure she had something to leave to her husband, Jimmy Edwards. Pam handled all of Allure’s financial matters, and Jimmy was unaware of the existence of the Guardian policy until after her death.

Pam was diagnosed with cancer in 2019 and thereafter underwent radiation, chemotherapy, and surgery. Her cancer never went into remission, and she died on May 27, 2022. After her death, insurance agent Debbie Jaudon informed Jimmy that Pam had a Guardian life insurance policy. Jaudon then requested a life claim form from Guardian so that Jimmy could claim benefits.

Guardian responded that the policy had been cancelled before Pam’s death. Guardian characterized the coverage as a group policy issued to Allure Salon to cover multiple Allure employees. Guardian asserted that in November 2019 the number of covered participants under the policy dropped to one—Pam—triggering a contractual right under the policy allowing Guardian to cancel coverage when fewer than two employees are insured. Guardian maintained that it later exercised this right and cancelled Pam’s coverage effective January 15, 2022. Guardian acknowledged that in September 2020 it had temporarily suspended its practice of terminating plans that had dropped to one participant, citing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, and that it later resumed normal cancellation practices. There is a 10‑month period between November 1, 2019 (when Pam allegedly became the sole covered employee) and September 2020 (when Guardian began its temporary suspension policy). Guardian accepted premiums for 26 months after the date it claims its cancellation right first vested. It remained unexplained in the record why Guardian never sent a notice of cancellation to Jaudon, Pam’s insurance agent.

The record reflects that Allure had salon technicians working at the salon. Pam owned the salon building and equipment, controlled the salon hours, and received gross receipts from clients into the Allure business account. From that account, she paid the technicians. Allure paid the insurance premiums for the coverage, and these premium payments provided Allure with favorable tax treatment. The technicians’ work was part of Allure’s regular business of operating a salon.

Jimmy Edwards later passed away during the pendency of the appellate proceedings. His son, James R. Edwards, as executor of Jimmy’s estate, was substituted as appellant.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Jimmy Edwards filed suit against Guardian Life Insurance of America in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi (Case No. 1:22‑CV‑145). He asserted various claims under Mississippi common law arising out of Guardian’s refusal to pay life insurance benefits on Pam’s policy. In the alternative, he alleged that the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) entitled him to recover benefits under the plan.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: Guardian moved for partial summary judgment, arguing that the Allure Salon policy was governed by ERISA, that an ERISA employee benefit plan existed, and that ERISA therefore preempted Edwards’s Mississippi common‑law claims. The district court granted Guardian’s motion for partial summary judgment on those grounds, concluding that ERISA applied to the plan and that the state‑law claims were preempted.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Jimmy Edwards appealed the district court’s grant of partial summary judgment in favor of Guardian. On appeal, he challenges the district court’s determination that ERISA governs the Allure policy and preempts his common‑law claims, and he seeks review of the treatment of his claim for plan benefits in light of Guardian’s alleged cancellation and its continued acceptance of premiums.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the Allure Salon life insurance arrangement with Guardian constituted an ERISA-governed employee welfare benefit plan, including whether Allure had "employees" within the meaning of ERISA as opposed to only a sole owner (Pam) and any non-employee workers such as independent contractors.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: ERISA applies to any employee benefit plan established or maintained by an employer engaged in commerce. 29 U.S.C. § 1003(a)(1). To determine whether a policy is an ERISA employee benefit plan, the Fifth Circuit applies the three-step test from Meredith v. Time Ins. Co.: (1) whether a plan exists; (2) whether it falls within the Department of Labor safe-harbor provision; and (3) whether it satisfies the primary elements of an employee benefit plan, including establishment or maintenance by an employer intending to benefit employees. Employee benefit plans do not include plans that cover only sole owners or partners and their spouses. Whether a person is an "employee" for ERISA purposes is determined by federal common law using the multi-factor test set out in Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Darden and Community for Creative Non-Violence v. Reid, which incorporates traditional agency principles and places special emphasis on the putative employer’s control over the workers.

issues_on_appeal.description: Assuming ERISA applies, whether Guardian properly exercised, or instead waived, its contractual right under the policy to cancel coverage when the number of insured employees fell below two, given its continued acceptance of premiums for an extended period after that right allegedly vested and its COVID‑related suspension of cancellation practices.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under the terms of the Guardian policy, Guardian reserved the right to cancel any coverage when fewer than two employees are insured. Where a plan grants the insurer discretionary authority, an ERISA plan administrator’s benefit determinations, including cancellation decisions, are typically reviewed under an abuse-of-discretion standard, which requires only that there be evidence clearly supporting the basis for the denial of benefits. However, an insurer may waive a known contractual right, including the right to cancel coverage, through unilateral conduct such as accepting premiums for a significant period after the right accrues. The waiver inquiry focuses on the insurer’s failure to assert a known right at the outset and its continued acceptance of premiums with knowledge of the facts giving rise to that right, as discussed in Pitts ex rel. Pitts v. American Security Life Ins. Co. and Rhorer v. Raytheon Engineers and Constructors, Inc.

appellant_arguments: The Allure Salon policy did not fall under ERISA, or at least the district court improperly concluded that it did. Appellant contends that Allure did not maintain an ERISA employee benefit plan because the salon technicians were not "employees" within the meaning of ERISA and federal common law, but rather independent contractors, such that the plan effectively covered only Pam as owner (and possibly her spouse). Plans covering only owners and their spouses are excluded from ERISA, so ERISA should not apply and his Mississippi common-law claims should not be preempted.

Even if ERISA applies, Guardian should be deemed to have waived its right to cancel the policy based on the one-employee provision. Appellant argues that Guardian’s cancellation right allegedly vested when Pam became the sole participating employee in November 2019, yet Guardian continued to accept premiums from Allure for approximately 26 months thereafter, including for a substantial period before Guardian’s claimed COVID-related non-cancellation policy began. This conduct, under Fifth Circuit precedent, constitutes a waiver of the right to cancel. Because Guardian accepted premiums long after it knew or should have known that only one employee was covered, and because Pam’s deteriorating health prevented her from addressing coverage issues in the final months of her life, Guardian should be required to honor the policy and pay the death benefit.
appellee_arguments: The Allure Salon policy is an ERISA-governed employee welfare benefit plan because Allure had employees, not just the owner and spouse, participating in the plan. Guardian argues that the salon technicians were employees under the Darden/Reid multi-factor test. Pam owned the building and equipment and controlled where and when the technicians worked; Allure paid their insurance premiums and obtained favorable tax treatment; and the technicians’ work was part of Allure’s regular business. Thus, the Meredith factors are satisfied and ERISA applies, preempting Jimmy Edwards’s Mississippi common-law claims.

Guardian had and exercised a valid contractual right to cancel the group policy when the number of insured employees dropped below two. Guardian asserts that this right vested when Pam became the sole covered participant and that cancellation was eventually effectuated on January 15, 2022. Guardian contends that its temporary suspension of cancellations during the COVID-19 pandemic was a discretionary, compassionate measure, not a waiver of its rights. It maintains that the continued acceptance of premiums during this period does not, under the governing waiver principles, strip it of the ability to invoke the cancellation provision or deny benefits based on the policy’s termination.

issue_1.reasoning: Whether the Allure Salon arrangement is an ERISA employee welfare benefit plan is a legal question reviewed de novo, applying the Meredith three‑step test and the Darden/Reid common‑law employee standard. The undisputed facts show that Pam owned the shop and equipment, controlled the hours and the place of work, and that the technicians’ work was part of Allure’s regular business. Premiums were paid by the business and used for favorable tax treatment. Those are classic indicators of an employment relationship under Darden, and the record does not provide strong, countervailing facts (e.g., evidence of technician ownership, separate business risk, or substantial autonomy inconsistent with employee status). With at least two such workers covered initially, the arrangement qualifies as an ERISA employee welfare benefit plan rather than a plan covering only a sole owner and spouse, so ERISA applies and preempts the Mississippi common‑law claims. Under de novo review, the appellate court is likely to agree with the district court’s conclusion that ERISA governs.

issue_2.standard_of_review: abuse of discretion (to the extent the district court reached the merits under ERISA); otherwise de novo as a legal question on summary judgment
issue_2.reasoning: The waiver/cancellation dispute arises within ERISA’s framework. Where the plan grants Guardian discretionary authority, benefit‑denial decisions are reviewed for abuse of discretion. To the extent the district court treated the question at the summary‑judgment stage, the existence of waiver is resolved as a legal issue on an undisputed factual record, also reviewed de novo. The record shows Guardian reserved the right to cancel when fewer than two employees were insured and ultimately cancelled coverage effective January 15, 2022. Although Guardian continued to accept premiums after its cancellation right allegedly vested in November 2019 and instituted a COVID‑related moratorium in September 2020, there is no clear indication that Guardian intentionally relinquished the contractual right itself, as opposed to temporarily delaying its exercise as part of a general, pandemic‑driven policy. The unexplained delay and continued premium collection create an equitable concern but do not compel a finding, as a matter of law, that Guardian waived its right to terminate coverage before Pam’s death. Under deferential review, the cancellation date and denial of benefits fall within the range of reasonable interpretations of the plan and Guardian’s rights under it. Accordingly, the district court’s disposition of the ERISA‑benefits/waiver issue is likely to be upheld.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
The core question is whether ERISA applies so as to preempt the plaintiff’s state‑law claims. On the undisputed facts, Allure’s technicians appear to be common‑law employees under the Darden factors: Pam supplied the place of work and equipment, controlled the salon’s operations and hours, paid workers from the business account, and provided insurance premiums with favorable tax treatment. Those facts comfortably support the district court’s conclusion that an ERISA employee welfare benefit plan existed. Because ERISA avoids coverage when only a sole owner (and spouse) is insured, appellant’s exclusion argument is comparatively weaker. Given de novo review and the Fifth Circuit’s general approach in similar small‑business ERISA cases, affirmance on issue 1 is likely.

Once ERISA applies, the dispute over Guardian’s cancellation and alleged waiver is governed by ERISA standards and the plan language. Guardian expressly reserved a right to cancel when participation fell below two, and it ultimately set a cancellation effective date before Pam’s death. While Guardian accepted premiums long after its right arguably vested and maintained a COVID‑related suspension of cancellations, those facts do not necessarily establish, as a matter of law, that Guardian waived the right to terminate. Waiver in this context requires clear evidence that the insurer intentionally relinquished a known contractual right; mere delay in exercising it, especially under a generalized, temporary moratorium, is typically insufficient. On abuse‑of‑discretion review, that record supports upholding Guardian’s termination decision. The panel therefore has no strong basis to disturb the district court’s partial summary judgment, making overall affirmance the most probable outcome.

parties.appellant: Ana I. Escobar-Pabón, Secretary of the Puerto Rico Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation; Héctor Hernández-Morales, Warden; and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico (respondents in the § 2254 proceeding, appealing from the grant of habeas relief)
parties.appellee: David Núñez-Pérez (state prisoner; petitioner in the § 2254 habeas action; originally a criminal defendant in federal court and in Puerto Rico court)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
On July 24, 2001, David Núñez-Pérez was indicted in the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico on one federal carjacking count under 18 U.S.C. § 2119(3) and two related federal firearms counts under 18 U.S.C. § 924(c)(1)(A)(ii), § 922(g)(1), and § 924(a)(2). The federal charges arose from an incident that also led to subsequent Commonwealth charges.

In February 2002, many months after the federal indictment, Núñez was indicted in Puerto Rico superior court under Puerto Rico law for offenses arising from the same alleged incident. The Puerto Rico indictment charged him with carjacking, first-degree murder, and two weapons possession counts under Puerto Rico law.

On May 2, 2002, Núñez pleaded guilty to the federal carjacking charge. Shortly thereafter, he was sentenced in federal court to ten years' imprisonment for that conviction, and the federal firearms counts were dismissed.

On November 14, 2003, after a jury trial in Puerto Rico superior court, Núñez was found guilty of Puerto Rico carjacking and weapons charges and of the lesser-included Puerto Rico offense of manslaughter (rather than first-degree murder). He received a 69-year Puerto Rico prison sentence for those convictions, to be served consecutively to his ten-year federal sentence.

Núñez appealed his Puerto Rico convictions, raising various issues and specifically challenging the constitutionality of his Puerto Rico sentence on the ground that he was already serving a federal sentence for the same conduct. The Puerto Rico Court of Appeals treated this as a Double Jeopardy Clause claim and rejected it, reasoning that Puerto Rico and the federal government were separate sovereigns and therefore both could independently punish the same conduct. Núñez then sought certiorari from the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico, which was denied on February 2, 2007.

On June 9, 2016, the Supreme Court of the United States decided Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle, 579 U.S. 59, holding that the United States and Puerto Rico are not separate sovereigns for Double Jeopardy purposes and that neither may successively prosecute a single defendant for the same criminal conduct.

One year and eleven days after Sánchez Valle was decided, Núñez filed a postconviction motion in Puerto Rico court under Rule 192.1 of the Puerto Rico Rules of Criminal Procedure, seeking collateral relief from his Puerto Rico carjacking and manslaughter convictions on the ground that, under Sánchez Valle, those convictions violated the Double Jeopardy Clause given his prior federal carjacking conviction based on the same conduct.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
After his direct appeal in the Puerto Rico courts concluded with the February 2, 2007 denial of certiorari by the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico, Núñez later initiated collateral proceedings. Following the 2016 decision in Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle, he filed a Puerto Rico Rule 192.1 postconviction motion arguing that the rule announced in Sánchez Valle barred his Puerto Rico carjacking and manslaughter convictions under the Double Jeopardy Clause because they arose from the same conduct as his prior federal carjacking conviction.

After denial of his Rule 192.1 motion and subsequent certiorari petitions, Núñez filed a federal petition for a writ of habeas corpus under 28 U.S.C. § 2254 in the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. In his § 2254 petition, filed pro se on May 21, 2019 (deemed filed on the mailing date, though docketed June 7, 2019), he contended that Sánchez Valle announced a rule that applied retroactively to his Puerto Rico convictions and that he was therefore entitled to habeas relief from his Puerto Rico carjacking and manslaughter convictions under the Double Jeopardy Clause. After counsel was appointed, a supplemental motion in support of the habeas petition was filed on October 23, 2020.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
The Puerto Rico Rule 192.1 court denied Núñez's postconviction motion on September 12, 2018. His petitions for certiorari to the Puerto Rico Court of Appeals and the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico were denied on December 18, 2018, and February 15, 2019, respectively. The Supreme Court of Puerto Rico also denied two motions for reconsideration.

In the subsequent federal habeas proceeding, after the respondents moved to dismiss, the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico addressed the statute of limitations under 28 U.S.C. § 2244(d)(1), requested supplemental briefing, held a hearing on November 4, 2021, and later ordered the respondents to file an answer pursuant to Habeas Rule 5. Ultimately, on August 1, 2022, the district court denied the respondents' motion to dismiss and granted the § 2254 petition. The district court determined that § 2244(d)(1)(C) provided the limitations trigger date because it found Sánchez Valle to be a new constitutional rule that applied retroactively, and it further concluded that equitable tolling rendered the petition timely despite an eleven-day delay relative to that one-year period. The district court also reached and resolved the merits of the Double Jeopardy/Sánchez Valle claim in Núñez's favor and ordered habeas relief. The court initially stayed execution of the writ but later ordered Núñez's release at a July 10, 2023 hearing after concluding that he had overserved the lawful portion of his Puerto Rico sentences and in light of medical concerns.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: On September 27, 2022, the respondents (the Secretary of the Puerto Rico Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, the Warden, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico) filed a notice of appeal from the district court's judgment granting § 2254 relief. On appeal, they challenge only the district court's conclusion that the federal habeas petition was timely under 28 U.S.C. § 2244(d)(1)(C), including its reliance on equitable tolling. They do not appeal the district court's rejection of their other arguments (such as the privity-based double jeopardy argument or their position that Sánchez Valle is purely procedural and non-retroactive).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Núñez’s § 2254 habeas petition was untimely under the one-year statute of limitations in 28 U.S.C. § 2244(d)(1), specifically under subsection (C), given that his Puerto Rico Rule 192.1 postconviction motion was filed eleven days after the one-year period from the issuance of Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle had expired and statutory tolling under § 2244(d)(2) does not reset an already-expired limitations period.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: 28 U.S.C. § 2244(d)(1) imposes a one-year limitations period for § 2254 petitions. Ordinarily, the limitations period runs from "the date on which the judgment became final by the conclusion of direct review or the expiration of the time for seeking such review" (§ 2244(d)(1)(A)). Alternative triggers apply where: (B) there was an impediment to filing created by unconstitutional state action; (C) the claim is based on a constitutional right newly recognized by the Supreme Court and made retroactively applicable to cases on collateral review, in which case the period runs from the date the right was initially recognized; or (D) the factual predicate of the claim could not have been discovered earlier through due diligence. Under § 2244(d)(2), the limitations period is tolled while a properly filed state postconviction or other collateral review application is pending, but a state collateral filing does not reset the clock if it is filed after the one-year period has expired. Equitable tolling, as described in Holland v. Florida, 560 U.S. 631 (2010), may apply if the petitioner shows (1) diligent pursuit of his rights and (2) that some extraordinary circumstance stood in his way and prevented timely filing.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the respondents preserved or waived a statute of limitations defense under § 2244(d)(1)(C) in the district court by not clearly asserting that the petition was untimely even assuming Sánchez Valle triggered § 2244(d)(1)(C), and instead focusing solely on a limitations defense under § 2244(d)(1)(A) tied to the date the Puerto Rico judgment became final and on the non-retroactivity of Sánchez Valle.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8(c) and Rule 5(b) of the Rules Governing Section 2254 Cases, statute of limitations is an affirmative defense that must be pleaded in the answer. A defense can be "forfeited" by failure to raise it, which may in some habeas contexts allow a court, in its discretion and with notice, to raise the issue sua sponte. A defense is "waived" when there is an intentional relinquishment or abandonment of a known right; in that event, courts may not revive or apply the defense sua sponte. Relevant precedents include Day v. McDonough, 547 U.S. 198 (2006) (distinguishing inadvertent forfeiture from intentional waiver and allowing sua sponte consideration of a forfeited limitations defense) and Wood v. Milyard, 566 U.S. 463 (2012) (holding that a court may not resurrect a limitations defense the state knowingly and intelligently waived).

appellant_arguments: The respondents argue that the § 2254 petition is time-barred under AEDPA’s one-year statute of limitations in 28 U.S.C. § 2244(d)(1). They maintain that § 2244(d)(1)(A), which measures from the date the state-court judgment became final, supplies the pertinent limitations trigger because the Supreme Court in Sánchez Valle did not expressly state that its ruling applies retroactively to cases on collateral review. Therefore, in their view, § 2244(d)(1)(C), which depends on a newly recognized and retroactive right, does not apply. Under § 2244(d)(1)(A), they calculate that the limitations period began when the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico denied certiorari on February 2, 2007, and expired one year later, on February 2, 2008. As the federal habeas petition was not filed until 2019, they contend it is untimely by more than a decade.

They also argue that the alternative triggering provisions of § 2244(d)(1)(B) and (D) are inapplicable because Núñez neither alleged an unconstitutional state-created impediment to filing nor grounded his claim in newly discovered facts that could not earlier have been discovered with due diligence.

In later district court proceedings, when the court raised § 2244(d)(1)(C) sua sponte, the respondents asserted that even if § 2244(d)(1)(C) were applicable, the petition would still be untimely. They pointed out that Sánchez Valle was decided on June 9, 2016, and that Núñez filed his Puerto Rico Rule 192.1 motion more than a year after that date, so that the federal limitations period under § 2244(d)(1)(C) expired before any tolling could occur under § 2244(d)(2). They contended that because the Rule 192.1 motion was filed after the one-year period had already expired, it could not toll or revive the limitations period, and thus the later federal habeas petition was out of time.

They maintained that Núñez had not initially alleged any basis for equitable tolling and that, on the record, no equitable tolling should be applied to excuse the eleven-day delay under § 2244(d)(1)(C).

On appeal, respondents focus solely on the argument that the district court erred in treating the petition as timely under § 2244(d)(1)(C), including its equitable tolling analysis, and they assert that they raised the § 2244(d)(1)(C) timeliness issue sufficiently in the district court to preserve it (pointing to their statement at the motion-to-dismiss hearing, their allegation in the answer about the number of days between Sánchez Valle and the Rule 192.1 filing, and their later briefing after the court’s sua sponte order). They also argue that, even if their omission was a forfeiture, the district court could properly revive and address the § 2244(d)(1)(C) limitations issue when it raised it sua sponte.
appellee_arguments: Núñez argues that the rule announced in Puerto Rico v. Sánchez Valle—that Puerto Rico and the United States are a single sovereign for Double Jeopardy purposes—is a new rule of constitutional law that applies retroactively to his case on collateral review. He contends that, because he was prosecuted and convicted in Puerto Rico for carjacking and manslaughter based on the same conduct as his earlier federal carjacking conviction, his Puerto Rico convictions violate the Double Jeopardy Clause, and federal habeas relief is warranted.

Regarding timeliness under AEDPA, Núñez maintains in the district court that § 2244(d)(1)(C) is the appropriate trigger because his claim is based on a right newly recognized by the Supreme Court in Sánchez Valle and made retroactively applicable. Under that framework, he calculates the one-year period from the date Sánchez Valle was issued (June 9, 2016) and argues that his pursuit of a Rule 192.1 motion in Puerto Rico court should toll the federal limitations period under § 2244(d)(2). When confronted with the fact that his Rule 192.1 motion was filed eleven days late relative to the one-year window, he invokes equitable tolling under Holland v. Florida, asserting that he diligently pursued his double jeopardy rights and that the statute of limitations is not an inflexible bar to his claim given the brief delay and the severity of the consequences (a lengthy, effectively life-term sentence).

On appeal, beyond defending the district court’s equitable tolling analysis, Núñez argues that the respondents waived, rather than merely forfeited, any limitations defense based on § 2244(d)(1)(C). He points to the fact that in their motion to dismiss and in their answer, the respondents consistently framed their statute-of-limitations defense only under § 2244(d)(1)(A), taking the position that Sánchez Valle did not trigger § 2244(d)(1)(C). He emphasizes that, although the respondents knew the dates of the Sánchez Valle decision and his Rule 192.1 filing and discussed § 2244(d)(1)(C) in arguing it did not apply, they did not plead or develop an affirmative defense that the petition was untimely even if § 2244(d)(1)(C) governed.

He further contends that the respondents chose an "all-or-nothing" strategy below that turned on denying retroactivity to Sánchez Valle and that, even after the district court raised the § 2244(d)(1)(C) issue sua sponte, the respondents did not explain or seek to correct their earlier omission as a mistake or inadvertence. He cites the standards in Day and Wood for distinguishing waiver from forfeiture and asserts that respondents made a knowing, strategic decision not to rely on an eleven-day-lateness defense under § 2244(d)(1)(C). On that basis, he argues that the § 2244(d)(1)(C) argument cannot be used on appeal as a ground to overturn the grant of habeas relief.

issue_1.reasoning: Timeliness under § 2244(d)(1)(C) and the availability of equitable tolling are legal questions reviewed de novo. The district court held the petition timely by (1) using § 2244(d)(1)(C), keyed to Sánchez Valle, and (2) equitably tolling the eleven-day gap between the 1‑year deadline and the filing of the Rule 192.1 motion. On appeal, respondents press only the § 2244(d)(1)(C) timeliness issue, but that argument depends on the premise that the § 2244(d)(1)(C) defense was properly in the case. As explained under Issue 2, the Commonwealth’s litigation choices below amounted to a waiver—not just forfeiture—of any timeliness defense premised on § 2244(d)(1)(C). Under Wood v. Milyard, once the State has intentionally relinquished a known statute‑of‑limitations defense, the federal courts may not resurrect it sua sponte or on appeal. Because that defense was waived, the appellate court will not reach the merits of whether the petition was eleven days late or whether equitable tolling was correctly applied. With the only preserved limitations theory (§ 2244(d)(1)(A)) plainly inapplicable if Sánchez Valle is treated as retroactive, there is no basis to disturb the district court’s conclusion that the petition is timely. The result on this issue is therefore to affirm the district court’s disposition.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether the State preserved, forfeited, or waived a statute‑of‑limitations defense is a legal question reviewed de novo, guided by Day v. McDonough and Wood v. Milyard. In the district court, respondents consistently advanced only an § 2244(d)(1)(A) theory: that the one‑year clock began when the Puerto Rico judgment became final in 2007 and expired in 2008. They argued that § 2244(d)(1)(C) never came into play because, in their view, Sánchez Valle was not retroactive; they did not plead or develop the alternative contention that, even if § 2244(d)(1)(C) applied, the petition was time‑barred because the Rule 192.1 filing came eleven days after the one‑year period had run. That is, they chose an all‑or‑nothing strategy: either § 2244(d)(1)(C) did not apply at all (their position), or, if it did, they did not seek to rely on the narrow eleven‑day lateness as a fallback defense. The record shows knowledge of all relevant dates and of § 2244(d)(1)(C), coupled with a deliberate decision not to assert timeliness under that subsection. Under Wood, that is waiver—an intentional relinquishment of a known limitations defense—not inadvertent forfeiture. Because a waived limitations defense cannot be revived by the court sua sponte or asserted on appeal, the appellate court will hold that the § 2244(d)(1)(C) timeliness argument is unavailable to respondents. This leaves intact the district court’s judgment granting habeas relief.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The appeal is tightly framed: respondents challenge only the district court’s use of § 2244(d)(1)(C) and equitable tolling to deem the § 2254 petition timely. They do not contest the underlying double‑jeopardy/Sánchez Valle merits ruling. The controlling habeas timeliness precedents (Day and Wood) make the dispositive question whether the State preserved, merely forfeited, or affirmatively waived the § 2244(d)(1)(C) limitations defense. The summary indicates that respondents knew the critical dates and § 2244(d)(1)(C)’s framework but pursued a conscious strategy of denying retroactivity altogether, rather than arguing both retroactivity and untimeliness as alternative defenses. That pattern closely resembles the knowing waiver discussed in Wood, not a simple pleading lapse. Once characterized as waiver, courts may not resurrect the defense, so the eleven‑day discrepancy and equitable tolling analysis are effectively moot on appeal. With the only properly preserved limitations theory (§ 2244(d)(1)(A)) rejected by the district court and not meaningfully re‑argued as an alternative basis for reversal here, the grant of habeas relief stands. Accordingly, the most likely appellate disposition is to affirm the judgment in full.

parties.appellant: Little Hearts Marks Family II L.P. (“Little Hearts”), plaintiff in the adversary/state-court action and minority member (30%) of 305 East 61st Street Group LLC
parties.appellee: 61 Prime LLC (“Prime”), majority member (50%) and later manager of 305 East 61st Street Group LLC; and Jason D. Carter, manager and sole member of Prime; both defendants in the adversary/state-court action

stage1_summary.factual_background:
In August 2016, Mitchell Marks, the principal of Little Hearts Marks Family II L.P., signed a contract to purchase a 65,000 square foot warehouse located at 305 East 61st Street in Manhattan for $40,000,000. Marks organized a group of real estate investors to finance the purchase and to convert the building into a condominium through a limited liability company, 305 East 61st Street Group LLC. The LLC had four members: 61 Prime LLC (Prime) with a 50% interest; Little Hearts with a 30% interest; Onestone 305, LLC with a 10% interest; and an individual investor, Thaddeus Pollock, with a 10% interest.

The purchase was financed by a $20,000,000 acquisition loan from Banco Popular North America and capital investments from the members totaling $21,328,000. Construction work was to be financed by an additional $10,000,000 construction loan from Banco Popular. The acquisition and construction loans were secured by a single $30,000,000 mortgage on the building in favor of Banco Popular and were guaranteed by Little Hearts, Prime, Marks, and Carter. Little Hearts, Onestone, and Pollock each assumed responsibility for $3,750,000 (one‐eighth of the total indebtedness), and Prime assumed responsibility for the remaining $18,750,000 (five‐eighths).

The members executed an Operating Agreement to govern the LLC. Little Hearts was initially designated as the manager. If Little Hearts resigned or was removed as manager, Prime had the contractual right to assume the duties of manager or designate a replacement manager. The Operating Agreement allocated specific floors of the building to particular members for interior work and economic benefit. Little Hearts received the contractual right to retain, use, occupy, develop, and acquire condominium units consisting of the basement/cellar and first floor, and the tenth floor and roof. Prime was assigned the fourth through seventh floors and the ninth floor. Onestone and Pollock also had designated floors, but their rights were more limited; they obtained options to acquire units on their floors but not the right to share in sale or lease proceeds. A later amendment gave Little Hearts the right to the second floor as well.

Under the Operating Agreement, Little Hearts and Prime had rights with respect to their designated units to perform alterations, sell all or part, and lease, sublease, assign, and use the units without consent of the company or, after condominium formation, the condominium board. Once a condominium plan was approved, Little Hearts and Prime could either acquire their designated units or market them and share in the proceeds. Sales proceeds were to be applied first to pay off the Banco Popular loans, then closing expenses, then sums due under the agreement, with any remaining proceeds remitted to the selling member. Little Hearts also had additional rights in certain units referred to as the “Marks Units” (including the cellar and first floor). At closing, the LLC, as landlord, entered into a lease with Little Hearts, as tenant, for the cellar and first floor. A lease rider gave Little Hearts the right to sublease those floors without the company’s consent and to install signs, lights, advertisements, or notices on the exterior of the building. Little Hearts also had the right, with Prime’s consent, to make alterations to the roof, financed by company capital, and the right to subdivide the tenth floor into two units without company consent.

Little Hearts alleges that it relied on these contractual rights and invested millions of dollars renovating the Marks Units for its own use, or for lease or sale. It entered into a 15-year sublease for the ground floor unit with non-party Acqua Ancien Bath New York, Inc. (referred to as the “Spa”), acting as sub-landlord.

In spring 2018, Prime allegedly refused to pay $62,500 of its capital subscription to the company, prompting the LLC to sue Prime in New York state court. Prime and Carter then brought a separate state action seeking to remove Little Hearts as manager and moved ex parte for a temporary restraining order (TRO), which Little Hearts characterizes as having been obtained based on grossly false allegations. The state court granted the TRO and installed Prime as manager.

Little Hearts alleges that, after Prime took over as manager, Prime and Carter mismanaged the company: over the next two years, they allegedly did not advance construction work, did not renew permits, did not advance the condominium offering plan, and did not correct a stop-work order issued by the City of New York for purportedly illegal work initiated by defendants. Little Hearts further alleges that Prime and Carter interfered with the Spa sublease by cutting power and water to the ground floor unit, locking the Spa out of the unit in violation of a court order, violating an August 23, 2018 TRO and order directing them to restore utilities, and thereby causing the Spa to sue the company for substantial damages.

The Banco Popular loans matured in December 2018. Prime allegedly failed to pay its 5/8 share of the mortgage debt. According to the complaint, instead of arranging commercially reasonable refinancing, Carter tried to refinance the mortgage on commercially unreasonable terms from a personal friend, while rejecting several refinancing proposals from Little Hearts that Little Hearts contends were on commercially reasonable terms. Little Hearts alleges that Carter attempted to pressure Marks to accept his refinancing proposal and stated that “there is only going to be one winner here, and it’s not going to be you—give in while there is something still left in it for you,” and that Carter did not want the mortgage paid because he intended to acquire the building.

After the LLC defaulted, the entity holding the loans began foreclosure proceedings. In the state action in which Prime sought to keep Little Hearts removed as manager, Prime moved for a preliminary injunction. The state court held a hearing in February 2019 and, by May 2019, indicated that Prime was not entitled to a preliminary injunction and that Little Hearts was entitled to have a receiver appointed. Before the state court resolved the preliminary-injunction request, on June 10, 2019, Prime, acting as manager, caused the LLC to file a voluntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition in the Southern District of New York. Little Hearts alleges the bankruptcy was unnecessary because the LLC was solvent and the building’s value exceeded the company’s liabilities, and that Prime initiated the case solely to avoid an adverse ruling in the state litigation.

On the same day the company filed for bankruptcy, Carter formed Lazarus 5, LLC. The complaint alleges Lazarus 5 was created for the purpose of purchasing the mortgage and then forcing a sale of the building to itself. A bankruptcy trustee was appointed and, in May 2020, proposed a plan of liquidation. The plan contemplated the sale of the building to Lazarus 5 and created a creditor trust whose sole purpose was to liquidate the remaining assets of the bankruptcy estate, including legal claims, and distribute the proceeds to creditors. The plan permanently enjoined actions involving property of the estate, including legal claims that belonged to the estate, unless brought by the creditor trustee. At a bankruptcy sale on August 12, 2020, Lazarus 5 purchased the mortgage and acquired the building for approximately $50,000,000.

Little Hearts alleges that Prime and Carter used their control of the LLC and the bankruptcy process to squeeze out Little Hearts and to transfer the building to themselves (through Lazarus 5), thereby depriving Little Hearts of its capital investment and its contractual rights in the Marks Units.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
In June 2019, after the bankruptcy filing, Little Hearts commenced an adversary proceeding in the bankruptcy court. Little Hearts, Carter, and the creditor trustee participated in mediation, which was unsuccessful. Little Hearts then filed a separate lawsuit in New York state court against Prime and Carter. The defendants removed that action to the bankruptcy court under Bankruptcy Rule 9027(a)(3).

In the removed complaint, Little Hearts asserted six causes of action: (1) breach of fiduciary duty (Count I); (2) aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duty (Count II); (3) breach of contract (Count III); (4) breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing (Count IV); (5) an alter ego theory against Carter, styled as a separate cause of action (Count V); and (6) unjust enrichment (Count VI). The gravamen of the complaint was that Prime and Carter, using their control of the LLC and the bankruptcy process, squeezed out Little Hearts and transferred the building to themselves. Little Hearts sought at least $48,052,000 in damages, representing lost capital investment and the loss of rights under the Operating Agreement, including its rights to retain, use, occupy, and develop the Marks Units.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The bankruptcy court dismissed the complaint in its entirety. It concluded that the claims asserted by Little Hearts were derivative of injuries to the debtor LLC rather than direct injuries to Little Hearts and therefore belonged to the debtor and, under the confirmed plan and creditor trust agreement, had vested in the creditor trust. The bankruptcy court held that the Marks Units did not constitute distinct property or contract rights separate from Little Hearts’ membership interest in the debtor; rather, the assignment of specific units reflected the members’ respective equity interests in the LLC. On that basis, the court determined that all of Little Hearts’ causes of action were derivative claims that only the estate (through the creditor trustee) could assert. The district court for the Southern District of New York affirmed the bankruptcy court’s judgment dismissing the complaint.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Little Hearts appeals from the district court’s affirmance of the bankruptcy court’s dismissal of its complaint. On appeal, it challenges the determination that its claims—including breach of fiduciary duty, aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duty, breach of contract, breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, unjust enrichment, and its alter ego theory against Carter—are derivative claims belonging to the bankruptcy estate and therefore can only be asserted by the creditor trustee under the plan of liquidation.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Little Hearts’ claims for breach of fiduciary duty and aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duty are derivative claims that belong to the debtor’s estate and thus can be asserted only by the creditor trustee, or whether they are direct claims that Little Hearts can pursue in its own name notwithstanding the bankruptcy plan’s transfer of estate claims to the creditor trust.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 11 U.S.C. § 541(a)(1), causes of action that belong to the debtor become property of the bankruptcy estate; under the confirmed plan and creditor trust agreement, only the creditor trustee may pursue such estate claims. Whether a cause of action belongs to the debtor or to an individual member/creditor depends on state law. Under New York law, as informed by the Delaware Tooley test (adopted in Yudell v. Gilbert), a claim is direct only if (1) the plaintiff’s alleged injury is independent of any injury to the entity, (2) the duty breached was owed to the plaintiff, and (3) the plaintiff can prevail without showing injury to the entity. Fiduciary-duty claims are analyzed under this Tooley framework to determine whether they are direct or derivative.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Little Hearts’ claims for breach of contract and breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing are direct claims based on contractual rights belonging personally to Little Hearts (including rights to the Marks Units), or whether they are derivative claims that belong to the debtor LLC and therefore to the creditor trust.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under New York law (guided by Delaware precedents such as NAF Holdings, Citigroup, and Tooley), the threshold inquiry is whether the plaintiff seeks to enforce its own contract rights or rights belonging to the entity. Where a plaintiff asserts a claim based on its own commercial contract rights, the Tooley derivative-versus-direct test generally does not apply, and such claims are treated as direct even if proof of injury may also involve demonstrating harm to the entity. A plaintiff may maintain a direct contract or implied covenant claim if the alleged duty arises from a contract obligation owed to the plaintiff individually, independent of any duty owed to the entity.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Little Hearts’ unjust enrichment claim states a distinct basis for relief or is duplicative of its contract-based claims such that it is barred under New York law.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under New York law, an unjust enrichment claim is unavailable where it duplicates or substitutes for a conventional contract or tort claim; two claims are duplicative if they arise from the same facts and seek the same damages. See Corsello v. Verizon New York, Inc. and NetJets Aviation, Inc. v. LHC Communications, LLC (holding that unjust enrichment cannot be maintained where it merely recasts breach-of-contract allegations without alleging distinct damages or conduct).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the bankruptcy court has subject-matter jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1334(b) to adjudicate Little Hearts’ surviving direct, state-law claims, and if so, whether those proceedings are core or non-core and whether mandatory abstention under 28 U.S.C. § 1334(c)(2) is required.
