issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 28 U.S.C. § 1334(b), district courts (and by reference bankruptcy courts) have original but not exclusive jurisdiction over all civil proceedings arising under title 11, arising in cases under title 11, or related to cases under title 11. Under 28 U.S.C. § 157, bankruptcy jurisdiction extends to core proceedings (including matters concerning administration of the estate and proceedings affecting liquidation of estate assets) and to non-core proceedings that are merely related to a bankruptcy case, where a proceeding is "related" if its outcome could conceivably have any effect on the estate. For non-core, related proceedings based on state law that could not have been commenced in federal court but for their relation to the bankruptcy, § 1334(c)(2) requires mandatory abstention if an action is pending in a state forum that can timely adjudicate the matter, with timeliness determined by a case-specific comparison of the expected pace of state and federal adjudication (see Parmalat Capital Finance Ltd. v. Bank of America Corp.).

appellant_arguments: Little Hearts contends that its claims, particularly for breach of contract and breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, are based on rights that belong to it personally under the Operating Agreement and related lease documents, especially its rights to retain, use, occupy, develop, acquire, lease, and sublease the Marks Units (cellar, first floor, second floor, tenth floor, and roof). It maintains that these unit-specific rights are distinct from its equity interest in the LLC and thus are not merely reflections of its membership share.

It argues that the bankruptcy and district courts incorrectly characterized all of its claims as derivative of injuries to the LLC, ignoring the fact that the Operating Agreement and lease granted Little Hearts unique, individual rights (e.g., to sublease the Marks Units without company consent, to install signs, to subdivide units) that no other member possessed. Little Hearts asserts that the alleged misconduct directly destroyed or impaired these personal contractual rights.

With respect to the fiduciary-duty-based counts, Little Hearts argues that Prime and Carter owed fiduciary duties not only to the LLC but also directly to Little Hearts as a member and manager, including duties arising from the Operating Agreement provisions that required the manager to devote reasonable time to managing the company’s business and to act in good faith and with due care. It maintains that the challenged conduct—including mismanagement, initiating what it characterizes as an unnecessary bankruptcy to block state-court relief, and engineering a sale of the building to Lazarus 5—directly harmed Little Hearts in ways not shared equally by all members because of its specific contractual interests in the Marks Units.

Little Hearts also claims that Prime and Carter’s conduct interfered directly with its sublease to the Spa and its economic expectations thereunder, causing harms tied to its individual leasehold/sublease rights rather than merely to the LLC’s general economic position. It points to actions such as cutting off utilities, locking out the Spa, and violating court orders, which allegedly induced the Spa to sue the company and undermined Little Hearts’ sublease value.

It asserts that its unjust enrichment claim is premised on Prime and Carter’s allegedly wrongful acquisition, through Lazarus 5, of the building and the economic benefits associated with the Marks Units, arguing that they were enriched at Little Hearts’ expense by appropriating property and contract-derived opportunities that rightfully belonged to Little Hearts.

On the jurisdictional question raised at oral argument, Little Hearts contends that the bankruptcy court lacks subject-matter jurisdiction over its remaining direct, state-law claims because they are insufficiently connected to the administration of the bankruptcy estate to qualify as core or related proceedings under § 1334(b). It further suggests that even if some related jurisdiction exists, the standards for abstention under § 1334(c)(2) are satisfied and the matter should proceed in state court.
appellee_arguments: Prime and Carter argue that all of Little Hearts’ claims, including those styled as contract and implied covenant claims, are derivative because they arise from alleged mismanagement and other conduct that principally injured the LLC as a whole. They maintain that any diminution in value or loss suffered by Little Hearts is the result of injury to the LLC (e.g., loss of the building, foreclosure, allegedly imprudent bankruptcy) and thus any cause of action belongs to the estate and, under the confirmed plan, to the creditor trust.

They contend that the Marks Units do not constitute separate property interests or contract rights independent of Little Hearts’ membership interest. According to their view, the allocation of particular floors among members was simply an internal arrangement reflecting each member’s equity share in the LLC, rather than a grant of independent, enforceable rights that survive or exist apart from the member’s general investment. They rely on the bankruptcy court’s conclusion that the unit designations merely formalized how membership interests correlated with space in the building.

With respect to the fiduciary-duty counts, they assert that any fiduciary duties arising from the Operating Agreement were owed primarily to the LLC, and that claims of mismanagement, improper bankruptcy filing, and sale of the building to Lazarus 5 allege harm to the company as a whole. They argue that under the Tooley framework (as applied by New York courts), these fiduciary-duty claims are necessarily derivative because Little Hearts cannot prevail without showing injury to the LLC.

They further argue that Little Hearts’ unjust enrichment claim is duplicative of its contract-based theories because it rests on the same alleged misconduct and seeks the same measure of damages—namely, recovery of Little Hearts’ alleged lost capital and lost rights to use, occupy, and develop the Marks Units—without alleging any distinct factual basis or damages beyond those asserted in the contract and implied covenant claims.

On standing and jurisdiction, they argue that, to the extent Little Hearts attempts to assert derivative claims, it lacks standing because such claims belong exclusively to the debtor estate and then to the creditor trust post-confirmation. They also assert that the bankruptcy court has jurisdiction to adjudicate disputes that bear on estate assets, including derivative claims and any related direct claims that could affect the administration or liquidation of those assets.

issue_1.prediction: MIXED (AFFIRM in part / REVERSE in part)
issue_1.reasoning: Whether claims are derivative or direct is a legal question reviewed de novo. Tooley/Yudell asks who was harmed and who would benefit from the recovery. The allegations about mismanagement, filing bankruptcy to avoid an adverse state‑court ruling, and engineering a low‑control sale of the building concern injuries to the LLC as an operating entity (loss of the building, foreclosure risk, value diminution). Those fiduciary‑duty theories are classic derivative injuries that any member would share and that require proof of injury to the LLC, so dismissal as estate/creditor‑trust claims is affirmed as to those aspects. But the complaint also describes conduct that targeted Little Hearts’ unique, contract-based position: cutting utilities to the Spa, locking out the Spa in violation of court orders (thereby destroying the value of Little Hearts’ sublease and related leasehold expectations), and using control of the bankruptcy and sale process specifically to strip Little Hearts of its bargained‑for rights in the Marks Units (exclusive rights to retain, occupy, develop, lease, and sublease specified floors, and to install signage, subdivide, and alter the roof). Those are injuries not shared pro rata by all members and trace to duties arguably owed directly to Little Hearts as counterparty to the Operating Agreement and related lease, not only to the LLC. Little Hearts could, in principle, prevail on those narrow theories by showing direct interference with or usurpation of its unit‑specific rights, without proving a net injury to the entity. Under New York law informed by Delaware’s Tooley line, those are direct fiduciary‑duty claims. The lower courts treated all fiduciary‑duty theories as derivative and belonging solely to the estate; that global characterization is overbroad. The appellate court is likely to affirm the dismissal of the mismanagement/overall value‑loss fiduciary claims as derivative, but reverse insofar as the courts barred Little Hearts from pursuing fiduciary‑duty theories predicated on the destruction or misappropriation of its distinct Marks‑Unit and Spa‑sublease rights.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether a claim sounds in direct contract or derivative injury is a legal question. Under New York law (and Delaware precedents like NAF Holdings), when a plaintiff sues to enforce its own contract rights, the derivative/direct Tooley test does not bar a direct action simply because the alleged breach also harmed the entity. Here, the Operating Agreement and lease gave Little Hearts specific, personal rights: to retain, use, occupy, lease, and develop identified units (cellar, first floor, second floor, tenth floor, roof), to sublease without company consent, to install exterior signage, and to subdivide the tenth floor. The complaint alleges that Prime and Carter’s conduct, including the way they used the bankruptcy and sale to Lazarus 5, directly destroyed those individual rights and made performance of the Spa sublease impossible. Those claims seek to vindicate Little Hearts’ own commercial contract rights, not the LLC’s. Under NAF Holdings, such contract and implied‑covenant claims are direct even if the same conduct also injured the company. The bankruptcy and district courts effectively collapsed those contract interests into Little Hearts’ equity stake and held the claims derivative; that misapplies the direct‑contract‑right doctrine. The appellate court is therefore likely to hold that the contract and implied‑covenant claims are direct and do not belong to the estate or creditor trust, and to reverse the dismissal on that basis.

issue_3.reasoning: The availability of unjust enrichment alongside contract claims is reviewed de novo at the pleading stage. Under New York law (Corsello, NetJets), unjust enrichment is barred when it merely repackages breach‑of‑contract allegations arising from the same facts and seeks the same damages. Little Hearts’ unjust‑enrichment theory rests on defendants’ alleged wrongful acquisition of the building and appropriation of the economic benefits of the Marks Units, and it seeks recovery of Little Hearts’ lost capital and lost unit‑based rights. Those are the same factual nucleus and measure of loss asserted in the contract and implied‑covenant counts. The complaint does not identify distinct conduct or a different category of damages that would survive if the contract were deemed valid and enforceable. Accordingly, the enrichment claim is duplicative and unavailable under New York law. The lower courts’ refusal to allow that claim to go forward will be affirmed.

issue_4.standard_of_review: de novo (existence of subject-matter jurisdiction and core/non-core characterization); abuse of discretion for timeliness/abstention application details
issue_4.prediction: MIXED (AFFIRM existence of related, non-core jurisdiction; REMAND for consideration of mandatory abstention)
issue_4.reasoning: Whether § 1334(b) jurisdiction exists and whether a proceeding is core is reviewed de novo. Even after recognizing Little Hearts’ surviving direct claims, there remains at least “related to” jurisdiction: the outcome of Little Hearts’ direct state‑law contract and fiduciary‑duty claims could conceivably affect the creditor trust’s administration (e.g., indemnity, claim preclusion, allocation of proceeds) or clarify the boundary between estate/creditor‑trust claims and individual-member claims. But once those surviving claims are characterized as direct state‑law claims between non‑diverse parties that could not have been brought in federal court absent § 1334(b), they are non‑core, related proceedings. Section 1334(c)(2) mandates abstention where: (1) a timely motion is made; (2) the proceeding is based on state law; (3) the action could not have been commenced in federal court but for § 1334(b); (4) it is a non‑core, related matter; and (5) an action is pending in a state forum that can timely adjudicate the dispute. The record shows these claims were originally filed in state court and removed under the bankruptcy rules; there is no finding by the lower courts applying the Parmalat timeliness standard or expressly analyzing § 1334(c)(2) after narrowing the case to surviving direct claims. Because the jurisdictional issue only sharpened once the claims are properly re‑classified as direct, the appellate court will likely hold that the bankruptcy court did have related, non‑core jurisdiction to entertain the removed action, but remand for the bankruptcy (or district) court to determine in the first instance whether mandatory abstention applies and, if not, whether permissive abstention or equitable remand is appropriate.

stage2_decision.reasoning: De novo review of the derivative‑versus‑direct characterization makes it likely the appellate court will correct the lower courts’ broad conclusion that every claim is derivative and belongs exclusively to the estate. Contemporary Second Circuit and New York/Delaware authority distinguish: (a) mismanagement and value‑loss theories, which are derivative, from (b) efforts to enforce a member’s own bargained‑for contract rights, which are direct. The facts and pleadings strongly support that Little Hearts possessed unique unit‑specific rights under the Operating Agreement and lease and that some alleged misconduct—especially the interference with the Spa sublease and the squeezing out of those Marks‑Unit rights through the bankruptcy sale—injured Little Hearts in a way not shared equally by all members. Under NAF Holdings and related cases, Little Hearts may bring direct contract and implied‑covenant claims on those rights. By contrast, the unjust‑enrichment theory simply repackages the contract‑right injury and is almost certainly dismissed as duplicative under Corsello and NetJets. On jurisdiction, once the surviving claims are accepted as direct state‑law claims between non‑diverse parties, they are best viewed as non‑core but at least “related to” the Chapter 11 case, supporting § 1334(b) jurisdiction but triggering a serious question of mandatory abstention, which the lower courts did not fully resolve in that posture. The likely appellate remedy is to affirm jurisdiction in principle, but remand for a proper § 1334(c)(2) analysis. The combined result is mixed: some fiduciary‑duty theories and all contract/implied‑covenant claims are reinstated as direct claims; unjust enrichment remains dismissed; jurisdiction is recognized but abstention is left for the lower court to address on remand.

parties.appellant: Scott Cannon, plaintiff in the district court, suing individually and as the personal representative of the Estate of Blaise Cannon
parties.appellee: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts, Inc. (BCBS), defendant in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background: Blaise Cannon was insured as a covered dependent under his domestic partner's group health insurance policy issued by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts (BCBS). The partner obtained this group health coverage through the partner's employer, and the policy was an employee benefit plan governed by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). Blaise suffered from asthma. On March 18, 2020, Blaise, through his physician, sought coverage under the BCBS policy for a Wixela Inhub inhaler as treatment for his asthma. On March 25, 2020, BCBS denied coverage for the Wixela Inhub. In its written denial, BCBS stated that its Pharmacy Operations Unit had reviewed the material submitted by Blaise's doctor and that coverage for Wixela Inhub, requested for the treatment of asthma, could not be approved because there was no documentation that Blaise had tried one prescription inhaled steroid, inhaled beta-agonist, inhaled mast cell stabilizer, oral albuterol, or theophylline product within the prior 130 days, and there was also no documentation of Blaise having tried two of the following medications: Dulera (which required prior authorization), Symbicort (which required prior authorization), and/or fluticasone/salmeterol (generic for Airduo, also requiring prior authorization). Blaise did not pursue or file any internal appeal of this denial of benefits through the BCBS plan procedures. Blaise later died from asthma-related complications. Scott Cannon alleges that BCBS's denial of coverage for the Wixela Inhub inhaler prematurely caused or contributed to Blaise's death.

procedural_history.claims_brought: After Blaise's death, Scott Cannon, individually and as personal representative of Blaise's estate, filed suit in state court asserting six state-law causes of action against BCBS: (1) declaratory judgment, (2) breach of contract, (3) bad faith, (4) wrongful death under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 229 § 2, (5) punitive damages associated with the wrongful death claim, and (6) loss of consortium.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: BCBS removed the case to the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts and moved to dismiss the action on ERISA preemption grounds. The district court allowed Cannon a brief period of limited discovery, including a Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 30(b)(6) deposition of BCBS. On November 7, 2023, the court denied BCBS's motion to dismiss without prejudice to BCBS raising the ERISA preemption issue later in a motion for summary judgment. After the limited discovery was completed, BCBS moved for summary judgment on February 28, 2024. Cannon conceded that ERISA preempted most of his state-law claims but argued that his wrongful death claim under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 229 § 2 and the corresponding punitive damages claim were not preempted and could proceed. On August 22, 2024, the district court concluded that the wrongful death claim was statutorily preempted by ERISA under 29 U.S.C. § 1144(a) because it "related to" the ERISA-governed health insurance policy, reasoning that resolving the claim would require consultation of the policy and that it arose from an alleged improper denial of benefits under that policy. The court further concluded that the wrongful death claim functioned as an alternative enforcement mechanism for recovering damages related to an alleged breach of the ERISA plan and therefore conflicted with ERISA's civil enforcement scheme under 29 U.S.C. § 1132(a). The court granted summary judgment to BCBS on ERISA preemption grounds.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Cannon appeals the district court's grant of summary judgment in favor of BCBS, challenging the ruling that his Massachusetts wrongful death and associated punitive damages claims based on the denial of coverage for the Wixela Inhub inhaler are preempted by ERISA.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Cannon's state-law wrongful death and punitive damages claims based on BCBS's denial of coverage for the Wixela Inhub inhaler are statutorily preempted by ERISA under 29 U.S.C. § 1144(a) because they "relate to" an ERISA-governed employee benefit plan.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 29 U.S.C. § 1144(a), ERISA preempts "any and all State laws insofar as they may now or hereafter relate to any employee benefit plan." A state law "relates to" an ERISA plan if it has a "connection with or reference to" such a plan, even if the law is not specifically designed to affect ERISA plans or its effect is only indirect. A law or cause of action is preempted if it governs a central matter of plan administration or interferes with nationally uniform plan administration, including when resolving liability requires evaluating or interpreting plan terms.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Cannon's wrongful death and punitive damages claims are preempted because they fall within, and conflict with, ERISA's exclusive civil enforcement scheme under 29 U.S.C. § 1132(a), which provides the remedies for denials of benefits under ERISA plans.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 29 U.S.C. § 1132(a)(1)(B), a participant or beneficiary may bring a civil action to recover benefits due under the terms of the plan, enforce rights under the plan, or clarify rights to future benefits. State-law causes of action that duplicate, supplement, or supplant ERISA's civil enforcement remedies are preempted. A claim is within the scope of § 1132(a)(1)(B) if the plaintiff complains of a denial of coverage for medical care where eligibility for coverage arises solely from an ERISA-regulated plan and no legal duty independent of ERISA or the plan terms is alleged to have been violated. If an individual, at some point, could have brought the claim under § 1132(a)(1)(B), and there is no other independent legal duty implicated, ERISA preemption under § 1132 applies.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, under Massachusetts wrongful death law, Cannon's wrongful death claim is derivative of Blaise's own potential claim for benefits under the ERISA plan, and, if so, whether that derivative nature brings the wrongful death claim within ERISA preemption.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Massachusetts law provides that only the executor or administrator of a decedent may bring a wrongful death action, and such an action is derivative of the decedent's own cause of action for the injuries causing death. Beneficiaries of the death action may recover only if the decedent would have had a viable cause of action at the time of death. If the decedent would have been bound by limitations such as arbitration agreements or ERISA preemption, those limitations also apply to the wrongful death claim because it is not a separate, independent legal interest.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the Supreme Court's decision in Rutledge v. Pharmaceutical Care Management Association, 592 U.S. 80 (2020), alters prior ERISA preemption precedent in a way that would permit Cannon's state-law wrongful death and punitive damages claims to avoid preemption.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Rutledge applied the "connection with or reference to" test for ERISA preemption and held that a generally applicable Arkansas statute regulating the reimbursement rates that pharmacy benefit managers pay pharmacies was not preempted because it functioned as cost regulation, did not dictate plan choices to an impermissible degree, and did not refer to ERISA plans as such (applying regardless of ERISA status). The analysis in Rutledge focuses on whether the challenged state provision mandates plan structures or specific benefits, or otherwise governs central aspects of plan administration, versus merely affecting costs in a way not targeted to ERISA plans.

appellant_arguments: Cannon contends that his wrongful death claim under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 229 § 2 and the associated punitive damages claim are not preempted by ERISA, even though he concedes that most of his other state-law claims are preempted. He argues that the Massachusetts wrongful death statute is a generally applicable law governing wrongful death and is not directed at, or intended to regulate, insurance or employee benefit plans, and therefore should not be treated as a state law that "relates to" an ERISA plan within the meaning of § 1144(a).

He asserts that the Supreme Court's decision in Rutledge v. Pharmaceutical Care Management Association overrules or substantially modifies earlier precedent, including First Circuit authority such as Turner v. Fallon Community Health Plan, Inc., which had held that wrongful death claims based on a denial of ERISA plan benefits were preempted. Cannon argues that Rutledge narrows the scope of ERISA preemption and indicates that generally applicable state laws that do not dictate plan choices or benefit structures, such as wrongful death statutes, fall outside ERISA's preemptive reach.

Cannon further argues that his wrongful death claim does not fall within ERISA's civil enforcement scheme under 29 U.S.C. § 1132(a) because he, in his individual capacity and as representative of the estate, is not a "participant" or "beneficiary" of the plan and thus could not have brought a benefits-enforcement action under ERISA. He also contends that the wrongful death claim did not exist during Blaise's lifetime and therefore could not have been brought by Blaise under § 1132(a)(1)(B), distinguishing it from a typical benefits lawsuit.

He maintains that the wrongful death claim is based on duties imposed by state wrongful death law, which he characterizes as independent from the ERISA plan terms, focusing on the alleged causal connection between BCBS's denial of coverage for the inhaler and Blaise's death, and not solely on the enforcement of contractual benefit rights.

Cannon emphasizes that the Massachusetts wrongful death statute is not a law regulating insurance, banking, or securities, and he suggests that its general tort character and remedial focus on death-related damages place it outside the core of ERISA preemption, especially under the approach he reads in Rutledge.
appellee_arguments: BCBS argues that Cannon's wrongful death and punitive damages claims are preempted by ERISA under 29 U.S.C. § 1144(a) because they "relate to" an ERISA-regulated employee benefit plan. The claims arise directly from BCBS's denial of a specific requested benefit—the Wixela Inhub inhaler—under the terms of the ERISA-governed health insurance policy, and adjudicating liability would require the court to consult and interpret the policy's coverage criteria. BCBS maintains that this creates the requisite "connection with" an ERISA plan for statutory preemption.

BCBS contends that longstanding First Circuit precedent, including Turner v. Fallon Community Health Plan, Inc., and decisions from other circuits, establish that wrongful death actions predicated on an insurer's denial of benefits under an ERISA plan are preempted. According to BCBS, these cases treat such wrongful death suits as attempts to obtain alternative state-law remedies for alleged breaches of plan obligations, which fall squarely within ERISA preemption.

BCBS further argues that Cannon's claims are preempted under ERISA's civil enforcement scheme, 29 U.S.C. § 1132(a), because the essence of his complaint is that BCBS wrongly denied coverage for medical treatment to an ERISA plan beneficiary. Under Supreme Court precedent such as Aetna Health Inc. v. Davila, BCBS asserts that state-law causes of action seeking damages for denial of coverage, where eligibility is derived solely from an ERISA plan and no independent legal duty is alleged, are within the scope of § 1132(a) and therefore preempted.

BCBS disputes Cannon's reliance on Rutledge, arguing that Rutledge involved a different kind of state law—a generally applicable cost-regulation statute governing pharmacy benefit manager reimbursement rates—and did not alter the principles governing preemption of individual benefit-denial claims. BCBS maintains that Rutledge reaffirmed, rather than undermined, the "connection with or reference to" test and did not call into question precedents like Turner addressing wrongful death claims based on denial of plan benefits.

BCBS also contends that under Massachusetts law, wrongful death actions are derivative of the decedent's own cause of action for the injury leading to death. Therefore, Cannon's wrongful death claim derives from any claim Blaise could have brought for damages arising from the alleged wrongful denial of benefits. BCBS argues that because any such claim by Blaise during his lifetime would have been subject to, and preempted by, ERISA's remedial scheme, the derivative wrongful death claim is likewise subject to ERISA preemption.

issue_1.reasoning: The preemption question under §1144(a) is purely legal and reviewed de novo. Cannon’s wrongful death and punitive damages claims rest entirely on BCBS’s denial of a particular ERISA plan benefit (the Wixela inhaler) to a covered dependent. To adjudicate liability, a court would have to examine the plan’s coverage criteria, prior-authorization rules, and BCBS’s application of those terms—classic “connection with” an ERISA plan. First Circuit precedent, especially Turner v. Fallon, holds that wrongful death claims based on benefit denials under ERISA-governed plans are preempted because they effectively challenge plan administration and seek plan-related remedies. The Massachusetts statute may be generally applicable, but when applied here it functions as a vehicle to obtain state-law remedies for alleged mishandling of an ERISA benefits decision. Rutledge did not narrow the ‘relates to’ test in a way that would alter that analysis in the individual-benefits context. Under binding circuit law, the district court’s conclusion that the wrongful death and associated punitive damages claims “relate to” the ERISA plan is likely to be affirmed.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether a state-law cause of action is completely/expressly preempted because it falls within §1132(a)’s exclusive remedial scheme is a legal question reviewed de novo. Under Davila, a state-law claim is preempted if (1) the plaintiff could have brought a claim under §1132(a)(1)(B) and (2) no independent legal duty is implicated. The substance of Cannon’s claim is that BCBS wrongly denied coverage for medical treatment to a plan beneficiary, and that denial allegedly caused death. Blaise plainly could have brought a §1132(a)(1)(B) action during his lifetime to challenge the denial and seek appropriate relief. Massachusetts wrongful death law is derivative, so the estate’s right depends on what Blaise could have asserted. The wrongful death claim does not rest on any duty independent of the ERISA plan; the alleged wrongful act is the denial of a plan benefit, not some separate medical negligence or non-plan-based duty. The fact that Cannon himself is not a plan “participant or beneficiary,” and that the wrongful death cause of action arose only upon Blaise’s death, does not satisfy Davila’s “independent legal duty” requirement where the underlying duty is entirely defined by the ERISA plan and ERISA governs who may enforce those duties. Consequently, the claim duplicates/supplements the ERISA remedial scheme and is preempted. The district court’s ruling on §1132 preemption is likely to be affirmed.

issue_3.reasoning: The characterization of Massachusetts wrongful death claims as derivative and the impact of that characterization on ERISA preemption present questions of law reviewed de novo. Massachusetts law treats wrongful death actions as derivative of the decedent’s own cause of action; beneficiaries recover only if the decedent would have had a viable claim, and defenses or limitations applicable to the decedent generally carry through. Here, Blaise’s only possible claim against BCBS would have been for wrongful denial of ERISA plan benefits, which would have been constrained by ERISA’s enforcement provisions, including preemption. Because the estate’s wrongful death claim is derivative of Blaise’s ERISA-governed rights and merely seeks a different measure of damages (death-related and punitive) for the same alleged wrongful denial of benefits, it falls within ERISA’s preemptive scope. The derivative nature of the claim thus reinforces, rather than avoids, preemption. The district court’s reliance on this derivative character to support preemption is likely to be affirmed.

issue_4.reasoning: Interpreting Rutledge and its effect on existing ERISA preemption precedent is a legal question reviewed de novo. Rutledge addressed a generally applicable state statute regulating PBM reimbursement rates, concluding that it did not impermissibly dictate plan choices or structures and did not refer specifically to ERISA plans, functioning instead as cost regulation. The decision reaffirmed the ‘connection with or reference to’ framework and distinguished prior cases on their facts; it did not purport to overrule Davila or cases like Turner that deal with individual benefit-denial suits. Cannon’s claims are not abstract cost regulation; they are targeted at a specific denial of benefits and would impose state tort remedies directly on the process of determining and administering coverage under an ERISA plan. That is the core territory in which earlier preemption cases apply with full force. A lower court is not free to treat Turner and similar circuit precedent as implicitly overruled by Rutledge absent clear incompatibility, which is not present here. Thus, the appellate court will almost certainly hold that Rutledge does not save Cannon’s wrongful death and punitive damages claims from preemption and will affirm the district court on this point.

stage2_decision.reasoning: All of Cannon’s remaining claims on appeal are tethered to the alleged wrongful denial of a specific ERISA-plan benefit and require examination of the plan’s terms and the administrator’s decision-making. Under Davila and longstanding First Circuit precedent (including Turner), wrongful death and similar state-law actions premised on improper benefit denials are both expressly preempted under §1144(a) and precluded by ERISA’s exclusive remedial scheme under §1132(a). Massachusetts wrongful death law is derivative, further tying the estate’s claim to whatever ERISA-limited rights Blaise had during his lifetime. Rutledge concerns a regulatory, generally applicable rate-setting statute and preserves the core principles of ERISA preemption; it does not undermine circuit authority on individual benefits litigation. Given these factors and the de novo standard of review, the appellate court is likely to affirm the district court’s grant of summary judgment for BCBS on all issues.

parties.appellant: Capitol Records, LLC; Caroline Records, Inc.; Virgin Records America, Inc.; EMI Blackwood Music Inc.; EMI April Music Inc.; EMI Virgin Music, Inc.; Colgems-EMI Music, Inc.; EMI Virgin Songs, Inc.; EMI Gold Horizon Music Corp.; EMI Unart Catalog Inc.; Stone Diamond Music Corporation; EMI U Catalog Inc.; Jobete Music Co., Inc.; all described as plaintiff rightsholders of musical recordings and affiliates of EMI
parties.appellee: Vimeo, Inc. (aka Vimeo.com) and Connected Ventures, LLC; defendants operating the Vimeo online video-hosting service

stage1_summary.factual_background: Plaintiffs are music rightsholders affiliated with EMI that own copyrights in various musical sound recordings and musical works. Vimeo operates an online video-sharing website where users can upload and share videos. Users uploaded videos to Vimeo that included, played, or synchronized copyright-protected music owned by Plaintiffs. Plaintiffs contend that Vimeo encouraged users to create and post certain kinds of videos, including so-called 'lip‑dub' videos—videos in which users mouth or perform along with popular songs—using Plaintiffs’ copyrighted music without authorization. The record includes evidence that Vimeo curated its site, enforced content restrictions, monitored user content, and that Vimeo employees sometimes interacted with users about use of copyrighted music. There were instances in which Vimeo employees, contrary to company policy, responded to user inquiries about using copyrighted music by suggesting that such uses were allowed unless and until a copyright holder sent a takedown notice. One such exchange involved a user asking about copyrighted music usage in 'lip‑dub' videos and being told by a Vimeo employee that 'we allow it, however if the copyright holder sent us a legal takedown notice, we could have to comply.' Plaintiffs characterize Vimeo’s conduct as including the creation, upload, and promotion of lip‑dub videos and a generalized effort to promote videos incorporating music, which they say encouraged or induced users to infringe Plaintiffs’ copyrights. Vimeo characterizes any such instances as sporadic deviations from policy and disputes that its conduct amounted to inducement of infringement or to the kind of control that would disqualify it from the DMCA safe harbor.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs brought copyright infringement claims against Vimeo, asserting that Vimeo is liable for infringements of their musical recordings and compositions by reason of hosting on its website user‑uploaded videos that play or otherwise use Plaintiffs’ copyright‑protected music. Vimeo asserted, among other defenses, eligibility for the safe harbor protection for service providers under 17 U.S.C. § 512(c) of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA).
procedural_history.district_court_decision: At summary judgment, the parties cross‑moved on DMCA safe harbor issues. Plaintiffs sought partial summary judgment rejecting Vimeo’s § 512(c) safe harbor defense, arguing that Vimeo had actual or red‑flag knowledge and failed to act expeditiously, and that Vimeo had the 'right and ability to control' the infringing activity coupled with a direct financial benefit under § 512(c)(1)(B). Following the analytical framework identified in Viacom Int’l, Inc. v. YouTube, Inc., the district court treated two distinct theories for 'right and ability to control' as 'analytical guideposts': (1) the 'Cybernet' path, where a service provider exerts substantial influence by imposing editorial standards and implementing a strict monitoring program (as in Perfect 10, Inc. v. Cybernet Ventures, Inc.), and (2) the 'Grokster' path, where a provider induces infringement through purposeful, culpable expression and conduct (as in Metro‑Goldwyn‑Mayer Studios Inc. v. Grokster, Ltd.). In a section titled 'Cybernet—Substantial Influence Through a Monitoring Program,' the court analyzed Plaintiffs’ evidence concerning Vimeo’s curation, content restrictions, and monitoring program and concluded there was no triable issue that Vimeo exerted substantial influence on user activity through a Cybernet‑type monitoring program. In a subsequent section titled 'Grokster—Substantial Influence through Inducement of Infringement,' the court analyzed Plaintiffs’ inducement theory—including the lip‑dub‑related evidence—and concluded there was 'no basis to conclude that Vimeo exerted substantial influence on its users’ activities through inducement.' The court recognized some 'stray instances of wrongful conduct by Vimeo employees' and a generalized effort to promote videos that incorporate music, but found this evidence did not rise to the level of the extensive inducement evidence present in Grokster. The district court thus rejected both the Cybernet‑based and Grokster‑based theories of 'right and ability to control' and found Vimeo eligible for the § 512(c) safe harbor on that ground. Separately, the district court certified three issues for interlocutory appeal that concerned: (i) whether § 512(c) safe harbor applies to pre‑1972 sound recordings; (ii) whether evidence of some viewing by Vimeo employees of videos that played all or virtually all of 'recognizable' copyrighted songs was sufficient to show red‑flag knowledge; and (iii) whether Plaintiffs had shown a general policy of willful blindness to infringement warranting imputation of knowledge of specific infringements.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: In the earlier interlocutory appeal (Vimeo I), Plaintiffs appealed the three certified questions: the applicability of the § 512(c) safe harbor to pre‑1972 sound recordings; whether employee viewing of videos with recognizable songs established red‑flag knowledge; and whether Vimeo had a general policy of willful blindness to infringement that would justify imputing knowledge of specific infringements. As part of their willful blindness argument on interlocutory appeal, Plaintiffs asserted that Vimeo 'actively encouraged users to post videos containing infringing material,' citing employee communications including those related to lip‑dub videos, and argued that a provider cannot encourage infringement and then avoid liability by claiming ignorance. The appellate court in that interlocutory proceeding rejected Plaintiffs’ willful blindness theory, characterizing the cited instances as 'sporadic' and insufficient to show generalized encouragement of infringement or red‑flag knowledge, and did not address Grokster or inducement terminology in that context. After the case returned to the district court and final judgment issues were resolved, Plaintiffs pursued a direct appeal challenging, among other rulings, the district court’s determination that Vimeo qualified for the DMCA safe harbor under § 512(c). On direct appeal, Plaintiffs’ opening brief challenged the district court’s 'right and ability to control' ruling principally under a Cybernet‑based 'substantial influence through editorial control' theory. In that brief, Plaintiffs included Footnote 5 acknowledging that service providers can also exercise substantial influence by inducing infringement as in Grokster, but further stating that 'the rightsholders acknowledge that Vimeo I forecloses (at this stage) the argument that Vimeo’s "urging" and "encouraging users to post infringing material" constituted inducement under Grokster,' and that they were merely 'preserv[ing]' that argument for further review. Vimeo’s opposition brief asserted that, on appeal, Plaintiffs had limited their challenge to the district court’s Cybernet analysis and had abandoned any Grokster‑based inducement theory; Plaintiffs did not contest that characterization in their reply. In a January 13, 2025 opinion on direct appeal, the Second Circuit treated Plaintiffs’ Grokster‑based 'right and ability to control' argument (including the lip‑dub inducement theory) as waived or forfeited on appeal based on the manner in which Plaintiffs framed their brief, and included a footnote (Footnote 15) questioning whether Plaintiffs had properly preserved that Grokster‑based argument for potential Supreme Court review. Plaintiffs then filed the present petition for rehearing, asking the Second Circuit to reconsider its conclusion that they had waived the Grokster inducement theory and to remove the language in Footnote 15 concerning preservation of that argument for Supreme Court review. Vimeo opposed the petition.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Plaintiffs, in their opening brief on direct appeal, waived or forfeited a Grokster‑based argument that Vimeo’s alleged inducement of users to create infringing lip‑dub and other music‑containing videos constituted a 'right and ability to control' infringing activity under 17 U.S.C. § 512(c)(1)(B), thereby disqualifying Vimeo from the DMCA safe harbor.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Appellate waiver/forfeiture rules in the Second Circuit, including the principle that issues not raised and developed in the argument section of an opening brief, or issues expressly disclaimed, are treated as forfeited, even if they were argued more fully in the district court; and that merely reciting facts or including a reservation in a footnote without developed argument does not ordinarily preserve an issue. Also relevant is the construction of 'right and ability to control' under § 512(c)(1)(B) as requiring 'something more' than the mere ability to remove or block content, as articulated in Viacom Int’l, Inc. v. YouTube, Inc., and as potentially satisfied either through a Cybernet‑type monitoring/editing program or a Grokster‑type inducement of infringement.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether language in the January 13, 2025 opinion’s Footnote 15, which expressed doubt about Plaintiffs’ ability to preserve the Grokster inducement theory of 'right and ability to control' for review by the Supreme Court after not raising it as an argued issue in the Second Circuit, should be removed or modified in response to Plaintiffs’ petition for rehearing.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Principles governing preservation of issues for Supreme Court review, including the general requirement that issues be properly raised and passed upon in the lower courts; and the appellate court’s authority on rehearing to amend, clarify, or remove portions of its prior opinion.

appellant_arguments: Plaintiffs contend that they did not waive or forfeit the Grokster‑based inducement theory of 'right and ability to control.' They assert that this theory was pressed throughout the text of their opening brief on direct appeal: in their statement of facts and in the argument section addressing Vimeo’s right and ability to control under § 512(c)(1)(B). They argue that their references to Vimeo’s encouragement of users to create lip‑dub videos, its promotion of music‑containing content, and employee communications about using copyrighted music were not limited to supporting a Cybernet‑style editorial control theory, but also implicitly or explicitly advanced a Grokster‑type inducement theory as an alternative path to showing substantial influence.

They further argue that Footnote 5 in their opening brief should not be read as an intentional waiver of the Grokster theory. Instead, they characterize the footnote as recognizing that the panel’s prior decision in Vimeo I was adverse to their inducement‑as‑willful‑blindness theory, while at the same time expressly preserving their argument that Vimeo’s urging and encouraging users to post infringing material constitutes inducement under Grokster for potential higher‑court review. In their view, acknowledging perceived adverse circuit precedent and noting preservation for further review is not the same as abandoning the argument in the Second Circuit.

Plaintiffs maintain that, given their extensive briefing of the Grokster and Cybernet theories in the district court, and the district court’s detailed analysis of both theories (including specific consideration and rejection of the lip‑dub inducement theory), their direct appeal should be understood as continuing to press both theories. They emphasize that the district court’s Grokster‑based analysis of inducement and its rejection of their lip‑dub theory was an integral part of the summary judgment ruling on Vimeo’s eligibility for safe harbor, and that they reasonably expected the court of appeals to review that component as well.

With respect to Footnote 15 of the January 13 opinion, Plaintiffs argue that the appellate court should remove or modify language expressing doubt about whether their Grokster‑based inducement theory is preserved for review by the Supreme Court. They assert that, by presenting the theory in the district court, litigating it there, and expressly citing Grokster and related inducement concepts in their appellate briefing (including Footnote 5’s 'preserve this argument for further review' language), they did enough to preserve the issue for potential review by the Supreme Court. They request that the appellate court not prejudge or constrain the Supreme Court’s ability to consider whether the issue was properly preserved.
appellee_arguments: Vimeo argues that Plaintiffs did, in fact, waive or forfeit any Grokster‑based inducement theory of 'right and ability to control' on direct appeal. Vimeo points to Plaintiffs’ district court briefing, which clearly separated the § 512(c)(1)(B) analysis into two distinct pathways (Cybernet monitoring/editorial control and Grokster inducement), and to the district court’s opinion, which followed that structure and explicitly rejected both theories. Vimeo then emphasizes that, on direct appeal, Plaintiffs’ argument section only developed the Cybernet‑based 'substantial influence through editorial judgment' theory and did not develop a Grokster‑based inducement theory.

Vimeo relies on Footnote 5 of Plaintiffs’ opening brief, which expressly 'acknowledge[d] that Vimeo I forecloses (at this stage) the argument that Vimeo’s "urging" and "encouraging users to post infringing material" constituted inducement under Grokster,' characterizing that argument as merely preserved for further review. Vimeo contends that this is an explicit disclaimer of the Grokster inducement theory as a live issue before the Second Circuit on direct appeal and thus constitutes waiver or forfeiture under established appellate practice.

Vimeo also notes that its own appellate brief explicitly stated that 'on appeal, Plaintiffs limit their challenge to the district court’s Cybernet analysis,' citing Plaintiffs’ pages and Footnote 5, and that Plaintiffs did not dispute or correct this characterization in their reply brief. Vimeo argues that Plaintiffs’ silence in the face of this characterization confirms that the Grokster inducement theory was intentionally not being pursued before the court of appeals.

Regarding the distinction Plaintiffs later attempt to draw between a 'Grokster‑based claim for induced infringement' and a 'Grokster‑based theory for forfeiture of the DMCA safe harbor,' Vimeo contends that this distinction was not articulated in Plaintiffs’ opening brief and is inapposite, because the issue on appeal concerned only Vimeo’s eligibility for the § 512(c) safe harbor, not any separate inducement cause of action. Vimeo maintains that Plaintiffs’ attempt, in the petition for rehearing, to recast the nature of the earlier waiver and to reintroduce the Grokster theory is inconsistent with the briefing history and the applicable waiver rules.

On the preservation-for-Supreme-Court issue, Vimeo’s position, as reflected in its opposition to the petition, is that because Plaintiffs did not properly present the Grokster inducement theory as a ground for reversing the district court’s DMCA safe harbor ruling in their argument section on direct appeal, and instead treated it as foreclosed while merely 'preserving' it in a footnote, the Second Circuit reasonably questioned in Footnote 15 whether that theory had been preserved for Supreme Court review.

issue_1.reasoning: Second Circuit law requires that an issue be affirmatively argued in the argument section of the opening brief; factual recitations or passing references do not suffice. Here, plaintiffs plainly bifurcated their §512(c)(1)(B) theories in the district court (Cybernet vs. Grokster) and the district court separately rejected both. On direct appeal, however, the argument section was framed as a Cybernet-style ‘editorial control’ challenge. Footnote 5 affirmatively stated that Vimeo I ‘forecloses (at this stage)’ their Grokster inducement theory and said they were only ‘preserving’ it for further review. Vimeo’s brief highlighted that plaintiffs had limited their appeal to Cybernet; plaintiffs did not correct that in reply. Under settled Second Circuit forfeiture doctrine, this combination—(1) explicitly saying a theory is foreclosed ‘at this stage,’ (2) not developing argument on it, and (3) acquiescing in the appellee’s description of the scope of the appeal—constitutes waiver/forfeiture. The panel therefore will stand by its conclusion that the Grokster-based ‘right and ability to control’ theory was not properly presented on direct appeal and decline to resurrect it on rehearing.

issue_2.standard_of_review: abuse of discretion (panel’s management and phrasing of its own opinion on rehearing)
issue_2.reasoning: The panel has broad discretion on rehearing to decide whether to amend or clarify its own language regarding preservation for Supreme Court review. Footnote 15 did not purport to bind the Supreme Court; it merely expressed the panel’s view that, given plaintiffs’ express statement that Vimeo I ‘forecloses’ their Grokster theory and their failure to argue that theory on appeal, there is serious doubt whether it was preserved. That observation is consistent with Supreme Court and circuit preservation principles and accurately reflects the procedural posture. The panel is unlikely to view this as misleading or unfair, and has no obligation to sanitize the opinion to improve appellants’ certiorari posture. It will therefore deny rehearing as to the request to remove or soften Footnote 15.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The petition for rehearing asks the Second Circuit to (1) reverse its own waiver/forfeiture determination and treat a Grokster-based §512(c)(1)(B) theory as having been live on direct appeal, and (2) revise a footnote that questions whether that theory is preserved for Supreme Court review. The record strongly supports the panel’s original waiver analysis: plaintiffs made a strategic decision to proceed in the Second Circuit only on the Cybernet/editorial-control path, explicitly stated that Vimeo I ‘forecloses’ the inducement argument ‘at this stage,’ failed to develop Grokster-specific argument in their opening brief, and did not dispute Vimeo’s characterization of the scope of the appeal. Under well-established Second Circuit practice, that is classic forfeiture. Rehearing is not a vehicle to relitigate or reframe that strategy after the fact. The same reasoning undercuts any need to alter Footnote 15; the panel’s expression of doubt about preservation for Supreme Court review is a fair statement of the procedural history and does not bind the Supreme Court in any event. As a result, the court will deny the petition for rehearing in full, effectively affirming its prior resolution on both issues.

parties.appellant: Ernst Theodore Tenemille, plaintiff in the district court, former police officer employed by the Town of Ramapo Police Department
parties.appellee: Town of Ramapo; Town of Ramapo Police Department; and various Town and Department officials, including Christopher St. Lawrence (Ex-Town Supervisor), Patrick Withers (Councilman), Bradley R. Weidel (Chief of Police), Thomas Cokeley (Chief of Staff), David Holmes (Police Lieutenant), William Gravina (Ex-Administrative Lieutenant), Daniel Hyman (Squad Lieutenant), Brian Corbett (Detective Sergeant), Salomon Matos (Squad Sergeant), Christopher Franklin (Desk Sergeant), and Al Gumbs (Police Sergeant), all defendants in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background: According to the fourth amended complaint, Ernst Theodore Tenemille was employed as a police officer by the Town of Ramapo Police Department from August 2002 until his termination in December 2016. In November 2015, the Department initiated an internal investigation into Tenemille for allegedly submitting improper or questionable sick notes relating to absences he took due to a minor injury. This investigation eventually culminated in his termination on December 16, 2016. Tenemille alleged that the investigation and his termination were not legitimate but instead were motivated by unlawful discrimination based on his national origin and/or race. He further alleged that these actions were taken in retaliation for his engaging in what he contended was protected activity: questioning defendants’ access to and use of his private medical information. As part of his discrimination allegations, Tenemille asserted that there were numerous similarly situated white officers who submitted doctors’ notes that he characterized as identical to his own, and that these officers’ notes were accepted without legal challenge or investigation based on the wording of the notes. He contended that, unlike these other officers, he was investigated and ultimately terminated, which he attributed to discriminatory and retaliatory motives.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Tenemille, proceeding pro se, commenced an employment discrimination action in the Southern District of New York against the Town of Ramapo, the Town of Ramapo Police Department, and multiple Town and Department officials. In his pro se fourth amended complaint, he alleged discrimination, harassment, and retaliation in connection with the investigation into his sick notes and his December 2016 termination. He claimed violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. § 1983 (including equal protection–type violations by persons acting under color of state law), and several unspecified state law provisions.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The defendants moved under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) to dismiss the fourth amended complaint as time-barred and for failure to state a claim. In January 2022, the district court granted the motion to dismiss, concluding that some of Tenemille’s allegations were untimely and that his remaining, timely allegations did not state a claim for relief under the pleaded federal and state-law theories. The court granted Tenemille 30 days to file a fifth amended complaint. Instead of filing another amended complaint, Tenemille submitted a motion for reconsideration, which the district court construed as a motion under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b). The court denied that Rule 60(b) motion, determining that he had not shown grounds for relief from the judgment, including with respect to his assertions that there had been fraud.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Tenemille filed a timely appeal from the district court’s judgment dismissing his employment discrimination action and from the June 7, 2022 order denying his Rule 60(b) motion for reconsideration. On appeal, he challenges the dismissal of his fourth amended complaint on Rule 12(b)(6) grounds and the denial of post-judgment relief under Rule 60(b), including his contention that fraud justified vacatur of the judgment.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly dismissed Tenemille’s fourth amended complaint under Rule 12(b)(6) as partially time-barred and, as to the timely allegations, for failure to state a plausible claim of discrimination and retaliation under Title VII, § 1983, and related state law provisions.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: On a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the court accepts as true all well-pleaded factual allegations and draws all reasonable inferences in the plaintiff’s favor, but does not credit legal conclusions or conclusory statements. A complaint survives dismissal if the facts alleged plausibly state a claim for relief. For a Title VII discrimination claim, a plaintiff must allege that the employer discriminated against the plaintiff because of race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. Absent direct evidence of discrimination, the plaintiff must plausibly allege that (1) he is a member of a protected class, (2) he was qualified for his position, (3) he suffered an adverse employment action, and (4) he has at least minimal support for the proposition that the employer was motivated by discriminatory intent. For a § 1983 claim premised on equal protection, the plaintiff must allege a violation of a federal right by a person acting under color of state law; the equal protection analysis parallels Title VII, though § 1983 allows individual liability. An inference of discrimination based on comparators requires that the comparators be similarly situated to the plaintiff in all material respects and that there be a reasonably close resemblance in the facts and circumstances of the cases.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court properly denied Tenemille’s motion for reconsideration, construed as a Rule 60(b) motion, including his argument that alleged fraud warranted relief under Rule 60(b)(3).
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A motion under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b) seeks relief from a final judgment under specified grounds, including fraud under Rule 60(b)(3). A denial of a Rule 60(b) motion is reviewed for abuse of discretion. To obtain relief under Rule 60(b)(3) based on fraud, the movant must show that the opposing party’s conduct prevented the movant from fully and fairly presenting his case. The inquiry focuses on whether the alleged fraud impaired the integrity of the proceedings or the movant’s ability to litigate his claims, not merely whether underlying facts were disputed.

appellant_arguments: Tenemille contends that his fourth amended complaint adequately alleged discrimination and retaliation under Title VII and § 1983. He argues that as a member of a protected class who was terminated following an internal investigation, he provided sufficient factual material to support an inference that defendants acted with discriminatory and retaliatory intent, including allegations regarding similarly situated white officers who were not investigated or disciplined for submitting doctors’ notes that he characterizes as identical to his.

He asserts that his allegations about the handling of his sick notes and the access to his medical information, coupled with the allegedly disparate treatment of white officers and the timing and nature of the investigation and termination, suffice at the pleading stage to make his claims plausible and to overcome a Rule 12(b)(6) motion.

With respect to the Rule 60(b) motion, Tenemille argues that his motion for reconsideration set forth claims of fraud that warranted relief under Rule 60(b)(3). He maintains that there was fraudulent conduct associated with the events underlying his termination and the litigation, and that this conduct should have led the district court to reopen the judgment.

He further contends that the alleged fraud and misconduct prevented him from fully and fairly presenting his case in the district court, and that the court therefore should not have denied his Rule 60(b) motion.
appellee_arguments: The defendants argue that the district court correctly dismissed the fourth amended complaint because many of Tenemille’s allegations were time-barred, and his remaining timely allegations failed to state a plausible claim for relief under Title VII, § 1983, or state law. They contend that the complaint is largely conclusory and does not contain nonconclusory factual matter showing discriminatory or retaliatory animus.

Regarding Tenemille’s comparator-based theory, defendants assert that he merely recited that white officers turned in identical doctors’ notes without investigation, without providing factual detail about those officers, their circumstances, the content of their notes, or any disciplinary histories that would show they were similarly situated to him in all material respects.

The defendants maintain that Tenemille’s allegations about the handling of his sick notes and investigation, even if true, describe a legitimate disciplinary process rather than unlawful discrimination or retaliation, and that his references to his protected activity and medical privacy do not connect non-conclusory facts to a discriminatory or retaliatory motive.

On the Rule 60(b) issue, defendants argue that the district court correctly construed and denied the motion because Tenemille’s purported fraud allegations related only to the same underlying events and theories already presented in his fourth amended complaint. They contend that he did not identify any conduct by defendants that prevented him from fully and fairly presenting his case, but instead simply reiterated prior factual allegations and disagreements with the court’s decision, which is insufficient to warrant Rule 60(b)(3) relief.

issue_1.reasoning: Reviewed de novo, the court will accept Tenemille’s factual allegations but still require enough nonconclusory detail to make discrimination and retaliation plausible. His core theory is comparator-based: that white officers submitted ‘identical’ notes but were not disciplined. Appellate courts routinely hold that bare assertions of ‘identical’ or ‘similar’ treatment, without factual allegations about who the comparators are, their ranks, supervisors, timing, disciplinary history, or the actual content and context of their notes, are too conclusory to raise a plausible inference of discriminatory intent. The summary indicates his pleading lacked that level of detail and was dismissed as conclusory. The fact that there was an internal investigation into arguably questionable sick notes, standing alone, describes a facially legitimate disciplinary process and does not itself imply discrimination or retaliation absent specific facts tying the investigation or termination to his race/national origin or alleged protected activity. His retaliation theory likewise lacks nonconclusory allegations linking the investigation and termination to his questioning of access to his medical information beyond temporal proximity and generalized assertions. Given Second Circuit pleading standards in employment cases and the district court’s conclusion that only some allegations were timely and those failed plausibly to allege discriminatory or retaliatory animus, the appellate court is very likely to agree that the complaint, even liberally construed pro se, fails to state a claim under Title VII, § 1983, or parallel state law. The partial time-bar ruling is also unlikely to be disturbed because nothing in the summary suggests a viable argument that the limitations periods were misapplied or that equitable tolling should apply.

issue_2.reasoning: Denial of Rule 60(b) relief is highly deferential. To prevail under Rule 60(b)(3), Tenemille had to show that specific fraudulent conduct by defendants prevented him from fully and fairly presenting his case. The summary reflects that his ‘fraud’ assertions rehashed the same underlying factual disputes about the investigation and termination that were already before the court in his complaint and opposition to dismissal. Appellate courts regularly hold that such arguments do not meet Rule 60(b)(3)’s requirement of fraud affecting the integrity of the proceedings; they simply express disagreement with the merits ruling. The district court also gave him an opportunity to file a fifth amended complaint before entering final judgment, reinforcing that he had a full chance to present his claims. On this record, the appellate court is very likely to conclude that the district court acted well within its discretion in treating the filing as a Rule 60(b) motion and denying it for failure to show fraud or any other ground for extraordinary relief.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Both issues line up with typical appellate outcomes in pro se employment-discrimination cases dismissed at the pleading stage. The complaint, as described, relies heavily on conclusory assertions of discriminatory and retaliatory motives and on inadequately detailed comparator allegations. Under de novo review, the appellate court will still apply Twombly/Iqbal and its own precedents requiring some factual content to support an inference of bias; it will not rewrite the complaint to fix missing comparator detail. On the post-judgment motion, the abuse-of-discretion standard and the nature of Tenemille’s Rule 60(b) arguments—essentially a repetition of his underlying merits contentions framed as ‘fraud’—make reversal particularly unlikely. Nothing in the summary suggests procedural irregularity or newly discovered misconduct that impeded his ability to litigate. Taken together, the most probable result is that the court affirms the dismissal of the fourth amended complaint and the denial of Rule 60(b) relief in full.

parties.appellant: Amber Lavigne, plaintiff in the district court, parent of minor A.B.
parties.appellee: Great Salt Bay Community School Board, municipal entity responsible for Great Salt Bay Community School; and Samuel Roy (school social worker), Kim Schaff (principal), Lynsey Johnston (district superintendent), and Jessica Berk (school social worker), all sued in their official capacities as school staff/administrators

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Great Salt Bay Community School ("Great Salt") is a K–8 school. Amber Lavigne’s minor child, A.B., began attending Great Salt in 2019. Lavigne was initially generally pleased with A.B.’s education. In December 2022, when A.B. was thirteen, Lavigne discovered a chest binder while cleaning A.B.’s room. The complaint defines a chest binder as a device used to flatten a female's chest so as to appear male. A.B. told Lavigne that school social worker Samuel Roy had provided the chest binder and had instructed A.B. on its use. Lavigne further alleges that, the same day, Roy gave A.B. a second chest binder and told A.B. he was not going to tell A.B.’s parents about the binders and that A.B. did not need to do so either. Lavigne alleges that she was never notified by the school that A.B. would be or had been given chest binders or instructed in their use.

Around this same period, Lavigne learned that at school A.B. was using a name and pronouns different from those given at birth and used at home. According to the complaint, the school never informed her that A.B. was using an alternate name and pronouns at school. Lavigne alleges that the defendants "withheld and concealed" information about both the chest binders and A.B.'s use of a different name and pronouns pursuant to what she characterizes as a "blanket policy, pattern, and practice" of withholding and concealing information from parents about so-called "gender-affirming" treatment of minor children. She further alleges there is no policy or procedure allowing parents to provide input when a student chooses to use a different name and pronouns at school.

Shortly after discovering the chest binder, Lavigne met with Principal Kim Schaff and Superintendent Lynsey Johnston. According to the complaint, both expressed sympathy and concern that the information had been withheld and concealed from her. Two days later, Superintendent Johnston told Lavigne that no policy had been violated by giving chest binders to A.B. or by school officials’ use of an alternate name and pronouns for A.B. Soon thereafter, Lavigne withdrew A.B. from Great Salt, citing what she viewed as the school’s policy, pattern, and practice of withholding and concealing important information about her minor child’s psychosexual development.

Lavigne alleges that school officials pointed her to certain written policies as supporting their actions: the Transgender Students Guidelines ("Guidelines") and the Staff Conduct with Students Policy ("Staff Conduct Policy"). The Guidelines state, among other things, that their purpose is to foster a safe and nondiscriminatory learning environment; that administrators and staff are to consider student needs on a case-by-case basis; and that, in addressing needs raised by a transgender student, the school should develop a plan "in consultation with the student, parent(s)/guardian(s) and others as appropriate." The Guidelines do not contain any express directive to withhold information from parents or guardians. Lavigne alleges that these Guidelines are silent regarding the provision of chest binders or other devices to students with or without parental involvement, and that they do not mandate parental involvement in decisions about alternate names and pronouns. The Staff Conduct Policy includes an express prohibition on staff asking students to keep secrets.

In late December 2022, Lavigne addressed the Great Salt Bay Community School Board at a public meeting. She described the trust she believed had been broken by the defendants’ withholding and concealment of information about her child's psychosexual development, and she stated that the school’s decisions had driven a wedge between herself and A.B.

Following the meeting, the Board issued two public statements, and Principal Schaff issued a separate statement. In its first statement, the Board said it could not discuss confidential student and staff information, emphasized that its priority was a safe, welcoming, and inclusive environment, and noted that it had specific policies and procedures for addressing student and parent concerns. The Board stated that its policies comply with Maine law protecting the right of all students, regardless of gender or gender identity, to equal access to education, supports, and services, and protecting student privacy regardless of age. The statement did not name Lavigne, A.B., or any specific staff.

In a second statement in January 2023, the Board addressed recent bomb threats made to the school, which it attributed to a "grossly inaccurate and one-sided story." Again emphasizing confidentiality obligations, the Board defended the school’s "ongoing and steadfast commitment" to providing all students with safe and equal access to educational opportunities without discrimination. The Board cited Maine statutes allowing minors to consent to treatment for emotional or psychological problems without parental consent (Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 22, § 1502) and protecting the confidentiality of school-based mental health counseling (Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 20-A, § 4008). The Board stated that neither it nor school administration was aware of any violation of policy or law requiring further action.

In February 2023, Principal Schaff issued a separate statement largely addressing threats against the school and staff. She stated that under Maine law, a school counselor or social worker generally may not be required to divulge or release information gathered during a counseling relationship with a minor client, except as otherwise provided by law. Lavigne alleges that this statement did not explain how providing a chest binder or using alternate names and pronouns constitutes "information gathered" in counseling, and did not mention A.B. or Lavigne or discuss specific Great Salt policies.

After Lavigne filed this lawsuit, the Board unanimously approved a second-year contract term for social worker Roy, who allegedly provided the chest binders to A.B. This post-suit contract renewal was not included in the original complaint but was later presented to the courts via a request for judicial notice.

procedural_history.claims_brought: In April 2023, Lavigne filed a civil action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Great Salt Bay Community School Board and four individual school employees (social workers Roy and Berk, Principal Schaff, and Superintendent Johnston), all in their official capacities. She alleged that the defendants’ actions in concealing from her the provision of chest binders to A.B. and the use of an alternative name and pronouns at school violated her substantive due process rights as a parent to control and direct A.B.’s education and upbringing. She also alleged a procedural due process violation based on being denied the opportunity to participate in decision-making regarding A.B.’s gender-identity expression at school. She asserted municipal liability against the Board and claims against the individual defendants.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
The defendants moved to dismiss, arguing: (1) that the claims against the individual defendants in their official capacities were redundant of the municipal liability claim against the Board; (2) that the municipal liability claim failed because the complaint did not allege facts showing that any unconstitutional acts were caused by an official policy or custom of the Board; and (3) that even if such a policy existed, the alleged conduct did not violate Lavigne’s constitutional rights. Lavigne opposed, arguing that keeping the individual defendants in the case would aid her ability to prove municipal liability, that her allegations showed the defendants acted pursuant to a policy or custom of withholding information from parents or that the Board ratified the conduct, and that she had sufficiently alleged constitutional violations.

After a hearing, the district court granted the motion to dismiss as to the individual defendants (the two social workers, the principal, and the superintendent), reasoning that Lavigne was not seeking relief from them individually and that their testimony could be obtained without them being named defendants. The court took the remainder of the motion under advisement. In a subsequent written decision, the court granted the motion to dismiss as to the Board. The court characterized all of Lavigne’s claims as centering on an alleged policy of withholding information from parents and concluded that the viability of the suit depended on whether she had adequately alleged such a policy. Focusing on the second element of municipal liability—whether a municipal policy or custom was responsible for any constitutional violation—the court determined that Lavigne had not plausibly alleged that a Board policy or custom caused the alleged violation. The court found her assertions of a "withholding policy" to be conclusory and unsupported by factual allegations, concluded that her allegations were insufficient to show a settled custom or practice of withholding information, and also found inadequate her theory that the Board had ratified the individual defendants’ conduct via public statements or by renewing Roy’s contract.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Lavigne filed a timely appeal from the district court’s order dismissing her complaint. On appeal she challenges the dismissal of her § 1983 municipal liability claim against the Great Salt Bay Community School Board, contending that she adequately alleged that the Board had a policy or custom of withholding information about students’ gender identity and expression from parents, or alternatively, that the Board ratified the challenged conduct, and that the district court erred in addressing only the second element of municipal liability. Although her notice of appeal referenced the prior order dismissing the individual defendants, she did not present arguments in her appellate briefing specifically challenging that order.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Lavigne’s complaint plausibly alleged that the Great Salt Bay Community School Board maintained an unwritten official policy, custom, or widespread practice of withholding from parents information about students’ use of alternate names and pronouns and the provision of chest binders or similar "gender-affirming" measures, sufficient to satisfy the second element of municipal liability under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Monell and its progeny, a municipality is liable under § 1983 only when the execution of its policy or custom inflicts the alleged constitutional injury. A plaintiff must plausibly allege: (1) municipal action constituting an official policy, custom, or practice attributable to the municipality (which can be written policy, a well-settled and widespread unwritten custom, or certain decisions by final policymakers); (2) that this policy or custom was the moving force causing the alleged constitutional violation; and (3) the requisite level of municipal fault. At the Rule 12(b)(6) stage, the complaint must contain nonconclusory factual allegations that, accepted as true, make the existence of such a policy or custom plausible, not merely possible.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the School Board can be held liable on a ratification theory—that is, whether its post-incident statements and its decision to renew social worker Roy’s contract plausibly alleged that authorized policymakers affirmatively approved the challenged decisions and the basis for them, thereby creating municipal liability for a single decision.
