Their use of BAYC Marks for the RR/BAYC project was nominative fair use: they used Yuga’s marks and imagery only because reference to the BAYC collection was necessary to criticize and comment on it and on NFTs more broadly; they used only so much of the marks as needed and did not imply Yuga’s sponsorship or endorsement, instead making clear through statements and context that their project was oppositional and critical.

Their RR/BAYC project was an expressive art and protest work criticizing alleged racist and Nazi imagery in BAYC and critiquing the NFT economy; under the First Amendment and the Rogers framework (as limited by Jack Daniel’s), their use of the marks in that expressive context should not be actionable as trademark infringement. They contend that their use of Yuga’s marks was not, in substance, a traditional source‑identifying use but part of a broader artistic and political commentary.

Even if trademark protections and theories formally apply, Yuga failed, at a minimum, to demonstrate on summary judgment a likelihood of consumer confusion under the Sleekcraft factors. Defendants argue that: (a) their RR/BAYC branding (including the "RR/" prefix and satirical framing) distinguished their work; (b) purchasers of BAYC and RR/BAYC NFTs are sophisticated and exercise a high degree of care, especially given the complexity of NFTs and the significant value of BAYC NFTs; (c) there were distinct marketing channels, since most RR/BAYC sales occurred on rrbayc.com rather than through the same primary distribution channels as BAYC; (d) evidence of actual confusion was limited and disputed; and (e) their artistic disclaimers and links to critical content made clear that RR/BAYC was a protest project, not an official Yuga collection.

Regarding the ACPA claim, defendants argue that rrbayc.com and apemarket.com are not "confusingly similar" to any protected Yuga marks as a matter of law. In particular, they contend that adding "rr" to "bayc" in rrbayc.com meaningfully changes the visual, aural, and semantic impression of the domain by associating it with "Ryder Ripps," and that apemarket.com does not copy any intact registered or asserted Yuga word mark (it uses only the word "ape," which Yuga concedes is not a protected mark in isolation). They also dispute any finding that they acted with a bad‑faith intent to profit from Yuga’s marks, asserting that their intent was protest and critique rather than commercial exploitation.

On the DMCA counterclaim, defendants argue that Yuga’s takedown notices to NFT marketplaces were materially false because Yuga has no registered copyrights in the Bored Ape images, yet it allegedly represented that RR/BAYC content infringed its copyrights. They maintain that marketplaces removed RR/BAYC content in reliance on those notices, and that there was evidence from which a factfinder could conclude that Yuga knew or should have known it lacked a valid basis for copyright assertions, thereby satisfying the "knowing misrepresentation" requirement.

On the declaratory‑judgment counterclaims, defendants argue that dismissal for lack of subject‑matter jurisdiction should have been without prejudice. They contend that labeling the dismissal "with prejudice" is inconsistent with standard practice for jurisdictional dismissals and could create confusion regarding their ability to reassert declaratory‑judgment claims in the future if Yuga later registers copyrights or brings copyright claims.

Defendants further argue that, to the extent the trademark and cybersquatting liability determinations do not stand, the district court’s equitable remedies—including disgorgement, statutory damages, the breadth of the injunction, and the attorneys’ fees award—must be vacated. They also assert that the remedies, especially disgorgement and statutory damages, infringed on their First Amendment rights and raised Seventh Amendment concerns, because factual issues underlying monetary relief were not tried to a jury.
appellee_arguments: NFTs, and BAYC NFTs in particular, are "goods" under the Lanham Act. Yuga points to the statutory language protecting marks used with "any goods or services" and to U.S. Patent and Trademark Office guidance treating NFTs as goods whose marks identify the source of associated digital assets and services. Yuga emphasizes that BAYC NFTs function as membership passes, carry commercial value, and are bought and sold as discrete products in NFT marketplaces.

Yuga asserts that it owns valid and enforceable rights in the BAYC Marks. It maintains it was the first user of these marks in commerce, establishing priority. Yuga argues that any alleged violation of securities registration laws is, at most, collateral to its use of the marks and not the type of unlawful conduct that invalidates trademark rights, because it does not affect the source‑identifying function of the marks or their role in protecting consumers. Yuga denies any assignment of trademark rights via its T&Cs, explaining that the T&Cs address ownership and licensing of the underlying artwork and derivative works (copyright‑related concepts), not trademarks, and that nothing in the T&Cs transfers or licenses trademark rights or the associated goodwill to NFT purchasers. Yuga further contends that it has actively policed its marks, including by sending takedown notices regarding infringing uses, and that any unlicensed third‑party uses cited by defendants are isolated and insufficient to show abandonment, naked licensing, or genericide.

Yuga argues that defendants’ use of the BAYC Marks is classic trademark use, not nominative fair use. It emphasizes that defendants embedded the "Bored Ape Yacht Club" and "BAYC" marks as the contract name and symbol within their RR/BAYC NFTs, used BAYC logos and names on social media and marketplace listings, and configured RR/BAYC NFTs to point to the same artwork and Ape IDs as BAYC NFTs. According to Yuga, this is not merely referencing BAYC for commentary, but using BAYC marks as designations of source for a competing NFT collection, intending to attract buyers and trade on BAYC’s goodwill.

On the First Amendment issue, Yuga contends that the RR/BAYC project does not fall within the limited expressive‑work exception recognized in Rogers and narrowed by Jack Daniel’s because defendants used the BAYC Marks as source identifiers for their own goods. Yuga argues that even if defendants had expressive aims such as criticism and parody, the key legal question is whether the marks are used as designations of origin, and here defendants used BAYC names and logos in precisely that way to label and sell their own NFTs.

Yuga maintains that the Sleekcraft factors support a finding of likelihood of confusion, and that the district court properly resolved that issue on summary judgment. It argues that the BAYC Marks are both conceptually and commercially strong; that the products (NFT collections) are highly proximate, particularly because RR/BAYC NFTs are tied to the same images and Ape IDs; that defendants used nearly identical marks (including "Bored Ape Yacht Club," "BAYC," and BAYC logos) and confusingly similar domains; that evidence of actual confusion exists in the record in the form of survey data, bot reports, and public commentary; that both sides marketed NFTs through similar online channels and NFT marketplaces, as well as Twitter; that many NFT purchasers are not as sophisticated as defendants claim, and in any event sophisticated consumers may still be confused where marks and content are effectively identical; and that defendants intentionally adopted Yuga’s marks and imagery in order to capitalize on BAYC’s reputation and goodwill.

Regarding the ACPA claim, Yuga asserts that rrbayc.com and apemarket.com are confusingly similar to its BAYC‑related marks. For rrbayc.com, Yuga emphasizes that the heart of the domain, "bayc," is identical to its BAYC mark and domain, and that the "rr" prefix is insufficient to dispel confusion, especially where defendants’ purpose was to parallel BAYC’s branding. For apemarket.com, Yuga points to its "BORED APE" and other APE‑based marks and contends that the use of "ape" in the domain, combined with the NFT context and defendants’ other uses, is likely to lead consumers to associate the domain with Yuga’s ape‑branded offerings. Yuga also argues that ample evidence supports the district court’s finding of bad‑faith intent to profit, including defendants’ admitted knowledge of BAYC’s fame, their decision to use similar branding, and their efforts to attract BAYC’s audience.

On the DMCA counterclaim, Yuga argues that the takedown notices relied on trademark infringement, not copyright, and that any references to the DMCA or "DMCA Agent" were either boilerplate or clerical and not materially relied upon by service providers. Yuga notes that the notices specifically listed Yuga’s trademarks and complained of unauthorized use of those marks, passing off as official Yuga accounts, and potential consumer confusion. Yuga maintains that defendants lack evidence that the marketplaces removed RR/BAYC content because of any alleged copyright claim as opposed to the clearly articulated trademark complaints, and therefore cannot show either a material misrepresentation or the requisite actual knowledge of falsity.

As to declaratory‑judgment counterclaims, Yuga argues that the district court correctly found no live case or controversy over copyright ownership because Yuga had not registered any copyrights in the Bored Ape images and had not brought copyright claims. Yuga contends that, under these circumstances, dismissal with prejudice was within the court’s discretion and does not preclude defendants from bringing a future declaratory‑judgment action if Yuga later registers copyrights and threatens or initiates enforcement. Yuga points out that a jurisdictional dismissal labeled "with prejudice" does not operate as an adjudication on the merits for res judicata purposes.

On remedies, Yuga maintains that the equitable awards and injunction entered after the bench trial are proper so long as the underlying liability determinations stand. It argues that disgorgement of defendants’ profits and statutory damages under the ACPA are permissible and supported by findings of willful infringement and bad‑faith cybersquatting; that the permanent injunction is appropriately tailored to prevent further misuse of Yuga’s marks, including RR/BAYC and ApeMarket; and that the case was properly deemed "exceptional" to justify attorneys’ fees. Yuga disputes that there were any First Amendment or Seventh Amendment violations at the remedies stage because the relief requested and awarded was equitable in nature and the court followed traditional equitable principles.

issue_1.reasoning:
The core liability questions on the Lanham Act claim are legal or mixed questions appropriate for summary judgment review de novo. The record, as summarized, strongly supports the district court’s conclusions.

(a) NFTs as “goods”: The Lanham Act covers marks used on “any goods or services.” Courts and the PTO now routinely treat NFTs and related digital assets as goods. BAYC NFTs are discrete, tradable items functioning as passes and collectibles. There is no doctrinal basis to exclude them; defendants’ argument would be an outlier and is unlikely to prevail.

(b) Valid, protectable marks and priority: Yuga was first in use with the BAYC marks in nationwide commerce and invested in goodwill. The “unlawful use” defense based on alleged securities-law violations is too collateral to the source-identifying function of the marks to defeat priority; there is no tight nexus between any securities-registration issue and consumer protection in trademark law. The T&Cs granting buyers broad rights to the artwork do not expressly transfer trademark rights or goodwill, and standard principles bar finding an implied assignment of marks to 10,000 dispersed purchasers. Alleged failures to police or control quality are limited and contradicted by Yuga’s actual enforcement efforts (takedowns etc.); that is insufficient as a matter of law to show abandonment, naked licensing, or genericide for relatively young, highly distinctive marks.

(c) Nominative fair use: Defendants did far more than refer to BAYC to comment on it. They embedded “Bored Ape Yacht Club” and “BAYC” as the contract name and symbol for their own NFTs, used the same images and Ape IDs, and marketed a parallel collection. That is classic source-identifying use of another’s mark, not mere reference. They also used more of the marks than necessary (names, logos, domains), and the blockchain-level use affords no clear built-in disclaimer. Under New Kids/Tabari, at least the second and third nominative-fair-use prongs are not satisfied.

(d) First Amendment / Rogers-Jack Daniel’s: After Jack Daniel’s, the Rogers test does not shield uses where the defendant is using the plaintiff’s mark “as a mark” to designate the source of its own goods. Here, RR/BAYC NFTs are marketed as a separate collection; the BAYC marks identify that collection in commerce. Even if the project has expressive, critical aims, the challenged conduct is precisely the sort of source-identifying use Jack Daniel’s leaves fully subject to ordinary trademark analysis. Thus, the First Amendment defense fails as a matter of law.

(e) Likelihood of confusion: The undisputed facts strongly favor Yuga on Sleekcraft. The marks are conceptually and commercially strong; the goods are identical (competing BAYC-linked NFT collections); defendants used nearly identical marks and even the same artwork/IDs; and channels of trade and marketing overlap (NFT marketplaces, Twitter, web sales). The defendant’s intent was to appropriate BAYC’s identifiers and audience, and Etherscan and bots actually misreported RR/BAYC as BAYC, indicating real confusion. Sophistication does not overcome confusion when marks and content are essentially identical. Against this record, no reasonable factfinder could conclude an absence of likely confusion. Summary judgment on liability, including rejection of the nominative-fair-use and First Amendment defenses, is therefore properly affirmed.

issue_2.reasoning:
The ACPA summary judgment ruling is reviewed de novo. The elements are clearly met on this record.

There is no dispute that defendants registered and used rrbayc.com and apemarket.com. BAYC is distinctive; defendants do not seriously undermine distinctiveness.

For rrbayc.com, the dominant portion of the domain is “bayc,” identical to Yuga’s mark and domain except for the “rr” prefix, which plausibly stands for Ryder Ripps. Minor additions rarely dispel confusing similarity under the ACPA, particularly where the addition is tailored to ride on the mark’s fame. Given that the site sold NFTs mapped to BAYC images and defendants marketed directly to the Yuga community, the domain is confusingly similar as a matter of law.

For apemarket.com, Yuga’s family of “Bored Ape” and ape‑themed marks and its well-known association with “apes” in the NFT context make “apemarket.com” at least confusingly similar in this niche commercial space. That domain was conceived to host BAYC and RR/BAYC NFTs side-by-side and was previewed to the same audience. The semantic overlap with Yuga’s ape branding, in the NFT marketplace context, supports a finding of confusing similarity.

Bad-faith intent to profit is evidenced by: defendants’ knowledge of BAYC’s fame; deliberate selection of domains incorporating or evoking Yuga’s marks; promotion to BAYC’s community; and the commercial sale of RR/BAYC NFTs mimicking BAYC. Their asserted protest motive does not negate that they earned over $1.4 million from the project and configured the domains to capitalize on BAYC’s goodwill. On this record, a reasonable jury could not find a lack of bad faith, so summary judgment is properly affirmed.

issue_3.reasoning:
Summary judgment on the § 512(f) counterclaim is reviewed de novo. Defendants must show a material misrepresentation in a DMCA notice and that Yuga knew the representation was false.

The summary describes Yuga’s notices as grounded in trademark, not copyright: they identified Yuga’s trademarks and complained of passing off and confusion. References to “DMCA” or a “DMCA agent” in online forms do not, by themselves, constitute a substantive copyright representation. Defendants’ theory is that because Yuga lacked registered copyrights, any takedown under the DMCA was necessarily a knowing misrepresentation. But: (1) registration is not a prerequisite to owning copyright; and (2) more critically, the record here does not show that Yuga actually asserted copyright infringement as the basis of removal. If marketplaces acted on trademark-based complaints, any incidental DMCA labeling is not a material misrepresentation causing removal.

Under Rossi, the scienter standard is subjective actual knowledge or bad faith; mere legal error or negligence is not enough. Defendants’ argument that Yuga “should have known” it lacked a copyright basis is therefore insufficient. Because defendants have not identified evidence that Yuga knowingly made a false copyright claim that materially caused takedowns, there is no triable § 512(f) issue. Summary judgment for Yuga is properly affirmed.

issue_4.standard_of_review: de novo (existence of Article III case or controversy); abuse of discretion (form of dismissal)
issue_4.reasoning:
Whether an Article III controversy exists is reviewed de novo; the manner of dismissal is reviewed for abuse of discretion.

On the merits of jurisdiction, the district court correctly found no actual copyright controversy. Yuga had not registered any Bored Ape copyrights and asserted no copyright claims. Defendants sought a declaratory judgment of non‑copyrightability in an essentially hypothetical dispute about future enforcement. Without registration or concrete enforcement threats, that is too speculative for Article III. Dismissal for lack of subject‑matter jurisdiction is therefore proper.

As to labeling the dismissal “with prejudice,” Ninth Circuit law recognizes that a jurisdictional dismissal is by definition not on the merits and does not have claim‑preclusive effect, regardless of label. The court could reasonably intend only to close the existing action. Given that future enforcement, if any, would arise in a different factual posture (e.g., after registration or threats), there is no practical bar against a new declaratory‑judgment suit at that time. Using the phrase “with prejudice” in this context, while arguably imprecise, does not constitute an abuse of discretion warranting reversal, because it neither rests on an erroneous legal premise nor imposes impermissible claim preclusion. Affirmance is therefore appropriate.

issue_5.standard_of_review: abuse of discretion (equitable remedies); clear error (underlying factual findings)
issue_5.reasoning:
Remedies after a bench trial—disgorgement, statutory damages selection within the ACPA range, injunction scope, and fee awards—are reviewed for abuse of discretion, with factual findings reviewed for clear error.

Because the liability determinations on the Lanham Act and ACPA claims stand, there is no basis to vacate remedies on that ground.

Disgorgement: The court awarded defendants’ profits based on willful infringement and unjust enrichment. The record shows deliberate copying of marks and appropriation of BAYC goodwill. This is a classic case for disgorgement. The court was entitled to treat profits as a surrogate for damages and deterrence. There is no indication it exceeded statutory or equitable bounds.

ACPA statutory damages: The court selected the maximum within the statutory range, grounded in findings of willful, bad‑faith cybersquatting. Given the strong evidence of bad faith and the close mimicking of Yuga’s marks, choosing the maximum is within its permissible discretion.

Permanent injunction: The injunction bars defendants from marketing, promoting, or selling products or services using the BAYC marks, including RR/BAYC and ApeMarket. It does not broadly prohibit criticism or discussion of Yuga; it targets infringing commercial uses. That is consistent with First Amendment limits and traditional equitable principles (irreparable harm, inadequacy of legal remedies, balance of hardships, public interest in avoiding confusion). The scope is tailored to stop misuse of the marks rather than silence protest.

Attorneys’ fees: In light of the willful infringement, bad‑faith cybersquatting, and litigation conduct, deeming the matter “exceptional” under § 1117 and § 1125(d) falls well within the range of reasonable outcomes.

First and Seventh Amendment objections to remedies lack force. After Yuga withdrew legal damages and proceeded solely on equitable relief, there was no entitlement to a jury on profits or injunctive relief. The bench trial afforded due process. The First Amendment does not bar equitable relief against non‑expressive, source‑identifying misuse of marks. The district court therefore did not abuse its discretion, and the remedial orders should be affirmed.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Across all issues, defendants’ arguments seek to push trademark, ACPA, and DMCA doctrines beyond accepted bounds, especially in light of later‑clarifying Supreme Court guidance in Jack Daniel’s on expressive uses. The undisputed facts show classic, willful, source‑identifying use of Yuga’s marks to sell a parallel NFT collection and related domains, with documented confusion. That justifies summary judgment on Lanham Act and ACPA liability. The § 512(f) counterclaim fails for lack of evidence of a knowing, material copyright misrepresentation; the declaratory‑judgment counterclaims fail for lack of a present copyright controversy; and the equitable remedies are squarely within the district court’s discretion given the findings of willfulness and bad faith. Nothing in the summary suggests reversible legal error or clearly erroneous factfinding, so a full affirmance of the district court’s judgment is the most likely appellate outcome.

parties.appellant: Harlan Shabshelowitz, plaintiff in the federal civil action and former criminal defendant in Rhode Island state court
parties.appellee: State of Rhode Island Department of Public Safety, State Police; and Lieutenant Michael Casey, individually and in his capacity as a police officer employed by the State of Rhode Island (defendants in the federal civil action)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
On March 28, 2013, a Rhode Island grand jury indicted Harlan Shabshelowitz and four co‑defendants on charges of obtaining money under false pretenses and conspiracy to obtain money under false pretenses, alleging a conspiracy to commit mortgage fraud. The criminal charges were brought under R.I. Gen. Laws §§ 11‑41‑4 and 11‑41‑5 (2002) for obtaining money under false pretenses and under R.I. Gen. Laws §§ 11‑1‑6, 11‑41‑4, and 11‑41‑5 (2002) for conspiracy.

In or around June 2015, while the criminal case was pending in the Rhode Island Superior Court, Shabshelowitz filed five separate motions to dismiss the criminal charges before a Superior Court Magistrate. In these motions he argued, among other things, that the indictment should be dismissed because of alleged misconduct during the grand jury proceedings, including prosecutorial misconduct, the presentation of misleading evidence, and missing or altered evidence.

The Magistrate held two hearings on the motions, including an evidentiary hearing on April 29, 2016, at which witness testimony was taken. In support of his motions to dismiss, Shabshelowitz submitted memoranda, grand jury transcripts, and witness testimony from three witnesses, including himself. After considering this material, the Magistrate rejected his arguments and denied the motions to dismiss in an oral order issued on June 10, 2016.

Shabshelowitz appealed the Magistrate's ruling to an Associate Justice of the Rhode Island Superior Court. He did not, however, appeal the Magistrate's decision rejecting his claim that evidence was missing. On December 13, 2016, the Associate Justice held a hearing on the appeal and, on de novo review, denied the appeal and adopted the Magistrate's decision in full. The Associate Justice added observations that Shabshelowitz had not presented evidence of prosecutorial misconduct that justified dismissal and had not established either a pervasive scheme to present false information to the grand jury or a sufficient amount of false factual information to justify dismissing the indictment. Shabshelowitz did not attempt to take a further appeal from the Associate Justice's ruling.

On June 5, 2017, the Rhode Island Attorney General's Office entered a nolle prosequi of the charges against Shabshelowitz pursuant to Rhode Island Rule of Criminal Procedure 48(a). The dismissal occurred as part of a plea agreement that the Attorney General's Office reached with one of Shabshelowitz's co‑defendants.

On February 27, 2020, more than thirty‑two months after the nolle prosequi, Shabshelowitz filed a civil lawsuit in federal court. In that lawsuit he alleged that the State lacked probable cause to prosecute him but nonetheless induced the grand jury to indict him by withholding exculpatory evidence and misrepresenting inculpatory evidence. The factual basis of his federal malicious prosecution claim centers on the alleged lack of probable cause for the indictment and the alleged misconduct in the grand jury proceedings that led to the indictment.

procedural_history.claims_brought: In the federal action filed on February 27, 2020, Shabshelowitz initially asserted claims against the Rhode Island Department of Public Safety, the Rhode Island State Police, and Rhode Island State Police Officer Michael Casey (in his individual and official capacities) under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Rhode Island Constitution, and several state‑law tort theories. On February 9, 2021, he amended his complaint to omit all but a single state‑law claim for malicious prosecution. The case proceeded in federal court under diversity jurisdiction.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: After discovery closed on November 22, 2023 (following multiple extensions), defendants moved for summary judgment on January 16, 2024. Among other grounds, they argued that Shabshelowitz was collaterally estopped from contesting whether his indictment was procured without probable cause or through prosecutorial misconduct, because those issues had already been litigated and decided against him in the state‑court proceedings on his motions to dismiss. The district court determined that Rhode Island collateral estoppel applied. It found that the issues in the state criminal motions to dismiss regarding alleged prosecutorial misconduct and fraud in procuring the indictment were identical to the issues Shabshelowitz sought to relitigate in his malicious prosecution claim. The court noted that two Rhode Island state courts (the Magistrate and the Associate Justice, on de novo review) had denied his motions to dismiss, rejecting his arguments that the indictment was procured by fraud and misconduct. The district court concluded that there had been a final disposition on those issues, that the parties were the same, and that Shabshelowitz had received a full and fair opportunity to litigate the matter in state court, supported in part by the state courts' evidentiary hearing and his failure to pursue a further appeal from the Associate Justice's ruling. On that basis, the court granted summary judgment to defendants, holding that collateral estoppel barred relitigation of the prosecutorial misconduct and lack‑of‑probable‑cause issues central to the malicious prosecution claim.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: On appeal, Shabshelowitz challenges the district court's grant of summary judgment to the state law enforcement defendants in his malicious prosecution suit. Specifically, he contests the district court's application of Rhode Island collateral estoppel law, arguing that the defendants did not establish the 'final judgment' element and that he was deprived of a full and fair opportunity to litigate the relevant issues in state court because appellate review in the Rhode Island Supreme Court was allegedly unavailable. He has conceded on appeal that the 'identity of issues' element of collateral estoppel is satisfied.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in concluding that the prior Rhode Island Superior Court proceedings on Shabshelowitz's motions to dismiss resulted in a 'final judgment on the merits' for purposes of applying Rhode Island collateral estoppel to bar his malicious prosecution claim.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Rhode Island law, collateral estoppel (issue preclusion) applies when: (1) there is an identity of issues between the two proceedings; (2) the previous proceeding resulted in a final judgment on the merits; and (3) the party against whom collateral estoppel is asserted is the same or in privity with a party from the previous proceeding. See Osifodunrin v. Desjardins, 333 A.3d 502, 504 (R.I. 2025). The federal court must look to state law to determine the preclusive effect of a prior state‑court judgment.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in concluding that Shabshelowitz had a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issues regarding alleged prosecutorial misconduct and the validity of the indictment in the Rhode Island Superior Court, in light of his contention that appellate review in the Rhode Island Supreme Court was unavailable or not realistically accessible.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: As part of applying collateral estoppel, courts consider whether the party against whom preclusion is asserted had a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issue in the prior proceeding. Federal courts, reviewing the preclusive effect of state‑court decisions, apply the state's collateral estoppel rules consistent with due process, which requires a full and fair opportunity to be heard.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether arguments challenging the 'final judgment' element of collateral estoppel and the existence of a full and fair opportunity to litigate, which were not raised in the district court, can be considered for the first time on appeal under the First Circuit's 'raise or waive' doctrine.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: In the First Circuit, legal theories not squarely raised in the district court are generally deemed waived and may not be presented for the first time on appeal, absent extraordinary or unique circumstances. The court applies a 'raise or waive' rule, which allows consideration of new arguments on appeal only in exceptional cases where strict application would result in a miscarriage of justice or other compelling circumstances.

appellant_arguments: The defendants failed to establish the 'final judgment on the merits' element required for collateral estoppel under Rhode Island law. According to Shabshelowitz, the denial of his motions to dismiss in the Rhode Island Superior Court (by the Magistrate and, on appeal, by the Associate Justice) did not constitute a final judgment on the merits that could preclude relitigation of the issues in his later malicious prosecution suit.

He was deprived of a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issues in state court because, he asserts, appellate review in the Rhode Island Supreme Court was unavailable or effectively foreclosed after the Associate Justice's ruling. He contends that the absence of a non‑frivolous avenue for further appeal should prevent the application of collateral estoppel to bar his malicious prosecution claim.
He has conceded on appeal that the 'identity of issues' element of Rhode Island collateral estoppel is satisfied, shifting his challenge to the finality and full‑and‑fair‑opportunity components.

Regarding appellate procedure, he maintains that the district court erred by assuming he could have appealed to the Rhode Island Supreme Court and by using his failure to do so as support for finding that he had a full and fair opportunity to litigate in state court.

On the merits of his malicious prosecution claim (as relevant to summary judgment), he argues that there was no probable cause to prosecute him and that the grand jury indictment was obtained through the withholding of exculpatory evidence and the misrepresentation of inculpatory evidence, such that summary judgment should not have been granted.
appellee_arguments: The defendants argued in the district court that Shabshelowitz was collaterally estopped from challenging whether his indictment was supported by probable cause or procured by prosecutorial misconduct because these issues were litigated and decided in the Rhode Island Superior Court on his motions to dismiss. They asserted that all three elements of Rhode Island collateral estoppel law were satisfied: (1) the parties were the same or in privity; (2) there was a final judgment on the merits in the prior proceeding; and (3) the issues in the federal malicious prosecution case were identical to those resolved in the state‑court proceedings.

They maintained that the Rhode Island state‑court process provided Shabshelowitz a full and fair opportunity to litigate his allegations of prosecutorial misconduct and fraud in obtaining the indictment. In support, they pointed to the evidentiary hearing before the Magistrate, the opportunity to present memoranda, grand jury transcripts, and witness testimony (including his own), and the subsequent de novo review by the Associate Justice, who adopted and supplemented the Magistrate's decision.

On appeal, defendants contend that Shabshelowitz waived any arguments concerning the 'final judgment' element of collateral estoppel and the alleged lack of a full and fair opportunity to litigate because he did not raise those arguments in the district court. They emphasize that in responding to the summary judgment motion, he challenged only the 'identity of issues' element, thereby abandoning other collateral estoppel challenges.

They argue that no extraordinary or unique circumstances justify departure from the First Circuit's 'raise or waive' rule and that allowing new arguments at this stage would be prejudicial, given the long passage of time since the grand jury proceedings, the state‑court hearings, and the filing and briefing of the summary judgment motion.

In addition to collateral estoppel, defendants also argued in the district court that Shabshelowitz's malicious prosecution claim failed on the merits, contending that probable cause existed for the prosecution and that the record did not support his allegations of misconduct in the grand jury proceedings.

issue_1.reasoning: The existence and scope of issue preclusion is reviewed de novo. Under Rhode Island law, a ruling can be ‘final’ for collateral estoppel purposes even though it does not terminate the entire criminal case, so long as the specific issue was fully decided and is not subject to further reconsideration in that proceeding. Here, the Superior Court Magistrate denied the motions to dismiss after an evidentiary hearing, and an Associate Justice, on de novo review, adopted and supplemented that ruling. The issues of prosecutorial misconduct and sufficiency of the indictment were thereby conclusively resolved in that forum. Rhode Island decisions treat such determinations as final for issue-preclusion purposes, particularly where, as here, they became law of the case in the criminal matter and were never disturbed. The appellant’s argument that only a judgment ending the criminal prosecution can be ‘final’ is too narrow and inconsistent with modern preclusion doctrine and Rhode Island’s application of collateral estoppel. The district court’s conclusion that there was a final judgment on the merits as to the issues decided on the motions to dismiss is thus likely to be upheld.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether the prior proceedings afforded a full and fair opportunity to litigate is a legal question tied to the application of collateral estoppel, reviewed de novo. The record shows that appellant filed multiple motions to dismiss in Superior Court, submitted written memoranda and grand jury transcripts, and participated in an evidentiary hearing at which three witnesses, including himself, testified. A Magistrate ruled against him, and an Associate Justice conducted de novo review, rejected his claims of misconduct and fraud, and adopted the decision in full. He did not seek any further review. Those procedures comfortably satisfy the ‘full and fair opportunity’ requirement under due process and Rhode Island law. His contention that collateral estoppel should not apply because he allegedly lacked a realistic opportunity to appeal to the Rhode Island Supreme Court is weak: (1) he never attempted such an appeal; (2) collateral estoppel in Rhode Island does not hinge on the availability of a second layer of appellate review, but on whether the litigant had a meaningful chance to present his case; and (3) federal courts routinely apply issue preclusion to state trial‑level determinations that have not been reviewed by a state supreme court. The district court’s reliance on the extensive Superior Court process and appellant’s failure to pursue further review was reasonable, and the ‘full and fair opportunity’ prong is likely to be affirmed.

issue_3.reasoning: Application of the First Circuit’s raise‑or‑waive doctrine and the scope of issues preserved for appeal are legal questions reviewed de novo. The summary‑judgment record shows that in the district court appellant contested only the identity‑of‑issues element of collateral estoppel and did not argue that (a) the Superior Court rulings were not ‘final judgments on the merits’ for preclusion purposes or (b) he lacked a full and fair opportunity to litigate due to an absence of state‑supreme‑court review. Those theories surfaced for the first time on appeal. Under the First Circuit’s well‑entrenched raise‑or‑waive rule, such arguments are deemed forfeited unless exceptional circumstances or a manifest miscarriage of justice is shown. None is present here: the record was developed years earlier, the arguments turn on legal theories that could have been raised below, and the equities do not suggest any extraordinary unfairness. The panel therefore is likely to hold that these new objections to the ‘final judgment’ and ‘full and fair opportunity’ components were waived, and to decline to consider them on the merits, which independently supports affirmance of the summary judgment.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The appeal turns entirely on collateral estoppel. Appellant has conceded identity of issues and does not dispute that the parties are the same; his remaining challenges focus on (1) whether there was a ‘final judgment on the merits’ and (2) whether he had a full and fair opportunity to litigate, with an additional procedural hurdle that these specific theories were not presented to the district court. Under the First Circuit’s raise‑or‑waive doctrine, the new attacks on the ‘finality’ and ‘full and fair opportunity’ components are likely deemed forfeited because appellant’s opposition below was limited to the identity‑of‑issues element and he offers no extraordinary circumstances justifying deviation from that rule. Even if the court elects to look past waiver, the Rhode Island Superior Court process—written submissions, an evidentiary hearing, and de novo review by an Associate Justice—easily qualifies as a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issues. The Associate Justice’s decision, adopting and supplementing the Magistrate’s ruling and left unappealed, is a sufficiently final adjudication of those discrete issues for purposes of Rhode Island issue preclusion. Because those determinations preclude relitigation of the lack‑of‑probable‑cause and prosecutorial‑misconduct allegations at the heart of the malicious prosecution claim, summary judgment for defendants was proper. Accordingly, the appellate court is likely to affirm the district court’s judgment in all respects.

parties.appellant: Monika Kapoor, petitioner in habeas corpus and the person whose extradition to India is sought
parties.appellee: Vincent F. DeMarco, United States Marshal for the Eastern District of New York, and Roberto Cordeiro, Chief Pretrial Services Officer for the Eastern District of New York (respondents to the habeas petition, representing the U.S. custodial authorities)

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Monika Kapoor is a citizen of India who entered the United States in 1999 and overstayed her visa. In March 2010 she was placed in immigration removal proceedings. She applied for asylum, withholding of removal, and relief under the Convention Against Torture (CAT).

On April 26, 2010, an Indian court issued a warrant for Kapoor’s arrest on five charges under the Indian Penal Code (IPC): (1) cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property (IPC § 420); (2) forgery of valuable security, will, etc. (IPC § 467); (3) forgery for the purpose of cheating (IPC § 468); (4) using as genuine a forged document (IPC § 471); and (5) criminal conspiracy to commit the foregoing offenses (IPC § 120B). These charges arise from allegations that Kapoor and her two brothers forged documents related to jewelry transactions and used those forged documents to obtain licenses from the Indian government to import raw materials duty free, allegedly causing the Indian government a loss of approximately $679,000.

In October 2010, India made a formal request to the U.S. Department of State for Kapoor’s extradition under the 1997 Treaty on Extradition between the United States and India. Under Article 2 of that treaty, an extraditable offense is one punishable in both countries by more than one year of imprisonment or a more severe penalty.

On May 2, 2011, the United States, acting on India’s request, filed a complaint in the Eastern District of New York seeking an arrest warrant for Kapoor under the extradition statutes. A magistrate judge issued a warrant that same day. Kapoor was arrested, arraigned, and released on bail while extradition proceedings were pending. Her ongoing immigration removal proceedings were held in abeyance pending resolution of the extradition matter.

An extradition hearing was held on July 28, 2011 before the magistrate judge, limited to determining extraditability under the treaty and statutes. Kapoor’s sole argument at the hearing was that there was no probable cause to sustain the charges. On April 17, 2012, the magistrate judge found that a valid treaty existed, that the charged offenses were extraditable under the treaty, and that the Indian government’s evidence established probable cause as to each of the five charges. The magistrate judge issued a certificate of extraditability and transmitted it to the Secretary of State, while denying the government’s request to revoke Kapoor’s bond.

After the judicial certification, the matter went to the Department of State for the discretionary surrender decision, including consideration of any CAT-based objections. On July 24, 2015, Kapoor submitted materials to the Secretary of State asking that extradition be denied on the ground that she would be at risk of harm if surrendered to India. On September 18, 2015, the State Department issued a surrender warrant (the "Surrender Warrant") authorizing her extradition to India under 18 U.S.C. § 3186 and the U.S.–India extradition treaty. In a September 25, 2015 explanatory letter, the Department stated that it had reviewed all materials submitted by Kapoor and the pleadings and filings in the district court proceedings, and it expressly addressed the United States’ obligation under CAT not to extradite a person to a country where there are substantial grounds for believing the person would be in danger of torture. Applying its CAT regulations (22 C.F.R. part 95) and the "more likely than not" standard, the Department stated that the decision to surrender Kapoor to India complied with the United States’ obligations under CAT and its implementing statute and regulations.

Kapoor submitted additional materials to the Department relating to her CAT claim after she filed a second habeas petition (which she later withdrew when the Department agreed to consider the new materials). On August 4, 2016, the State Department informed Kapoor that it reaffirmed its earlier decision to authorize her surrender, again stating that it had reviewed the additional materials and that the extradition decision complied with the United States’ CAT-related obligations.

Later, developments occurred in the Indian criminal proceedings. Kapoor advised the U.S. district court in 2021 that two of the Indian charges against her (IPC §§ 467 and 468) had been dismissed and that her two brothers, who were co-defendants in India, had resolved the remaining three charges by paying fines. She submitted a letter from an Indian law firm indicating that the Indian court would allow Kapoor to resolve the three remaining charges with fines. Based on this, she argued that she no longer faced any offense requiring imprisonment and therefore no longer faced an "extraditable" offense under the treaty.

The Indian government responded by letter dated February 7, 2022, stating that neither it nor the Indian court had offered to resolve Kapoor’s remaining charges with a fine alone and characterizing Kapoor’s contrary representation as "misleading and false." It explained that Kapoor’s co-defendants had been fined and given credit for time already served in custody, resulting in sentences of time served, but the remaining offenses against Kapoor themselves carried potential terms of imprisonment exceeding one year. The Indian government also confirmed that the extradition request remained valid notwithstanding the dismissal of two counts, as the remaining charges were still punishable by imprisonment of more than one year under Indian law.

On March 3, 2022, after receiving updated information from India, the Department of State issued an Amended Surrender Warrant limited to the remaining three charges (IPC §§ 420, 471, and 120B). In a sworn declaration, the Department stated that, in connection with issuing the Amended Surrender Warrant, it reviewed all materials submitted by Kapoor to the district court and to the Department up to March 3, 2022 and concluded that nothing received after the original 2015 surrender warrant required reassessing its prior analysis of Kapoor’s CAT-related claims. The declaration again stated that the Amended Surrender Warrant complied with the United States’ obligations under CAT and its implementing statute and regulations.

Throughout this period, Kapoor remained on bond subject to conditions. Her habeas litigation in federal court challenged the legality of her custody and continued extradition in light of the Secretary of State’s decisions concerning her CAT claim and the subsequent modification of charges in India.

procedural_history.claims_brought:
In the underlying extradition proceedings, the United States, acting on behalf of India, sought certification of Kapoor’s extraditability on five Indian criminal charges. Kapoor contested the extradition at the 2011 extradition hearing only on the ground that there was no probable cause supporting the charges. After the magistrate judge certified her extraditability, Kapoor brought multiple habeas corpus petitions under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and related requests for relief:

1. First habeas petition (2012): Kapoor challenged the magistrate judge’s extradition certification, arguing (a) that the magistrate judge improperly excluded certain evidence she proffered at the extradition hearing, and (b) that the dual criminality requirement of the India–U.S. extradition treaty was not satisfied. She sought to invalidate the magistrate judge’s extraditability certification.

2. Second habeas petition (2015): After the Secretary of State issued the September 2015 Surrender Warrant, Kapoor filed a habeas petition challenging the Department of State’s extradition decision, focusing on her CAT claim. She submitted additional evidence in support of alleged risk of torture in India. After the Department agreed to consider the new evidence, she withdrew this petition without prejudice.

3. Third habeas petition (2016, at issue on this appeal): Kapoor filed a new § 2241 petition asserting that the Secretary’s extradition decision violated her procedural and substantive due process rights, CAT, and FARRA. She alleged that she would likely be tortured if returned to India and that the Secretary had erred in concluding otherwise. She sought several forms of relief: (a) that the district court assume jurisdiction over her humanitarian and torture-related claims; (b) a preliminary injunction prohibiting her extradition or surrender to Indian authorities while the matter was pending; (c) an order allowing her to give depositions in the United States to the Indian government; (d) a writ of habeas corpus ordering her release from what she characterized as "executive detention"; and (e) any other appropriate relief.

Later, through supplemental filings, Kapoor also argued that the extradition request and the prior certification had become "stale" due to (i) the dismissal of two IPC charges in India, and (ii) her contention that the remaining charges were effectively resolvable by fines and therefore no longer met the treaty’s requirement of punishable offenses exceeding one year of imprisonment.
procedural_history.district_court_decision:
On her first habeas petition, the district court held that the magistrate judge had properly excluded Kapoor’s proffered evidence at the extradition hearing and that the dual criminality requirement was satisfied. The court therefore denied the writ. The Second Circuit later affirmed that denial.

On the third habeas petition (the petition underlying this appeal), the district court received briefing and held oral argument on November 18, 2021. At argument, the court requested supplemental briefing on several matters, including whether it had jurisdiction to review the Secretary of State’s CAT determination in the extradition context, and the impact of changed circumstances in the Indian criminal case.

After additional submissions, including updated communications from the Indian government and notice of the Amended Surrender Warrant from the State Department, the district court issued a written decision on September 20, 2022. The court concluded that it lacked subject-matter jurisdiction to review Kapoor’s CAT-based challenge to the Secretary’s extradition decision. It reasoned that, while earlier Second Circuit authority had allowed habeas review of CAT claims under FARRA, Congress’s subsequent enactment of 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(4) (as part of the REAL ID Act) limited judicial review of CAT claims to petitions for review of immigration removal orders and precluded habeas review in other contexts, such as extradition. Relying in part on D.C. Circuit precedent, the district court characterized the statute as leaving an extraditee with no statutory right to judicial review of conditions in the receiving country. The district court also concluded that this limitation did not violate the Suspension Clause because historically the writ of habeas corpus in extradition did not encompass review of anticipated conditions in the receiving country. On that basis, the district court denied Kapoor’s third habeas petition for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Kapoor appeals from the district court’s September 20, 2022 judgment denying her third § 2241 habeas petition. She challenges the district court’s determination that it lacked subject-matter jurisdiction to review her CAT claim in the extradition context under 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(4), and she further asserts due process errors in the district court’s handling of her case, including its alleged shift in position on jurisdiction after oral argument and its failure to adjudicate certain due process arguments she raised regarding the alleged staleness of the extradition certification and her treatment by the Department of State.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(4), enacted as part of the REAL ID Act, deprives federal courts of habeas corpus jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 to review a CAT-based claim (including alleged violations of FARRA and the CAT implementing regulations) brought by an individual facing extradition, rather than immigration removal.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Courts interpret statutory jurisdictional restrictions by examining the plain text of the statute, giving effect to explicit references to habeas corpus or 28 U.S.C. § 2241 where present. Under Supreme Court precedent such as I.N.S. v. St. Cyr and Demore v. Kim, a statute is deemed to repeal or restrict habeas jurisdiction only if Congress articulates a specific and unambiguous statement of intent; implications from text or legislative history are insufficient. Additionally, when a construction of a statute would raise serious constitutional questions under the Suspension Clause, and an alternative interpretation is fairly possible, courts are to adopt the interpretation that avoids the constitutional problem.

issues_on_appeal.description: If § 1252(a)(4) is read to bar habeas review of CAT claims in extradition cases, whether that application violates the Suspension Clause by unconstitutionally restricting the historical core of the writ of habeas corpus available to persons challenging their extradition.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under the Suspension Clause, Congress may not eliminate the writ of habeas corpus as it existed at the time of the Founding except in cases of rebellion or invasion where public safety requires suspension. The core of the writ involves judicial review of the legality of executive detention. In determining whether a statutory restriction on habeas review violates the Suspension Clause, courts examine whether the type of claim and relief sought falls within the historically protected scope of the writ, as described in cases such as Boumediene v. Bush, Department of Homeland Security v. Thuraissigiam, and St. Cyr. In the extradition context, longstanding doctrine, including the "rule of non-inquiry," limits habeas review to specific questions such as the extradition court’s jurisdiction, the presence of a valid treaty, whether the charged offense falls within the treaty, and whether there was any evidence supporting the finding of probable cause; historically, habeas has not been used to review anticipated treatment in the receiving country.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, independent of CAT, Kapoor stated a colorable procedural or substantive due process claim sufficient to support habeas jurisdiction, including claims that (a) the district court changed its jurisdictional position after hearing without fair process, (b) the district court failed to address her due process arguments regarding the alleged staleness of the extradition certification in light of changed charges and potential penalties in India, and (c) the Secretary of State’s decision-making process concerning her extradition and CAT claim was constitutionally inadequate.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: For habeas jurisdiction based on due process violations, a petitioner must allege a non-frivolous deprivation of a constitutionally protected liberty interest caused by the government’s actions in ordering continued detention or extradition. Courts assess whether the alleged due process violation is independent of claims that are jurisdictionally barred (such as CAT claims) and whether the alleged government action is arbitrary, fundamentally unfair, or contrary to procedures required by the Constitution. The court also considers whether the claim fits within the limited scope of judicial review in extradition proceedings, which traditionally allows inquiry only into the extradition court’s jurisdiction, the applicability of the treaty, and the existence of evidence supporting probable cause.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the changes in Kapoor’s criminal case in India—specifically, dismissal of two IPC charges and the subsequent Amended Surrender Warrant based only on three remaining charges—rendered the original extradition certification "stale" or otherwise invalid, such that the district court should have revisited or revoked the certification or evaluated whether the remaining offenses still qualify as extraditable offenses under the treaty.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Extradition treaties, including the U.S.–India treaty, typically define an "extraditable offense" by reference to whether the offense is punishable by a specified minimum term of imprisonment (here, more than one year), rather than by reference to the particular sentence that will be imposed in an individual case. Under Second Circuit extradition precedent, courts look to the maximum authorized penalty or the statutory range to determine extraditability, not the actual or anticipated sentence imposed in the foreign proceedings. A certificate of extraditability is treated as a non-final, non-appealable order, but may be indirectly challenged in habeas proceedings on narrow grounds, including whether the offense remains within the treaty given subsequent developments. The court must consider whether post-certification changes in foreign charges alter the treaty extraditability analysis.

appellant_arguments: Kapoor contends that the district court erred in concluding that 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(4) deprived it of jurisdiction to review her CAT-based challenge to extradition. She argues that § 1252(a)(4) should be interpreted as applying only to review of CAT claims in the context of immigration removal orders, not extradition, and therefore should not foreclose habeas review in extradition cases. She maintains that the statute’s reference to petitions for review of final removal orders indicates a limited scope confined to the immigration context.

Relying on prior Second Circuit authority such as Wang v. Ashcroft, Kapoor argues that FARRA and CAT claims historically have been reviewable via habeas and that nothing in § 1252(a)(4) specifically and unambiguously revokes habeas jurisdiction for extradition-based CAT claims. She emphasizes that any ambiguity must be resolved in favor of preserving habeas review under the clear-statement rule articulated in St. Cyr and related cases.

Kapoor asserts that, even if § 1252(a)(4) could be read to limit habeas review, applying it to bar all judicial review of her CAT claim in the extradition context would raise serious Suspension Clause issues. She argues that access to habeas review is constitutionally required because she is challenging the legality of her continued restraint and potential transfer to a country where she alleges she faces a likelihood of torture, and that such review falls within the historic role of habeas as a check on unlawful executive detention.

She contends that the rule of non-inquiry should not preclude judicial review where Congress, through CAT and FARRA, has created a substantive standard and obligations regarding torture in the receiving country. In her view, the Secretary’s decision to extradite in alleged violation of those obligations necessarily presents a legal question that a habeas court must be able to review, at least to ensure that the Secretary meaningfully considered and applied the "more likely than not" CAT standard.

On the merits of her CAT claim (as a prerequisite to jurisdiction), Kapoor alleges that the Secretary of State failed to conduct a meaningful or adequate review of her evidence concerning the risk of torture in India. She argues that the State Department’s letters and warrants do not show an individualized, reasoned adjudication of the risk she faces, thereby violating CAT, FARRA, and the implementing regulations.

Kapoor further argues that her due process rights were violated. She claims the district court initially indicated it had jurisdiction to consider her CAT arguments, requested supplemental briefing, and then later dismissed for lack of jurisdiction without fully addressing her due process and humanitarian contentions. She also maintains that the district court failed to address her arguments that the extradition request had become stale and that the certification should be revisited in light of developments in the Indian criminal proceedings.

Regarding staleness, Kapoor argues that dismissal of two IPC charges and the treatment of her brothers’ cases, which she characterizes as being resolved by the payment of fines, show that the remaining offenses no longer qualify as extraditable under the treaty’s requirement of offenses punishable by more than one year of imprisonment. She contends that, if the remaining offenses can and likely will be resolved through fines, they should not support extradition and the original certification is no longer valid.

She also suggests that the Secretary’s failure to issue a new CAT analysis between 2016 and the 2022 Amended Surrender Warrant in light of the changed circumstances, and the Department’s reliance on prior determinations, demonstrates a lack of fresh and meaningful consideration of her risk of torture and renders the decision to extradite arbitrary and capricious or constitutionally deficient.
appellee_arguments: The government, on behalf of the Marshal and Chief Pretrial Services Officer, argues that 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(4) clearly and unambiguously strips federal courts of habeas jurisdiction over all CAT-based claims except in the context of petitions for review of final orders of removal (and limited exceptions not applicable here). The government emphasizes that the statute explicitly references 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and "any other habeas corpus provision" and designates a petition for review of a removal order as the "sole and exclusive means" for judicial review of any cause or claim under CAT, thereby foreclosing extradition-related CAT claims in habeas proceedings.

The government maintains that Congress enacted § 1252(a)(4) to clarify and supersede earlier case law (including Wang) that had allowed habeas review of CAT claims under FARRA. According to the government, the statute’s broad use of the word "any" in describing CAT claims shows that the restriction applies regardless of whether the claim arises in the removal context, in extradition, or in other transfer settings, except where Congress has specifically preserved review.

On the constitutional issue, the government argues that barring habeas review of CAT claims in extradition cases does not violate the Suspension Clause because such claims fall outside the historic core of habeas corpus. It cites the longstanding rule of non-inquiry in extradition, under which habeas review does not extend to anticipated conditions or treatment in the receiving country, including the fairness of foreign criminal procedures or risk of mistreatment. The government contends that historically, habeas in extradition has been limited to narrow questions such as jurisdiction of the committing magistrate, existence of a valid treaty, coverage of the offense under the treaty, and sufficiency of evidence to establish probable cause.

The government notes that, in this statutory and doctrinal framework, the Executive Branch—specifically the Secretary of State—has traditionally held exclusive authority and responsibility to weigh humanitarian considerations and potential mistreatment in the requested state when deciding whether to surrender a fugitive. The government argues that CAT and FARRA did not alter this foundational division of responsibility between courts and the Executive but rather codified the Executive’s role and directed the State Department to adopt internal regulations, which it did (22 C.F.R. part 95) while specifying that the Secretary’s extradition decisions are matters of executive discretion not subject to judicial review.

With respect to Kapoor’s specific CAT allegations, the government points to the State Department’s 2015 and 2016 letters and the sworn declaration accompanying the 2022 Amended Surrender Warrant, all of which state that the Department considered her submissions, including the materials filed in court, and concluded that extraditing her would comply with the United States’ obligations under CAT, FARRA, and the implementing regulations. The government argues that, under § 1252(a)(4) and the rule of non-inquiry, courts lack authority to second-guess the Department’s evaluation of country conditions and risks of torture.

Regarding due process, the government contends that Kapoor has not stated a cognizable due process claim independent of her CAT-based challenge. It maintains that the district court’s inquiry into its jurisdiction, including its request for supplemental briefing and subsequent conclusion that it lacked jurisdiction, was a proper exercise of judicial process and does not itself violate due process. The government also asserts that Kapoor received all process to which she was entitled in the extradition proceedings and through the Secretary of State’s consideration of her humanitarian submissions.

As to the "staleness" and extraditability arguments, the government argues that the dismissal of two IPC charges in India and the sentencing outcomes for Kapoor’s brothers do not negate extraditability. It relies on the Indian government’s communications that the remaining three charges (IPC §§ 420, 471, and 120B) remain punishable by imprisonment exceeding one year and thus continue to meet the treaty’s extraditability standard, regardless of the particular sentence the Indian court may impose on Kapoor if she is convicted. The government emphasizes that under treaty practice and Second Circuit precedent, extraditability turns on the statutory maximum penalty or range, not on whether, in practice, a defendant might receive a fine or time-served sentence.

The government contends that the issuance of the Amended Surrender Warrant demonstrates that the Secretary of State updated the surrender authorization in light of changes to the Indian charges and again confirmed conformity with CAT obligations. It argues that no further judicial review is necessary or permitted, and that the Secretary’s actions remain within the Executive’s discretionary authority in extradition matters.

issue_1.reasoning: Section 1252(a)(4) is textually framed around review of CAT claims via a petition for review of a “final order of removal.” Read in context with § 1252 as a whole, it regulates judicial review in the immigration-removal setting, not extradition. Under St. Cyr and related cases, Congress must speak with an unmistakably clear statement to curtail § 2241 habeas; here, Congress clearly displaced habeas only for CAT claims arising from removal orders. Applying that same language to extradition-specific CAT claims would require extending a provision centered on removal orders far beyond its natural scope. Given (1) the absence of any reference to extradition, (2) the structure of § 1252, and (3) the constitutional-avoidance canon in light of the serious Suspension Clause concerns that a total bar on review would raise, the better reading is that § 1252(a)(4) does not strip habeas jurisdiction over extradition-related CAT/FARRA claims. The district court therefore erred in dismissing the petition for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction on that basis.

issue_2.prediction: AFFIRM (but not reached or resolved narrowly)
issue_2.reasoning: Because the statute can reasonably be construed not to bar habeas review of extradition-related CAT claims, the Second Circuit can and likely will avoid deciding the Suspension Clause issue. To the extent the court comments, it will endorse the historical limits of habeas in extradition (rule of non‑inquiry) and note that claims about anticipated treatment abroad were not historically part of the core of the writ. But having interpreted § 1252(a)(4) not to reach extradition CAT claims, it need not hold that applying § 1252(a)(4) in that broader fashion would be unconstitutional. Thus, the district court’s specific Suspension Clause ruling (that applying § 1252(a)(4) to bar review would not violate the Clause) will either be deemed unnecessary to the disposition or implicitly rejected as dicta without a formal reversal. The operative constitutional holding is avoided.

issue_3.standard_of_review: de novo (jurisdiction), with underlying due process sufficiency assessed as a legal question
issue_3.reasoning: Kapoor’s stand‑alone due process theories do not supply an independent jurisdictional hook beyond her CAT/FARRA challenge. (a) The district court’s request for supplemental briefing, followed by a jurisdictional dismissal, is a routine exercise of judicial authority and not arbitrary or fundamentally unfair; a court may change its preliminary views after full briefing without violating due process. (b) Her “staleness” arguments rest on developments going to the scope of extraditable offenses and the foreign prosecution, which fall within the traditional limits of extradition review and were functionally addressed by the magistrate’s earlier certification and by the State Department’s amended surrender decision. To the extent she claims the court failed to adjudicate those arguments, they either duplicate her treaty/extraditability contentions (addressed elsewhere) or are folded into her CAT challenge. (c) Her attack on the Secretary’s internal decisionmaking (alleged lack of a sufficiently reasoned CAT analysis) is essentially an attempt to obtain merits review of the CAT determination, not the assertion of a freestanding constitutional procedural right; there is no precedent recognizing a due process right to judicially review the quality of the Secretary’s CAT analysis in extradition. Accordingly, apart from the CAT‑based jurisdictional question in issue 1, Kapoor has not alleged a colorable procedural or substantive due process violation that would expand habeas jurisdiction, and the district court’s rejection of those due process theories is sustained.

issue_4.standard_of_review: de novo (treaty interpretation and legal effect of changed foreign charges)
issue_4.reasoning: Under the U.S.–India extradition treaty and settled Second Circuit precedent, extraditability turns on whether the remaining offenses are, by their statutory definition, punishable by more than one year of imprisonment—not on the sentence likely to be imposed in practice. The Indian authorities confirmed that the three surviving charges (IPC §§ 420, 471, 120B) each carry maximum penalties exceeding a year, and that the extradition request remains valid. The fact that Kapoor’s brothers received fines and time served does not retroactively alter the statutory character of the offenses or their treaty status. Nor does the dismissal of two counts invalidate the original certification; at most it narrows the set of offenses for which surrender may be authorized, which the State Department addressed by issuing an Amended Surrender Warrant limited to the three remaining counts. There is no doctrine under which such intervening developments, without more, render the certification “stale” or void. The district court, therefore, properly declined to invalidate or reopen the certification on this basis.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The central legal issue is whether § 1252(a)(4) strips § 2241 jurisdiction over extradition‑related CAT/FARRA claims. The statutory text, structure, and the St. Cyr clear‑statement rule favor a narrow reading: § 1252(a)(4) channels CAT challenges to petitions for review of final removal orders and does not speak to extradition. Extending the bar to extradition would require both a strained reading of the phrase “review of any cause or claim under the Convention” and disregard of the provision’s anchoring in removal‑order review. Because an alternative reading that preserves some habeas review in extradition is “fairly possible,” avoidance of serious Suspension Clause concerns also points toward that interpretation. On that ground, the district court’s jurisdictional dismissal should be reversed and the CAT‑based habeas claim remanded for consideration on the merits (subject to the traditional limits of extradition review and the rule of non‑inquiry). By contrast, Kapoor’s independent due process theories and her “staleness” challenge to extraditability are weak under existing extradition doctrine. Extraditability is measured by statutory maximums, not anticipated fines, and the Executive’s handling of changed foreign charges via an amended surrender warrant is consistent with treaty practice. The court will therefore affirm the district court’s rejection of those arguments. The net result is a mixed disposition: reversal of the jurisdictional ruling as to CAT/FARRA claims, with remand for further proceedings, but affirmance on the remaining due process and staleness/extraditability issues.

parties.appellant: Tyrone Walker, plaintiff in a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 civil rights action and an incarcerated individual challenging the process used to keep him in administrative segregation (solitary confinement).
parties.appellee: Deputy Commissioner Joseph Bellnier, Superintendent Donald Uhler, Deputy Superintendent of Security Paul P. Woodruff, Deputy Superintendent of Programs Joanne Fitchette, Offender Rehabilitator Coordinator Melissa A. Cook, James A. O’Gorman, and other officials of the New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision (DOCCS), defendants in their official or individual capacities alleged to have been responsible for Walker’s administrative segregation reviews.

stage1_summary.factual_background:
Tyrone Walker entered New York State prison custody in 1994 and has spent most of his incarceration in maximum-security conditions and, from 2000 onward, largely in solitary confinement. His convictions stem from a series of violent crimes committed in 1993. On February 18, 1993, in Cragsmoor, New York, Walker murdered a rival drug dealer, Michael Monsour, during an attempt to rob Monsour of cocaine and drug proceeds. On February 23, 1993, Walker committed two additional armed robbery attempts: he shot at a woman, Bonnie Bear, in Manhattan during an attempted robbery, causing injuries that led to her death eight days later, and he shot at a man, Herbert Muskin, in Brooklyn during another attempted robbery, though Muskin was not physically injured. For the February 23 incidents, a New York state court sentenced Walker to an aggregate term of 32½ years to life in prison for robbery, murder, and weapons offenses. For the February 18 murder of Monsour, Walker was prosecuted federally in the Northern District of New York; the government sought the death penalty. The jury did not unanimously agree to impose death, and Walker received a federal sentence of life imprisonment without parole.

During the early 1990s, including while his prosecutions were pending, Walker engaged in additional violent conduct. In 1992 he participated in the beating and stabbing of another incarcerated person at the Sullivan County jail, during which the victim was stabbed approximately 18 times. In 1995, while awaiting his federal trial, he allegedly attempted to escape from custody, smuggled a razor blade into court, attempted to hire a hitman to kill a government witness, assaulted a deputy in an effort to steal keys, and engaged in other violent or escape-related acts. Some of these allegations were documented in communications from federal prosecutors to prison authorities and during the penalty phase of his federal trial; not all resulted in separate prosecutions or unanimous factual findings by the jury.

Once in DOCCS custody, Walker was initially housed in the general population of maximum-security facilities, including Downstate and Green Haven Correctional Facilities. Between 1994 and mid-2000, he incurred a series of disciplinary infractions. He received approximately twelve Tier II misbehavior reports for relatively less serious rule violations such as being out of place, refusing direct orders, unauthorized phone use, smuggling, creating disturbances, possessing contraband, and an incident involving threats and delay of count. He also received one Tier III misbehavior report in 1996 for possession of a weapon and an altered item.

On September 27, 2000, Walker committed an extremely violent assault in the recreation yard at Green Haven. He obtained an ice pick and a knife, secured them to his hands with leather thongs, and attacked the Deputy Superintendent of Security (DSS), stabbing him multiple times and causing serious injuries including multiple stab wounds and fractures to the head and shoulder areas. During the incident, Walker stabbed a second officer and punched a third officer while being escorted to segregation. He was prosecuted in state court for attempted murder, pled guilty, and received an additional sentence of 15 years to life, increasing his state minimum to 47½ years. Administratively, DOCCS imposed an approximately 14‑year term of Disciplinary Segregation, which he served under solitary confinement conditions in Special Housing Units (SHUs) at various facilities from about late 2000 until 2014.

During his years in Disciplinary Segregation, Walker incurred further misbehavior reports, particularly in the early years. From 2000 to 2014 he received four Tier II and seven Tier III misbehavior reports, including infractions for harassment, creating disturbances and interference, threats, altered items and unauthorized exchanges, smuggling, demonstration, refusing direct orders, bribery/extortion, drug use, possession of an alleged weapon, and property-related violations. One incident in 2011 involved a small piece of plexiglass that DOCCS classified as a weapon; Walker contended it was only a mirror used to look out of his cell. None of the documented infractions during this period involved new acts of physical violence against persons. Over time, Walker’s behavior improved. He stated that he learned to address grievances through formal grievance and litigation procedures. His later record in Disciplinary Segregation led to reductions (“time cuts”) in his SHU sentence. From March 2012 until his punitive SHU term ended in January 2014, he incurred no misbehavior reports.

As Walker’s Disciplinary Segregation term approached its end in January 2014, DOCCS staff reviewed his history to determine his housing status. Administrative Segregation (Ad Seg) in New York is a non-punitive, indeterminate status for people whom officials believe would pose a threat to facility safety and security if housed in the general population. Individuals in Ad Seg are ordinarily housed in SHU under the same restrictive solitary conditions as those serving disciplinary sentences. The regulatory standard for Ad Seg at the time required a determination that the inmate’s presence in the general population would pose a threat to safety and security. DOCCS procedures required an initial Ad Seg recommendation based on identified security concerns, a hearing with written disposition, and, thereafter, periodic multi-tier reviews.
