On the day before Walker’s Disciplinary Segregation sentence was to end, a DOCCS employee recommended that he be placed in Ad Seg rather than returned to general population. The recommendation cited his 1993 murder and robbery offenses, his earlier alleged escape-related conduct and violent incidents while awaiting trial, the 2000 assault on the DSS and other staff, his disciplinary record in prison, and statements from a 2010 intercepted letter in which he had described himself as extremely capable at fighting and "one of the most dangerous prisoners in the state" and referenced disciplining his partner’s teenage sons. After an Ad Seg hearing in early 2014, DOCCS formally designated Walker for Ad Seg. Walker did not challenge that initial 2014 designation in this lawsuit.

The day after his Ad Seg designation was affirmed, while still in SHU, Walker handed a small crescent-shaped piece of metal to an officer, saying he had found it while cleaning his cell and joking that there should be a reward for his good behavior. The officer perceived the item as a sharpened weapon and issued a Tier III misbehavior report charging bribery/extortion, weapon possession, altered item, and property in an unauthorized area.

After his Ad Seg designation, Walker was transferred to the SHU at Upstate Correctional Facility, a prison where approximately 80 percent of the housing consists of SHU cells. From 2014 through at least July 2019 (when the district court summary judgment record closed), Walker remained in Ad Seg housing at Upstate. DOCCS later advised that he remained in SHU until March 2022, after which he was transferred to a step-down unit under new state legislation limiting segregated confinement.

Conditions in SHU during the relevant period were highly restrictive. Incarcerated individuals in SHU generally spent nearly all of their time alone in small concrete cells with solid doors and food hatches, with one hour of solitary exercise in a small enclosed “rec cage” per day. They had significantly limited access to personal property, reading materials, packages, telephone calls, showers, and visits compared to general population. They could not physically access the law library and were limited to borrowing small amounts of legal material at a time. Non-legal visits and phone calls were strictly capped, and they had access to only a few showers per week. Some limited incentives, such as additional showers, minor commissary privileges, or clothing items, could be earned through positive behavior. Over the relevant period, state authorities and courts noted that prolonged SHU confinement was associated with serious mental and physical harms, and DOCCS regulations and state statutes were gradually revised to shorten or restrict the use of segregated confinement.

From 2014 to 2019, while in Ad Seg at Upstate, Walker’s disciplinary record was largely clean. He incurred only one misbehavior report, in June 2017, when he refused to end a telephone call with his daughter at the direction of Offender Rehabilitator Coordinator (ORC) and Defendant Melissa Cook and cursed at her. The Central Office Committee later noted that he anticipated and valued these calls, that he had been reassigned to a different staff member without further problems, and that aside from that incident his behavior was appropriate. Other than that event and the 2014 metal-object incident, there were no disciplinary reports for violent conduct after 2000 and no misbehavior reports at all between 2012 and 2014.

During his years in Ad Seg, facility and central office documentation repeatedly described Walker’s behavior in SHU as appropriate, polite, cooperative, quiet, and non-problematic, and noted that he caused no issues with staff. He earned the maximum incentives available in Upstate’s SHU incentive programs, first under a Pilot Incentive Program and then under the Uniform Progressive Inmate Movement System (PIMS), retaining Level III status for an extended period. He also participated in programming, including completing an aggression-replacement training (anger-management type) course and engaging in academic self-study even though he already had a high school diploma. The record is unclear why he did not advance to PIMS Level IV, despite the apparent eligibility periods noted in DOCCS program charts.

Walker’s Ad Seg status was subject to periodic review under DOCCS regulations then in effect. During the 2014–2019 period, he received 46 periodic Ad Seg reviews. Each review involved up to three levels: (1) a Facility Committee at Upstate that reviewed his institutional file and met with him; (2) a Central Office Committee in Albany that reviewed the Facility Committee report and any written statement from Walker; and (3) a final decision by the Deputy Commissioner for Correctional Facilities (first Defendant Bellnier, later Defendant O’Gorman).

At Upstate, the facility-level practice was that an ORC would meet with Walker and other staff, prepare the Facility Committee report, and then the other Facility Committee members would review and comment. Defendants Uhler (Superintendent), Woodruff (Deputy Superintendent of Security), Fitchette (Deputy Superintendent of Programs), and Cook (ORC) all served on the Facility Committee at various times. According to Walker’s deposition testimony, in an early meeting at Upstate, Woodruff and Cook told him that they would never recommend his release from Ad Seg. Walker asserts that this reflected a pre-determined commitment to keep him in solitary; Defendants denied making such statements.

The Facility Committee reports followed a standard three-part format: (1) reasons for initial Ad Seg designation; (2) information on subsequent behavior and attitude; and (3) other factors that may favor retaining or releasing the inmate from Ad Seg. Over five years, the first part consistently repeated a description of Walker’s 2000 assault on the DSS and related violence. The second part typically noted his current behavior, almost always describing it as appropriate or appropriate with staff, sometimes adding that he was polite, cooperative, quiet, and caused no problems. Many reports repeated his historical disciplinary infractions in the "subsequent behavior" section, even when those infractions predated his Ad Seg status. The third part of the reports—where other factors supporting retention or release were supposed to be discussed—contained a nearly identical set of sentences in each review, emphasizing that Walker had demonstrated a propensity for assaultive and dangerous behavior in his criminal history and in prison, and that his ability and willingness to inflict extreme violence on staff and inmates made his presence in general population an extreme risk to facility safety and security. Until mid-2017, this section did not mention his positive conduct in Ad Seg as a factor, either for or against continued segregation. Beginning in August 2017, the Facility Committee added a paragraph detailing Walker’s broader violent past, including his federal and state convictions and alleged violent behavior while awaiting federal trial, but still concluded that his prior conduct justified continued Ad Seg.

The Central Office Committee conducted a second review following each Facility Committee report. Walker frequently submitted written statements to this committee. In these submissions, he consistently argued that he had changed, that he had gone many years without any violent incidents, that his record in recent years showed he could live safely in general population, and that he had learned to use legal channels rather than violence. He expressed remorse, described his efforts at self-improvement, and repeatedly asked what he needed to do to earn release from Ad Seg. Many of his letters specifically requested guidance on programs or steps that could demonstrate he no longer posed a security threat. He also raised concerns about delayed reviews, medical issues, and difficulties obtaining legal materials or copies of his Ad Seg review reports.

The Central Office Committee varied in how often it responded in detail to Walker’s letters. On some occasions it addressed his points; on others it largely ignored them or discussed only selected issues, such as medical complaints. It generally agreed with the Facility Committee’s recommendation that Walker remain in Ad Seg, citing his history of serious violence, weapon possession, escape-related conduct, and unpredictability. Committee reports frequently noted that his behavior in Ad Seg was appropriate and that he had no new disciplinary infractions other than the 2017 phone-call incident. In several reviews, the committee characterized his written submissions as demonstrating a sense of entitlement, inadequate humility, anger, or a tendency to blame others. At times it deemed his requests—such as seeking past review reports, legal resources, better ventilation, programming, or certain privileges—expressions of entitlement, even though facility staff considered many of those requests routine.

In December 2018, for the first time, the Central Office Committee proposed specific steps that might support a transition to less restrictive housing. It noted that Walker would "always remain a risk for violence" because of his history, but stated that he must develop insight into his behavior and recommended enrollment in two programs: Aggression Replacement Training (ART) and a substance abuse program (ASAT), suggesting these could better prepare him for eventual movement to a less restrictive environment. Walker responded appreciatively and asked to be put on the waiting list. The record shows he completed the ART program and attempted to access ASAT but could not complete ASAT because there was no SHU-compatible workbook format; a later review acknowledged that ASAT did not exist in workbook form.

The Deputy Commissioner for Correctional Facilities (Bellnier, then O’Gorman) provided the third, final level of review. On each available review form, the Deputy Commissioner checked a box indicating that Walker’s Ad Seg status would continue. On some forms, the line designated for stating reasons was left blank; on others, generic statements such as "Your release from Admin. Segregation would pose a threat to the safety and security of the Institution" or "Inmate Walker’s placement is appropriate at this time" were written. Defendants acknowledged that staff sometimes pre-filled these reason lines before the Deputy Commissioner signed. The Deputy Commissioners later filed declarations explaining that they had considered Walker’s entire record, including his improved conduct, but ultimately believed his past violence and risk profile required continued Ad Seg.

The timing and documentation of Walker’s reviews exhibited delays and irregularities. Regulations required periodic review (initially every 60 days, later every 30 days) and provision of written notice and reasons to the inmate, along with a statement that he could respond in writing before the next review period. In practice, some reviews were completed by the Deputy Commissioner after the next review period had already begun or even after a subsequent review had been completed. For example, certain 2016–2017 reviews were signed months late, and in at least two instances the Deputy Commissioner completed a review for an earlier period after already approving continued Ad Seg for a later period. Additionally, Walker often received copies of his completed reviews months after the relevant period, sometimes in large batches. At one point he received nine separate reviews at once in January 2019, covering a series of prior review cycles.

These delays affected his ability to respond to specific rationales being used to continue his Ad Seg. In one example, the Central Office Committee characterized an incident involving a forgotten visitor package as showing that Walker became enraged and suggested he might assault security staff. Because he did not timely receive that review, he could not correct the account until long after the fact. When he did respond, he stated that he had thanked Woodruff for helping hold the package and that he had not threatened anyone. Later documentation appears to reflect that the Committee accepted this clarification and stopped relying on that particular description. In another example, the Committee began describing Walker’s 2014 possession of the small metal object as a deliberate attempt to manipulate his transfer by obtaining a weapon so as to incur a misbehavior report that would cancel his transfer. Walker later explained in writing that he did not know about transfers in advance, had sought transfer away from Clinton, and had contested the misbehavior report; after repeated written objections, the Committee stopped using that specific "manipulation" narrative, although it continued to note the incident as evidence of weapon-related behavior.

Throughout 2014–2019, Walker remained continuously in Ad Seg SHU at Upstate. When the record closed in 2019, he had been in solitary confinement for nearly 20 years (initially punitive Disciplinary Segregation, then preventive Ad Seg) and in prison for about 25 years. He had not been involved in any violent incident since the 2000 assault, and his only misbehavior during the five years at Upstate was the 2017 non-violent phone-call incident. Defendants continued to consider him a very high security risk based largely on his prior violent and escape-related conduct and his perceived propensity and capacity for sudden extreme violence. Walker acknowledged the seriousness of his earlier offenses but contended that his long record of relatively good behavior, aging, and participation in programs showed that he no longer posed the same risk and that, at a minimum, he was entitled to a periodic review process that genuinely evaluated whether continued solitary confinement was still necessary for institutional safety.

procedural_history.claims_brought: In 2017, Walker, proceeding pro se, filed a civil rights lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York. He alleged, among other things, that DOCCS officials responsible for his Administrative Segregation status and reviews violated his Fourteenth Amendment procedural due process rights by failing to conduct constitutionally meaningful periodic reviews of his Ad Seg confinement. His operative second amended complaint, accepted by the district court in 2019 after screening and motion practice, focused on claims related to the allegedly inadequate process surrounding his continued placement in Ad Seg from 2014 to 2019. He did not challenge the adequacy of the initial 2014 Ad Seg hearing itself.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: After limited discovery—during which Walker remained pro se and did not take depositions—both sides moved for summary judgment. A magistrate judge issued a report and recommendation in December 2020 recommending that summary judgment be granted to all defendants. The magistrate judge concluded that the periodic Ad Seg reviews Walker received satisfied the requirements set forth in Proctor v. LeClaire and were constitutionally meaningful; accordingly, the magistrate judge rejected Walker’s procedural due process claim at the merits stage and did not reach the qualified immunity argument. The district court (Chief Judge Suddaby) considered Walker’s objections, adopted the report and recommendation in full in March 2021, and granted summary judgment to the defendants. In the alternative, the district court ruled that even if there were any deficiency in the review process, the defendants were entitled to qualified immunity because no clearly established right of Walker’s had been violated under the circumstances.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Walker appealed the district court’s grant of summary judgment to the DOCCS defendants. On appeal, he challenges the district court’s conclusions that there were no genuine issues of material fact as to (1) whether his Ad Seg reviews between 2014 and 2019 were constitutionally meaningful under the Due Process Clause and the standards articulated in Hewitt v. Helms and Proctor v. LeClaire, and (2) whether the defendant officials are entitled to qualified immunity. The appeal concerns the adequacy of the procedures used to review and continue his Administrative Segregation status, not the legality of the initial 2014 Ad Seg designation or the substantive correctness of the decision to keep him in solitary confinement.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the periodic Administrative Segregation reviews conducted by DOCCS officials for Walker from 2014 to 2019 satisfied the Fourteenth Amendment requirement of "meaningful" periodic review of preventive solitary confinement, or whether the process was so rote, delayed, and predetermined that it failed to provide constitutionally adequate procedural due process.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under the Due Process Clause, incarcerated individuals have a protected liberty interest in avoiding atypical and significant hardships such as long-term solitary confinement. When an inmate is placed in Administrative Segregation for preventive, security-based reasons, prison officials must provide periodic reviews to determine whether the inmate remains a security risk. These reviews must occur at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner. Meaningful review requires that officials actually evaluate whether continued Ad Seg confinement is justified by present and future institutional safety and security concerns, consider relevant new evidence and changes in the inmate’s behavior or circumstances over time, and avoid using Ad Seg as a pretext for indefinite punishment for past misconduct. Officials may accord substantial weight to past violent acts, and courts must defer to prison officials’ judgment on safety and security, but cannot uphold purely nominal or sham reviews with predetermined outcomes.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the DOCCS officials named as defendants are entitled to qualified immunity from Walker’s § 1983 due process claim on the ground that, even if there were deficiencies in the Ad Seg review process, any violated right was not clearly established or a reasonable official could believe that the process complied with constitutional requirements.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Qualified immunity shields government officials from civil liability under § 1983 unless (1) the facts, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, show that the official’s conduct violated a federal right, and (2) the right was clearly established at the time of the challenged conduct such that every reasonable official would understand that what he or she was doing violated that right. In the context of Administrative Segregation, it has been established since Hewitt v. Helms that prison officials must conduct some form of periodic review of Ad Seg to ensure it is not used as a pretext for indefinite confinement, and subsequent decisions, including Proctor v. LeClaire, have clarified that the review must be meaningful. On summary judgment, qualified immunity is unavailable if there are genuine disputes of material fact relevant to whether officials violated clearly established rights.

appellant_arguments: Walker contends that, although DOCCS conducted 46 nominal reviews of his Administrative Segregation status between 2014 and 2019, the process was not constitutionally meaningful. He argues that the Facility Committee reports were largely boilerplate, repeating the same language about his 2000 assault and past violent conduct in every review, and that the "other factors" section never seriously engaged with or credited his sustained record of appropriate, non-violent behavior over many years in SHU.

He asserts that prison officials effectively predetermined that he would remain in Ad Seg indefinitely, pointing to his testimony that Defendants Woodruff and Cook told him at the outset that they would never recommend his release from Ad Seg, and to Central Office Committee statements suggesting that he would "always" be a risk and that his clean record was attributable solely to restrictive conditions, rather than genuine change.

He argues that the reviews improperly relied almost exclusively on long-past misconduct—his 1993 homicides, 1990s jail violence and escape-related acts, and the 2000 assault—without assessing whether he still posed a current security risk in light of his aging, his absence of violent incidents for nearly two decades, and his compliance with rules and completion of programs in recent years. He maintains that this reliance on remote events shows that Ad Seg was being used to punish him for past wrongs rather than to address present and future institutional safety.

Walker contends that the Central Office Committee used circular reasoning to discount his good behavior, by treating the absence of violent incidents in SHU as evidence only of the security provided by SHU itself and not as evidence of reduced risk, and by treating his attempts to participate in the process and request programming, legal resources, and medical care as indications of "entitlement" rather than as positive or neutral behavior.

He maintains that the Deputy Commissioner’s role in the review process was a "rubber stamp" rather than an independent review. He relies on the fact that the Deputy Commissioner’s section of many forms either lacked any explanation or contained only generic conclusions apparently pre-written by subordinates, and that there was no documented instance where the Deputy Commissioner disagreed with or significantly modified the committees’ recommendations.

Walker further argues that chronic delays in completing and delivering review reports to him undermined the meaningfulness of the process. He points to multiple review cycles where the Deputy Commissioner signed reviews months late, sometimes after subsequent cycles were already decided, and to instances where he received long-delayed batches of prior reviews all at once. He contends these delays deprived him of timely notice of the factual bases for continued Ad Seg and of a real opportunity to rebut inaccuracies or adjust his behavior in response, as illustrated by his belated ability to correct the Central Office Committee’s account of the visitor’s package and its characterization of the 2014 metal-object incident.

He emphasizes that he repeatedly and explicitly asked DOCCS officials what he needed to do to earn release from Ad Seg and that, for several years, he received no concrete guidance. He argues that when the Central Office Committee finally suggested programs in late 2018, one of the recommended programs (ASAT) was not actually available in a form he could access in SHU, thereby reinforcing his contention that the process never seriously contemplated his eventual return to general population.

On qualified immunity, Walker argues that by the time of the challenged conduct it was clearly established, through Hewitt and Proctor and related decisions, that Ad Seg could not be used as an indefinite pretext for punishment and that periodic reviews must be meaningful, consider current circumstances and new evidence, and not be mere formalities. He asserts that the evidence, viewed in his favor, shows violations of these clearly established procedural requirements, precluding summary judgment on qualified immunity grounds.
appellee_arguments: The DOCCS defendants argue that Walker received extensive process far exceeding constitutional minima: 46 separate reviews over five years, each involving a three-step mechanism—Facility Committee review with an in-person interview, Central Office Committee review that considered his file and written submissions, and final determination by the Deputy Commissioner. They contend that this structure satisfied the requirement for periodic and meaningful review.

They maintain that the reviews did consider Walker’s current behavior and up-to-date circumstances, not only his past. The Facility Committee reports documented his disciplinary record for each period and acknowledged his generally appropriate behavior and lack of recent violent infractions. The Central Office Committee reports noted positive developments such as long stretches free of misbehavior and program participation. Defendants argue that the committees simply concluded that his dangerousness based on his extreme history of murders, attempted murders, escape attempts, and the 2000 prison-yard stabbings outweighed evidence of improved conduct in a highly controlled environment.

Defendants contend that under governing law prison officials are entitled to accord significant, even decisive, weight to past violent conduct when assessing risk to institutional safety and are not required to release an inmate to general population merely because he has behaved appropriately in Ad Seg. They argue that Walker’s history—including multiple homicides, violence in custody, efforts to escape, use and possession of weapons, and an exceptionally brutal attack on staff—reasonably supported a continued assessment that he posed an extreme risk if returned to a less restrictive setting.

They dispute that the process was predetermined or a sham. They argue that no competent evidence shows that policy or practice barred release from Ad Seg or that the outcome in Walker’s case was fixed regardless of his conduct. They emphasize that some officials in Proctor made sweeping admissions about never releasing inmates, whereas in Walker’s case there is no comparable testimony. They characterize Walker’s account of comments by Woodruff and Cook as disputed and insufficient, standing alone, to show system-wide or case-specific bad faith.

Regarding the Deputy Commissioner’s role, defendants acknowledge that staff sometimes drafted standard language for the Deputy Commissioner’s reasons but assert that this is an administrative convenience and does not mean the Deputy Commissioner failed to review the case. They point to declarations in which Bellnier and O’Gorman explain that they considered Walker’s complete record—including his improved behavior—but remained convinced that his demonstrated capacity for severe and unpredictable violence warranted continued Ad Seg for safety and security. They argue that due process does not require detailed written reasoning at the final stage so long as the overall process considers relevant factors.

On the alleged "circular" reasoning about good behavior in SHU, defendants argue that it is rational to view an inmate’s clean record in an extremely restrictive environment as less probative of his risk level in a less controlled setting, and that officials are entitled to make such predictive judgments. They emphasize that due process allows prison officials to rely on subjective evaluations and risk predictions and that courts should not reweigh the evidence or second-guess their assessment of how much weight to give past versus recent conduct.

With respect to delays in completing and delivering reviews, defendants concede there were administrative delays but argue these do not show that the reviews were meaningless or unconstitutional. They note there is no evidence that delays were intentional or that they prevented Walker from participating in interviews, submitting written statements, or being reviewed at regular intervals for purposes of determining his placement. They argue that not every departure from state regulatory time frames constitutes a federal due process violation and that Walker cannot show that timing irregularities changed the substance of the decisions or deprived him of a meaningful opportunity to be heard.

On qualified immunity, defendants contend that, even assuming some arguable procedural imperfections, it was not clearly established that the specific combination of factors in Walker’s case—reliance on serious past violence, discounting of non-violent behavior in SHU as less probative, use of standardized language in reports, and administrative delays—violated due process. They assert that reasonable officials in their position, guided by Hewitt and Proctor, could believe that conducting frequent, multi-layered reviews that considered both Walker’s history and his current behavior satisfied constitutional requirements. Therefore, they argue, they are entitled to qualified immunity as a matter of law.

issue_1.reasoning: On summary judgment, the court must view the record in Walker’s favor. Hewitt and Proctor require that preventive segregation be supported by periodic, genuinely evaluative reviews that consider current risk, not simply serve as a vehicle for indefinite punishment for past conduct. The record, taken favorably to Walker, shows (1) nearly uniform, boilerplate Facility Committee narratives repeating his 2000 assault and older history over 46 reviews, with the ‘other factors’ section barely changing for years; (2) documentation that for a five‑year span he had no violent infractions and only one minor disciplinary ticket, while being consistently described as polite, quiet, and cooperative and achieving the highest incentive levels; (3) his repeated, specific written requests for guidance on what he needed to do to get out of Ad Seg, largely unanswered until late 2018, when he was finally directed to programs, one of which (ASAT) could not be completed in SHU; (4) substantial evidence of delays and back‑dated reviews, including Deputy Commissioner sign‑offs after later review periods and Walker receiving batches of many reviews at once, undermining his ability to rebut factual assertions in real time; (5) his testimony—disputed but cognizable at summary judgment—that key Facility Committee members told him they would never recommend his release; and (6) Deputy Commissioner forms that uniformly continued Ad Seg with either no reasons or generic language sometimes pre‑filled by staff, with no recorded instance of disagreement with subordinate recommendations. A reasonable jury could find that the reviews, while frequent on paper, were rote, substantially predetermined, relied almost exclusively on remote events, and did not function as a meaningful, contemporaneous assessment of current risk as Proctor requires. Because these are classic fact‑intensive questions about the sincerity and substance of the review process, there is at least a genuine dispute of material fact. The district court therefore erred in granting summary judgment to defendants on the merits of the procedural due process claim.

issue_2.reasoning: Qualified immunity at summary judgment is inappropriate where material facts bearing on whether clearly established law was violated are in dispute. By the time of the challenged conduct, Hewitt and especially Proctor (a Second Circuit case closely on point) had clearly established that: (a) inmates in long‑term administrative segregation are entitled to periodic reviews that are actually meaningful; (b) such reviews must genuinely consider whether continued segregation is justified by current and future security needs, not simply recycle historical misconduct; and (c) purely perfunctory or sham reviews, or decisions that treat Ad Seg as a permanent punishment for past acts, violate due process. Viewing the record in Walker’s favor, a jury could find that officials (i) treated past violence as dispositive without real engagement with his subsequent two decades of non‑violent behavior; (ii) effectively predetermined the outcome, as suggested by Walker’s account of Woodruff’s and Cook’s statements and by the unbroken string of boilerplate Facility and Central Office conclusions; (iii) used circular reasoning to discredit good behavior in SHU while offering no realistic path out despite his specific requests; and (iv) allowed significant delays and back‑dating that deprived him of timely notice and opportunity to rebut rationales. If a jury credited that version of events, it could conclude that defendants violated clearly established law as articulated in Hewitt and Proctor. Because that conclusion turns on disputed facts about how the reviews were actually conducted and what weight was truly given to current versus past conduct, the officials are not entitled to qualified immunity on summary judgment. The district court’s alternative qualified‑immunity ruling should therefore be reversed.

stage2_decision.reasoning:
This case sits squarely in the shadow of Proctor v. LeClaire, which is binding and factually analogous: an inmate held for very long periods in New York administrative segregation, extensive but allegedly rote and predetermined reviews, boilerplate rationales that rest almost entirely on remote past violence, and evidence that officials viewed Ad Seg as essentially permanent. Proctor held that such claims present triable questions of fact about whether reviews are ‘meaningful’ within the meaning of Hewitt and the Due Process Clause and therefore cannot be resolved in prison officials’ favor on summary judgment. 

Here, the record—taken favorably to Walker—contains several Proctor‑type indicators of potentially sham or perfunctory review: (1) the near‑identity of rationales over many years despite a dramatic change in his recent disciplinary record; (2) long‑term, well‑documented compliance and positive behavior in SHU with almost no infractions, yet no movement toward less restrictive conditions; (3) evidence that Walker persistently sought guidance and programming to secure release but was only belatedly offered one viable program and one unavailable one; (4) substantial timing irregularities and delayed delivery of review decisions, sometimes in large batches; and (5) the Deputy Commissioner’s consistent, minimally reasoned rubber‑stamping of committee recommendations. While the defendants present plausible explanations and emphasize their discretion to give great weight to past violence, that goes to the weight of the evidence, not to the existence of disputes. Under de novo review, these disputes preclude summary judgment. 

Given Proctor’s clear statement of the governing principles, and the fact that qualified immunity cannot be granted where those principles are clearly established and the central question is factual—whether the reviews were genuinely evaluative or merely nominal—the better prediction is that the appellate court reverses the grant of summary judgment on both the merits and qualified‑immunity grounds and remands for further proceedings (likely trial or additional fact development) rather than reinstating judgment for defendants.
